editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: THE KING'S Vi≈øitatorial Power ASSERTED.
BEING An Impartial Relation of the late Vi≈øitation of St. Mary Magdalen College in Oxford.
As likewi≈øe an Hi≈øtorical Account of ≈øeveral Vi≈øitations of the Univer≈øities and particular Colleges.
Together with ≈øome nece≈ø≈øary Remarks upon the Kings Authority in Eccle≈øia≈øtical Cau≈øes, according to the Laws and u≈øages of this Realm.
By NATHANIEL JOHNSTON, Doctor in Phy≈øic, Fellow of His Maje≈øties College of Phy≈øicians in London.
LONDON, Printed by Henry Hills, Printer to the King's Mo≈øt Excellent Maje≈øty, for His Hou≈øhold and Chappel; And are ≈øold at his Printing-hou≈øe on the Ditch-≈øide in Black-Fryers. 1688.

div.head: TO THE Judicious Reader.
div.p: AS ≈øoon as His Maje≈øty had been plea≈øed to lay His Commands upon me, to Collect materials for this Subject; I could not but reflect that it was to Treat of a matter that I knew not any had Writ upon before; and of ≈øuch a largene≈øs, that it takes in not only the Ca≈øe of Magdalen College but regards all other Corporations and Societies of that Con≈øtitution, and ≈øpreads it ≈øelf into ≈øome branches of the Prerogative Royal: Wherefore the nature of the Thing requires a Treati≈øe of me, not altogether un≈øuitable to the Dignity of the per≈øons concerned, viz. The King and the Univer≈øities, which would induce per≈øons of all Ranks to peru≈øe it, who de≈øire ≈øatisfaction in a matter of ≈øuch importance both to the Prince and Subject.
This ≈øugge≈øted to me a nece≈ø≈øity of enquiring into Records of preceding ages, and to render the Work, at lea≈øt, a Collection of various in≈øtances in ≈øeveral Ca≈øes of Vi≈øitations.

Therefore finding no compleat Hi≈øtory of any Vi≈øitation of our Univer≈øities, except that of the long Parliament, I judged it nece≈ø≈øary to give an Impartial account of the proceedings, from the Kings Mandate for Mr. Farmer, to the clo≈øe of the Vi≈øitations by the Lords Commi≈ø≈øioners; whereby, this and after
ages might have an Authentic Precedent, if any occa≈øion ≈øhould happen of this kind, and that people concerned might know their Boundaries; and in this part I followed the Regi≈øters, Original Papers, Authentic Copies of Letters and Orders, or the Diaries & accounts of ≈øuch as were pre≈øent, and actors in the di≈øqui≈øition; and in this particular I have u≈øed as much diligence as I could, not to be impo≈øed upon, and had fini≈øhed mo≈øt of this before the Oxford Relation was Printed; and wherein I differ from that, I have done it upon the be≈øt Intelligence I could obtain.

After the fini≈øhing of this I judged it not improper, before I entred upon An≈øwering the Objections I found urged by the Vice-Pre≈øident and Fellows of St. Mary Magdalen College, to clear the Kings Prerogative over the Univer≈øities, in making, and Abrogating their Statutes, or di≈øpen≈øing with them, and placing or di≈ø placing of their Members, which obliged me to con≈øider the matter not only in General, but al≈øo to de≈øcend to many particulars, and ≈øhew, who by the Kings Authority or ≈øufferance have exerci≈øed the like Authority; In which I have endeavored to follow the mo≈øt approved Authors, and ≈øure≈øt Records.

I have the rather enlarged upon this head, that I might afford variety of Ca≈øes, whereby the di≈øtinct claims of Right of Vi≈øitation might be Illu≈øtrated, and this Tract might be a Repertory, whereby, upon emergences, the Original Records might be enquired after.

If ≈øome may judge me too tedious, I de≈øire them to con≈øider, that it was not enough to clear the point of St. Mary Magdalen College, but likewi≈øe to di≈øcover in what other Ca≈øes the
Kings of England had exerted their Prerogatives.

The Contemplation of this led me to touch, tho' with a trembling hand, the Regalia of our Kings, and look into the Laws and u≈øages of former times, and in what ≈øort the Soveraignty and Supremacy of our Kings in matters of Eccle≈øia≈øtical cognizance, are declared by the Laws in being. In which part I treat of the Kings Authority ab≈øtractedly from Doctrinal Religion.

This I the rather have done, that the Subjects of all conditions may ob≈øerve how great the Authority and Prerogative of the King is, in di≈øpen≈øing with Univer≈øity and College Statutes, ≈øince by the plain and direct Laws that A≈ø≈øert the Kings Right, in oppo≈øition to all Foreign powers, his Supremacy is ≈øo E≈øtabli≈øhed in Eccle≈øia≈øtical matters and cau≈øes, that it is applicable to other purpo≈øes than at the fir≈øt view may appear obvious, which I leave to the di≈øcu≈ø≈øion of tho≈øe better ver≈øed in the Laws than I ≈øhall ever pre≈øume to be. Neverthele≈øs I hope in the treating of this ≈øubject, it will be owned, that I have Introduced no Novelty, but Copy'd what is found in Hi≈øtory or the public Records, and brought to light a Prerogative in≈øeparable from the Royal State of our Kings, which ≈øome for want of con≈øulting the ≈øame have not ≈øo well di≈øcerned.

It is to caution the Heads and Fellows of our mo≈øt eminent Univer≈øities not to contend with their Sovereign, that I have ≈øo copiou≈øly produced In≈øtances of the practice of former times, and have ≈øo largely treated of them before and ≈øince the Reformation.

It was for this end ≈øolely, and not in the lea≈øt to erect Trophies for any Victory over the unfortunate, that I have pointed out the≈øe Sea-marks, that others may avoid da≈øhing them≈øelves
again≈øt the Rock, upon which the Briti≈øh Monarchy is ≈øo firmly placed, that no Tempe≈øts of open Rebellion, or the highe≈øt ≈øwelling Seas, much le≈øs any ≈øingle Billow can be able to ≈øhake.

It is far from my Intention in this, to enter into any di≈øpute about the limits of Eccle≈øia≈øtical or Secular power: It is ≈øufficient that I ≈øhew it in ≈øome particulars of known practice; without examining the grounds, any more than as declared by the po≈øitive Laws or practice of the re≈øpective Sovereigns.

I know ≈øome may look upon this as a matter treated of ex ≈øuperabundanti, yet I thought my ≈øelf obliged ≈øo far to enter into a di≈ø≈øertation upon it, as I might thereby make it appear, that by the exten≈øivene≈øs of the Sovereignty, Univer≈øities, much more private Colleges, (both which the Law accounts among the Creatures of the Crown) mu≈øt own a ≈øubjection of them≈øelves and their private Statutes, to the King as Supreme.

Neither hath it been any de≈øire to render the Kings Prerogative greater than the Laws and u≈øages of our Kings do manife≈øt that I have ≈øhewn how it hath been in≈øi≈øted upon, even again≈øt ≈øome exemptions of the Apo≈øtolic See, or to E≈øtabli≈øh any Paradox; but only to A≈ø≈øert the ju≈øt Rights of the Crown, at lea≈øt according to my Reading, and do with all deference ≈øubmit what I have compo≈øed, to the Judgment of the Learned in our Laws.

But to leave this; I de≈øire the Candid Reader will peru≈øe the Contents of the Book in the following Pages, before he enter upon the whole, whereby he may ≈øee the connexion, and ≈øequences
of the matter; and he mu≈øt not expect that tho≈øe Contents are exactly according to the Marginal Notes, but according to the matter treated in the ≈øeveral Paragraphs, and Pages; in ≈øome of which he will find ≈øome rectifyings of what by chance was mi≈ø-printed.

I mu≈øt likewi≈øe here give ≈øatisfaction to the Reader why I have added an Appendix to the whole, and thereby plead my excu≈øe, why this Treati≈øe hath been ≈øo long Printed, in the greate≈øt part, before it was Publi≈øhed: The Rea≈øons of which are the≈øe in ≈øhort.

Being de≈øirous to obtain an exact account from the Regi≈øters of St. Mary Magdalen College, concerning Dr. Haddons being Elected upon King Edward the 6ths. Mandate, knowing the ca≈øe was exactly Parallel to this in hand; I made application to the late Bi≈øhop of Oxford, and the Vice-Pre≈øident, but the Sickne≈øs and Death of the fir≈øt, and the taking away of ≈øome Keys where the Regi≈øters were pre≈øerved, hindred me from recieving ≈øatisfaction from the one or other: So that being unwilling to ≈øtop the Printing, I was forced to pa≈øs by that In≈øtance, with a Reference to treat of it after; and when by applying my ≈øelf to the Learned Mr. Wood, Author of the Antiquities of that Univer≈øity, I could get no other ≈øatisfaction, than appears by his Letter I have Printed: I begun to de≈øpair of retriving it, and ≈øo re≈øolved to have clo≈øed all without it: Yet being very unwilling to neglect any thing I could do in a matter of ≈øuch Importance, I applyed my ≈øelf to the Right Reverend Bi≈øhop Giffard, from whom, after his Lord≈øhips arrival I had ≈ømall encouragement; but at la≈øt after repeated ≈øollicitations,
by his Lord≈øhips directions, and the indu≈øtry of a Learned Gentleman, and Conference with Mr. Wood, the Regi≈øter was found, but ≈øo late as the matter could not otherwi≈øe be In≈øerted but in an Appendix.

I will not trouble the Courteous Reader with the di≈øtinct Rea≈øons, why other matters are there likewi≈øe in≈øerted; but only in general, that ≈øome of them being committed to ≈øome hands that had mi≈ø-layed them, or taken them with them upon ≈øome removals from Town, I could not retrive them when the matters were Printing which they related to; and ≈øome few of them have come to my knowledge ≈øince Writing of the re≈øt: ≈øo that the Candid Reader mu≈øt be de≈øired to place them according to the Notes in the Margents directing for that purpo≈øe.

La≈øtly, I mu≈øt de≈øire the Reader will not peru≈øe this by parcels, or come to the Reading of it with prejudice, a≈ø≈øuring him the Author is free from pa≈ø≈øion and private de≈øign and hath endeavored to adhere to the Laws, for which purpo≈øe he hath ≈øhewn the whole to ≈øome of the eminente≈øt in that Profe≈ø≈øion, and hath had Approbation accordingly.

closer.signed: N. J.

div.head: The Candid Reader is de≈øired to Correct the≈øe following ERRATA's with his Pen before his Peru≈øal, e≈øpecially tho≈øe marked*.

The Fellows were all pre≈øent at Dr. Bonds taking his Oath, and he was received and Admitted Pre≈øident according to the Queens Mandate. Ibid.
The Inferences from this Mandate. Ibid.
An Hi≈øtorical account of King Charles the Fir≈øts di≈øpen≈øing with a Statute of Emanuel College in Cambridge. ¬ß. 12. pag. 347.
The Petition of the Ma≈øter and Fellows of Emanuel College, to the Lord Chancellor, and the grounds of it. ¬ß. 13. pag. 348.
Nine Rea≈øons for the Petition. pag. 349.
Ob≈øervations upon the Petition. ¬ß. 14. pag. 350.
Dr. Brady's Account of the Kings Nominating the Provo≈øt of King's College in Cambridge. ¬ß. 15. pag. 352.

div.head: THE KING's Vi≈øitatorial Power ASSERTED, &c.
CHAP. I.

argument.p: The Proceedings upon the Kings Mandate for Mr. Anthony Farmer, to the time when the Lord's Vi≈øitors were appointed to go to Oxford.

div.head: SECT. I.

argument.p: The Tran≈øactions from the fore≈øaid Mandate to the Summoning the Vice-Pre≈øident and Fellows of St. Mary Magdalen College in Oxford before the Lords Commi≈ø≈øioners at Whitehall.

div.p: UPON the Death of Dr. Henry Clark late Pre≈øident of St. Mary Magdalens College in Oxford, the King was Graciou≈øly plea≈øed to Grant this following Mandate.

div.head: ¬ß. 1. A Copy of the Kings Mandate for Mr. Farmer.
div.p: TRu≈øty and Well-beloved, We Greet you well, Whereas We are well ≈øatisfied of the Piety, Loyalty, and Learning of Our Tru≈øty and Well-beloved Anthony Farmer, Ma≈øter of Arts of that our College of St. Mary Magdalen. We have thought fit hereby effectually to recommend him to you for the place of Pre≈øident of Our ≈øaid College, now void by the Death of Dr. Clark late Pre≈øident thereof; Willing, and Requiring you forthwith, upon Recept hereof, to Elect, and Admit him the ≈øaid Anthony Farmer into the ≈øaid place of Pre≈øident, with all and ≈øingular the Rights, Privileges, Emoluments and Advantages thereunto belonging; any Statute, Cu≈øtom, or Con≈øtitution to the Contrary in any wi≈øe notwith≈øtanding, wherewith We are Graciou≈øly plea≈øed to di≈øpen≈øe in his behalf; And ≈øo not doubting of your ready Compliance herein, We bid you Farewel.

closer.dateline: Given at our Court at Whitehall the 9th. Day of April 1687. In the Third Year of Our Reign.
closer.salute: To Our Tru≈øty and Well-beloved the Vice-Pre≈øident and Fellows of St. Mary Magdalen. College of Our ∆≤niver≈øity of Oxford.
closer.signed: By his Maje≈øties Command. Sunderland P.

div.head: ¬ß. 2. The Authors account of his method of proceeding in this di≈øcour≈øe.
div.p:
I Have In≈øerted this Mandate at length as I ≈øhall the re≈øt of the Letters and Di≈øpatches, becau≈øe there being nothing that I know of Printed of a Vi≈øitation, whereby the curious may be ≈øatisfied in the very Forms of Addre≈øs and Proceedings; I thought
it might be grateful to ≈øuch, and might be In≈øtructive to after times and tho≈øe who have not acce≈øs to the Secretaries or Paper Office: and I have kept my ≈øelf as much as I could, to the Originals and Regi≈øters, that as to matters of Fact none might have occa≈øion to find fault with me for giving a partial account, neither have I omitted the ≈øtre≈øs of the Pleadings by Dr. Hough, or the Vice-Pre≈øident or Fellows; and tho' I have not Interrupted the Series of the Di≈øcour≈øe by an≈øwering the Arguments as they were In≈øi≈øted upon; yet I have in the clo≈øe of the Di≈øcour≈øe ≈øummed up all that they could or did ≈øay by way of Objection, and given ≈øuch An≈øwers to them as the matter required, and ≈øhall take notice of the late Treati≈øe, called A Relation of the Proceedings, &c. Containing only matters of Fact, publi≈øhed on purpo≈øe to make the generality of the people favor the Ejected. Whereas I hope to make it appear, that the King might have proceeded in a ≈øummary way, and if he had plea≈øed inflicted ≈øeverer puni≈øhments upon them than the Commi≈ø≈øioners have done, and tho' at ≈øome times there ≈øeems to be a dutiful behavior in the Fellows, and expre≈ø≈øions that were agreeable to the condition of humble Subjects, and a plea of tenderne≈øs of Con≈øcience in not daring to break their Oaths, yet in effect whenever they were put upon a pinch, whether they would yield to the King's Authority, and acknowledge them≈øelves to have acted contrary to their Duties, they never would own they had been in the wrong, which was the true cau≈øe why tho≈øe that refu≈øed to ≈øub≈øcribe the ≈øubmi≈ø≈øion that was at la≈øt propo≈øed to them were ≈øo Expelled, and however ≈øome might at fir≈øt Interpo≈øe for them, as the Bi≈øhop of Winche≈øter did in the following Letter; yet in the
progre≈øs of this Di≈øcour≈øe I ≈øhall make it clear, that in former times greater puni≈øhments than that of Expul≈øion, even to Impri≈øonments, have been Inflicted upon ≈øuch as have ≈øhewed le≈øs ob≈øtinacy and contempt of the Authority of their Sovereign.
I now proceed to the Bi≈øhop of Winche≈øters Letter to my Lord Pre≈øident upon the fir≈øt noi≈øe of the Mandate.

div.head: ¬ß. 3. The Bi≈øhop of Winche≈øters Letter to my Lord Pre≈øident.

body.p:
THe Obligation I have upon me as Vi≈øitor of St. Mary Magdalen College Oxon occa≈øions this Addre≈øs: For I am informed that great endeavors are u≈øed with his Maje≈øty to Recommend one Mr. Farmer, who is not at pre≈øent, nor ever was, Fellow of that College, to be Pre≈øident of it, which is directly contrary to the Statutes of the Founder, as I am confident ≈øome who promote Mr. Farmer's Intere≈øt cannot be Ignorant of; And were there not many per≈øons, now actually Fellows and ≈øeveral who have formally been (in particular the Bi≈øhop of Man and Dr. Je≈ø≈øop) very Eminent for their Learning and Loyalty, and every way qualified according to the Statutes, I ≈øhould not pre≈øs your Lord≈øhip to lay the concern of the College (which hath upon all occa≈øions expre≈ø≈øed it's Zeal and forwardne≈øs in defence of the Crown, and as I particularly know in the great affair of the Succe≈ø≈øion) before his Maje≈øty, who I hope will leave them to the Rules of their Statutes which haveThe contrary to this will be made out in Ancient and late times by ≈øeveral in≈øtances of this College and others. hitherto (excepting in the times of Rebellion) been con≈øtantly ob≈øerved, and which will be the highe≈øt ≈øatisfaction to that truly Loyal Univer≈øity, and
promote his Maje≈øties ≈øervice, which has always been the endeavor of,

closer.dateline: Farnham Ca≈øtle April 8th. 1687.
closer.salute: To the Right Honorable the Earl of Sunderland Pre≈øident of the Council, and One of his Maje≈øties Principal Secretaries of State.
closer.signed: The≈øe Your Lord≈øhips mo≈øt humble Servant. P. Winche≈øter.

div.p: I now ≈øhall proceed to give an account what the Vice-Pre≈øident and Fellows did, and begin with their Petition to the King upon their notice of the Kings Mandate.

div.head: ¬ß. 4. To the King's Mo≈øt Excellent Maje≈øty. The Petition of the Vice-Pre≈øident and Fellows of St. Mary Magdalen's College in Oxford.
div.p: VVE have been Credibly Informed, that Mr. Anthony Farmer, who was never of our Foundation, has obtained your Maje≈øties Recommendation to be Pre≈øident of this your Maje≈øties College, in the Room of Dr. Henry Clark lately Decea≈øed.

We do therefore with all Submi≈ø≈øion, as becomes your mo≈øt Dutiful and Loyal Subjects, mo≈øt humbly repre≈øent to your Sacred Maje≈øty, that the ≈øaid Mr.
Anthony Farmer is a per≈øon in ≈øeveral re≈øpects uncapable of that Character, according to our Founders Statutes, and do mo≈øt earne≈øtly be≈øeech your Maje≈øty, as your Maje≈øty ≈øhall judge fitte≈øt in your mo≈øt Princely Wi≈ødom, either to leave us to the di≈øcharge of our Duty, and Con≈øciences, according to your Maje≈øties late Mo≈øt GraciousNot Toleration as the Oxford relation hath it. Declaration and our Founders Statutes, or to Recommend ≈øuch a per≈øon who may be more ≈øerviceable to your Maje≈øty and this your Maje≈øties College.

closer.signed:
And Your Maje≈øties Petitioners ≈øhall ever Pray, &c.
Charles Aldworth, V. P.
Henry Fairfax, S. T. D.
Alex. Pud≈øey, S. T. D.
Tho. Smith, D. D.
John Smith, D. D.
Tho. Bayley, D. D.
Tho. Stafford, L. L. D.
Main. Hammond, S. T. D.
Rich. Strickland, M. A.
Henry Dob≈øon, M. A.
James Bayley, M. A.
John Davys, M. A.
Ja≈ø. Thomp≈øon, M. A.
Francis Bag≈øhaw, M. A.
James Fayrer, M. A.
Jo≈øeph Harwar, M. A.
Tho. Ludford, M. A.
Tho. Goodwin, M. A.
Rob. Hyde, M. A.
Edw. Yerbury, M. A.
Rob. Holt, M. A.
Stephen Weelkes, M. A.

div.head: ¬ß. 5.
div.p: THe fore≈øaid Petition is Endor≈øed as Dated the 10th. of April, 1687. And delivered to my Lord Pre≈øident by Dr. Thomas Smith and Captain Bag≈øhaw.

I find among the other papers delivered me from the Regi≈øter, one from Dr. Thomas Smith, read and publi≈øhed at a Meeting of the Fellows at his Return from pre≈øenting the fore≈øaid Petition: In the≈øe words,

IT is my opinion (for I will not pretend to call it by any other Name, much lefs by that of advice) leaving every one here pre≈øent to the liberty of his own judgment, that his Maje≈øty not having thought fit, upon our late Application to him, to Revoke his Royal Mandate, nor as we pray in the clo≈øe of the Petition, to leave us to our own choice, according to the direction of our Founders Statutes, nor to recommend ≈øuch a per≈øon as may be more ≈øerviceable to his Maje≈øty and to the College: We mo≈øt humbly Petition the King again, and repre≈øent the ≈øeveral re≈øpects referred to in our Petition, which render Mr. Farmer incapable of being Elected, and admitted Pre≈øident of the College. This Method and procedure being mo≈øt prudent, and dutiful, and fit to be entered upon immediatly. The King having interpo≈øed his Royal plea≈øure and Authority; which if it had not been done, I readily acknowledge that we not only might but ought to proceed to the Election of a Pre≈øident in that very In≈øtant, according to the expre≈øs Letter of the Statute in every particular. But for this, let every one concerned be his own Ca≈øui≈øt. The≈øe are my private Thoughts, and upon mature deliberation: I conceive that I ≈øhould be very defective in my Duty to the King, and my Re≈øpect to you (whatever Mi≈ø-interpretation ≈øome po≈ø≈øibly may frame of it.) If I had not made you acquainted with them at this meeting.

closer.dateline: St. Mary Magdalen College, April the 14th. 1687.
closer.signed: Tho. Smith, D. D.

div.head: ¬ß. 6.
div.p: I In≈øert this, for the honor of this Gentleman who is known by his Learned Writings, which give account of his Travels to the Port and through part of Greece, and in defence of the Doctrin of the Church of England: As al≈øo to let all know how happy it had been if the Fellows had hearkned to his hone≈øt, ≈øober and faithful advice, which was a≈ø≈øented to by Dr. Aldworth, Dr. Fairfax and Dr. Pud≈øey at their private Conference before proceeding to Election, tho' they after changed their minds.

‚òû It hath been the practice in former times, and according to the Canon Laws, that when any Superior enjoyned any matter upon Inferiors which they judged to be prejudicial to their Rights: It was their Duty re≈øcribere, to Write to the Prince, or other Superior to ≈øhew him wherein, by ≈øuch Mandate their Rights were invaded, or what other inconveniences might en≈øue, and not to proceed forthwith to do that which was forbid; e≈øpecially not to proceed to Election as here they did when the King had after their Petition pre≈øented to him, expre≈ø≈øed him≈øelf, that he would be obeyed. In Duty and Obedience therefore they ≈øhould have ≈øtayed their Election, and repre≈øented their Ca≈øe more particularly, and it is mo≈øt certain, that the neglect of this and the contempt of the Kings Authority were the Original cau≈øes of all that hath befallen them, but I ≈øhall leave this and proceed in the matters of Fact.

div.head: ¬ß. 7. My Lord Pre≈øident to the Bi≈øhop of Winche≈øter.

body.p:
I Have received your Lord≈øhips Letter of the 8th. In≈øtant, with an Addre≈øs or Petition inclo≈øed in it from St. Mary Magdalen College in Oxford, which
I laid before the King, who had before granted his Mandate in behalf of Mr. Farmer to be Elected and Admitted Pre≈øident of that College, and being ≈øince informed, that notwith≈øtanding the ≈øame, they have made Choice of Mr. Hough; His Maje≈øty Commands me to acquaint your Lord≈øhip, that his plea≈øure is you ≈øhould not Admit Mr. Hough to be Pre≈øident till further Order from him.

closer.signed: I am MY LORD, Your Lord≈øhips mo≈øt humble Servant. Sunderland P.

div.p: This being ≈øent to the Bi≈øhop, he returned this following An≈øwer the next Day.

body.p: THis Morning I received yours of the 16th. Bi≈øhop of Winche≈øters An≈øwer. (by the hands of Mr. Smith one of His Maje≈øties Me≈ø≈øengers) In which your Lord≈øhip ≈øignifies to me His Maje≈øties plea≈øure not to Admit Mr. Hough to be Pre≈øident of St. Mary Magdalen College Oxon, until further Order from him.

But Mr. Hough being Ye≈øterday Morning pre≈øented to me by ≈øome of the Fellows of the College, as Statutably Elected, I did according to the Tru≈øt repo≈øed in me by the Founder, after he had taken the Oath enjoyned by the Statute, Admit him Pre≈ødent, and am certain when the Statutes of the College are laid before His Maje≈øty he will find, that I have not violated my Duty; in performance of which
I never was, nor ever ≈øhall be remi≈øs, as I de≈øire you to a≈ø≈øure him from.

closer.dateline: Farnham Ca≈øtle April the 17th. 1687.
closer.signed: Your mo≈øt humble Servant. P. Winche≈øter.

div.head: ¬ß. 8. By the Statutes there are five days allowed for the Bi≈øhop of Winche≈øter's confirmation.
div.p: ‚òû By this it appears how ≈øedulous the new Elected Pre≈øident and the Fellows were, to have the Election confirmed; pre≈øuming, that this being done, the Pre≈øident would have a Legal Right, and could not be removed but by cour≈øe of Common Law: But I hope to ≈øhew hereafter, that the practice of the Kings of England, and of the Vi≈øitors appointed either by the Kings or the Popes (the latter of who≈øe power our pre≈øent Laws give his Maje≈øty) hath been to di≈øpen≈øe with Statutes, and to place, and di≈øplace for di≈øobedience, Heads of Colleges and Fellows by the ≈øignificaton of their Royal plea≈øure, or to Impower Vi≈øitors by Commi≈ø≈øion to do the ≈øame; and of this it cannot be conceived, that the Members of the College could be Ignorant; but that they rather were animated to lay hold of this opportunity, to ≈øee if they could di≈øpute the Kings Authority, or which is of equal concern to many, render the King's Actions di≈øobliging, whereby they might gain the point of rai≈øing iealou≈øie, and male-contentedne≈øs in peoples minds, with which de≈øigns I will not charge all the Members of the Society; But it is too apparent, that tho≈øe who underhand encourged them to per≈øi≈øt in their oppo≈øition, de≈øigned ≈øome ≈øuch matter.

I now pa≈øs to their Application to his Grace the Duke of Ormond their Chancellor, and the Repre≈øenting their Ca≈øe in the be≈øt dre≈øs they could; and
≈øhall only note at pre≈øent, that the≈øe were like to have little effect, ≈øince they were the ju≈øtifyings of their actions upon ≈øuch ≈ølender grounds, as in the ≈øequel will be made appear, and carried no tokens of relenting or repentance for their by-pa≈øt di≈øobedience, ≈øo that the King could not look upon them, as any Acts of theirs that might induce him to a Clemency or Pardon, where they would not own their failor of duty, but were a denial of his Sovereign and Supreme Authority of di≈øpen≈øing and being obeyed; contrary to the known Laws and practice of his Royal Predec≈ø≈øors, as I ≈øhall make clear when I come to An≈øwer their Objections, and ≈øhew the obligation to their Oaths of owning the Kings Supremacy and the Sovereign Juri≈ødiction the King hath to alter and make null their Statutes that any ways Impugn his Prerogative over ≈øuch Societies, and Corporations; which owe their Foundation, and ≈øub≈øi≈øtence to the Royal plea≈øure, and may be proceeded again≈øt, when the King plea≈øeth, by a more ≈øever method of Quo Warrante; whereby they may be totally, ≈øuppre≈ø≈øed: Whereas the King in great Clemency proceeded only by way of Vi≈øitation, which is a mo≈øt undoubted Prerogative of the King, that mu≈øt ever be owned by tho≈øe who que≈øtion the extent of the Eccle≈øia≈øtical Commi≈ø≈øion.
I now proceed to the Addre≈øs the Society made to his Grace the Duke of Ormond as followeth,

div.head: ¬ß. 9. The Pre≈øident and Fellows of St. Mary Magdalens College Oxon to the Duke of Ormond, then Chancellor.

div.p:
VVE the Pre≈øident and Fellows of St. Mary Magdalens College in Oxford, ≈øen≈øible of the Honor and Benefit we enjoy under your Graces Patronage, and how much it Imports us to have recour≈øe
to your Advice in all tho≈øe difficulties wherewith we are pre≈øt; having, as we fear, di≈øplea≈øed His Maje≈øty in our late Election of a Pre≈øident, do humbly beg leave to repre≈øent to your Grace a true State of our Ca≈øe, and hope you will plea≈øe to Inform the King how uncapable we were of obeying his Commands.

His Maje≈øty was plea≈øed, upon the Death of Dr. Henry Clark Pre≈øident of this College, to Command us by his Letter, to Elect, and Admit Mr. Anthony Farmer into that Office, a per≈øon utterly uncapable of it by our Statutes, as we are ready to make appear in many particulars: And ≈øince we have all taken a po≈øitive Oath of obedience to them, and that Exclu≈øive of all Di≈øpen≈øations what≈øoever; We humbly conceive we could not obey that Command in favor of Mr. Farmer, unle≈øs he had brought tho≈øe Qualifications with him which our Founder requires in the per≈øon of the Pre≈øident. And being confined as to the time of our Election, we have been forced to proceed to the Choice of one who has approved his Loyalty in the whole cour≈øe of his Life, and whom we think Statutably qualified for the place.

May it therefore plea≈øe your Grace to Interpo≈øe with his Mo≈øt Sacred Maje≈øty in our behalfs, that we may not lie under the weight of his di≈øplea≈øure for not being in a capacity of obeying his Command. We know him to be a Prince of Eminent Ju≈øtice, and Integrity, and therefore cannot think he would value any In≈øtance of Duty to him≈øelf, which manife≈øtly breaks in upon the obligation of our Con≈øciences; And your Graces extraordinary unblemi≈øht Loyalty to the Crown, and that regard which we a≈ø≈øure our ≈øelves, our mo≈øt Honored Lord and Chancellor
has to the peace and well-fare of this place, induces us to pre≈øume your Grace will omit no endeavors to ≈øet before his Maje≈øties Eyes the true rea≈øon and nece≈ø≈øity of our proceedings.
That God Almighty will protect your Grace ≈øhall be the daily prayers of,

closer.dateline: From St. Mary Magdalen College in Oxford April the 19th. 1687.

signed.hi: May it plea≈øe your Grace, Your Graces mo≈øt obedient Servants.

list.item: J. Hough, Pre≈øident.
Ch. Aldworth, Vice-Pre≈øident.
Hen. Fairfax, D. D.
John Smith, D. D.
Thomas Smith, D. D.
Tho. Baley, D. D.
Alex. Pud≈øey, S. T. D.
Tho. Stafford, L. L. D.
Rob. Almont, B. D.
Main. Hammond, B. D.

div.p: While the College was making this application, the King thought fit to require an account of their actions; therefore ordered my Lord Pre≈øident to write as followeth.

div.head: ¬ß. 10. My Lord Sunderlands Letter to the Vice Pre≈øident and Fellows of St. Mary Magdalens College in the Univer≈øity of Oxford.

body.p: THe King being given to under≈øtand, that notwith≈øtanding his late Mandate, ≈øent to you for Electing Mr. Farmer to be Pre≈øident of that College, you have made choice of another Per≈øon; His Maje≈øty Commands me to tell you, he is much ≈øurpri≈øed at tho≈øe proceedings, and expects you ≈øhould ≈øend me an Account of what pa≈øt upon that occa≈øion, and whether you did not receive His Maje≈øties ≈øaid Letters Mandatory before you cho≈øe Mr. Hough.

closer.signed: I am Gentlemen, Your Affectionate and humble Servant. Sunderland P.

div.p: The An≈øwer returned to this Letter was as followeth.

div.head: ¬ß. 11. The An≈øwer.
div.p:
YOur Lord≈øhips of the 21≈øt. we received, ≈øignifying to us His Maje≈øties plea≈øure, that we ≈øhould give your Lord≈øhip an Account of what pa≈ø≈øed at our late Election of a Pre≈øident, and of the Receipt of His Maje≈øties Letters Mandatory, in behalf of Mr. Anthony Farmer. In all Dutiful obedience to His Maje≈øty we have accordingly ≈øent to your Lord≈øhip, a plain State of the Ca≈øe wherein nothing in this World could ≈øo much affect us as
that we could not Elect the ≈øaid Mr. Farmer Pre≈øident, in compliance with His Mo≈øt Sacred Maje≈øties Letters, being a per≈øon in our Judgments utterly uncapable of that Office. We beg leave to repre≈øent to your Lord≈øhip, that our Princes di≈øplea≈øure would be the greate≈øt misfortune that could befall us; and our only ≈øupport under this apprehen≈øion is, that a Loyal Society can never ≈øuffer, in the hands of ≈øo Generous and Gracious a Prince, for what they have done out of a Con≈øciencious di≈øcharge of the Tru≈øt repo≈øed in them by their Founder.
That God Almighty would Crown all your Lord≈øhips endeavors with ≈øuucce≈øs: and pre≈øerve your Lord≈øhip in the Grace and Favor of the be≈øt of Princes, ≈øhall be the Daily Prayer of,

closer.signed: Your Lord≈øhips mo≈øt humble and mo≈øt obedient Servants. The Vice-Pre≈øident and Fellows of St. Mary Magdalens College in Oxford.

div.head: ¬ß. 12. The Ca≈øe of the Vice-Pre≈øident and Fellows of St. Mary Magdalen College, in Oxford, in their late Election of a Pre≈øident.
div.p:
UPon the fir≈øt Notice of the Death of Dr. Clark, Late Pre≈øident of St. Mary Magdalen College in Oxford; the Vice-Pre≈øident called a Meeting of the Fellows, in order to appoint a day for Election of a new Pre≈øident. And the 13th. day of April was the time prefix'd; with power to prorogue the Election
as they ≈øhould ≈øee cau≈øe till the 15th. beyond which time it was not in their Power to defer the ≈øame. This being agreed, a Citation or Praemonition was fixt upon the Chappel-door of the College, ≈øignifying the ≈øame, and ≈øummoning all the ab≈øent Fellows to repair home to the en≈øuing Election, as the Statute in that ca≈øe directs. After this, upon the 8th. of April they received His Maje≈øties Letter in behalf of Mr. Farmer, requiring them to Elect and Admit him Pre≈øident: But he having never been Fellow of that College, or of New-College in Oxford, (which are the only Per≈øons capable of being cho≈øen by the Statutes) and wanting likewi≈øe ≈øuch per≈øonal Qualifications as are requried in the Character of a Pre≈øident, they did not imagin it was, or could be His Maje≈øties plea≈øure, that they ≈øhould act ≈øo directly again≈øt the expre≈øs words of their Statutes, to which they are ≈øtrictly and po≈øitively Sworn. But did humbly conceive they were bound in Duty to believe, His Maje≈øty had been mi≈ø-informed in the Character, and Capacity of Mr. Farmer, and therefore upon the 15th. of April (the la≈øt of tho≈øe days within which they are confined to fini≈øh the Election) they proceeded to a choice, and having fir≈øt Received the Ble≈ø≈øed Euchari≈øt, and taken an Oath, as the Founder enjoyns, to choo≈øe a per≈øon ≈øo qualified as is there ≈øpecified, they did Elect the Reverend Mr. Jo. Hough, Batchellor in Divinity, who is a Per≈øon every way qualified by the Statutes of the ≈øaid College: And if it ≈øhall be objected that His Maje≈øty did in His Letter for Mr. Farmer, Graciou≈øly di≈øpen≈øe with all tho≈øe Statutes that rendered him uncapable of being Elected, and that therefore they might have obeyed without breach of their Oath.

They humbly beg leave to Repre≈øent, that there is an expre≈øs Clau≈øe in that Oath, which every Man takes when he is admitted Fellow of the College, wherein he Swears, neither to procure, accept, or make u≈øe of any Di≈øpen≈øation from his Oath, or any part thereof by whom≈øoever procured or by what Authority ≈øoever granted.

As to their former practice, when they have Elected in obedience to the Kings Letters heretofore, it has been always in ≈øuch Ca≈øes where the per≈øons recommended have been every way qualified for this Office by their Statutes, in which ca≈øes they always have been and ever will be ready to comply with His Maje≈øties plea≈øure, it not being without un≈øpeakable regret that they di≈øobey the lea≈øt of His Commands. They know how entirely their welfare depends upon the countenance, and favor of their Prince, neither can any thing more deeply affect and grieve their Souls, than when they find them≈øelves reduced to this unfortunate nece≈ø≈øity of either di≈øobeying his Will, or violating their Con≈øciences by a notorious perjury.

div.head: ¬ß. 13. Some Clau≈øes of particular Statutes to which the foregoing Ca≈øe Relates.
div.p: IN the Statute concerning the Election of a Pre≈øident, his Character is thus de≈øcribed, That he mu≈øt be a Man of good Reputation, and good Life, of approved under≈øtanding, good manners, and temper, and di≈øcreet, provident, and circum≈øpect both in Spiritual, and Temporal Affairs.

In the ≈øame Statute, the Oath which every Fellow
is obliged to take before he can give his voice in the Nomination of a Pre≈øident is this.

That he will name one or two of the Fellows of St. Mary Magdalen College, or of tho≈øe who have formerly been Fellows there, and have left the place upon a Legal, and creditable account: Or that he will name one or two of the Fellows of St. Mary Winche≈øter College, commonly called New-College in Oxford, or of tho≈øe who have formerly been Fellows there, and have left the place upon a creditable account: After this the Thirteen Senior Fellows Swear, that of the two that are nominated, they will with all ≈øpeed Elect one to exerci≈øe the Office of Pre≈øident whom in their Con≈øciences they think mo≈øt proper, and ≈øufficient, mo≈øt di≈øcreet, mo≈øt u≈øeful, and be≈øt qualified for it, without any regard to love, hatred, ≈øavor, or fear, &c. As in the forementioned Statute is more largly expre≈øt.

div.head: Part of that Oath which all Per≈øons take when they are admitted actual Fellows, runs thus,
div.p:
ITem, I do Swear, that I will not procure any Di≈øpen≈øation contrary to my fore≈øaid Oaths, or to any part thereof, nor contrary to the Statutes and Ordinances to which they relate, or any of them, nor will I endeavor that ≈øuch Di≈øpen≈øation ≈øhould be procured by any other, or others publickly, or privately, directly or indirectly; And if it ≈øhall happen that any Di≈øpen≈øation of this ≈øort ≈øhall be procured, or freely granted or obtained, of what Authority ≈øoever it be: Whether in General or particular or under what Form of words ≈øoever it ≈øhall be granted;
I will neither make u≈øe of it nor in any ≈øort con≈øent thereunto, So help me God.

postscript.p: Endor≈øed on the back of this, April the 24th. 1687.
The Ca≈øe within Stated was then Publicly Read by the Vice-Pre≈øident of St. Mary Magdalen College in Oxford, at a Meeting of the Fellows and Generally approved of in the Pre≈øence of me,

closer.signed: James Almont, Public Notary.

div.head: ¬ß. 14. The Addre≈øs of the Fellows of St. Mary Magdalens College to his Maje≈øty, ≈øent to my Lord Pre≈øident to be delivered to the King.

opener.salute: May it plea≈øe your Mo≈øt Excellent Maje≈øty.

div.p:
VVE your Maje≈øties mo≈øt humble and mo≈øt dutiful Subjects the Fellows of St. Mary Magdalen College in Oxford, being deeply afflicted with the late ≈øence of your Maje≈øties heavy di≈øplea≈øure, grounded, as we in all rea≈øon humbly pre≈øume, upon the mo≈øt unkind mi≈ø-repre≈øentation of our actions in relation to the Election of a Pre≈øident into your Maje≈øties ≈øaid College; do humbly beg leave to pro≈øtrate our ≈øelves at your Royal feet, offering all real Te≈øtimonies of Duty and Loyalty. And as we have never failed to evince both our principles and practices to be truly Loyal, in obedience to the Commands of your Royal Brother and your Sacred Self, in matters of the like Nature; So what≈øoever way your Maje≈øty ≈øhall be plea≈øed to try our readine≈øs to obey your Royal plea≈øure (in any in≈øtances that does not interfere with, and violate our Con≈øciences, which your Maje≈øty is Studious to pre≈øerve) we ≈øhall mo≈øt gladly and effectually comply therewith. A ≈øtubborn and groundle≈øs re≈øi≈øtance
of your Royal Will and Plea≈øure in the pre≈øent, and all other Ca≈øes, being that which our Souls eternally abhorr, as becomes

signed.hi: Your Maje≈øties mo≈øt Dutiful and Obedient Subjects.

div.head: SECT. II.

argument.p: The Proceedings before the Lords Commi≈ø≈øioners for Eccle≈øia≈øtical Affairs.

div.head: ¬ß. 1.
div.p: HAving thus far related what was Tran≈øacted betwixt His Maje≈øty and the forementioned Lords, and the Vice-Pre≈øident and Fellows of St. Mary Magdalen College, His Maje≈øty thinking it expedient, that they ≈øhould be called to an account for their di≈øobedience, ordered the Lords Commi≈ø≈øioners for Eccle≈øia≈øtical Cau≈øes to proceed again≈øt them.
Poceedings of St. Mary Magdalen College in Oxford.

div.head:
Extracted out of the Regi≈øter-Book, from the 28th. of May,
May 28. 1687. to the 5th. of Augu≈øt. By His Maje≈øties Commi≈ø≈øioners for Eccle≈øia≈øtical Cau≈øes, and for the Vi≈øitation of the ∆≤niver≈øities, and of all, and every Cathedral and Collegiate Churches, Colleges, Grammar-Schools, Ho≈øpitals and other the like Incorporations or Foundations and Societies.
div.p: COmplaint having been made unto Us, that the Vice-Pre≈øident and Fellows of St. Mary Magdalen College in the Univer≈øity of Oxford, have refu≈øed to comply with His Maje≈øties Letters Mandatory for Electing and Admitting Mr. Anthony Farmer Pre≈øident of the ≈øaid College; in the room of Dr. Clark Decea≈øed, and that notwith≈øtanding His Maje≈øties ≈øaid Letters, they have Elected Mr. John Hough Pre≈øident of the ≈øaid College: You and either of you are hereby required to Cite and Summon the ≈øaid Vice-Pre≈øident and Fellows, requiring them, or ≈øuch of the ≈øaid Fellows as they ≈øhall Depute in their behalf, to appear before Us in the Council Chamber at Whitehall upon Munday the Sixth of the next Month of June at Four in the Afternoon, to An≈øwer to ≈øuch matters as ≈øhall be objected again≈øt them concerning the premi≈ø≈øes. And of the due execution hereof you are to certifie to Us then and there.

closer.dateline: Given under our Seal the 28th. of May. 1687.

div.trailer: To Thomas Atterbury, and Robert Eldows, Or either of them.

div.head: ¬ß. 2. The An≈øwer of the Vice-Pre≈øident and Deputed Fellows, &c.
div.p: Ex Regi≈øtro. Upon June the 6th. the Vice-Pre≈øident and Deputies of the Fellows appear, and do de≈øire time which is allowed till this day Sennight.
June the 13th. they attend with their An≈øwer, which being Read, the Lords took time till the 22d. In≈øtant, for the further con≈øideration of the matter.

div.head: The An≈øwer of the Vice-Pre≈øident and other Fellows of St. Mary Magdalen College in Oxon, who≈øe Names are hereunto ≈øub≈øcribed (being Deputed by the re≈øt of the Fellows of the ≈øaid College) to the Que≈øtion propo≈øed by the Right Honorable, and Right Reverend the Lords Commi≈ø≈øioners for Eccle≈øia≈øtical Cau≈øes, &c.
div.p: Why they did not obey His Maje≈øties Letters, requiring them to Elect and Admit Mr. Anthony Farmer Pre≈øident of the ≈øaid College.

THe ≈øaid Vice-Pre≈øident and other deputed Fellows an≈øwer and ≈øay, That the ≈øaid College of St. Mary Magdalen in Oxon is a Body Corporate, governed by Local Statutes, granted and confirmed to them by His Maje≈øties Royal Predece≈ø≈øor, King Henry the 6th. for him his Heirs and Succe≈ø≈øors under the Great Seal of England, which are al≈øo ≈øince confirmed by ≈øeveral other Letters Patents of others His Maje≈øties Royal Predece≈ø≈øors under the Great Seal of England.

That by the Statutes of the ≈øaid College (to the ob≈øervation of which, each Fellow is Sworn) it is ordered that the per≈øon to be Elected Pre≈øident thereof, ≈øhall be a Man of good Life, and Reputation, of
approved Under≈øtanding, and of good Manners and Temper, and Di≈øcreet, Provident and Circum≈øpect, both in Spiritual and Temporal Affairs. And at the time of the Election of a Pre≈øident, the ≈øaid Fellows are bound by the ≈øaid Statutes to take an Oath, that they ≈øhall nominate none to that Office, but ≈øuch as are or have been Fellows of the ≈øaid College, or of New-College in Oxford, and if they are not actually Fellows at the time of Election, that they be ≈øuch as have left their Fellow≈øhips, in tho≈øe re≈øpective Colleges, upon creditable accounts. And when two qualified per≈øons ≈øhall be nominated at the time of Election, by the greater number of all the Fellows to the ≈øaid Office of Pre≈øident; The thirteen Seniors al≈øo ≈øwear that they will Elect one of them, whom in their Con≈øciences they think mo≈øt proper, and ≈øufficient, mo≈øt di≈øcreet, mo≈øt u≈øeful and be≈øt qualified for that place, without any regard to love, hatred, favor or fear, and every Fellow when he is fir≈øt admitted to his Fellow≈øhip in the ≈øaid College, Swears that he will inviolably keep and ob≈øerve all the Statutes, and Ordinances of the College, and all and every thing therein contained, ≈øo far, as does, or may concern him, according to the plain, litteral, and grammatical ≈øen≈øe and meaning thereof, and as much as in him lies will cau≈øe the ≈øame to be kept and ob≈øerved by others: And that he will not procure any Di≈øpen≈øation contrary to his afore≈øaid Oaths, or any part thereof, nor contrary to the Statutes and Ordinances to which they relate, or any one of them, nor will he endeavor that ≈øuch Di≈øpen≈øation ≈øhall be procured by any other, or others publickly, or privately, directly or indirectly, and if it ≈øhall happen that any Di≈øpen≈øation of this ≈øort ≈øhall be procured, granted,
or obtained of what Authority ≈øoever it be, whether in general or particular, or under what Form of words what≈øoever, it ≈øhall be granted, that he will neither make u≈øe of it nor in any ≈øort con≈øent thereunto; all which ≈øeveral Oaths follow in expre≈øs words at the End of this their An≈øwer.

That upon notice of the Death of Dr. Clark, late Pre≈øident of the ≈øaid College, the Vice-Pre≈øident called a Meeting of the ≈øaid Fellows in order to appoint a day for Election of a new Pre≈øident and the 13th. day of April la≈øt, was the time prefixt, with power to prorogue the ≈øame as they ≈øhould ≈øee cau≈øe until the 15th. day of the ≈øame Month, beyond which time they could not Statutably defer their Election, and in pur≈øuance thereof a Citation or Praemonition was fixed upon the Chappel-door of the ≈øaid College, ≈øignifying the ≈øame, and by which the ab≈øent Fellows are ≈øummoned to repair home to the ≈øaid Election, as the Statute in that ca≈øe requires.

And the ≈øaid Vice-Pre≈øident and other deputed Fellows further ≈øay, that upon the 11th. day of the ≈øaid Month of April they received His Maje≈øties Letters requiring them to Elect and Admit the ≈øaid Mr. Anthony Farmer to be Pre≈øident of the ≈øaid College. But fora≈ømuch as the ≈øaid Vice-Pre≈øident and the other Fellows apprehended the Right of Election to be in them≈øelves, and did believe His Maje≈øty never intended to di≈øpo≈ø≈øe≈øs them of their Rights; And fora≈ømuch as the ≈øaid Mr. Farmer had never been Fellow, either of Magdalen College, or of New-College in Oxford, and had not tho≈øe qualifications which in and by the Statutes of the ≈øaid College are required in the Character of a Pre≈øident, as they in their Con≈øciences did and do verily believe, and in regard they
could not comply with His Maje≈øties Letters, without the violation of their Oaths, and hazard of that Legal Intere≈øt and property, whereof they are by the ≈øaid Statutes po≈ø≈øe≈øt, and which by their Oaths they are bound to maintain. They repre≈øented the ≈øame by their Humble Petition to His Maje≈øty, and having deferred their Election of a Pre≈øident to the la≈øt day limited by their Statutes, they then proceeded to Election. And having fir≈øt Received the Ble≈ø≈øed Euchari≈øt, and taken the ≈øaid Oaths, as the Statutes require, to choo≈øe a per≈øon ≈øo qualified as is before expre≈øt, they did Elect the Reverend Mr. John Hough Batchellor in Divinity, and one of the Fellows of the ≈øaid College, a per≈øon every way qualified to be their Pre≈øident, who has been ≈øince Confirmed by the Lord Bi≈øhop of Winche≈øter their Vi≈øitor, as the Statutes of the ≈øaid College direct.

And that they might not lie under His Maje≈øties di≈øplea≈øure by their proceedings, on the 19th. day of the ≈øaid Month of April they made humble Repre≈øentation thereof to His Maje≈øty, by his Grace the Duke of Ormond, Chancellor of the Univer≈øity of Oxford, ≈øetting forth their indi≈øpen≈øable obligation to ob≈øerve their Founders Statutes.
All which matters the ≈øaid Vice-Pre≈øident, and other deputed Fellows, do humbly offer to your Lord≈øhips con≈øideration, and pray to be di≈ømi≈ø≈øed with your Lord≈øhips favor.

div.head: ¬ß. 3.
div.p: To this were ≈øubjoyned the following Statutes for regulating the Election of a Pre≈øident.

div.head: De numero Scholarium & Electione Prae≈øidentis.
div.p: IN primis ≈øiquidem ut Sacra Scriptura, ≈øeu pagina ≈øcientiarum omnium aliarum Mater & Domina, ≈øua liberius dilatet tentoria, & cum ea utraque militet Philo≈øophia,The College to con≈øi≈øt of one Pre≈øident and 40 poor and indigent Scholars Clerks. praefatum no≈øtrum Collegium Oxoniae, in & de numero unius Prae≈øidentis & Quadraginta pauperum, & indigentuim Scholarium Clericorum, in dictis ≈øcientiis ≈øtudere debentium, ≈øub≈øi≈øtere, Statuimus & etiam Ordinamus; & ≈øic ip≈øum volumus Deo propitio perpetu√≤ permanere. Praeter quem numerum ≈øint alii Triginta pauperes Scholares,And 30 poor Schollars called Demys. vulgariter vocati Demyes, Grammaticalia, Logicalia, vel Sophi≈øticalia diligenter addi≈øcentes; & ut cultus Dei, a quo bona cuncta procedunt, amplius augeatur, & melius ≈øu≈øtentetur, Volumus quod praeter dictos numeros Scholarium ≈øint etiam quatuor Presbyteri Capellani,And 4 Presbyters Chaplains, 8 Clerks and 16 Chori≈øters. octo Clerici, Sexdecim Chori≈øtae Cappellae dicti Collegii in Divinis ≈øervitiis de≈øervientes: Provi≈øo quod de dicto numero quadragenario, ex ≈øpeciali providentia Prae≈øidentis,Two or 3 of the 40 to be Students of the Canon and Civil Laws, and as many in Phy≈øic. Vice-Prae≈øidentis, Decanorum, & trium aliorum Seniorum, duo vel tres in jure Canonico & Civili, alii vero duo vel tres in Medicinis, quos ad hoc Ip≈øi aptos, habiles, & idoneos decreverint, ≈øtudere poterint.

Prae≈øidens vero omnibus Scholaribus, Sociis, Clericis, Mini≈øtris, & quibu≈øcunque aliis exi≈øtentibus & degentibus in eodem praefit, & Prae≈øidens perpetu√≤ nuncupetur:The Character of the Pre≈øident. Vir bonae conver≈øationis & hone≈øtae, ≈øcienti√¢, bonis moribus, & conditionibus approbatus, in Spiritualibus & temporalibus di≈øcretus, providus ac
etiam circum≈øpectus, cujus Nominationem Electionem & Praefectionem, perpetuis futuris temporibus Statuimus, Ordinamus & volumus debere fieri ≈øub hac form√¢ viz. Quod cedente decedente vel etiam amoto Prae≈øidente huju≈ømodi,The Form of the choo≈øing the Pre≈øident. vel alias dicto Collegio quoquo modo de≈øtituto Prae≈øidente, infra duos dies immediate ≈øequentes de≈øtitutionem huju≈ømodi,Upon the death or removal of the Pre≈øident, the Vice-Pre≈øident or in his ab≈øence the Senior Fellow within two days ≈øhall convene the pre≈øent Fellows to con≈øider of the day for Election, which ≈øhall be within 15 days after, ≈øo that the ab≈øent Fellows may have notice by Citation. omnes & ≈øinguli ≈øocii no≈øtri Collegii praedicti in Univer≈øitate prae≈øentes, per Vice-Prae≈øidentem, ≈øi prae≈øens fuerit, vel eo ab≈øente, vel alias impedito, per ≈øocium ≈øimpliciter ≈øeniorem ip≈øius no≈øtri Collegii praemoniti, ≈øimul conveniant in Capella dicti no≈øtri Colegii, de die Nominationis Prae≈øidentis futuri fiendo (ut convenit) tractaturi, Quam Nominationis diem quam citius fieri poterit, infra quindecim dies, ex tunc immediate ≈øequentes continue numerandos, pro Nominatione huju≈ømodi facienda, Vice-Prae≈øidens, vel dictus ≈øocius Statuat, & praefigat per literas citatorias, & monitorias in valvis Capellae dicti Collegii no≈øtri figendas; Provi≈øo tamen quod ≈øocios ≈øuos ab≈øentes per duodecim dies a tempore praemonitionis in hoc ea≈øu fiendae priu≈øquam ad futuri Pre≈øidentis Nominationem procedant teneantur & debeant expectare. Quibus duodecim diebus huju≈ømodi tran≈øactis,Upon the 13th day all the Pre≈øent Fellows to appear under pain of Expul≈øion. in cra≈øtino convocentur per Vice-Prae≈øidentem, vel ip≈øo ab≈øente por ≈øocium ≈øeniorem ad Capellam praedictam omnes & ≈øinguli Collegii no≈øtri ≈øocii prae≈øentes cujus quidem Vice-Prae≈øidentis ≈øeu ip≈øo ab≈øonte ≈øocii huju≈ømodi ≈øeniores vacatione, omnes & ≈øingulos ≈øocios ante dictos parere volumus, ≈øub paena perpetuae amotionis a Collegio no≈øtro memorato, quam non parentes incurrere volumus ip≈øo facto;The like penalty upon Election of other Officers. quam etiam poenam omnes & ≈øingulos ≈øocios in Nominationibus & Electionibus quorumcunque Officiariorum intere≈ø≈øe habentes, & effectualiter nominare
≈øeu eligere renuentes incurrere volumus-ip≈øo facto.He that convenes the Fellows to declare the cau≈øe of the meeting. Then the Ma≈øs of the Holy Gho≈øt to be celebrated. Expo≈øit√¢ vero per eundem convocantem cau≈øa Convocationis predictae, ≈øcilicet pro Nominatione futuri Prae≈øidentis facienda, pro Spiritus Sancti gratia in hac parte uberius impetranda, antequam ad Nominationem procedant Mi≈ø≈øam de eodem Spiritu Sancto faciant inter ≈øe ≈øolenniter celebrari, qua celebrata ≈øtatim legatur hoc prae≈øens Statutum plen√® & perfecte per Vice-Prae≈øidentem, vel ip≈øo ab≈øente per ≈øocium ≈øeniorem, palam & public√® deinde ad Nominationem futuri Prae≈øidentis expectatorum,Then this Statute to be read publicly ≈øo to proceed to Election not ≈øtaying for the ab≈øent Fellows: The two Senior Fellows to be Scrutators or Tryers, who with all the other Fellows ≈øhall take an Oath before the Vice-Pre≈øident or the Senior Fellow. ut praemittitur, ab≈øentia non ob≈øtante, in forma infra ≈øcripta ulterius procedatur. Duo ≈øocii no≈øtri Collegii omnibus aliis ≈øociis ≈øeniores, quos Scrutatores in i≈øta Nominatione e≈ø≈øe volumus, ac omnes alii ≈øocii ≈øupra dicti, tactis per ip≈øos & ip≈øorum quemlibet ≈øacro-Sanctis Dei Evangeliis, coram Vice-Prae≈øidente praedicto, vel ip≈øo impedito, ≈øeniori ≈øocio prae≈øente, corporale prae≈øtent juramentum, public√® tunc ibidem.

Quod po≈øtpo≈øitis omnimodis,The Oath. To nominate one or two of the Fellows of this College or have been Fellows of that College and have removed thence for lawful and hone≈øt cau≈øes, or of St. Mary of Winche≈øter College in Oxford, or ≈øuch as have been Fellows as before. amore, favore, odio, timore, invidia, partialitate, affectione con≈øanguinitatis, affinitatis, facultatis & ≈øcientiae n√©c non acceptione per≈øonarum & patriae, & occa≈øione quacunque precis, aut pretii, cum omni celeritate qua poterint, Nominabunt unum vel duos de ≈øociis ip≈øius Collegii, aut de illis qui aliquando fuerint ip≈øius Collegii ≈øocii, & ex cau≈øis licitis & hone≈øtis inde rece≈ø≈øerint; vel noÃÑminabunt unum, vel duos de ≈øociis no≈øtri Collegii Beatae Mariae Winton in Oxon, vel de his qui quondam fuerint ≈øocii ip≈øius no≈øtri Collegii, & ex cau≈øis rece≈ø≈øerint hone≈øtis. Ita vero quod Nominent duos ex his predictis Collegiis, vel ex
altero Eorundem in Theologi√¢, Jure Canonico, Civili,The per≈øons named, to be Drs. of Divinity, Canon or Civil Law, or in Phy≈øic or Ma≈øters of Arts. The Character of tho≈øe ≈øo to be nominated. aut in Medicina Doctores, vel artium Magi≈øtros quos in ip≈øorum Con≈øcientiis magis idoneos, ≈øufficientiores, di≈øcretiores, utiliores, & aptiores ad ≈øubeundum, gerendum, & exercendum Prae≈øidentis Officium ≈øperaverint, & firmiter crediderint; nec non quod illos quos Nominaverint ≈øperant, & firmiter credunt, quoad bonum & ≈øalubre regimen & diligentem curam ip≈øius Collegii, per≈øonarum, Statutorum, & bonorum eju≈ødem Collegii, Terrarum, Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øionum, & Reddituum, Spiritualium & Temporalium,The Oath of the Tryers before the ≈øcrutiny to examin the vote of every Fellow, who ≈øhall give their votes ≈øeverally in ≈øecret and in writing. The Oath to be tendred by the next immediate ≈øenior. If the votes fall upon two, the elde≈øt. Tryer having exactly computed, it ≈øhall be publi≈øht. & jurium eorundem Con≈øervationem, plus po≈ø≈øe proficere & debere. Jurabunt in≈øuper dicti Scrutatores, ante ip≈øum Scrutinium, quod votum cuju≈ølibet ≈øociorum praedictorum, in ip≈øa Nominatione diligenter & fideliter examinabunt, qui ut praemittitur examinati, coram dictis Scrutatoribus, ≈øua vota ≈øecrete, & ≈øigillatim emittere, & ea propria manu in ≈øcriptis redigere teneantur ac debeant: ad quod etiam dictos Scrutatores per duos proxime ≈øeniores (modo quo praefertur) examinatos, arctari volumus & Ordinamus. In quo quidem Scrutinio ≈øi contingat duas per≈øonas vota majoris partis omnium ≈øociorum tunc prae≈øentium habere, ≈øenior dictorum Scrutatorum, dicto Scrutinio inter ≈øe Communicato, & fideliter calculato, ip≈øum Scrutinium mox de huju≈ømodi Nominatis per≈øonis publicet in communi; qua publicatione facta, illae per≈øonae pro Nominatis habeantur.

Si vero in dicto Scrutinio in duas per≈øonas con≈øen≈øum non fuerit (ut praefertur) ab≈øque omni tumultu & contradictione,If the votes befor more then two, the ≈øcrutiny ≈øhall be repeated and ≈øo to continue for three days, if not determined before upon the third day tho≈øe ≈øhall be reputed the two Elects who have the greater number of votes. If no two have the Majority of votes tho≈øe ≈øhall be the two Elects who have the greate≈øt number of the ≈øenior Fellows, which ≈øhall be publi≈øhed by the ≈øenior Tryer. After this publication the Vice-Pre≈øident or ≈øenior Fellow ≈øhall convene 13 of the ≈øenior Fellows to make the final Election of the Pre≈øident. The≈øe 13 ≈øenior Fellows ≈øhall take an Oath as formerly. If the Vice-Pre≈øident be one of the ≈øenior Fellows then the Oath ≈øhall be admini≈øtred to him by another ≈øenior Fellow. iterum con≈øimile fiat Scrutinium, & ≈øic deinceps per tres dies continuos, quod ≈øi in tertio die non concordatum fuerit, illi duo pro Nominatis
habeantur, qui Scrutinio inter dictos Scrutatores communicato plures ≈øociorum no≈øtri Collegii voces partium comparatione, numero habere inveniuntur: Si vero nulli duo plures voces ≈øimpliciter, ≈øed multi aequales voces numero habuerint, illi pro Nominatis habeantur, qui de habentibus aequales voces numero fuerint ≈øeniores, quod per ≈øeniorem ip≈øorum Scrutatorum in Communi publicetur. Qua publicatione facta Statuimus & volumus Vice-Prae≈øidentem, vel ip≈øo ab≈øente, ≈øocium ≈øimpliciter ≈øeniorem prae≈øentem, Convocare tre≈ødecim ≈øocios ≈øeniores Collegii, ad efficacem & finalem Electionem unius de per≈øonis Nominatis in Prae≈øidentem a≈ø≈øumendi, & prae≈øiciendi. Quibus convenientibus jurabunt omnes & ≈øinguli tredecim ≈øeniores praedicti, quod, po≈øtpo≈øitis omnimodis amore, favore, odio, timore, acceptione per≈øonarum, & patriae, ac partialitate facultatis & ≈øcientiae, ac occa≈øione quacunque precis, aut pretii, cum omni celeritate unum de praedictis Nominatis, quem in ip≈øorum con≈øcientiis magis idoneum, ≈øufficientiorem, di≈øcretiorem, utiliorem, & aptiorem crediderint, ad exercendum Prae≈øidentis Officium eligent; Vice Prae≈øidente no≈øtri Collegii, vel ip≈øo ab≈øente ≈øocio ≈øeniori, dictos tre≈ødecim & quemlibet eorum cum dicto jurarnento onerante: Quod ≈øi Vice-prae≈øidens de illis tre≈ødecim ≈øenioribus unus exi≈øtat, per alterum ≈øeniorem, ≈øimili juramento oneretur. Quo facto Scrutatores in prima Nominatione, Scrutinium de votis praedictorum tre≈ødecim ≈øeniorum Prae≈øidentem eligere debentium facere teneantur, in quo Scrutinio, ≈øocii Prae≈øidentem eligere debentes, vota ≈øua pure ≈øimpliciter & ≈øecrete manibus propriis ≈øcribere teneantur, ip≈øis Scrutatoribus videntibus, & au≈øcultantibus: Et praedicti Scrutatores juramento
≈øimili prae≈øtito,The votes to be given to the Tryers as before. The Tryers being ≈øworn likewi≈øe ≈øhall give their votes. If one per≈øon have all the votes of the 13 the ≈øenior Tryer ≈øhall publi≈øh him Pre≈øident. ≈øua vota ≈øcribant coram duobus ≈øenioribus po≈øt eos proximis, pure, ≈øimpliciter, & ≈øecrete, in quo quidem Scrutinio, ≈øi contingat unam per≈øonam vota omnium praedictorum tredecim habere, Scrutatores praedicti, dicto Scrutinio inter ≈øe communicato, ip≈øum Scrutinium de huju≈ømodi electa per≈øona, mox per ≈øeniorem illorum publicent in Communi: Qua publicatione ≈øic fact√¢ illa per≈øona pro Electa habeatur in quam tre≈ødecim ≈øocii praedicti con≈øen≈øerint.

Si vero in dicto Scrutinio in unam per≈øonam per dictos tre≈ødecim unanimiter con≈øen≈øum non fuerit;If the 13 Fellows votes agree not in one per≈øon he ≈øhall be Pre≈øident who hath the majority of the votes of the 13 ≈øenior Fellows. He ≈øhall in≈øtantly be publi≈øhed Pre≈øident and without any further ≈øolemnity. As ≈øoon as may be the Elected Pre≈øident by one of the ≈øenior Fellows Elected by the majority of the 13 Fellows together with Letters of his Election and conteining the Statute and the Oath under the common Seal of the College ≈øhall be pre≈øented to the Bi≈øhop of Winche≈øter for the time being, or in his ab≈øence to his Vicar general or the Guardian of the Spirituality in the vacancy and the Letters are to be believed by the Bi≈øhop or tho≈øe in his place without proof. Nihilominus illa per≈øona, pro Electa habeatur ab≈øque tumultu, contradictione, querela, appellatione, ≈øupplicatione, ≈øeu quocunque impedimento Juris, vel facti, in quam, per majorem partem praedictorum tre≈ødecem con≈øen≈øum fuerit, & coram omnibus & ≈øingulis tunc ibidem prae≈øentibus, celerius quo fieri poterit, pro Prae≈øidente no≈øtri Collegii per unum praedictorum Scrutatorum denuncietur; quibus omnibus ≈øic peractis, nullo alio juris ordine, proce≈ø≈øu, ≈øeu ≈øolennitate in hac parte ob≈øervatis, ≈øeu etiam requi≈øitis, illa per≈øona in Prae≈øidentem, in Scrutinio finaliter nominata, citius quo commode fieri poterit, per unum ≈øeniorem ≈øocium ip≈øius Collegii, per Majorem partem ip≈øorum tre≈ødecim ≈øeniorum nominandum, una cum Literis Electionis praedictae, formam ac prae≈øentis no≈øtri Statuti, & Nominati huju≈ømodi juramenti prae≈øtandi tenores plenarie continentibus, ≈øigillo communi dicti Collegii ≈øigillatis Domino Epi≈øcopo Winton. qui protempore
fuerit, vel ip≈øo in remotis extra Diaece≈øin ≈øuam agente, ip≈øius in Spiritualibus Vicario generali aut ≈øede Epi≈øcopali vacante, Cu≈øtodi Spiritualitatis eju≈ødem prae≈øentetur.

Quibus literis ≈øuper Electione,The Fellow ≈øent with the Pre≈øident ≈øhall propo≈øe the Pre≈øident to the Bi≈øhop or tho≈øe in his place, ≈øpecially decently and honorably commending the Pre≈øident and all el≈øe of the College. The Bi≈øhop or his Vicar, &c. without delay of time, any Judicial Proce≈øs, or refu≈øing ≈øhall admit him Pre≈øident. If the Bi≈øhop or his Vicar, &c. for five days to be numbred from the pre≈øenting the Pre≈øident ≈øhall refu≈øe to prefer the per≈øon thus propo≈øed to be Pre≈øident then by vertue of the Statutes he ≈øhall be and be judged Pre≈øident without it. The Pre≈øident ≈øhall pre≈øently after ≈øuch preferring to the Pre≈øident≈øhip, fir≈øt take the following Oath before the Bi≈øhop or his Vicar, &c. and after before all the Fellows. ≈øeu Nominatione huju≈ømodi modoque & forma praedictis, ab≈øque probatione alia plenam fidem volumus adhiberi. Qui quidem ≈øocius, cum dicta per≈øon√¢ in Prae≈øidentem Nominata & Electa mittendus, coram Domino Epi≈øcopo Winton. ip≈øius Collegii tunc Patrono, ≈øeu illo cui dictam prae≈øentationem fieri tunc continget, propo≈øitionem facere teneatur, dictum Collegium, Per≈øonam in Prae≈øidentem Nominatam, & omnes alias per≈øonas dicti Collegii eidem ≈øpecialiter, decenter & honorifice commendando, ip≈øe vero Epi≈øcopus dictus Winton. ≈øeu ip≈øius Vicarius aut Cu≈øtos Spiritualitatis, eju≈ødem cui dictam prae≈øentationem fieri continget, per≈øonam ≈øic Electam ab≈øque morae di≈øpendio, & ≈øine proce≈ø≈øu judiciario, & ab≈øque impugnatione Electionis five Nominationis praedictae dicti Collegii praeficiat, extrajudicialiter in Prae≈øidentem. Si autem Dominus Epi≈øcopus Winton. aliu≈øve ex praedictis per≈øonis ad quem dicti Prae≈øidentis prae≈øentationem ≈øpectare volumus, ut praefertur, per quinque dies, a tempore Prae≈øentationis praedictae ≈øibi factae continue numerandos, noluerit per≈øonam in forma praedicta Electam, praeficere in Prae≈øidentem, ex tunc Electus huju≈ømodi, eo ip≈øo prae≈øentis no≈øtri Statuti vigore, in Prae≈øidentem dicti no≈øtri Collegii ≈øit praefectus, & pro vero & legitimo
& perpetuo Prae≈øidente inibi habeatur. Prae≈øidentem vero huju≈ømodi quemcunque Statim po≈øt praefectionem ≈øuam (≈øi huju≈ømodi praefectio tunc fiat) primo coram illo qui ip≈øum praefecerit in Prae≈øidentem, & ≈øub≈øequenter in prae≈øentia omnium ≈øociorum ip≈øius Collegii prae≈øentium, antequam quoquo modo admini≈øtrat, tactis & in≈øpectis per ip≈øum Sacro≈øanctis Evangeliis ≈øub≈øcriptum prae≈øtare volumus juramentum.

div.head: Juramentum admittendorum in veros Socios.
div.p:
EGo N. Juro ad haec Sancta Dei Evangelia per me Corporaliter tacta,The Oath of a Pre≈øident or Fellow. quod omnia Statuta, & Ordinationes hujus Collegii edita, & edenda, per Reverendum in Chri≈øto Patrem Gulielmum Waynfleet Fundatorem praedictum, ac omnia & ≈øingula in ei≈ødem Contenta, quatenus per≈øonam meam concernunt, vel concernere poterint ≈øecundum planum, literalem, & Gramaticalem ≈øen≈øum & intellectum inviolabiliter tenebo, & etiam ob≈øervabo, & quantum in me fuerit teneri faciam ab aliis, & etiam ob≈øervari, &c. Item quod non impetrabo Di≈øpen≈øationem aliquam contra juramenta mea praedicta, vel aliquam particulam eorundem, nec contra Ordinationes, & Statuta de quibus praemittitur, aut ip≈øorum aliqua, nec di≈øpen≈øationem huju≈ømodi, per alium vel alios publice vel occulte impetrari vel fieri procurabo, directe, vel indirecte; & ≈øi for≈øan aliquam di≈øpen≈øationem huju≈ømodi impetrari aut gratis concedi, aut acquiri contigerit cuju≈øcunque fuerit Authoritatis ≈øeu ≈øi generaliter, ≈øeu ≈øpecialiter,
aut alias ≈øub quacunque verborum forma conce≈ø≈øa ≈øit, ip≈øa non utar, nec eidem con≈øentiam quovi≈ømodo, ≈øicut Deus me adjuvet & haec Sancta Dei Evangelia.

div.head: ¬ß. 4. Out of the Regi≈øter.
At a Court held, &c. June the 13th. 1687.
div.p: The Vice-Pre≈øident and Deputies of St, Mary Magdalen College in Oxford, attend with their An≈øwer, which was Read and they being withdrawn, the Lords Commi≈ø≈øioners thought fit to put of the further con≈øideration of that matter, till the 22d. In≈øtant at Ten in the Morning, at which time they were required to appear.

div.head: At a Court held, &c. the 22d. day of June. 1687.
div.p:
The Vice-Pre≈øident and the Fellows of St. Mary Magdalen College attend, and are asked whether they had any thing el≈øe to offer by way of An≈øwer. Upon which they gave in a Paper containing an account of ≈øeveral mi≈ødemeanors committed by Mr. Anthony Farmer, which being Read, the Lords Ordered Mr. Farmer ≈øhould have a Coppy of the ≈øaid Paper, and appointed to hear him upon it at the next meeting, requiring ≈øome of the Fellows of the ≈øaid College to attend
at the ≈øame time, and as to the bu≈øine≈øs of the ≈øaid College their Lord≈øhips made this following Order.

div.head: By His Maje≈øties Commi≈ø≈øioners, &c.
div.p: VVHereas it appears unto Us,The Lords Commi≈ø≈øioners pronounce the Election of Mr. Hough void. that Mr. John Hough Batchellor in Divinity, has been unduly Elected Pre≈øident of St. Mary Magdalen College, in the Univer≈øity of Oxford; We have thought fit, upon mature con≈øideration thereof, That the ≈øaid Election be declared void, and that the ≈øaid Mr. John Hough be amoved from the ≈øaid Pre≈øident≈øhip: And accordingly We do hereby declare, pronounce, and decree, That the ≈øaid Election is void, and do amove the ≈øaid Mr. John Hough from the place of Pre≈øident of the ≈øaid College.

closer.dateline: Given under our Seal the 22d. of June, 1687.

div.head: ¬ß. 5. The Sentence of Su≈øpen≈øion again≈øt Dr. Charles Aldworth, and Dr. Henry Fairfax.

p.hi: At the ≈øame Court the≈øe two following Orders were made.

div.head: By His Maje≈øties Commi≈ø≈øioners, &c.
div.p:
VVHereas Charles Aldworth, Doctor of Laws, Vice-Pre≈øident of St. Mary Magdalen College in the Univer≈øity of Oxford, and the Deputies of the Fellows of the ≈øame, have been convened before Us, for their Contempt in not obeying His Maje≈øties Letters Mandatory, for Electing and Admitting Mr. Anthony Farmer Pre≈øident of that College; And the ≈øaid Dr. Aldworth, and Deputies having been heard thereupon, We have thought fit to declare pronounce and decree, That the ≈øaid Dr. Charles Aldworth ≈øhall for the ≈øaid Contempt be ≈øu≈øpended from being Vice-Pre≈øident of the ≈øaid College,
and al≈øo that Henry Fairfax Doctor of Divinity, one of the Fellows of the ≈øaid College, ≈øhall for the ≈øaid Contempt be ≈øu≈øpended from his Fellow≈øhip, and accordingly We do hereby Su≈øpend the ≈øaid Dr. Charles Aldworth from being Vice-Pre≈øident of the ≈øaid College, and the ≈øaid Dr. Henry Fairfax from his Fellow≈øhip in the ≈øaid College.

closer.dateline: Given under our Seal the 22d. day of June, 1687.

div.head: By His Maje≈øties Commi≈ø≈øioners, &c.
div.p: WHereas We have thought fit to declare,The Order of the Lords Commi≈ø≈øioners for the publication of the former decrees. pronounce and decree, that the Election made by you of Mr. John Hough Batchellor in Divinity to be Pre≈øident of St. Mary Magdalen College in the Univer≈øity of Oxford is void, and to amove the ≈øaid Mr. John Hough from the place of Pre≈øident of the ≈øaid College. And whereas we have thought fit to Su≈øpend Dr. Charles Aldworth from being Vice-Pre≈øident of the ≈øame, and D. Henry Fairfax from his Fellow≈øhip in the ≈øaid College, We do hereby enjoyn, and require you to cau≈øe our Orders vacating the ≈øaid Election and ≈øu≈øpending the ≈øaid Dr. Aldworth and Dr. Fairfax, (Copies of which Order under our Seal are hereunto annexed) to be affixed on the Gates of the ≈øaid College,The Fellows An≈øwer was not Read till the 5th. of Augu≈øt. to the end that due notice may be taken of the ≈øame. And you are to Certifie Us under your Hands and Seals of the due Execution of what is hereby required.

closer.dateline: Given under our Seal the 22d day of June, 1687.

div.trailer: Super≈øcribed. To the Fellows of St. Mary Magdalen College in the ∆≤niver≈øity of Oxford.

div.p: The Fellows ≈øtudying all the ways they could to evade and refu≈øe Obedience to the Kings Mandates, or the Lords Commi≈ø≈øioners Orders did it colourably in this particular, as will appear in this following Letter.

div.head: ¬ß. 6. Mr. Atterbury's Letter concerning his reception at St. Mary Magdalen College.
div.p:
MR. Thomas Atterbury Me≈ø≈øenger, was ≈øent with this Order to the College, and he returns An≈øwer June the 24th. that he came thither that day, and enquired for Dr. Pud≈øey who he under≈øtood was Senior Fellow upon the place, and told him that he was directed by the Lords Commi≈ø≈øioners to apply him≈øelf to him as Senior Fellow and de≈øired him to A≈ø≈øemble the re≈øt of the Fellows, that he might deliver to them the Orders from the ≈øaid Lords; Dr. Pud≈øey reply'd, That he did not Act as Senior Fellow, for that he was made Bur≈øer, but would endeavor to get him an An≈øwer at Five a Clock, as ≈øoon as Prayers were done, at which time he told him, that he had no power to A≈ø≈øemble the Fellows, neither could he any ways do it, ≈øo long as there was a Pre≈øident on the place the Fellows had no Authority to Act; There being two or three Fellows with this Doctor, one of them asked Mr. Atterbury to ≈øee the Orders, to which he An≈øwered: If he with Dr. Pud≈øey and the re≈øt would receive them he would deliver them to them, but would not Read them; So he ≈øhewed them the Indor≈øment, that they were directed to them, and offered to deliver them to them: But they refu≈øed, ≈øaying, they had no Authority to call an A≈ø≈øembly, neither could they do it, therefore it was not fit they ≈øhould receive them, and being de≈øired to tell him, if that was their final An≈øwer, they ≈øaid yes, ≈øo he told
Dr. Pud≈øey he mu≈øt give a ≈øpeedy An≈øwer to the Regi≈øter Mr. Bridgman, to whom he ≈øends this account, and adds, that the Doctor treated him with very good words, and Invited him to Dine with them while he ≈øtayed in Town.
Thus far Mr. Atterbury's Letter, I now proceed to what was done next.

div.head: ¬ß. 7. The Orders of the Lords concerning Mr. Farmer, upon the Reading his defence.
At a Court held, &c. the 1≈øt. day of July 1687.
div.p: Mr. Anthony Farmer gave in his An≈øwer to the Complaint exhibited again≈øt him by the Fellows of Magdalen College, which was Read, and the Court Ordered to hear the matter at their next meeting, when all parties concerned are required to Attend, and that Compul≈øories ≈øhould be granted to both ≈øides for Witne≈ø≈øes.e Regi≈øtro.
The Form whereof was as followeth.

div.head: By His Maje≈øties Eccle≈øia≈øtical Commi≈ø≈øioners for Eccle≈øia≈øtical Cau≈øes, &c.
div.p:
YOu and either of you are hereby required forthwith to Cite and Summon James Fayrer Ma≈øter of Arts of Magdalen College, &c. to appear per≈øonally before us in the Council Chamber Friday the 29th. day of July In≈øtant, at Four of the Clock in the Afternoon, then and there by vertue of this Citation, as Witne≈ø≈øes to give their Te≈øtimonies in the matter depending before us, betwixt the Fellows of St. Mary Magdalens College in Oxford, and one Mr. Anthony Farmer, under pain of the
Law and Contempt thereof. And of the due execution hereof you are to certifie us, the day and year afore≈øaid, together with the≈øe pre≈øents.

closer.dateline: Given under our Seal the 1≈øt. day of July, 1687.

div.trailer: To Thomas Atterbury and Robert Eddows. Or either of them.

div.p: July the 1≈øt. Their Lord≈øhips having been informed,Out of the Regi≈øter. that their fore≈øaid Order of June the 22d. had not been obeyed, Ordered the following Citation.

div.head: By His Maje≈øties Commi≈ø≈øioners, &c.
div.p:
WHereas We thought fit by our Order of the 22d. of June la≈øt,Citation of the Fellows for di≈øobeying the former Order. to enjoyn and require the Fellows of St. Mary Magdalen College in the Univer≈øity of Oxford to cau≈øe our Orders for the vacating the Election made by them of Mr. John Hough to be Pre≈øident of the ≈øaid College, and for Su≈øpending Dr. Charles Aldworth from being Vice-Pre≈øident and Dr. Henry Fairfax from his Fellow≈øhip in the ≈øame, to be affixed on the Gates of the ≈øaid College, and whereas we are given to under≈øtand that our ≈øaid Order hath not been obeyed by the ≈øaid Fellows: You and either of you are hereby required to Cite and Summon the ≈øaid Fellows of St. Mary Magdalen College, requiring them to appear before Us in the Council Chamber at Whitehall, upon Friday the 29th. In≈øtant, at Four in the Afternoon to An≈øwer the ≈øaid Contempt, and of the due execution hereof, you are to certifie
Us then and there.

closer.dateline: Given under our Seal the fir≈øt day of July. 1687.

div.trailer: Super≈øcribed. To Thomas Atterbury and Robert Eddows. Or either of them.

div.head: ¬ß. 8.
div.p: During this interim, before the Fellows appeared before the Lords Commi≈ø≈øioners, the King, according to former Pre≈øidents, ≈øends this following Inhibitory Mandate to the Fellows of St. Mary Magdalen College.

TRu≈øty and Well-beloved,Inhibitions ≈øent to the Fellows neither to Elect nor Admit any Fellow or Demy till the Kings further plea≈øure was known, which is according to former Pre≈øidents as in due place will be ≈øhown. We Greet you well, whereas We are informed, that a Sentence or Decree lately made by Our Commi≈ø≈øioners for Eccle≈øia≈øtical Affairs, touching an Election in that Our College hath not been obeyed, Our will and plea≈øure is, that no Election, or Admi≈ø≈øion be made of any per≈øon, or per≈øons what≈øoever, to any Fellow≈øhip, Demy≈øhip, or other place or Office in our ≈øaid College, until We ≈øhall ≈øignifie Our further plea≈øure, any Statute, Cu≈øtom, or Con≈øtitution, to the contrary notwith≈øtanding; And ≈øo expecting your ready obedience herein, We bid you farewell. Given at our Court at Wind≈øor the 18th. day of July. 1687. In the third Year of our Reign.

closer.signed: By His Maje≈øties Command. Sunderland P.

div.trailer: Super≈øcribed. To Our Tru≈øty and Wellbeloved the Fellows of St. Mary Magdalens College in Our ∆≤niver≈øity of Oxford.

div.head: ¬ß. 9. Order to Mr. Atterbury, &c. to affix the Decree concerning Mr. Hough Dr. Aldworth, and Dr. Fairfax, upon the College Gates.
div.p: The next Court was held the 29th. day of July. At which time I do not find, that the Fellows of St. Mary Magdalen College did exhibit their An≈øwer why they obeyed not the Order of the Lords Commi≈ø≈øioners of the 22d. of June, nor that their Lord≈øhips required it, but I find in the Regi≈øter this following Order to affix the Sentence on the College Gates.

div.head: By His Maje≈øties Commi≈ø≈øioners, &c.
div.p: WHereas We have thought fit to declare pronounce and decree,Out of the Regi≈øter. that the Election made of Mr. John Hough Batchellor in Divinity to be Pre≈øident of St. Mary Magdalen College in the Univer≈øity of Oxford is void, and to amove the ≈øaid Mr. John Hough from the place of Pre≈øident of the ≈øaid College.
