And whereas We have al≈øo thought fit to Su≈øpend Dr. Charles Aldworth from being Vice-Pre≈øident of the ≈øame, and Dr. Henry Fairfax from his Fellow≈øhip in the ≈øaid College; you and either of you are hereby required to cau≈øe our Orders, Vacating the ≈øaid Election, and Su≈øpending the ≈øaid Dr. Aldworth and Dr. Fairfax (Copies of which under our Seal are hereunto Annexed) to be affixed on the Gates of the ≈øaid College to the end that due notice may be taken of the ≈øame, and of the due Execution hereof you are to certifie unto Us at the next Court.

closer.dateline: Given under Our Seal the 29th. day of July. 1687.

div.trailer: To Thomas Atterbury and Robert Eddows. Or either of them.

div.head: ¬ß. 10. The An≈øwer of the Fellows why they obeyed not the order of the 22d. of June.
At the Court held, &c. the 29th. of July 1687.
div.p: Mr. Anthony Farmer was heard upon the complaint exhibited again≈øt him by Magdalen College.

I find nothing more relating to him entred in the Regi≈øter, therefore ≈øince the Information again≈øt him and his defence are to be reckoned among the Attentatar as the Civilians Style them, and are no ways material to the di≈øcu≈ø≈øing or clearing the Authority of His Maje≈øty or the Lords Commi≈ø≈øioners, I ≈øhall wholly omit any account of them, and proceed to what was done in the Court.

div.head: The An≈øwer of the Fellows of St. Mary Magdalen College in Oxon, who≈øe Names are hereunto ≈øub≈øcribed (being Deputed by the re≈øt of the Fellows of the ≈øaid College) made to the Citation of the Right Honorable the Lords Commi≈ø≈øioners of Eccle≈øia≈øtical Affairs, &c.
div.p: THe ≈øaid Fellows, on the behalf of them≈øelves and the re≈øt by whom they are Deputed, do An≈øwer that they humbly conceive, that the Order mentioned in the ≈øaid Citation was not Legally ≈øerved upon them, for that Dr. Alexander Pud≈øey only was de≈øired by the Me≈ø≈øenger to call a Meeting of the Fellows to publi≈øh the ≈øaid Order which he declared he could not do, for that he was Bur≈øer of the ≈øaid College, and had no Authority to do the ≈øame, nor was the ≈øaid Order particularly directed to him but to the Fellows in General as the Me≈ø≈øenger there declared.

And when one of the Fellows de≈øired of the Me≈ø≈øenger to have it Read, the ≈øaid Me≈ø≈øenger refu≈øed
it, ≈øaying, his directions were to Communicate it to the Fellows at a Meeting, whereas the ≈øaid Fellows cannot meet together till they are Statutably called. Saving which Declaration of the ≈øaid Me≈ø≈øenger the Re≈øpondents were wholly Ignorant of the Contents of the ≈øaid Order until the forementioned Citation of the Fir≈øt of July was ≈øerved upon them.

And that in the ordinary cour≈øe of Law all Decrees and Orders of Courts are ≈øerved and executed by the Mini≈øters and Officers of the ≈øaid Courts, but not by any per≈øon or per≈øons upon or again≈øt them≈øelves as they conceive the pre≈øent Ca≈øe is.
Aug. 5th. the Deputies of the Fellows attend,Out of the Regi≈øter. and give in their An≈øwer in Writing (as before recited) which being Read were di≈ømi≈ø≈øed.

div.head: SECT. III.

argument.p: The Tran≈øactions from the Mandate for the Bi≈øhop of Oxford to the Lords Commi≈ø≈øioners Vi≈øiting St. Mary Magdalen College.

div.head: ¬ß. 1. The Kings Man late to the Fellows, &c. to Admit the Bi≈øhop of Oxford Pre≈øident.
div.p: THe King being willing to place ≈øuch a Pre≈øident over the College, as by the Character he bore in the Church, being Bi≈øhop of the Dioce≈øs, might be an Honor to the Society, was Graciou≈øly plea≈øed to grant the following Mandate.

TRu≈øty and Beloved, 14th. Aug. 1687. We Greet you well: Whereas the place of Pre≈øident of that Our College of St. Mary Magdalen, is now void, Our Will and Plea≈øure is, and We do hereby Authorize and Require you forthwith, upon receipt hereof, to Admit the Right Reverend Father in God, Samuel Lord Bi≈øhop of Oxon, in the ≈øaid place of Pre≈øident, to hold and enjoy the ≈øame, with all the Rights, Priviledges, Profits, Emoluments and Advantages thereunto belonging, any Statute or Statutes, Cu≈øtom or Con≈øtitution to the contrary in any wi≈øe notwith≈øtanding, wherewith we are Graciou≈øly plea≈øed and do accordingly hereby Di≈øpen≈øe herein; We bid you farewell. Given at our Court at Wind≈øor the 14th. day of Augu≈øt. 1687. In the Third Year of Our Reign.

closer.signed: By His Maje≈øties Command. Sunderland P.

div.trailer: Super≈øcribed. To Our Tru≈øty and Wellbeloved the Senior Fellow of St. Mary Magdalen College in Our ∆≤niver≈øity of Oxford, or in his Ab≈øence to the Senior Fellow re≈øideing there, and to the re≈øt of the Fellows of the ≈øaid College.

div.p:
Note that this Mandate was ≈øent after the hearing of Mr. Farmers cau≈øe before the Lords Commi≈ø≈øioners,
who≈øe Accu≈øation is Printed in a late Book, without his Reply, on purpo≈øe to vindicate the proceedings of the Electors of Dr. Hough, but ≈øince there was no Juridical Sentence upon it, and the ≈øtre≈øs of the Ca≈øe lies not upon his qualifications, I ≈øhall pa≈øs it by, and next in≈øert my Lord Pre≈øidents Letter pur≈øuant to the Mandate.

div.head: ¬ß. 2. My Lord Pre≈øidents Letter to the Senior Fellow of the College, &c.

body.p: THe King having been plea≈øed by his Letter Mandatory to require the Fellows of St. Mary Magdalen College, to Admit my Lord Bi≈øhop of Oxford Pre≈øident of that College: His Maje≈øty Commands me to let you know, that Immediately upon receipt hereof he would have you A≈ø≈øemble the Fellows, and Communicate to them His Maje≈øties ≈øaid Letters, and I am further Commanded to tell you, that His Maje≈øty expects ready obedience to be paid to his plea≈øure herein, I de≈øire you will ≈øend me an Account of your Proceedings as ≈øoon as you can, that I may acquaint His Maje≈øty with it.

closer.signed: I am SIR, Your Affectionate friend and Servant. Sunderland P.

body.trailer: To the Senior Fellow of St. Mary Magdalen College.

div.p: To this Dr. Pud≈øey returned the following An≈øwer.

div.head: ¬ß. 3. The An≈øwer of Dr. Pud≈øey the Senior F „Äà‚óä„Äâ llow to the fore≈øaid Letter.

body.p: UPon Saturday the 27th. of Augu≈øt la≈øt at Night, I received His Maje≈øties Letter Mandatory, together with your Lord≈øhips; In behalf of the Right Reverend Father in God Samuel Lord Bi≈øhop of Oxon, which I the next Morning Communicated to the Fellows and Read them in the Chappel with all deference to His Maje≈øty and your Lord≈øhip, the An≈øwer that was given to me was, that they humbly conceived the place of the Pre≈øident to be full; And becau≈øe your Lord≈øhip requires an Account of the Proceedings of the Society in this matter, I ≈øend their own words Unanimou≈øly agreed upon, and in Compliance to your Lord≈øhip with all Celerity of di≈øpatch. My reque≈øt is, that your Lord≈øhip would accept of this Letter with Candor, and favorably Interpret it as to the point of Obedience, and that I may have the Honor of being accounted.

closer.dateline: Mag. Coll. Oxon. Aug. 28th. 1687.
closer.signed: Your Lord≈øhips mo≈øt faithful and mo≈øt humble Servant. Alexander Pud≈øey.

body.trailer: Sub≈øcribed. To the Right Honorable the Earl of Sunderland Principal Secretary of State.

div.p:
By this Letter is appears, that the Fellows per≈øi≈øted in their ob≈øtinacy, in not paying obedience to
the Kings Second Mandate for admitting the Bi≈øhop of Oxford their Pre≈øident.

div.head: ¬ß. 4. The Coppy of the Bi≈øhop of Oxfords Letter to the Senior Fellow of St. Mary Magdalen College in Oxon, or in his ab≈øenc√© to the Senior Fellow re≈øiding there.
div.p: Upon the Receipt of the Kings Mandate the Bi≈øhop Writ the following Letter to the Senior Fellow of St. Mary Magdalen College.

body.p: YOu will receive herewith His Maje≈øties Mandate to Admit me Pre≈øident of the College of St. Mary Magdalen in Oxon, together with a Letter of my Lord Sunderland, pur≈øuant to His Maje≈øties Command. I am indi≈øpo≈øed, as I have been for ≈øome time, and not in a condition as yet to Travel; and therefore my reque≈øt to you is, that upon Receipt of the King's Plea≈øure, you would do me the favor to Admit me by Proxy, that is, either the next Senior Fellow under your ≈øelf, re≈øident, or either of my Chaplains, Mr. William Wickins, or Mr. Thomas Collins, whom I depute in my ≈øtead, which is as valid in Law, as if I were pre≈øent my ≈øelf; and is the mo≈øt u≈øual cu≈øtomary Practice. And by ≈øo doing, you will oblige

closer.signed: Your very Loving Friend and Brother. Samuel Oxon.

div.p: Dr. Pud≈øey being the Senior Fellow returned this following An≈øwer.

body.p: I Have peru≈øed your Lord≈øhips Letter,Dr. Pud≈øeys An≈øwer. and in obedience to His Maje≈øty have Read His Letter Mandatory, and my Lord Sunderlands Letter pur≈øuant to the ≈øame bu≈øine≈øs, in the Chappel before the Society this Morning. I askt the Fellows how they would proceed in this matter of concernment, and what An≈øwer I was to return to my Lord of Sunderland's by the Me≈ø≈øenger. They replyed unanimou≈øly, that the place of the Pre≈øident≈øhip was full, and that they could not Admit any other into the place.
This my Lord is the matter of Fact, and ≈øo I remain

closer.signed: Your Lord≈øhips mo≈øt humble Servant. Alex. Pud≈øey.
closer.dateline: Magd. Coll. Aug. the 28th. 1687.

div.p: I ≈øhall now pa≈øs to what I find ≈øucceed.

div.head: ¬ß. 5. My Lord Pre≈øidents Letter to the Bi≈øhop of Oxford.

body.p:
THe King Commands me to ≈øend your Lord≈øhip the three Inclo≈øed Copies, that you may be the better informed in the Ca≈øe of Magdalen College, the con≈øideration whereof he has Committed to you the Dean of Chri≈øt-Church and Mr. Walker. The fir≈øt is a Copy of a Letter to me, after the Delivery of the King's Mandate, which His Maje≈øty
having peru≈øed, ≈øent for all the Fellows on Sunday la≈øt, to attend him at Chri≈øt-Church College, and Commanded them to Admit your Lord≈øhip Pre≈øident of that College without any further delay or pretence. In≈øtead of Compliance they Signed a Paper, and ≈øent it to me, containing a Direct refu≈øal, but upon ≈øecond thoughts became more ≈øen≈øible of their Duty, and ≈øub≈øcribed another Paper in terms very ≈øubmi≈ø≈øive: Copies of both which you will herewith receive. Their meaning in the la≈øt Paper I am told is this: That if His Maje≈øty ≈øhall think fit, by his own Authority, to Con≈øtitute you their Pre≈øident, they will very readily acknowledg and obey you, de≈øiring only to be excu≈øed from Electing you, which they allege without breach of their Oaths they cannot do. His Maje≈øty thought it nece≈ø≈øary that your Lord≈øhip and the two Gentlemen above named ≈øhould be made acquainted with the≈øe Circum≈øtances for the direction in the advice you ≈øhall offer to His Maje≈øty upon this occa≈øion: I am further Commanded to tell you, that His Maje≈øty intends to be at Wind≈øor on Saturday Sennight, and would have you attend him there on the Munday, or Tue≈øday following, if your health will give you leave.
body.closer: September the 4th. 1687. I am MY LORD, Your Lord≈øhips mo≈øt humble Servant. Sunderland P.

p.hi: This was agreed on and done by the Fellows after His Maje≈øty had ≈øpoken to them.

div.p: The≈øe following Papers are the Copies mentioned in the fore≈øaid Letter.

div.head: ¬ß. 6. The Copy of one of the Papers mentioned in the preceding Letter.
div.p: At a Meeting of the Fellows of St. Mary Magdalen College in the Univer≈øity of Oxon in the Chappel of the ≈øaid College the 4th. day of September in the Year of our Lord God, 1687. Between the hours of Four and Five in the Afternoon of the ≈øame day in obedience to His Maje≈øties Command.

JOhn Smith Doctor of Divinity ≈øaith, that he is as ready to obey His Maje≈øty in all things that lie in his power as any other of His Maje≈øties Subjects what≈øoever, but he apprehends it to be contrary to the Founders Statutes and his Oath to Elect the Right Reverend Father in God Samuel Lord Bi≈øhop of Oxford Pre≈øident of St. Mary Magdalen College in Oxon, and therefore it does not lie in his Power.

closer.signed:
All the≈øe following agree with Dr. Smiths An≈øwer above Written.
Dr. Stafford.
Mr. Hammond.
Mr. Rogers.
Mr. Strickland.
Mr. Bayley.
Mr. Davys.
Mr. Bag≈øhaw.
Mr. Fayrer.
Mr. Hunt.
Mr. Craddock.
Mr. Penni≈øton.
Mr. Hyde.
Mr. Yerbury.
Mr. Holt.
Mr. Thornton.
Mr. Holden.
Mr. Wilks.

postscript.p: Mr. Henry Dob≈øon Ma≈øter of Arts ≈øaith, that he is ready to obey his Maje≈øty to the utmo≈øt of his power in the Election of the Bi≈øhop of Oxon.
Mr. Robert Charnock Ma≈øter of Arts and Fellow of the ≈øaid College ≈øaith, that he is ready to obey His Maje≈øties Order in the Electing the Bi≈øhop of Oxon Pre≈øident of Magdalen College.
Alex. Pud≈øey Doctor in Divinity, and Fellow of Magdalen College in Oxford ≈øaith, that the doth agree with the re≈øt of the Society.

closer.signed: In the Pre≈øence of John Greneway, Pub. Notary.

div.p: I have omitted what pa≈ø≈øed betwixt His Maje≈øty and the Fellows of St. Mary Magdalen College while the King was at Oxford; ≈øince there was nothing done by the Fellows which tended to a ≈øubmi≈ø≈øion to the Kings Authority, but rather to a Ju≈øtifying of their undutifulne≈øs in their Per≈øonal Addre≈øs to him, which as it was ≈øo contrary to expectation at a time when the King Honored their Univer≈øity with his Pre≈øence, and was the only di≈øobligation he had met withall in his whole Royal Progre≈øs: It cannot be wondred, that he re≈øented it as he did, that a number of Fellows of a ≈øingle College ≈øhould per≈øi≈øt ≈øo in their di≈øobedience, in not Admitting the Bi≈øhop of their Dioce≈øs to be their Pre≈øident, an Honor they never had ≈øince their Foundation, if we may be allowed to call it an Honor to have a per≈øon of that Character their Supreme Governor.

Since therefore they were not required to Elect him, but only Admit him by vertue of the Kings Mandate, the King having by that ≈øuper≈øeded the
former for Mr. Farmer, no Man can think it ≈øtrange, that the King re≈øolved to Cha≈øti≈øe them for their contempt in a method Ju≈øtifiable by Canon, Civil and Statute Law, both to vindicate his own Royal Authority, as likewi≈øe to deter others from following ≈øuch pernicious Examples.

div.head: CHAP. II.

argument.p: The Proceedings of the Lords Commi≈ø≈øioners in the Local Vi≈øitation of St. Mary Magdalen College in Oxford.

div.head: SECT. I.

argument.p: The Tran≈øactions from the Citation ≈øent October the 17th 1687. To the Nineteenth of the ≈øame Month.

div.head: ¬ß. 1. Citation of St. Mary Magdalen College, October 17th. 1687.
div.p: HIs Maje≈øty being ≈øo greatly provoked by the di≈øobedience to the ≈øecond Mandate, and now finding it nece≈ø≈øary to A≈ø≈øert his own Power, re≈øolved upon ≈øending down certain Local Vi≈øitors according to which I find it thus Regi≈øtred.

Memorandum, Out of the Regi≈øter. There being a new Commi≈ø≈øion with the Addition of Thomas Bi≈øhop of Che≈øter, Sir Robert Wright Lord Chief Ju≈øtice of the Kings Bench, and Sir Thomas Jenner one of the Barons of the Court of Exchequer with particular Power to them, or any two of them to vi≈øit St. Mary Magdalen College in the Univer≈øity of Oxford, the Commi≈ø≈øioners
thought fit to meet at the Council Chamber this day, being the 17th. of Ooctober 1687.
The Commi≈ø≈øion was Read, and the ≈øame Officers confirmed as before.
The Lords Commi≈ø≈øioners for Vi≈øiting Magdalen College, agreed upon the following Citation in Order to their Vi≈øitation.

div.head: By Thomas Lord Bi≈øhop of Che≈øter, Sir Robert Wright Knight, Chief Ju≈øtice of the Court of King's Bench, and Sir Thomas Jenner Knight, one of the Barons of His Maje≈øties Court of Exchequer, His Maje≈øties Commi≈ø≈øioners (among≈øt others) for Eccle≈øia≈øtical Cau≈øes and for the Vi≈øitation of the ∆≤niver≈øities and all Cathedral and Collegiate Churches, Colleges, Grammar-Schools, Ho≈øpitals and other the like Incorporations or Foundations and Societies, and particularly Authorized, and Impowered, by His Maje≈øties Letters Patents, to Vi≈øit St. Mary Magdalen College in the ∆≤niver≈øity of Oxford, &c.
div.p:
YOu and either of you are hereby required forthwith to Cite and Summon Mr. John Hough the pretended Pre≈øident, and al≈øo the Fellows, and all other the Schollars, and Members of the ≈øaid College of St. Mary Magdalen in the ≈øaid Univer≈øity of Oxford, to appear before Us in the Chappel of the ≈øaid College, on Friday next, being the 21≈øt. day of this In≈øtant October, at Nine of the Clock in the Morning, to undergo our Vi≈øitation, and further to An≈øwer to ≈øuch matters as ≈øhall then and there be objected again≈øt them. Intimating thereby (and we do hereby Intimate) unto them and every one of them, that
We Intend at the ≈øame time and place to proceed in our ≈øaid Vi≈øitation, the ab≈øence or contempt of him the ≈øaid pretended Pre≈øident, or the ≈øaid Fellows, Schollars or other Members of the ≈øaid College, or any of them to the contrary notwith≈øtanding. And of the due Execution hereof you are to certifie us at the time and place afore≈øaid.

closer.dateline: Given under the Seal, which we in this behalf u≈øe, the 17th. day of October. 1687.

div.trailer: Sub≈øcribed. To Thomas Atterbury and Robert Eddows. Or either of them.

div.p: On Wedne≈øday October the 19th. the Citation was fixed on the College and Chappel Doors, and on Thur≈øday the Commi≈ø≈øioners entred, attended by the three Troops of Hor≈øe that Quartred in the Town.

div.head: ¬ß. 2. The Proceedings of the Lords Commi≈ø≈øioners at Oxford, on Friday morning Octo. 21. 1687.
div.p: I ≈øhall from the Regi≈øter, Original Papers, the Bi≈øhop of Che≈øters notes, or the Printed Relation, give a Faithful account of the Fir≈øt and Second Vi≈øitation.

div.head: FRIDAY Morning.
div.p:
THe Lords Commi≈ø≈øioners appointed by His Maje≈øty under the Great Seal,Out of the Regi≈øter. Note the rea≈øon why the Commi≈ø≈øioners left the Chappel, was by rea≈øon of the crowd, and for that provi≈øion was not made for their ≈øitting there. for Vi≈øiting St. Mary Magdalen College in Oxford, met on Friday Morning the 21≈øt. of October 1687. In the Chappel of the ≈øame College, and Adjourned to the Hall where their Commi≈ø≈øion being Read, their Lord≈øhips took upon them the Execution thereof, and Ordered the Fellows Names to be called over: And
Dr. John Hough with ≈øeveral of the Fellows and Schollars appearing, the Lord Bi≈øhop of Che≈øter ≈øpoke to them upon the occa≈øion of the Vi≈øitation as followeth.

IF he who provokes the King to Anger ≈øins again≈øt his own Soul, what a Complicated mi≈øchief is yours, who have done and repeated it in ≈øuch an Ingrateful and Indecent manner as you have done, and upon ≈øuch a trifling occa≈øion? You were the fir≈øt, and I hope will be the la≈øt, who did ever thus unde≈øervedly provoke him. There is a great Re≈øpect and Reverence due to the Per≈øons of Kings; and be≈øides the Contempt of his Authority in this Commi≈ø≈øion, you were ≈øo unrea≈øonably Valiant as to have none of tho≈øe fears and jealou≈øies about you, which ought to po≈ø≈øe≈øs all Subjects in their Princes Pre≈øence, with a due veneration of his Soveraignty over them. 'Tis neither good nor ≈øafe for any ≈øort of Men to be wi≈øer than their Governors; nor to di≈øpute the Lawful Commands of their Superiors, in ≈øuch a licentious manner, that if they ≈øometimes obey for wrath, they oftner di≈øobey, (as they pretend,) for Con≈øcience ≈øake. The King is God's Mini≈øter, he receives his Authority from him, and Governs for him here below; and God re≈øents all Indignities and injuries done to him, as done to him≈øelf. Now God hath ≈øet a Ju≈øt and Gracious King over us, who has obliged us in ≈øuch a Princely manner, as to puzle our Under≈øtandings as well as our Gratitude; for
he hath bound him≈øelf by his Sacred promi≈øe to ≈øupport our Altars, at which he does not Wor≈øhip; and in the fir≈øt place to maintain our Bi≈øhops and Arch-Bi≈øhops, and all the Members of the Church of England, in their Rights Privileges and Endowments.

No doubt but he will do his own Religion all the Right and Service he can, without unju≈øt and cruel Methods, which he utterly abhors; and without wronging ours, which is by Law E≈øtabli≈øhed; and by his own Sacred and free promi≈øes, which have been more than once renewed, and repeated to us, without our ≈øeeking or ≈øolliciting for them, which we, under ≈øome Princes, might have been put to crave upon our bended Knees. This is a mo≈øt Royal and Voluntary Pre≈øent the King hath made to his Subjects, and calls for a ≈øuitable veneration from them; notwith≈øtanding the pretended Oxford Rea≈øons, which were Publi≈øh'd (by who≈øe means and endeavors you be≈øt know,) to ob≈øtruct it: As if the King had not Thorns enough growing in his Kingdom, without his Univer≈øities planting more. Now a Prince ≈øo exceedingly tender of his Honor as he is, ≈øo highly Ju≈øt to all, and ≈øo kind beyond example to his Loyal Subjects and Servants of what per≈øua≈øion ≈øoever, is one under whom you might have had all the ea≈øe, ≈øatisfaction, and ≈øecurity imaginable, if you had not been notoriou≈øly wanting to your ≈øelves, and under a vain pretence of acting for the pre≈øervation of our Religion, you had not wilfully, again≈øt all Rea≈øon and Religion, expos'd it, (as much as in you lay,) to the greate≈øt ≈øcandal and apparent dangers Imaginable. Your di≈øingenuous, di≈øobliging, and petulant humor, your ob≈øtinate and unrea≈øonable ≈øtifne≈øs, hath brought this pre≈øent Vi≈øitation upon
you; and might ju≈øtly have provoked His Maje≈øty to have done tho≈øe things in his di≈øplea≈øure, which might have been more prejudicial to this, and other Societies, then you can ea≈øily imagin.

But tho' you have been very irregular in your provocations, yet the King is re≈øolved to be exactly Regular in his proceedings; And accordingly, as he is Supreme Ordinary of this Kingdom, which is his Inherent Right, of which he never can be dive≈øted, and the unque≈øtionable Vi≈øitor of all Colleges; he hath delegated his Commi≈ø≈øioners with full Power to proceed according to the ju≈øt mea≈øures of the Eccle≈øia≈øtical Laws, and his Royal Prerogative again≈øt ≈øuch offenders as ≈øhall be found among≈øt you, and not otherwi≈øe.
'Tis a great grief to all ≈øober Men to ≈øee any, who would be thought True Sons of the Church of England, act like Men frighted out of their wits, and Religion, as you have certainly done.

Never any True Son of the Church of England was, or will be di≈øobedient to his Prince; the Loyalty which ≈øhe hath taught us, is ab≈øolute and unconditional. Tho' our Prince ≈øhould not plea≈øe, or humor us, we are neither to open our Mouths, or lift up our hands again≈øt him.

Yours, like all other Corporations, is the Creature of the Crown; and how then dur≈øt you make your Statutes ≈øpurn again≈øt their Maker? Is this your way to recommend and adorn our Religion, and not rather to make it odious; by practi≈øing that in ≈øuch a froward manner which our Church Profe≈ø≈øes to abhor? Do we not pray for the King, as the Head of it under Chri≈øt? Do we not acknowledge him for the Fountain of Honor? And does not
Solomon Command his Sons to fear God and the King, the one with a Religious, the other with a Civil fear? Is he not the Lord's Annointed, and not to be toucht but with Reverence, either in his Crown or Per≈øon? And why ≈øhould we not render then to all their dues, Fear to whom Fear, and Honor to whom Honor? Is not this an Eternal tye both of Ju≈øtice and Gratitude? For where the Word of a King is, there is Power; And who may ≈øay unto him, what do≈øt Thou? Are we not, next to God, and his Good Angels, mo≈øt beholden to him for our ≈øafety, who≈øe Honor and Lawful Authority We are now come to Vindicate? Is he not the Father of our Country, and ought he not to be more dear to Us than our Natural Parents; e≈øpecially con≈øidering how Indulgent he has been to Us, and what care he dayly takes to keep us from biting and devouring one another, we know not why. Is not he the Center of the Kingdom, and do not the concurrence of all Lines meet in him, and his fortunes; and how can we then under≈øtand the limits of ≈øelf love, if a tender Sen≈øe of his Honor and happine≈øs be not deeply rooted and imprinted in our Souls? 'Twas neither dutifully nor wi≈øely done of you, to drive the King to a nece≈ø≈øity of bringing this Vi≈øitation upon you. And as it mu≈øt needs grieve every Loyal and Religious Man in the Kingdom to the heart, to find Men of your Liberal Education and Parts ≈øo Untractable, and Refractory to ≈øo Gracious a Prince; ≈øo it will be very mi≈øchievous to you, at the Great Day of Gods Vi≈øitation; Who will then be the greate≈øt loo≈øers by your Contumacy: For God will Revenge this among your other Crimes, that you have behav'd your ≈øelves ≈øo ungratefully towards his Vicegerent, as to oppre≈øs his Royal Heart
with grief for your Stubbornne≈øs, to whom by your chearful Obedience, you ought to have admini≈øtred much cau≈øe of rejoycing. They who Sow the Seeds of Di≈øobedience, have never any great rea≈øon to boa≈øt of their Harve≈øt, for what≈øoever they vainly promi≈øe them≈øelves in the beginning, they are in the end a≈øhamed, and afraid of the Income of their evil Practices; and indeed every ≈øort of di≈øobedience hath ≈øo ill a report in the World, that even they who are guilty of it them≈øelves, do yet ≈øpeak ill of it in others: Let therefore the di≈øreputation, and Obloquy which it will inevitably bring upon you, make you out of Love with it; or if that will not do, let the Stings of your guilty Con≈øciences, and the fear of Divine Vengeance re≈øtrain you; or if you are ≈øtill In≈øen≈øible of all the≈øe, yet at lea≈øt let the pre≈øent fear of tho≈øe Temporal Puni≈øhments, which the Laws of the Kingdom have ≈øuperadded to the Contemners of Gods and the Kings Authority, oblige every Soul that hears me this day to be Subject to the Higher Powers. If neither a mo≈øt Merciful God, nor a mo≈øt Gracious King can plea≈øe you, your wages will he recompence upon your own Heads: Were it not for this Serpent of di≈øcontent and jealou≈øies, which are now ≈øo bu≈øie in it, this Kingdom would be like the Garden of Eden before the Cur≈øe, a Mirrour of pro≈øperity and happine≈øs to all the World be≈øides, but this Serpentine humor of Stinging and Biting one another, and of Tempting Men to Rebel again≈øt God and the King, becau≈øe others who differ from us in Judgment are as happy as our ≈øelves, will as certainly turn us, as it did our fir≈øt Parents, out of Paradi≈øe. Our Nation is in greater danger of being de≈øtroyed by Prophanne≈øs, then Popery; by Sin, then by Super≈øtition; by
other Iniquities, then by Idolatry; and I pray God we may not ≈øee Sacrilege once more committed under the pretence of abhorring Idols, as I my ≈øelf have ≈øeen in this place. If there be any among you who have ≈øinn'd with ≈øo high a hand again≈øt our Gracious Sovereign, as the obdurate Jews did again≈øt our Saviour, ≈øaying, we will not have this Man to Rule over us; ≈øuch your petulant humor, ≈øuch your ≈øhameful Inju≈øtice and Ingratitude, will de≈øerve the ju≈øt Animadver≈øions of this Court. What di≈øtempers this College is ≈øick of, which we are now come to vi≈øit by the Kings Commi≈ø≈øion, your ≈øelves are be≈øt able to tell us: We are informed of too many already, and yet we ≈øu≈øpect there may be more; and therefore be but Ingenuous, and make a Con≈øcience of giving us ≈øincere An≈øwers, and you ≈øhall find, that we will abate nothing of the ju≈øt mea≈øures of our Duty for fear or favor, to ≈øatisfie the Importunities of any Man; being well a≈ø≈øured that God and the King will bear us out. I am ≈øorry that you ≈øhould any of you run ≈øo far upon the ≈øcore of the Kings Royal Patience and Pardon, as ≈øome of you have already done; And that you ≈øhould be in ≈øuch va≈øt Arrears of Duty and Re≈øpect to him as you are. But they go far who never turn: The Influence you may have upon other parts of the Kingdom, makes me Charitably hope, that your future Fidelity, and Allegiance will for ever An≈øwer your Duty, and the Kings ju≈øt Expectation; And therefore I hope it will not be in vain for me to exhort you in the Bowels of Chri≈øt to a more entire ≈øubmi≈ø≈øion, and obedience; becau≈øe if ≈øuch Men as you, bred in ≈øo Famous an Univer≈øity, are not thoroughly convinced of the nece≈ø≈øity of it; the more Popular you become, the more pernicious will you be in encouraging
your deluded Admirers, who have their Eyes upon you from all parts of the Kingdom, to be as Di≈øobedient and Contumacious as your ≈øelves: by which the Honor and Authority of the King may be dimini≈øhed, and the peace both of Church and State come to be endanger'd. Obey them who have the Rule over you, either in Church or State, and ≈øubmit your ≈øelves before it be too late; for your contumacious behaviour towards them will yeild you no profit at all; but your Obedience much every way; the former will prove like the Sin of Witch-craft, but the latter will be better accepted than Sacrifice, becau≈øe in that you only offer up a bea≈øt to God, but in this you Sacrifice your Pa≈ø≈øions, you ≈ølay them and offer them up to Gods ≈øervice. Remember Error ≈øeldom goes in Company with Obedience, and that none are ≈øo likely to find the way to Eternal happine≈øs in the end, as they who follow the Conduct of their Superiors from the beginning; not with Eye ≈øervice, as Men plea≈øers; but in ≈øinglene≈øs of Heart, Fearing God and the King; and what≈øoever you do, do it heartily; as unto the Lord, and not unto us Men: And the Lord give you under≈øtanding in all things.
The Speech being ended, the Lords adjourned till the Afternoon to the Common Room of the College.

div.head: FRIDAY Afternoon.
div.p: AT which time the Court being ≈øat, Dr. Hough in behalf of him≈øelf and the Fellows demanded a Copy of their Lord≈øhips Commi≈ø≈øion, which was denyed him, and the Court ordered to proceed, and then admoni≈øhed the Fellows to produce the Regi≈øtery of the College Affairs, and al≈øo to give an account of what Lea≈øes had been Lett for two Years la≈øt pa≈øt, together with the Benefactions given to the College and likewi≈øe ordered them to bring in the Buttry Book to Morrow Morning, to which time they adjourned.

div.head: ¬ß. 3. SAT∆≤RDAY Morning, October 22d. 1687.
div.p: DR. Hough was called in, and it appearing to their Lord≈øhips, that his Election to the Pre≈øidents place was made null and void by a Sentence given by the Lords Commi≈ø≈øioners for Eccle≈øia≈øtical Cau≈øes, and that he the ≈øaid Dr. Hough had legal notice of the ≈øame, but notwith≈øtanding the ≈øaid Sentence he had and did ≈øtill refu≈øe to ≈øubmit thereunto. The Court ordered him forthwith peaceably to depart the College, and deliver up the Keys of the Lodgings, and ≈øtruck his Name out of the Buttry-Book; and having ≈øo done, declared to the Fellows, that he was Actually Expelled, and admoni≈øhed them not to own him as their Pre≈øident.

Then the Court askt the Fellows whether they would amdit the Bi≈øhop of Oxon their Pre≈øident, according to the Kings Mandate, but all of them
refu≈øed, except Mr. Charnock, but ≈øaid they would not oppo≈øe it.

div.head: SAT∆≤RDAY Afternoon.
div.p: DR. Hough came into the Court, and made his prote≈øtation again≈øt the proceedings, and appealed from the ≈øame, as Illegal, Unju≈øt and Null, as he a≈ø≈øerts. Whereupon there was a Tumultuous Hum or Acclamation made by the by-≈øtanders, which gave the Court ≈øome di≈øturbance, in ≈øo much, that they thought fit to bind over Dr. Hough in 1000 l. and two Sureties in 500 l. each, to appear at the Kings Bench, and again admoni≈øhed Dr. Hough to quit the College, which he accordingly did that Night.

Thus far out of the Regi≈øter. But becau≈øe the Paper ≈øent with the Letter to the Earl of Sunderland is more full in ≈øeveral particulars, I ≈øhall In≈øert it after the following Letter, together with ≈øuch Additions as the Bi≈øhop of Che≈øters own Journals afford me.

div.head: ¬ß. 4. The Lords Commi≈ø≈øioners ≈øent the Following Letter to my Lord Pre≈øident, Dated 22d. October 1687.

body.p:
BY His Maje≈øties Me≈ø≈øenger, See the An≈øwer to this after the Programma ¬ß. 6. we have ≈øent your Lord≈øhip a particular account of our proceedings here (to which we humbly refer) in which your Lord≈øhip will perceive the Temper of that Society;
My Lord we hope your Lord≈øhip will ea≈øily believe, that we are not unwilling to do any thing which may vindicate the Kings Honor and Authority, but we humbly de≈øire to be well advi≈øed by your Lord≈øhip in the Methods of it, for we are now a little at a ≈øtop by rea≈øon of the Bi≈øhop of Oxon's not appearing in Per≈øon, having no Power as we humbly conceive, either by the Kings Mandate or by our Commi≈ø≈øion to Admit him by Proxy, His Maje≈øties Letter Mandatory for the ≈øame being directed to the College, who all but two or three do as yet refu≈øe it. We therefore humbly Pray your Lord≈øhip to di≈øpatch His Maje≈øties Mandate directed to Us to Admit the Bi≈øhop or his Proxy, or that you would plea≈øe to give us ≈øome other Directions, ≈øuch as your Lord≈øhip in your Great Wi≈ødom ≈øhall Judge more expedient. We do crave leave al≈øo to Intimate to your Lord≈øhip, that it is our humble Opinion, that We cannot proceed any further then Expul≈øion again≈øt Dr. Hough (which your Lord≈øhip will find already done) according to the Power we have by the Commi≈ø≈øion, and we humbly Pray your Lord≈øhips Pardon and further Commands, which ≈øhall be readily obeyed by His Maje≈øties mo≈øt Dutiful Subjects, and

list.item: Tho. Ce≈øtrien≈øis.
R. Wright.
Tho. Jenner.

postscript.p: My Lord ≈øince the Writing of this Letter, We have rea≈øon to believe we ≈øhall have an entire ≈øubmi≈ø≈øion from the College on Tue≈øday next, for Dr. Hough ≈øince his Expul≈øion, hath left the College and taken Lodgings in the Town.

div.head: ¬ß. 4. The account ≈øent by the Lords Commi≈ø≈øioners of their proceedings till Saturday night Octob. 22.
div.p:
HIs Maje≈øties Commi≈ø≈øioners for Vi≈øiting the College of St. Mary Magdalen in Oxford, Note that what is conteined betwixt the≈øe [] is what is in the Bi≈øhop of Che≈øters and Dr. Th ‚Ä¢ mas Smi ‚Ä¢ hs Diary and not in the Account ≈øent by the Lords Commi≈ø≈øioners. Friday Afternoon. being Ye≈øterday [viz. Thur≈øday the 20th. of October] come at the time appointed [viz. Friday Octob. 21.] for the Pre≈øident Fellows and Schollars thereof to appear, their Lord≈øhips took upon them the Execution thereof: My Lord Bi≈øhop of Che≈øter made a Speech to them upon the occa≈øion of the Vi≈øitation, and after an adjournment of the ≈øame, to the Afternoon, there then appeared Dr. Hough and ≈øeveral of the Fellows, and mo≈øt of the Schollars and Officers of the College: Dr. Hough objected to the ≈øhortne≈øs of the time from the notice of the Vi≈øitation, and prayed a Copy of the Commi≈ø≈øion and time to con≈øider of it (which was over ruled by the Court) ≈øaying, that if he and they could take any advantage from the Commi≈ø≈øion, he hoped the King and their Lord≈øhips did not intend to bar them of it: And [in his own Name and the greate≈øt part of the Fellows,] ≈øaid, that he ≈øubmitted to the Vi≈øitation ≈øo far as was con≈øi≈øtent with the Laws of the Land, and the Statutes of the College and no further, and that he could ≈øuffer no alteration of the Statutes, neither by the King nor any other Per≈øon [for which he had taken an Oath, from which he could not ≈øwerve, and thereupon Quoted the Statutes confirmed by King Henry the Sixth and their Oath, that they ≈øhould ≈øubmit to no Alteration made by any Authority] [The Oxford Relation ≈øaith, that my Lord Chief Ju≈øtice an≈øwered, you cannot Imagin, that we Act contrary to the Laws of the Land, and as to the Statutes the
King has di≈øpen≈øed with them. Do you think we come here to Act again≈øt Law?]

Then the Sentence given the 22d. Day of June, 1687. Again≈øt Dr. Hough's Election, and for the removing him from the Office of Pre≈øident of the College was Read, and he was asked whether he knew of it being given again≈øt him: He replyed, he had notice of it, but ≈øaid he was no party to it, and ≈øo was advi≈øed it did not any wi≈øe concern him.

The Sentence likewi≈øe again≈øt Dr. Aldworth and Dr. Fairfax for ≈øu≈øpending them, was Read, and the Petition of Dr. Aldworth, Dr. Fairfax and others delivered to my Lord Pre≈øident on the Tenth of April la≈øt (being about Five Days before their Election of Dr. Hough,) was al≈øo Read to them to which was replyed, that they had noIt was An≈øwer ≈øufficient to have obliged them not to have proceeded to Election till they had particularly made out their Information again≈øt Mr. Farmer. An≈øwer from my Lord Pre≈øident, but that the King expected to be obeyed, and they receiving no other Mandate than that for Admitting Mr. Farmer, they proceeded to Elect Mr. Hough.

Then after their Lord≈øhips orders to them to bring in ≈øome Books [viz. The Regi≈øter] and other Papers relating to the Revenues and Government of their College [which the Doctor promi≈øed they ≈øhould have next Morning,] they adjourned to Eight of the Clock this Morning.

div.head: SAT∆≤RDAY Octob. 22d.
div.p:
VVHo being met and ≈øuch Books brought in [Dr. Hough being called in,The words of the Account are, their Lord≈øhips proceeded and propo≈øed the≈øe two Que≈øtions to Dr. Hough, whether he was willing, &c. the Bi≈øhop of Che≈øter told him, Doctor, here is a Sentence under Seal before us, of the Kings Commi≈ø≈øioners for Vi≈øiting the Univer≈øities, by which the Election to the Pre≈øident≈øhip of Magdalen College is declared Null and
Void, which you heard Ye≈øterday Read, and of which you Confe≈øs your ≈øelf to have Legal notice before, by being fixed upon the Doors. This Sentence and the Authority by which it was pa≈ø≈øed you have contemned, and in contempt thereof have kept Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the Lodgings, and the Office of Pre≈øident to this day, to the great contempt and di≈øhonor of the King and his Authority.] Are you yet willing, upon better and ≈øecond thoughts to ≈øubmit to the Sentence pa≈ø≈øed by their Lord≈øhips again≈øt you or not?

To which he An≈øwered, that the Decree of the Commi≈ø≈øioners is a perfect Nullity from beginning to End, as to what relates to him, he having never been Cited nor ever appeared before them, either in his Per≈øon, or Proxy: Be≈øides his Cau≈øe it ≈øelf was never before them: Their Lord≈øhips never enquiring, or asking one que≈øtion concerning the Legality or Statutablene≈øs of the Election,The≈øe Arguments will particularly be an≈øwered. for which rea≈øon he is informed, that That Decree was of no validity again≈øt him according to the Methods of the Civil Laws, but if it had, he was po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of a Freehold according to the Laws of England and Statutes of the Society, having been Elected as Unanimou≈øly, and with as much Formality as any of his Predece≈ø≈øors, Pre≈øidents of the ≈øaid College, and afterwards Admitted by the Bi≈øhop of Winche≈øter their Vi≈øitor as the Statutes of the College required, and therefore he could not ≈øubmit to that Sentence, becau≈øe he thought he could not be deprived of his Freehold, but by Cour≈øe of Law in We≈øtmin≈øter-Hall, or by being ≈øome way Incapacitated according to the Founders Statutes which are Confirmed by King James the Fir≈øt.

Second Que≈øtion put to Dr. Hough was, whether he would deliver up the Keys and Lodgings (as by a Clau≈øe in the Statutes of Admi≈ø≈øion he is tyed to do) to the u≈øe of the Pre≈øident who hath the Kings Letters Mandatory to be Admitted into that Office.

To which he An≈øwered, that there is not, neither can there be, any Pre≈øident whil≈øt he Lives, and obeys the Laws of the Land and the Statutes of the place, and therefore doth not think it rea≈øonable to give up his Right, nor the Keys and his Lodgings now demanded of him. He takes the Bi≈øhop of Winche≈øter to be his Ordinary Vi≈øitor, and yet he would deny him the Keys [he takes the King to be his Extraordinary Vi≈øitor as he believes, but it had been controverted whether the King had Power to Vi≈øit, as in Coveny's Ca≈øe, 4o. Eliz.] and looked upon their Lord≈øhips Commanding it to be a requiring him to deliver up his Office.

He ≈øaid, he had appeared before their Lord≈øhips as Judges, and that he now Addre≈ø≈øed him≈øelf to them as Men of Honor, and Gentlemen, and did be≈øeech them to repre≈øent him as Dutiful to His Maje≈øty to the la≈øt degree, as he always will be where his Con≈øcience permits to the la≈øt Moment of his Life, and when he is Di≈øpo≈ø≈øe≈øt here he hopes they will intercede, that he may no longer lie under His Maje≈øties di≈øplea≈øure, or be frowned upon by his Prince which would be the greate≈øt affliction, that could befall him in this World.

Then their Lord≈øhips admoni≈øh'd him three times to depart peaceably from the Pre≈øidents Lodgings, and to Act no more as Pre≈øident or pretended Pre≈øident of the College in Contempt of the King and his Authority: which he refu≈øing to do, [Mr. Lee
Proctor to the Lords accu≈øed his Contumacy, and prayed the Judgment of the Court,The words of the Account are, then the Lords proceeded to give Judgment again≈øt him, viz. That he forth with, &c. which was thus pronounced; The Lords Commi≈ø≈øioners for Eccle≈øia≈øtical Cau≈øes, and for Vi≈øiting the Univer≈øities have Decreed the Pre≈øidents place of this College to be Null and Void: Therefore we by the Authority to us committed, do Order and Command you Dr. Hough forthwith] to quit all preten≈øions to the ≈øaid Office, upon which they Ordered his Name to be ≈øtruck out of the Buttry-Book, which was accordingly done, and admoni≈øhed the Fellows and other Members of the Society, no longer to own him as their Pre≈øident.

Then the Kings Mandate for Admitting the Bi≈øhop of Oxford was Read,See for this, ≈øect. 2. ¬ß 3. and they were then Ordered to withdraw, and being ≈øoon after called in again, the Que≈øtion was put to the Fellows ≈øingly, one by one, whether they would Admit the Bi≈øhop of Oxford their Pre≈øident according to the Kings, Mandate. Dr. Pud≈øey ≈øaid, he would ≈øubmit to the King, and would be by, but could not Act, being Bur≈øer. Dr. Thomas Smith replyed,From Dr. Smiths Diary. See his other An≈øwer ¬ß. 10. My Lords Commi≈ø≈øioners, if it be the Kings plea≈øure to make the Bi≈øhop of Oxford Pre≈øident of this College, and your Lord≈øhips Acting by that Authority have declared and made him ≈øuch, I do, becau≈øe I mu≈øt, ≈øubmit, I make no oppo≈øition. Mr. Charnock ≈øaid, he was ready to obey the Kings Mandate; all the re≈øt of the Fellows refu≈øed to receive him as Pre≈øident, as being again≈øt their Statutes and Oaths, and that which would make them guilty of Perjury. All who≈øe Verbal An≈øwers were taken in Writing by the Lords Commi≈ø≈øioners, and their Lord≈øhips after ≈øome time ≈øaid, if you think we have not taken the An≈øwer right put
them in Writing your ≈øelves again≈øt the Afternoon, to which time they adjourned the Court.

The Court being Sate in the Afternoon,Afternoon. Dr. Hough appeared with a great Rabble of followers, and after a ≈øhort time ≈øaid, whereas your Lord≈øhips this Morning have been plea≈øed, pur≈øuant to the former Decree of the Lords Commi≈ø≈øioners, to deprive me of my place of Pre≈øident of this College, and to ≈øtrike my Name out of the Buttry-Book: I do hereby prote≈øt again≈øt the ≈øaid proceedings, and again≈øt all that you have done, or hereafter ≈øhall do in prejudice of me and my Right, as Illegal, Unju≈øt and Null, and I do hereby Appeal to our Sovereign Lord the King in his Courts of Ju≈øtice.Dr. Tho. Smiths Diary. Upon which there was a Tumultuous Hum in the Room, which the Lords Commi≈ø≈øioners re≈øented very much, and ≈øaid, they would never ≈øuffer the Kings Authority to be ≈øo affronted; my Lord Chief Ju≈øtice ≈øaid, he would defend the Kings Authority while he had Blood in his Body, and told Dr. Hough that he was the occa≈øion of this mi≈ø-behaviour by his popular Prote≈øtation, which he might have made in the Morning, that he had broke the Kings Peace, and that now they had brought in the Civil Power over them, and that if need were they would u≈øe the Military; that he mu≈øt An≈øwer that affront of the Kings Authority at the Kings Bench Court. Upon which he was bound in a Thou≈øand pound Bond, and his Sureties in Five Hundred pound a piece.

Then the Bi≈øhop of Che≈øter gave-the Doctor this An≈øwer to his Appeal, Doctor, we look upon the Appeal as to the matter and manner of it to be unrea≈øonable, and not to be admitted by us: Fir≈øt, becau≈øe it is in a Vi≈øitation where no Appeal is allowable:
Secondly, becau≈øe our Vi≈øitation is by Commi≈ø≈øion under the Broad Seal of England, which is the Supreme Authority, therefore we over-rule this Prote≈øtation and Appeal, and Admoni≈øh you once for all to avoid the College, and obey the Sentence. The Doctor and Fellows declared their grief for the di≈øorder of the Crowd, and di≈øclaimed their having any hand in it.]

After which Dr. Pud≈øeys Letter to the Lord Pre≈øident being Read,See this Letter c. 1. ≈øect. 3. ¬ß. 3. their Lord≈øhips askt the Fellows concerning the Kings Verbal Command to them at Oxford, to which they ≈øaid it was to Elect the Bi≈øhop of Oxford, which they could not: Then being askt why they did not Admit him, which was all the Kings Letter required, and to which the Verbal Command referred; Eight of the Fellows ≈øaid they were not there, and Thirteen owned they were, and gave con≈øent to the Letter.

div.head: ¬ß. 5. ∆≤pon Complaint made by the Lords Commi≈ø≈øioners of the Hubub before mentioned, the Vice-Chancellor publi≈øhed this following Programma.
div.p: QUum nihil minus deceat Viros Ingenuos, nedum Academicos ad optima enutritos, quam morum Inelegantia, & Ru≈øticitas; Quam ab≈øonum videri debeat Adventantes ≈øtrepitu, & ≈øibilis excipere, & pro Coetu Philofophorum, turbam Morionum Peregrinis o≈øtentare!

Quocirca dolemus hac in parte peccatum e≈ø≈øe in Viros Illu≈øtres, & admodum Reverendos; & quod omnium Gravi≈ø≈øimum e≈øt, Regia in≈øuper Authoritate munitos; ≈øperamu≈øque hoc Indecentiae, vel potius contumeliae, aut ≈øaltem maximam partem, ab Infrunitis
hominibus & de plebis Faecula natis, omnino proveni≈ø≈øe; monemu≈øque omnes, quotquot ≈øunt Scholares, ut ab omnibus Illiberalibus Dicteriis, ≈øannis, Pedum ≈øupplo≈øione, male feriatorum & Turbinum Cachinno, Screatu, clamore, & murmure „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ penitus ab≈øtineant.
Si quis vero in po≈øterum, in aliquibus i≈øtius modi deliquerit, ≈øciat ≈øe non mediocres Temeritatis & In≈øolentiae ≈øuae paenas luiturum.

closer.signed: Gilb. Iron-≈øide Vice-Cancelarius.

div.head: ¬ß. 6. My Lord Pre≈øidents Letter to the Lords Vi≈øitors, in An≈øwer to theirs of the 22d. of October.
div.p: To the Lords Commi≈ø≈øioners Letter and the account ≈øent of their proceedings, I find this An≈øwer given by my Lord Pre≈øident.

body.p:
I Have received your Lord≈øhips of the 22d. with the account of your proceedings, which His Maje≈øty is well ≈øatisfied with, I herewith ≈øend you ≈øuch an Order for Admitting the Bi≈øhop of Oxford as you de≈øired, and am directed by His Maje≈øty to acquaint you, that if the Fellows of the College can be brought to ≈øubmit to the Admi≈ø≈øion of the Bi≈øhop as their Pre≈øident, His Maje≈øty is Graciou≈øly pleas'd no Puni≈øhment ≈øhould upon that account be Inflicted by you upon ≈øuch as do ≈øubmit, but if any of them be refractory you are to proceed again≈øt them according to the Commi≈ø≈øion, and His Maje≈øty would have you
al≈øo to In≈øpect the Con≈øtitutions, Orders and Statutes of the College, and to Enquire into the behaviours of the Members thereof, and what abu≈øes may have been Committed either by mi≈ø-applying their Revenues or other mi≈ø-doings, a particular account of which together with the Names of the Offenders, you are to tran≈ømit up to His Maje≈øty, that he may give ≈øuch further Order as ≈øhall be requi≈øite in the matter.

closer.signed: I am MY LORDS, Your Lord≈øhips Mo≈øt humble Servant. Sunderland P.

div.p: The Lords Commi≈ø≈øioners An≈øwer to this, I ≈øhall In≈øert in it's place, and now proceed to what was tran≈øacted at the Court held, October the 25th. In the Morning.

div.head: ¬ß. 7.
div.p:
Dr. Stafford Read the following Paper in An≈øwer to what was objected on Friday,
October 25th. Morning.that a Mandate Implyed an Inhibition, which I think fit to In≈øert out of the Printed Relation.

div.head: To the Right Reverend and Honorable the Commi≈ø≈øioners for Vi≈øiting of St. Mary Magdalen College in Oxon.
div.p:
ON Friday la≈øt in the Afternoon, you ≈øeemed to In≈øi≈øt very much upon this particular, viz. That His Maje≈øty in Commanding the Fellows of
the ≈øaid College to Elect Mr. Farmer Pre≈øident, did thereby Inhibit them to Elect any other Per≈øon what≈øoever, which has not yet been made to appear to be Law,To the≈øe Arguments An≈øwer will be given in due place. out of Civil, Canon or Common-Law, neither is it agreeable to rea≈øon, that a Command to Elect a Per≈øon uncapable ≈øhould oblige not to Elect a Per≈øon Capable, that being a kind of Contradiction in Terminis, yet this being granted it cannot at lea≈øt affect the ≈øaid Fellows, or Invalidate the Election of Dr. Hough, notwith≈øtanding His Maje≈øties Mandate in behalf of Mr. Farmer wholly uncapable of the place. The Fellows cannot be ≈øaid to be Guilty of any di≈øobedience, or di≈øloyalty in proceeding to the Election of another Per≈øon, who was qualified according to the Statutes, being forced to make an Election, for they are obliged by the Statutes of the College, when called together to Elect a Pre≈øident or any other Officer, under pain of Expul≈øion perpetual from that College, to meet and make an Election, which Puni≈øhment they Incur Ip≈øo facto, who either refu≈øe to meet when ≈øo called, or being met do not Nominate and Elect a Per≈øon into the Office void, as appears by the Statutes of the College, Titulo de numero Scholarium & Electione Prae≈øidentis. Now according to the Founders direction in the ≈øaid Statute on the 9th. of April la≈øt, the Fellows were called together by the Vice-Pre≈øident to Elect a Pre≈øident in the place of Dr. Clark Deceas'd.The obligation of this Oath will be examined. The Oath required to be taken before the Election was Admini≈øtred to them by the Vice-Pre≈øident, whereby they are obliged to Nominate and Elect a Per≈øon, that either is or has been Fellow of Magdalen College or New-College, which Oath when the Fellows had taken, it was not in their Power to Elect Mr. Farmer, and yet then they were
obliged to make an Election, under pain of perpetual Amotion from the College, as appears by the afore≈øaid Statutes, and it cannot be imagined that His mo≈øt Sacred Maje≈øty did expect, that the Fellows ≈øhould be either Perjur'd or forfeit their Right to their Fellow≈øhips rather then di≈ø-obey his Command. His Maje≈øty having mo≈øt Graciou≈ølyThis fir≈øt is a ≈øtrange plea, that will be an≈øwered. declared, that Con≈øcience ought not to be forced, and that none of his Subjects ≈øhould be mole≈øted in the enjoyment of their Rights and Privileges. Now that our proceeding to Election, cannot lay any Imputation of di≈øobedience or di≈øloyalty upon us, will thus be made appear. Either we had Power to Elect or not;The Dilemma will be ≈øolved when I an≈øwer the objections. If we had not, to what end or purpo≈øe did His Maje≈øty Command us to Elect one; If we had, our Power was re≈øtrained to per≈øons ≈øo and ≈øo qualified, or we were at liberty to choo≈øe whom we plea≈øed. But we could not do the latter, as appears by our Statutes, therefore we could not Elect Mr. Farmer being not Inve≈øted with any Power to Elect a per≈øon not qualified, and if we had ≈øo done, our Election had been Void and Null in it ≈øelf, and the Per≈øon Elected lyable to be turned out by our Vi≈øitor: As for the Decree of His Maje≈øties Commi≈ø≈øioners (in pur≈øuance whereof your Lord≈øhips have admoni≈øhed Dr. Hough to recede from the place of Pre≈øident and quietly to re≈øign the Keys of his Office, and ≈øtruck his Name out of the Book) we humbly conceive it to be Null and Void in it ≈øelf, to all intents and purpo≈øes, Dr. Hough being thereby deprived of a Free-hold for Life, the which he was duely and legally po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of, without ever being called to defend his Right,The rea≈øon of this will be an≈øwered in the la≈øt Chapter. or any mi≈ø-demeanor objected again≈øt him; wherefore we humbly beg of your Lord≈øhips, that Dr. Hough may be
permitted to defend his Right and Title to the Pre≈øident≈øhip at Common Law, before any other per≈øon is po≈ø≈øe≈øt of his place.

This, Oxford Relation, which all along I ≈øo ≈øtyle to di≈øtingui≈øh it from other Relations or Papers. ≈øaith the Oxford Relation, their Lord≈øhips having peru≈øed would not allow to be Read publicly, but they asked the Fellows whether they would Sign it, Challenging them to do it at their Perils, then the Fellows withdrew into the Hall where being not ≈øatisfied, it was nece≈ø≈øary to Sign a Plea, which their Lord≈øhips refu≈øed to admit, returned the Paper into the Court only ≈øub≈øcribed by Dr. Fairfax, and Dr. Stafford, the latter after ≈øome debate de≈øiring to withdraw but Dr. Fairfax ≈øtood to it.

div.head: ¬ß. 8. The Bi≈øhop of Oxfords Proxy.
div.p: After the Plea of Dr. Stafford, Tue≈øday Morning the 25th. of October. 1687. Was thus let fall, Mr. Wickins Procuratar and Chaplain to the Bi≈øhop of Oxon, was called, who delivered the Proxy, the Tenor whereof followeth.

opener.salute: OMnibus ad quos hoc prae≈øens Scriptum praevenerit ≈øalutem.

div.p:
Ego Samuel permi≈ø≈øione Divina Oxon. Epi≈øcopus, & Prae≈øes Collegii Magdalen≈øis infra Univer≈øitatem Oxon. ≈øituati vigore litterarum Mandatoriarum Domini Regis Con≈øtitutus: Dilectum mihi in Chri≈øto Gulielmum Wickins in Artibus Magi≈øtrum Clericum & Sacellanum meum, ut vice & Nomine meo ad Officium Prae≈øidentis Collegii praedicti una cum membris, Juribus, & pertinentiis eidem ≈øpectantibus Univer≈øis admittatur; nec non ad juramenta ≈øolita, & requi≈øita, in Animam meam prae≈øtanda, caeteraque omnia facienda & Exequenda in ea parte requi≈øita, Procuratorem & Deputatum meum (ip≈øe
valitudine impeditus quo minus praedictae admi≈ø≈øioni per≈øonaliter intere≈ø≈øe valeam) firmiter con≈øtituo per pre≈øentes Datas & Sigillatas Vice≈øimo 1o. die men≈øis Octobris Anno Tertio Regni Jacobi Secundi Angliae, Scotiae, Franciae, & Hib√®rniae Regis, Fidei Defen≈øoris Annoque Domini. 1687.
div.closer:
In Prae≈øentia
W. Bigges.
Ric. Brooke.
Georgii Cholwill.
The Bi≈øhop of Oxfords Seal is in the Margent, Sub≈øigned. Sa. Oxon.

div.p: Then was Read the following Mandate.

div.head: ¬ß. 9. The Kings Mandate to the Vi≈øitors for admitting the Bi≈øhop of Oxford Pre≈øident, &c. 23d. Octob. 1687.
div.p:
RIght Reverend Father in God, Right Tru≈øty and Well-beloved, and Tru≈øty and Well-beloved, We Greet you well: Whereas We did by Our Letters bearing Date the 14th. Day of Augu≈øt la≈øt, Authorize and Require the Fellows of St. Mary Magdalen College in Our Univer≈øity of Oxon, to Admit the Right Reverend Father in God Samuel Lord Bi≈øhop of Oxon, into the place of Pre≈øident of the ≈øaid College, with all the Rights, Privileges, Emoluments, and Advantages thereunto belonging, any Statute, or Statutes, Cu≈øtom or Con≈øtitution to the contrary in any wi≈øe notwith≈øtanding, wherewith We did di≈øpen≈øe in his behalf. And whereas the Fellows of the ≈øaid College not obeying our ≈øaid Letters Mandatory, We thought it requi≈øite to Impower you to Vi≈øit the ≈øaid College, and all the Members
thereof. Our Will and Plea≈øure is, and We do hereby Authorize and Require you, that in ca≈øe the ≈øaid Fellows do ≈øtill per≈øi≈øt in refu≈øing to Admit the ≈øaid Bi≈øhop of Oxon as their Pre≈øident, you do forthwith Admit him, if pre≈øent, or in ca≈øe of his ab≈øence by his Proxy, into the place of Pre≈øident of the ≈øaid College, any Statute or Statutes, Cu≈øtoms, or Con≈øtitutions to the contrary in any wi≈øe notwith≈øtanding, with which we do by the≈øe pre≈øents di≈øpen≈øe, And for ≈øo doing, This ≈øhall be a ≈øufficient Warrant and Authority to you, and all other Per≈øons whom it may concern,

closer.salute: and ≈øo We bid you heartily farewel.
closer.dateline: Given at our Court at Whitehall the 23d. of October. 1687. In the 3d. Year of our Reign.
closer.signed: By His Maje≈øties Command. Sunderland P.

div.trailer: This was Super≈øcribed. To the Right Reverend Father in God Thomas Lord Bi≈øhop of Che≈øter. Our Right Tru≈øty and Well-beloved, Sir Robert Wright Kt. Ch. J. of the Pleas before ∆≤s to be holden A≈ø≈øigned. Our Tru≈øty and Well-beloved Sir. Tho. Jenner Kt. one of the Barons of our Court of Exchequer, Our Commi≈ø≈øioners for the Vi≈øitation of St. Mary Magdalen College in Our ∆≤niver≈øity of Oxon.

div.head: ¬ß. 10.
div.p:
THe foregoing Proxy together with the Kings Mandate being Read for the Bi≈øhop of Oxon:
Tue≈øday Morning Octo. 25. The Fellows being pre≈øent were askt, if they would Admit and In≈øtal the Bi≈øhop of Oxford made Pre≈øident by the King, and declared ≈øuch by their Lord≈øhips. Dr. Pud≈øey being fir≈øt asked the Que≈øtion refu≈øed to Act, but ≈øeemed to yield to be pre≈øent.
Dr. Thomas Smith being askt the ≈øame Que≈øtion by the Bi≈øhop of Che≈øter, Read the following An≈øwer.

I An≈øwer with all Humble and Dutiful ≈øubmi≈ø≈øion to the Kings Maje≈øties Authority, and your Lord≈øhips Vi≈øitatorial Power, That it is not in my Power to do this. Your Lord≈øhips, who have deprived Dr. Hough, and have declared the Bi≈øhop of Oxford Pre≈øident, may In≈øtal him: This Method being altogether new and extraordinary, I cannot be ≈øatisfied how I can or ought to be the Executioner of your Lord≈øhips Sentence. Be≈øides I beg leave to propo≈øe a ≈øhort Ca≈øe to your Lord≈øhips, whether or no I can In≈øtal or give Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion without being Impowered, and Authorized by a Rule out of the High Court of Chancery or Kings Bench for my Security, if there were nothing of Con≈øcience in the Ca≈øe.
To this the Lord Chief Ju≈øtice replyed, to this purpo≈øe, that as they were His Maje≈øties Commi≈ø≈øioners for this Vi≈øitation, they had the Kings Power of Chancery and Common Law.

Then the Lords adjourned to the ChappelThe words of the Regi≈øter are, and forthwith admitted the Bi≈øhop of Oxon Pre≈øi ent by his ≈øaid Procurator, from thence they adjourned to the Pre≈øidents Lodgings and finding the Door lockt demanded the Keys, but they being not to be ≈øound, they ordered the Door to be broken open, which was accordingly done, and the Lords went in and viewed the ≈øaid Lodgings; having ≈øo done adjourned to the Common Room, and Entred the Bi≈øhops Name as Pre≈øident in the Buttry-Book. where the Bi≈øhop of Che≈øter put Mr. Wiggins into the Pre≈øidents Seat where he took the Oaths which the Statutes enjoyn to the Pre≈øident at his Admi≈ø≈øion, and the Oath of Allegiance and Supremacy, the latter of which the Bi≈øhop of Che≈øter Ordered him to take upon his Knees, which he did accordingly; then their Lord≈øhips Conducted him to the Door of the Pre≈øidents Lodgings, where knocking Thrice and the Doors not being opened, they returned to the Common Room, and Commanded Mr. Atterbury to fetch a Smith to knock open the Door, which was done accordingly, their Lord≈øhips being pre≈øent all the while and none of the Fellows but Mr. Charnock a≈ø≈øi≈øting, or being as much as pre≈øent at either of the performances.

div.head: ¬ß. 11.
div.p:
Then their Lord≈øhips being returned to the Common Room, Oxford Relation pa. 30. they Entred the Bi≈øhops Name into the Buttry-Book. Dr. Fairfax, ≈øaith the Oxford Relation, de≈øired leave at lei≈øure to ≈øpeak, and being permitted he told their Lord≈øhips, that they had been doing that which he by no means could con≈øent to. The Bi≈øhop of Che≈øter told him he was big to be delivered of his own De≈øtruction, and asked him if he would ≈øubmit to the Bi≈øhop of Oxon In≈øtalled Pre≈øident by Vertue of the Kings Mandate, to which the Doctor An≈øwered, he would not nor could not, becau≈øe they had a Statutable and Legal Pre≈øident already.Regi≈øter. And the Lords having ask'd the Fellows if they would now ≈øubmit to the Bi≈øhop of Oxon as their
Pre≈øident, they de≈øired time, and their Lord≈øhips gave them till the Afternoon to con≈øider of it, and the Court ordered them to give in an Account of what Gifts, or Provi≈øions were made by the Statutes for poor Travellors, &c. to Morrow Morning. Then the Lords demanded of them, if they had Elected or Admitted any Members ≈øince the Kings Inhibition, to which they reply'd, that they had Admitted none but Mr. Holden who was Fellow Elect before, and his Year of Probation≈øhip Expired, and if he had not then been Admitted he mu≈øt have ≈øtood Expelled by their Statutes. Then adjourned till two in the Afternoon.

div.head: ¬ß. 12. T∆≤ESDAY Afternoon.
div.p: THe Fellows being called in, Regi≈øter. the Que≈øtion was again put to them, whether they would ≈øubmit to the Bi≈øhop of Oxon as their Pre≈øident, to which they gave in an An≈øwer in Writing as followeth.

VVHereas His Maje≈øty has been plea≈øed by His Royal Authority,The ≈øubmi≈ø≈øion of the Fellows. to cau≈øe the Right Reverend Father in God Samuel Lord Bi≈øhop of Oxon to be In≈øtalled Pre≈øident of this College, we who≈øe Names are hereunto Sub≈øcribed do ≈øubmit as far as is Lawful and agreeable to the Statutes of the ≈øaid College.This Clau≈øe was Equivocal.
Dr. John Smith gave in a Paper Writ and Signed by him≈øelf in the ≈øame words.
Dr. Thomas Smith gave in his Paper of ≈øubmi≈ø≈øion as followeth in ¬ß. 14.
The Demys ≈øub≈øcribed a Paper in the ≈øame Form who≈øe Names are.

list.item: Tho. Holt Senior.

div.p: The Chaplains ≈øub≈øcribed the like, who≈øe Names were.
The Chori≈øters ≈øub≈øcribed the like, who≈øe Names were.
The Clerks ≈øub≈øcribed the like ≈øubmi≈ø≈øion, who≈øe Names are.
The under Porter of the College would give in no Paper of ≈øubmi≈ø≈øion.

The Oxford Relation ≈øaith, that to the ≈øubmi≈ø≈øion, Oxford Relation. the Clau≈øe was added, and no ways prejudicial to the Right of Dr. Hough.Page 31. In the Original Paper I found it ≈øcored out, and as the Relation ≈øaith, it was yielded to by the ≈øub≈øcribers, becau≈øe the Lord Chief Ju≈øtice and Barron Jenner as Judges declared that it was in≈øignificant, ≈øince nothing they ≈øhould do could Invalidate Dr. Hough's Title, but le≈øt them ≈øtill at liberty to be Witne≈ø≈øes for him or any other way ≈øerviceable to him in the Recovery of his Right, upon which a≈ø≈øurance the SocietyIf this be as related, it ≈øhews the great conde≈øcention of the Lords Commi≈ø≈øioners to have won them to obedience. was prevailed with to leave it out.

div.head: ¬ß. 13.
div.p: The Lords askt Dr. Fairfax if he owned their Juri≈ødiction, Out of the Regi≈øter Octo. 25th. 1687. to which he reply'd,His words were, under Correction I do not. that he did not; then he was askt if he would ≈øubmit to the Bi≈øhop of Oxon as Pre≈øident, to which he refu≈øed to do:His words were, I will not, nor cannot, becau≈øe he is not my Legal Pre≈øident. And the Sentence was pronounced again≈øt him, That whereas he had denyed the Authority of the Court, and in Contempt of the Sentence of Su≈øpen≈øion given again≈øt him by the Lords Commi≈ø≈øioners at Whitehall, taken his Commons and Battled in the College as a Fellow of the College notwith≈øtanding his ≈øaid Su≈øpen≈øion, the Court proceeded to deprive him of his Fellow≈øhip, and Ordered his Name to be ≈øtruck out of the Buttry-Book.
The Sentence pronounced again≈øt him, I find in the Regi≈øter, tho' not in this place, in the words following.

div.head: By His Maje≈øties Commi≈ø≈øioners, &c.
div.p: WHereas in our Vi≈øitation of the ≈øaid College it appeareth unto us, that Henry Fairfax Doctor in Divinity one of the Fellows of the ≈øaid College has been guilty of Di≈ø-obedience to His Maje≈øties Commands, and ob≈øtinately contemned his Royal Authority, and doth ≈øtill per≈øi≈øt in the ≈øame, we have thought fit upon mature con≈øideration thereof to Declare, Pronounce and Decree, that the ≈øaid Dr: Henry Fairfax be Expelled and Deprived of his ≈øaid Fellow≈øhip, and accordingly we do hereby deprive him and Expel him from the ≈øame.

closer.dateline: Given under our Seal the 25th. day of October 1687.

div.p: Then the Lords i≈ø≈øued the following Order.

div.head: By His Maje≈øties Commi≈ø≈øioners, &c.
div.p: WHereas we have thought fit to Deprive and Expell Dr. Henry Fairfax from his Fellow≈øhip in the ≈øaid College, you and either of you are hereby required to cau≈øe our ≈øaid Sentence and Decree, a Copy whereof is hereto annexed, to be affixed on the Gate of the ≈øaid College, to the end that due notice may be taken of the ≈øame, and of the due Execution hereof you are to certifie us.

closer.dateline: Given under our Seal the 25th. of October 1687.

div.trailer: To Thomas Atterbury and Robert Eddows. Or either of them.

div.p: He then gave in his Prote≈øtation again≈øt their Proceedings, which the Court over-ruled and ordered him to depart and quit his Lodgings in the College in Fourteen Days.
Then the Doctor prevailed with much a do, ≈øaith the Oxford Relation, to Read the following Prote≈øtation and left it in Court which was as followeth.

I Henry Fairfax, Fellow of St. Mary Magdalen College,Dr. Fairfax's Prote≈øtation. do under my former An≈øwer heretofore made, and to the Intent it may appear that I have not con≈øented, nor agreed to any thing done again≈øt me to my prejudice, I prote≈øt that this Sentence given here again≈øt me, is Lex nulla, and ≈øo far forth as it ≈øhall appear to be aliqua; I do ≈øay it is iniqua & inju≈øta, and that therefore I do from it, as iniqua & inju≈øta, appeal to our Sovereign Lord the King in his Courts
of Ju≈øtice as the Laws Statutes and Ordinances of this Realm will permit in that behalf.

closer.signed: Henry Fairfax.

div.head: ¬ß. 14.
div.p: The under Porter deprived.Then the Lords askt Robert Gardiner the Under Porter if he would ≈øubmit to the Bi≈øhop of Oxon as Pre≈øident of the College, which he refu≈øing to do the Lords deprived him of his Office, and adjourned the Court till the next Morning.

Mr. John Gilman's Paper I find thus‚ÄîThat the Statutes of the College,This Paper is mi≈ø-placed and ≈øhould have been October 22d. Afternoon. to which I am po≈øitively Sworn, are the only Rule of my Actions and Obedience, in this and all other Ca≈øes of the like Nature, and I conceive the Bi≈øhop of Oxon has not tho≈øe Statutable Qualifications which are required, therefore I cannot A≈ø≈øi≈øt at the Admi≈ø≈øion of the Bi≈øhop of Oxon.

The ≈øubmi≈ø≈øion of Dr. Thomas Smith was as followeth,Dr. Tho. Smiths ≈øubmi≈ø≈øion, which he gave in when the Fellows gave in theirs, I have put here by it ≈øelf becau≈øe I would not mix it with the other. given in in Writing al≈øo.

I Own from my Heart and acknowledge the Kings Supremacy. I do now and will always pay all Dutiful, Ju≈øt, and Humble Obedience to His Maje≈øties Authority, as becomes a Prie≈øt of the Catholic and Apo≈øtolic Church of England E≈øtabli≈øh'd by Law. I make no exception to the Legality of your Lord≈øhips Commi≈ø≈øion, nor to the exerci≈øe of it in this pre≈øent Vi≈øitation.
I am ready and willing to obey, in licitis & hone≈øtis the Pre≈øident whom the King has plea≈øed to Con≈øtitute Pre≈øident when ever he ≈øhall come and pre≈øide in the College.

closer.signed: Thomas Smith, D. D.

div.p: The Paper given in by Mr. Craddock was as followeth.

ABout Six Years ≈øince,This Paper was given in October 22d. Afternoon. when I was made Fellow by the Kings Permi≈ø≈øion, I took an Oath, that I would not be di≈øpen≈øed with from my Local Statutes, by which Statutes and Oaths it does not belong to me to Admit any Man Pre≈øident, be≈øides I conceive Dr. Hough cannot be Legally di≈øpo≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of the Pre≈øident≈øhip of Magdalen College, till he has Appealed to We≈øtmin≈øter, or an Higher Court, and till then I ≈øhall not cea≈øe my obedience to him.

closer.signed: Willi. Craddock.

div.p: I ≈øhall now in≈øert the Lords Commi≈ø≈øioners An≈øwer to my Lord Pre≈øidents la≈øt Letter, and then proceed in the Narrative.

div.head: ¬ß. 15. The An≈øwer to the Lord Pre≈øidents Letter of the 23d. of October.

body.p:
IN Obedience to your Lord≈øhip of the 23d. In≈øtant, and the Kings Letters Mandatory, we have this day In≈øtalled the Lord Bi≈øhop of Oxon's Proxy, by placeing him in the Pre≈øidents Seat in the
Chappel, and ≈øome while after Dr. Hough having left the College, and the Keys being deny'd us, we cau≈øed the Doors of the Lodgings to be broken up, and gave his Proxy Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion thereof.

My Lord we proceeded to examin the Fellows concerning their ≈øubmi≈ø≈øion to the Lord Bi≈øhop of Oxon now their Pre≈øident, their An≈øwers were Unanimous in ≈øcriptis, that they would all ≈øubmit but Dr. Fairfax, whom, for that, and denying the Juri≈ødiction of the Court, and Contempt of his former Sentence of Su≈øpen≈øion, we have Deprived and Ejected, and one Robert Gardiner a Porter, all the re≈øt of the College we left this Night in good temper, and the Bi≈øhops Servants in quiet Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion. We have likewi≈øe looked into the Con≈øtitutions, Orders, and Statutes of the College, and cannot find any of the Society to have offended therein, or in mi≈ø-applying their Revenues. They having given us, as we conceive, a clear An≈øwer to the Accu≈øation again≈øt them for Imbezling ≈øuch a part of it, as was pretended to be ≈øet a ≈øide for Pilgrims, and poor Travellors, which we will bring up, and tran≈ømit to your Lord≈øhip:Here may be noted how tender the Lords Commi≈ø≈øioners were and willing to have won them to obedience. And this we mu≈øt ≈øay my Lord, that generally they have behaved them≈øelves with great regard, and deference to His Maje≈øties Command, ≈øaving in that particular whereof we gave your Lord≈øhip an account in our la≈øt, and even for that they have expre≈ø≈øed a very hearty ≈øorrow, and ≈øubmi≈ø≈øion, and we do humbly conceive that the Bi≈øhop of Oxon, when he comes in Per≈øon to the College (which he promi≈øes ≈øuddenly to do ≈øo ≈øoon as his health will give him leave) will be be≈øt able to find out tho≈øe faults of the particular Members of this Society, which we cannot get any the lea≈øt Information of, and have
≈øufficient Power to redre≈øs them, and to puni≈øh the Delinquents, for the Irregularities Committed by the Statutes of the ≈øame, and having brought the Fellows to the Submi≈ø≈øion to his Admi≈ø≈øion, and had notice from your Lord≈øhip of the Kings Gracious plea≈øure,This Graciou≈øne≈øs of the King is to be ob≈øerved. that no puni≈øhment ≈øhould be inflicted upon them by us, upon the account of their former di≈øobedience, we hope we have hitherto obeyed His Maje≈øties Command, and that if he have no further plea≈øure to ≈øignifie to us, we may have his Gracious leave to return to attend his Service at London. We crave leave further to intimate to His Maje≈øty, that the Vice-Chancellor and Heads of Hou≈øes pay great re≈øpect to this Commi≈ø≈øion, as will in part appear by the Inclo≈øed Paper of the Programma. See the Programma before cap. 2. ≈øect. 1. ¬ß. 5. And ≈øo begging your Lord≈øhips favourable Repre≈øentation of our Duty and Service to His Maje≈øty we re≈øt.

signed.hi: Your Lord≈øhips mo≈øt obedient and humble Servants.

list.item: Tho. Ce≈øtrien≈øis.
R. Wright.
Tho. Jenner.

div.p: With this Letter was ≈øent the following account, which in ≈øeveral particulars I have only given the abridgment of, as being le≈øs nece≈ø≈øary to the main bu≈øine≈øs.

div.head: ¬ß. 16. The Account the Fellows gave in, concerning their Ho≈øpitality, &c.
div.p: THe Fellows of the College brought in an Account of their Gifts towards Ho≈øpitality, Here may be noted that the Lands of this Ho≈øpital were alienated. and then the Court adjourned till Thur≈øday Morning, the abridgment of the Account is this.

In the time of King Henry the Sixth, the Ho≈øpital of St. John was di≈ø≈øolved and the Lands thereunto belonging were purcha≈øed by William Wainfleet, then Bi≈øhop of Winton, and in the place or ≈øcite of that Ho≈øpital he Built Magdalen College. He him≈øelf left no Compo≈øition, Injunction, Statute, Order, or Provi≈øo for the Maintenance of any Poor People, or Strangers, that ever we could find in any writing or Record what≈øoever.

Then they relate ≈øome ≈ømall Gift of John Claimond the third Pre≈øident who left 3 l. per Annum whereof 2 l. 10 s. is to be di≈øtributed among≈øt the Fellows and Scholars, on the fir≈øt Munday in Lent Yearly, and 10 s. thereof for the repairing of four Beds and Bed≈øteads which he placed in a Room over the Vault of the old Chappel, but he made no provi≈øion they find of Victuals, or Maintenance of tho≈øe who were allowed to Lodge there, which, at the mo≈øt, were to be but four at a time. But in the time of the Rebellion the ≈øaid Chappel, with the Vault, was made no other u≈øe of but to lay Fuel in, whereupon at the Re≈øtauration the Vi≈øitor directed, that it ≈øhould be Converted into Chambers for the u≈øe of the Fellows and Demys.

Two other of their Benefactors, Ingledue and Pre≈øton, ordered 20 d. at a time, to be di≈øpo≈øed of on fourteen Fea≈øts to the poor, the whole amounting
to 1 l. 3 s. which is accordingly di≈øtributed yearly by the Bur≈øers. Pre≈øton gave 6 s. per Annum for the u≈øe of two or three poor Lanca≈øhire Scholars, which is yearly di≈øtributed by the Pre≈øident, ≈øo that all the Mony which we are obliged to be≈øtow on Charitable u≈øes amounts to but 2 l. 3 s. 4 d. per Annum be≈øides Perrots Compo≈øition which is faithfully performed.

Notwith≈øtanding which, 4 s. is given yearly to the Ca≈øtle for Straw for the Pri≈øoners, and we allow 8 s. yearly to the Alms-Men of Bartholomews, we allow 6 l. 6 s. 8 d. yearly to the poor of Bridewell, and 20 l. per Annum to the Pre≈øident, for the entertainment of Strangers, and Forreigners, and there is allowed every Meal at the Bur≈øers Table a Commons for the Entertainment of Strangers, and the Bur≈øers have Power to add thereunto as they ≈øee occa≈øion, and be≈øides what is con≈øtantly allowed, as above≈øaid, there is a con≈øiderable Sum di≈øpo≈øed of yearly, by the Pre≈øident and Thirteen Senior Fellows, at the conclu≈øion of the Accounts and other times, to Indigent Per≈øons, Strangers, and Travelors, and chiefly to ≈øuch as are in great want, but a≈øhamed to make their nece≈ø≈øities ≈øo public, as to de≈øire Alms of their re≈øpective Pari≈øhes amounting to above 50 l. per Annum.

And if we might not be thought to boa≈øt of our Charity, we could in≈øtance in con≈øiderable Sums given to the Fire of London, Northampton, and Southwark, and other places, and to the French Prote≈øtants, to one of which we allow at pre≈øent 6 l. yearly, whence it appears, that we Expend out of the College Stock near 100 l. per Annum in Charitable u≈øes.

div.head: ¬ß. 17. Dr. Thomas Smiths Paper about the College Charity, &c.
div.p: Dr. Thomas Smith gave in the following Paper at the ≈øame time.

AS to your Lord≈øhips Que≈øtion propo≈øed, whether we have applyed the Revenue of any Land, or other E≈øtate, given for Ho≈øpitality, to private u≈øes, we cannot for want of time give your Lord≈øhips that ≈øatisfaction, and full Accompt which we de≈øire, and ≈øhall do hereafter when we ≈øhall look over the Evidences and the E≈øtate of the College, of which we are but the U≈øu-fructuaries, and other Munuments locked up in the Tower.

As to our Ho≈øpitality in General, the Bur≈øers Table is the place where not only our Tenants, but Strangers, according to their Quality are Entertained, there being a dayly Allowance made by the College for that purpo≈øe, which when ≈øcanty, and not ≈øufficient for a ≈øuitable Entertainment, it is left in many Ca≈øes to the di≈øcretion of the Bur≈øers to add what they ≈øhall Judge fit and becoming. But be≈øides this it is our con≈øtant Practice and Cu≈øtom at the end of
the Year to give Sums of Mony away to the poor, which are greater, or le≈øs, according to the Surplu≈øage of our Corn Rents that year.

Thirdly, The Bur≈øers are Impowered to give Mony away to the poor, upon the greater and more ≈øolemn Fe≈øtivals of the year. Fourthly, Oftentimes upon great Emergencies, ≈øuch as were the Brief for the Re-edifying the Town of Northampton, for the Rebuilding the Cathedral of St. Pauls London, for the relief of the French Prote≈øtants, be≈øides other Briefs for Fires and for Redemption of Captives, and the like, we give con≈øiderable Sums of Mony, as well out of the public Stock, as out of our private Pur≈øes.

As for turning the remaining part of the Ho≈øpital of St. John, about twenty Years ≈øince, into Lodging Chambers, which were very much wanting for the Fellows, that alteration was not made without con≈øulting the Bi≈øhop of Winton our Local Vi≈øitor, and without having obtained his Lord≈øhips con≈øent. There having been no u≈øe as we could ever learn from our Predece≈ø≈øors of tho≈øe Rooms, and as we may ≈øeem, not without good grounds, to believe, ≈øince the Time that Pilgrimages were left off, and di≈ø-u≈øed here in England.

But my Lords, if upon re-≈øearch (which we will endeavor to make with all hone≈øt diligence) we ≈øhall find any obligation lying upon us, to u≈øe larger mea≈øures of Ho≈øpitality, we a≈ø≈øure your Lord≈øhips we will be ju≈øt to that obligation, and for the future will fully ≈øatisfie it as we will any other point of Duty which is Incumbent upon us as Fellows of the College.

This we hope will ≈øatisfie your Lord≈øhips at pre≈øent, and we humbly de≈øire of your Lord≈øhips to make, as we are a≈ø≈øured your Lord≈øhips will do, a fair and Candid Interpretation of this An≈øwer to his Sacred Maje≈øty, whom God ble≈øs with long Life and an happy and glorious Reign.

closer.signed: Tho. Smith, D. D.

div.head: ¬ß. 18. The Stewards account Regi≈øter.
div.p: THe Steward Mr. James Almont, according to the Lords Order, brought in an account in Writing of the Lea≈øes Lett, and Fines taken for the two la≈øt years.
Then the Fellows de≈øired, that Dr. Aldworth their Vice-Pre≈øident his Su≈øpen≈øion might be taken off, his pre≈øence being ≈øo nece≈ø≈øary at their Audit which was night at hand.

To which the Court reply'd, that they mu≈øt apply to the Lords Commi≈ø≈øioners above, who had Su≈øpended him. Then adjourned till Five in the Afternoon, at which time they met and adjourned till the next day at Seven in the Morning, before which Meeting the following Letter was delivered to the Lords.

div.head: ¬ß. 19. The Lord Pre≈øidents Letter to the Lords Commi≈ø≈øioners, in An≈øwer to theirs of the 25th. of Octob.
div.p:
I Have received your Lord≈øhips of the 25th. and laid it before the King, who Commands me to tell you, that he thinks the Fellows, who have ≈øubmitted to the Bi≈øhop of Oxford as their Pre≈øident,
ought to make an Addre≈øs to His Maje≈øty, asking Pardon for their late Offences and ob≈øtinacy, and acknowledging the Juri≈ødiction of the Court, and the Ju≈øtice and Legality of it's proceedings in the whole matter: His Maje≈øty leaves the Wording of it to you, and the manner of doing it, but would have it done before you come away; And if any Per≈øon ≈øhall refu≈øe to joyn herein, His Maje≈øty would have you Expel them, ≈øince he cannot look upon this which is called a Submi≈ø≈øion to be ≈øuch indeed, unle≈øs it be attended with the≈øe Circum≈øtances.
