The King is very well ≈øatisfied with the proceedings again≈øt Dr. Hough and Dr. Fairfax, but thinks they de≈øerve ≈øome further puni≈øhment, and therefore when you return will have the whole Eccle≈øia≈øtical Commi≈ø≈øion pa≈øs a Sentence of Incapacity upon them.

The King would have you before you come away,By this it appears that the Fellows ≈øubmi≈ø≈øion was expected. place Mr. Willi. Joyner in the Fellow≈øhip lately enjoy'd by Dr. Fairfax, and likewi≈øe appoint Judge Allibons' Brother, and Mr. Charles Goring to be Fellows of that College if there are two Vacances more. If there is but one, then Judge Allibons Brother to have that Fellow≈øhip, and Mr. Goring to come in upon the fir≈øt Vacancy. In ca≈øe Mr. Goring be a Fellow, His Maje≈øty would have Mr. Middleton, who is his Nephew ≈øucceed him in his Demy≈øhip.

closer.signed: I am, MY LORDS, Your Lord≈øhips mo≈øt humble Servant. Sunderland. P.

div.head: ¬ß. 20. FRIDAY Morning the 28th. of Octob. 1687.
div.p: THe Lords, in order to fill up the void places, demanded of the Fellows how many places were Vacant, and it appeared to their Lord≈øhips that there was none but Dr. Fairfax's and Mr. Ludfords who was lately Dead, then enquiry was made for the Per≈øons recommended, and no body appearing the Lords could proceed no further in that matter.

Then the Lords told the Fellows, &c. That they could not heartily recommend them to His Maje≈øties favour, unle≈øs they did Addre≈øs to His Maje≈øty in Writing, asking pardon for their offences, and acknowledge the Juri≈ødiction of this Court.

[The Fellows making a little pau≈øe the Bi≈øhop of Che≈øter told them they might word it them≈øelves, or if they thought fit Mr. Tucker ≈øhould A≈ø≈øi≈øt them in a Form.] Upon which the Fellows withdrew into the Hall to con≈øider of it, and after ≈øome time brought in a Paper with all their hands ≈øub≈øcribed of the Tenor following.

div.head: ¬ß. 21.

div.p:
VVE have endeavored in all our Actions to expre≈øs our ≈øelves with all humility to His Maje≈øty, By this it appears how far they were from making a ≈øubmi≈ø≈øion according to his Maje≈øties expectation. and being con≈øcious to our ≈øelves, that in the whole Conduct of this bu≈øine≈øs before your Lord≈øhips, we have done nothing but what our Oaths, and Statutes Indi≈øpen≈øably obliged us to, we cannot make any Declaration whereby we acknowledge that we have done ami≈øs, as having acted according
to the principles of Loyalty and obedience to his Sacred Maje≈øty as far as we could without doing violence to our Con≈øciences or prejudice to our Rights (one of which we humbly conceive that of Electing a Pre≈øident to be) from which we are Sworn upon no account what≈øoever to depart. We therefore humbly beg your Lord≈øhips to repre≈øent this favourably with our utmo≈øt Duty to His Maje≈øty, whom God Grant long and happily to Reign over us.

This being Read and the Court, ≈øaith the Regi≈øter, looking upon the ≈øame to contradict the ≈øubmi≈ø≈øion they had given in before, the Lords again asked them, whether they would ≈øubmit to the Bi≈øhop of Oxon as their Pre≈øident or not.

Dr. Pud≈øey, Dr. Stafford, Mr. Hollis and Mr.Regi≈øter. Penni≈øton, referred to their Paper of ≈øubmi≈ø≈øion given in on Tue≈øday, and the greate≈øt part of the re≈øt de≈øired to be excu≈øed from an≈øwering the Que≈øtion, declaring that their obedience or di≈ø obedience would be≈øt appear by their actions, when the Bi≈øhop came
among≈øt them, and if they were di≈ø-obedient to the Pre≈øident, they were lyable to be puni≈øhed by their Statutes, and ≈øaid further, that they having given in their ≈øubmi≈ø≈øion on Tu≈øeday, they thought their Lord≈øhips Honor was engaged to require nothing further from them. But the Court in≈øi≈øting to have a po≈øitive An≈øwer to the Que≈øtion, and the Bi≈øhop of Che≈øter ≈øaying, it was Prote≈øtatio contra factum; Dr. Bayley, Mr. Hammond, Mr. Dob≈øon, Mr. Bayley, Mr. Bag≈øhaw, Mr. Harwar, Mr. Bateman, Mr. Craddock, Mr. Gilman, Mr. Holden, Mr. Weelks, and Mr. George Fulham po≈øitively refu≈øed.

div.head: ¬ß. 23. The Oxford Relation gives this account of the Di≈øcour≈øes following.
div.p: UPon their Lord≈øhips peru≈øing the Paper, they expre≈ø≈øed their di≈ølike of it, and ≈øaid it did not come up to what they delivered on Tue≈øday.

Dr. Bayley an≈øwered, they had acted conformable to them≈øelves, and truly he could not confe≈øs any Crime. To which the Bi≈øhop of Che≈øter reply'd, that they did not expect of them to Confe≈øs a Capital Crime; only to make ≈øome acknowledgment. To which Mr. Fulhum ≈øaid,This is according to the original, the Oxford Relation varying in words tho' not in Sen≈øe. My Lords, we were ordered to Addre≈øs our ≈øelves as having acted in Contempt of His Maje≈øties Authority, which he looked upon as ≈øo great a Crime, that upon no account he would be guilty of; My Lords continued he, I did obey His Maje≈øty as far as I could to the utmo≈øt of my Power, and your Lord≈øhips having been plea≈øed to accept the ≈øubmi≈ø≈øion on Tue≈øday, I humbly conceive your Lord≈øhips are engaged that nothing further be required of me of what I have done, being Con≈øcious
of no Contempt to His Maje≈øties Authority. To which the Bi≈øhop of Che≈øter An≈øwered, you are a very forward ≈øpeaker and abound in your own Sen≈øe Mr. Fulham reply'd, he hoped their Lord≈øhips would give them leave to ≈øpeak, when their Fortunes were ≈øo con≈øiderably at Stake, as their own Relatoin ≈øaith.

Then Dr. Bayley de≈øired their Lord≈øhips to give him leave to explain what he meant by the word ≈øubmit,By this it appears how nece≈ø≈øary it was to have a more clear and full ≈øubmi≈ø≈øion ≈øub≈øcribed. in his An≈øwer on Tue≈øday, viz. The word Submit, was to be under≈øtood with reference to the King, and that he did not intend it as a ≈øubmi≈ø≈øion to the Bi≈øhop as Lawful Pre≈øident.

div.head: ¬ß. 23.
div.p: Upon this a fre≈øh Que≈øtion was put to the Fellows, whether they would obey the Bi≈øhop of Oxon as their Pre≈øident in licitis & hone≈øtis, to which all, except one or two, An≈øwered they would not. Upon this Que≈øtion put to Mr. Fulham he An≈øwered, that he could not confe≈øs any Crime or Offence done again≈øt the King; that Dr. Hough having been Duly Elected and Admitted Pre≈øident he thereby obtained a Right, which he was not ≈øatisfied that he had any ways forfeited, therefore he could obey no other Per≈øon as Pre≈øident. The Bi≈øhop of Che≈øter asked him if he would obey the Bi≈øhop of Oxon as in Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, to which according to the Relation of tho≈øe who Writ down what he ≈øpoke in Court, he thus An≈øwered,The Oxford Relation palliates this An≈øwer. that he could not ≈øubmit otherwi≈øe then as it was agreeable to the Law of the Land and Statutes of the College, without prejudice to the Right of the Election of the Fellows, and that he humbly conceived the Bi≈øhop was violently and unju≈øtly put into Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, and that it ≈øhould have been by the Po≈ø≈øe Comitatus.

Then my Lord Chief Ju≈øtice ≈øaid,Not as the Oxford Relation hath it, that their Oxford Law was no better then their Oxford Divinity. that their Oxford Divinity was better than their Oxford Law: If they had a mind to a Po≈ø≈øe Comitatus they might have it ≈øoon enough: to which Mr. Fulham ≈øaid, he intended nothing but re≈øpect to their Lord≈øhips, and had endeavored to ≈øpeak and behave him≈øelf with due Reverence, and de≈øired their Lord≈øhips would put a favourable con≈øtruction of what he ≈øaid, as the Oxford Relation ≈øaith.

div.head: The Sentence of Su≈øpen≈øion again≈øt Mr. George Fulham.
div.p: Then all were Commanded to withdraw, and the Buttry-Book called for, after which Mr. Fulham was called in with the re≈øt, and the Bi≈øhop of Che≈øter ≈øaid to him, Mr. George Fulham, whereas you have openly, and in Opprobrious Language, Contemned the Authority of the Court, we Su≈øpend you from the profits of the Fellow≈øhip, during the Kings plea≈øure, and you are accordingly Su≈øpended; of which all the Fellows and other Members of this College are Commanded to take notice: and to the re≈øt his Lord≈øhip further ≈øaid; whereas there are ≈øeveral Fellows ab≈øent who are in Contempt of His Maje≈øty, that they may not ≈øuffer for want of greater notice then they have yet had, we do direct and order you, who are Fellows now pre≈øent to give them notice by the u≈øual Methods, and to take notice your ≈øelves, that we have adjourned this Court till Wedne≈øday the 16th. of November en≈øuing, to be held at this place at Nine in the Morning.

div.head: SECT. II.

argument.p: The Second Vi≈øitation, by Adjournments, of St. Mary Magdalens College, by the Lords Commi≈ø≈øioners.

div.head: ¬ß. 1. The Kings Mandate for Mr. Willi. Joyner and Mr. Job Allibon.
div.p: THe Lords Commi≈ø≈øioners, having in this Interval of time Communicated their Proceedings to His Maje≈øty, and by his appointment to the re≈øt of the Lords Commi≈ø≈øioners at Whitehall; The three Lords Commi≈ø≈øioners Vi≈øitors took their Journy to Oxford, where upon the 15th. of November they arrived,

p.hi: WEDENSDAY the 16th. of November 1687. At Nine of the Clock in the Morning.

div.p: Proclamation being made, the Statute-Book and Buttry-Book were Ordered to be brought in, Then Mr. William Joyner and Mr. Job Allibon were called, and the Mandate for their Election was Ordered to be Read, which followeth.

RIght Reverend Father in God, Right Tru≈øty and Well-beloved, and Tru≈øty and Well-beloved, We Greet you well: Being Informed, that there are two Fellow≈øhips now Vacant in St. Mary Magdalen College, by the Expul≈øion of Dr. Fairfax, and the Death of Thomas Ludford, and having received
a good Character of the Learning and Sobriety of Our Tru≈øty and Well-beloved William Joyner and Job Allibon, We have thought fit hereby to Authorize and require you forthwith to Admit the ≈øaid William Joyner and Job Allibon into the Fellow≈øhips lately enjoyed by the ≈øaid Dr. Fairfax and Tho. Ludford, with all the Rights, Privileges and Profits, Perqui≈øits, Emoluments and Advantages what≈øoever thereunto belonging, without Admini≈øtrating any Oaths to them but that of a Fellow: Any Law, Statute, Cu≈øtom or Con≈øtitution to the contrary notwith≈øtanding; with all which We are plea≈øed to Di≈øpen≈øe in this behalf, and for ≈øo doing this ≈øhall be your Warrant. And ≈øo We bid you heartily farewell.

closer.dateline: Given at Our Court at Whitehall the 11th. Day of November 1687. In the Third Year of Our Reign.
closer.signed: By His Maje≈øties Command. Sunderland P.

div.p: This being done,Regi≈øter. the ≈øaid Mr. Joyner and Mr. Allibon were Admitted Fellows of the ≈øaid College, taking only the Oath required by their Statute-Book to be taken at the Admi≈ø≈øion of a Fellow, and their Names were Entred into the Buttry-Book.

Then the Fellows were called in, except tho≈øe hereafter to be mentioned, and Dr. Younger, who was excu≈øed, being in waiting upon her Royal Highne≈øs the Prince≈øs of Denmark, ≈øeveral Certificates were produced to excu≈øe Mr. Charles Hawles, Mr. Edward Maynard, Mr. John Hicks, Mr. Thomas Goodwin, Mr. Francis Smith, Mr. Robert Holt, and Mr. Robert Thornton.

div.head: ¬ß. 2. The Lord Bi≈øhop of Che≈øters Speech.
div.p: The Fellows being thus Convened the Lord Bi≈øhop of Che≈øter made this following Speech.

YOur ∆≤ndutiful, and I might ≈øay, your Ingrateful behavior towards His Maje≈øty, for Six Months la≈øt pa≈øt, your ob≈øtinate froward and unrea≈øonable ≈øtiffne≈øs to ≈øo good and Gracious a Prince, was that which brought this pre≈øent Vi≈øitation upon you; which how great a ≈øin it was again≈øt God (who≈øe Vicegerent you have contemned beyond all Moderation and Rea≈øon,) how great a ≈øcandal to our Religion, how great a ≈øtain to the liberal and ingenuous Education, which this Society would afford you, and how very mi≈øchievous it will be to your ≈øelves at la≈øt, I endeavored to convince you at the fir≈øt Opening of our Commi≈ø≈øion. Since which time ≈øome of you have been ≈øo unrea≈øonably incon≈øiderate and ob≈øtinate, as to run yet farther upon the ≈øcore of His Royal Patience and Pardon, for which you are now to receive the ju≈øt and nece≈ø≈øary Animadver≈øions of this Court, that the Honor and Authority of the King may be Vindicated, and the Peace of Church and State not be endangered by your Impunity, or our Connivance, at this your petulant humor and contumacious behavior.

No Subjects can be wi≈øe or ≈øafe, but they who are ≈øo ≈øincerely hone≈øt, as to take all fair occa≈øions of doing their Prince acceptable ≈øervices and executing his Will: Reputation abroad, and Reverence at home, are the Pillars of ≈øafety and Soveraignty, the≈øe you have endeavored as much as in you lies to ≈øhake, nor can the King hope to be well ≈øerved at home, or
ob≈øerved abroad, if your puni≈øhment, be not as public as your Crimes.

No Society of Men in this or the other Univer≈øity ever had ≈øo many Male-contents and Mutineers in it, as this College: your continual cla≈øhings and di≈øcords, ≈øometimes with your Pre≈øident, at others with your Vi≈øitor, and ≈øo frequently among your ≈øelves, ever ≈øince his late Maje≈øties happy Re≈øtauration have been too public to be concealed. I have more than once heard your late Vi≈øitor of Pious Memory, bewaile the great unhappine≈øs of this Noble Foundation, in being over-≈øtockt with a ≈øort of Men whom a wantonne≈øs of Spirit had made re≈øtle≈øs and unquiet, who would never be ≈øatisfied, who≈øe di≈øea≈øe was fed by Conce≈ø≈øion, and then mo≈øt violent, when they knew not what they would have. You have been long experienced in the Methods of Quarreling with your Vi≈øitor, Pre≈øident and your ≈øelves, and by the≈øe ≈øteps you are at la≈øt arrived to the top and highe≈øt degree of in≈øolence, which is to Quarrel with your Prince, which as it di≈ø-honors your Religion, ≈øo it Proclaims your Pride and Vanity, for every di≈ø-obedient Man is proud, and would obey, if he did not think him≈øelf wi≈øer than his Governor. You have dealt with His Sacred Maje≈øty, as if he Reigned only by Courte≈øie, and you were re≈øolved to have a King under you, but none over you; and till God give you more ≈øelf denyal and humility, you will never approve your ≈øelves to be good Chri≈øtians, or good Subjects, who≈øe Patience and Petitions are the only Arms they can ever hone≈øtly u≈øe again≈øt their Prince.

You could not be ignorant of the Kings being your Supreme Ordinary by the Antient Common Law of this Land, of which the Statutes are not Introductory
but declaratory; you have Read what Bracton ≈øays de leg. lib. 1. c. 8.
‚Ä¢ . 5. (who was Lord Chief Ju≈øtice of England for Twenty Years in Henry the Thirds time) Nemo de factis ≈øuis prae≈øumat di≈øquirere, mult√≤ min√πs contra factum ≈øuum venire. Now His Maje≈øty the Fifth of April ≈øent his Letters Mandatory to you to Elect and Admit one Mr. Farmer into your Pre≈øidents place then void by the Death of Dr. Clark your la≈øt Pre≈øident. Whom the Tenth of April you repre≈øented to His Maje≈øty as incapable of that Character in ≈øeveral re≈øpects, and be≈øought him (as His Maje≈øty ≈øhould think fitte≈øt in His Princely Wi≈ødom) either to leave you to the di≈øcharge of your Duty and Con≈øciences according to his late Gratious Declaration, and your Founders Statutes, or to recommend ≈øuch a per≈øon who might be more ≈øerviceable to His Maje≈øty and the College. This Paper was delivered to my Lord Pre≈øident the Tenth of April, and on the Fifteenth of April without expecting His Maje≈øties An≈øwer (as your Hypocritical ≈øubmi≈ø≈øion would have per≈øuaded all Charitable Men to believe, you did and would expect) in Contempt of his former Mandate, which had the force of an Inhibition, you proceeded to Elect Dr. Hough for your pretended Pre≈øident. Upon the fir≈øt notice whereof, the Sixteenth of April my Lord Pre≈øident ≈øent a Letter by His Maje≈øties Command to the Bi≈øhop of Winche≈øter, not to Admit him. But they who have ill de≈øigns in their Heads, are always in ha≈øt, by which you ≈øurprized your Vi≈øitor, which occa≈øioned my Lord Pre≈øident the 21≈øt. of April to Write another to you, to let you know how much the King was ≈øurprized at your Proceedings, and that he expected an Account of it. Then were you Cited before the Eccle≈øia≈øtical Commi≈ø≈øioners
at Whitehall, where upon mature deliberation and a Con≈øultation had with the be≈øt Common Lawyers and Civilians, Dr. Houghs Election was declared void, the 22d. of June, and he amov'd from the ≈øame by their Lord≈øhips ju≈øt Sentence. Of this you were certified by an In≈øtrument under the Seal of the Court of the ≈øame Date, affixed to your College Gates; which being di≈ø-obeyed, you were once more Cited by an In≈øtrument of the fir≈øt, to appear before their Lord≈øhips the 29th. of July to An≈øwer your Contempts. You pretended when you came before their Lord≈øhips, that you were deeply affected with the late Sen≈øe of His Maje≈øties heavy di≈ø-plea≈øure, and beg'd leave to pro≈øtrate your ≈øelves at His Royal Feet, offering all Real Te≈øtimonies of Duty and Loyalty, as Men that abhorr'd all ≈øtubborn and groundle≈øs re≈øi≈øtance of His Royal Will and Plea≈øure. So ≈øaid, and ≈øo done, had been well, but you were re≈øolv'd it ≈øeems to give him nothing but good words, and that your Practice ≈øhould confute your Profe≈ø≈øion. I wi≈øh you had known in time as well (as you pretended to do) how entirely your welfare depended upon the Countenance and Favour of your Prince, it would then have been as great a grief to you to have di≈ø-obeyed His Maje≈øties Commands as it was a guilt, and will be a puni≈øhment, both in this Life and that to come, if not repented of in time. On the 14th. of Augu≈øt His Maje≈øty ≈øignified His Will and Plea≈øure to you by His Letters Mandatory, and thereby Authorized and required you forthwith to Admit the Bi≈øhop of Oxon into the place of Pre≈øident, any Statute or Statutes, Cu≈øtom or Con≈øtitution to the contrary notwith≈øtanding, wherewith he was Graciou≈øly plea≈øed to di≈øpen≈øe, to which he expected your ready
obedience (but all in vain;) for to your ≈øhame be it ≈øpoken, you had done an ill action, and re≈øolv'd to ≈øet your bu≈øie Wits on work to defend it. And Con≈øcience (the old Rebellious Topick) mu≈øt be call'd in at a dead lift to plead for you. But you are not the fir≈øt who have mi≈øtaken an humor or a di≈øea≈øe for Con≈øcience; your ≈øcruples were not ≈øuch, but that they might, without ≈øin, have been Sacrificed to your Princes plea≈øure as a Peace-offering to the Father of your Country, to your Mother Church, and to the good of this and all other ≈øuch Charitable Seminaries of good Learning and Religion, and Men as wi≈øe (as you perhaps may think your ≈øelves) will be of opinion, that they who are too Tall to ≈øtand, and too ≈øtubborn to bow de≈øerve to be broke. One would have thought that His Maje≈øties Patience after ≈øo many and great Provocations as the≈øe, ≈øhould have made a way to your Hearts through your Brains, and made you a≈øhamed of your ob≈øtinacy and in love with obedience before now. But you have deceived his and all good Mens expectations ≈øtill. In≈øomuch, that on Sunday the 4th. of September His Maje≈øty ≈øent for you to Attend him at Chri≈øt-Church, and Commanded you to Admit the Bi≈øhop of Oxon your Pre≈øident without any further delay or pretence; you ≈øay it was to Elect him, which ≈øounds like the re≈øt of your Sophi≈øtry, for you well knew that admi≈ø≈øion would have ≈øatisfied him, for which you had his Written Mandate lying by you, which would have determined that Scruple. But the truth of it was, you re≈øolv'd (as time the be≈øt Expo≈øitor of Mens intentions has di≈øcover'd) to per≈øi≈øt in your ob≈øtinacy, till you had convinced him and others, that you were none of the good Centurions Servants, for in≈øtead of complying with His Maje≈øties Plea≈øure,
you went back to your Chappel (where you ≈øhould have learned and paid more Devotion) and Signed a Paper containing a direct and di≈ø-obedient refu≈øal.

Which peevi≈øh carriage of yours to your Prince from one end to the other, is ≈øuch a Compo≈øition of folly and frowardne≈øs as was little de≈øerv'd by ≈øo good and Gracious a King. There ever went a Miraculous Power of Conver≈øion with his Royal Pre≈øence where ever he came in his whole Progre≈øs but here, he convinced all ≈øuch as he had di≈øcour≈øed with, of the Ju≈øtice and equity of his Proceedings; your ≈øelves excepted, no body of Men ever departed un≈øatisfied from him, but that they departed from the ble≈ø≈øing of enjoying his Royal pre≈øence no longer. And I mu≈øt confe≈øs I do not ≈øee how it is po≈ø≈øible to do any thing more in point of Honor, Con≈øcience, Clemency, Ju≈øtice and Royal Tenderne≈øs, for the pre≈øervation of this Society and every Member of it, than what His Sacred Maje≈øty hath already done in ≈øpight of your Di≈ø-obedience and Contumacy, and yet he was and is ≈øtill re≈øolved to continue his Princely Piety and Goodne≈øs to all tho≈øe who ≈øhall no longer pretend to make it a ≈øin again≈øt Con≈øcience to return to their Obedience to him, and to tho≈øe whom he has ≈øet in Lawful Authority over them, of which I gave you a full account at the fir≈øt opening of our Commi≈ø≈øion on Friday the 21≈øt. of October in your College Hall as you may well remember. On Saturday the 22d. of October we required you to Admit and In≈øtal my Lord of Oxon according to the Kings Mandate to you before directed, which all but three of you refu≈øed again to do, and gave your pretended Rea≈øons for it in the Morning, and in the Afternoon Dr. Hough, tho' before Expelled, came in without leave, but not without Attendance and Followers
unbecoming his Circum≈øtances, and Appealed from what we had done, or ≈øhould do, as Illegal, ∆≤nju≈øt and Null (by word of Mouth and not in Writing, nor with the decent ≈øalvo's of all other Appeals) which was applauded by a loud Tumultuous and In≈øolent Hum, to affect the Populacy to the e≈øpou≈øing of your cau≈øe, for which open breach of the Peace, Dr. Hough was bound over to the Kings Bench, and if mo≈øt of you had not been better plea≈øed with that In≈øolent behavior than became you (and indeed Acce≈ø≈øaries to it, if not Actors in it) you might and would have di≈øcovered the Turbulent per≈øons who had been guilty of it.

On Tue≈øday the 25th. of October, we our ≈øelves cau≈øed the Bi≈øhop to be In≈øtalled by his Proxy, and we then askt you, whether you would ≈øubmit to the Bi≈øhop as your Pre≈øident now In≈øtalled by the Kings Mandate In lieitis & hone≈øtis? To which all that were pre≈øent (except Dr. Fairfax) gave in an An≈øwer in ≈øcriptis in the Affirmative, and reque≈øted us to repre≈øent you as Dutiful to His Maje≈øty in the highe≈øt degree: But from this good Re≈øolution you quickly fell: for on Friday the 28th. of October when we advi≈øed you to make an humble ≈øubmi≈ø≈øion to His Maje≈øty according to the Nature of the Offence, it had ≈øo ill an effect upon you, that after an hours con≈øideration or more, you brought us down a Paper Signed by all but two or three of the Fellows then pre≈øent, which ≈øeemed to us to be rather a prote≈øtation again≈øt your former ≈øubmi≈ø≈øion than a begging of the Kings Pardon for your pa≈øt offences: and that you might clear your ≈øelves, at lea≈øt from any the lea≈øt ≈øu≈øpition of that which lookt like Repentance or Obedience, you de≈øired to withdraw or expound your Submi≈ø≈øion, which you made in writing the Tue≈øday before,
and to limit the word ≈øubmi≈ø≈øion to the Kings Authority, telling us plainly, that you did not nor could not ≈øubmit to the Bi≈øhop of Oxon as your Lawful Pre≈øident: With the In≈øolent Ju≈øtification of your continued di≈ø-obedience, we were deeply affected and a≈øtoni≈øhed, and tho' we might then ju≈øtly have Expelled you, yet we forbore and went back to London to acquaint His Maje≈øty with your carriage, who re≈øented it according to your Demerits. He who is too proud to ask God and the King Pardon, de≈øerves neither. I am ≈øure the be≈øt of us need both. I wi≈øh it had been in our Power to have per≈øuaded you then, ≈øo to have moderated your ≈øelves, as to have Sacrificed the mo≈øt di≈øingenuous Arts of Contention to the ≈øafety and honor of the Chri≈øtian Religion, and not to have pur≈øued your little ≈øcruples, and great Animo≈øities to the evident hazard at lea≈øt of bringing a ≈øcandal on it.

I hope I have ≈øaid enough to convince you, that the Fig leaves, which you have ≈øtitched ≈øo Artificially together, will not cover your Nakedne≈øs: you pretend Con≈øcience of your Oaths, among which that of Allegiance and Supremacy ought not to have been forgotten. But partiality in Duty is a great Symptom of Hypocri≈øie. You Di≈øpen≈øe with your own Oaths your ≈øelves, and make too bold with ≈øome parts of your Founders Statutes, in which I have in≈øtanced, and could do in more, as in that wherein you are bound to be ≈øerved ≈øolum per Ma≈øculos, for want of which we found ≈øome ≈øcandals to have been brought upon the College by Ba≈øtard Children, and will you not ≈øuffer the King who alone hath Power to do it, to give you a Di≈øpen≈øation in others? Can he who is ≈øo tender of his Honor put up ≈øuch Indignities as the≈øe? And can we who are intru≈øted with the vindication of
it, ≈øuffer this to go unpuni≈øhed? I wi≈øh you had half ≈øo much kindne≈øs and Charity for your ≈øelves, and ≈øo great a con≈øideration of the happine≈øs of this Foundation, as His Maje≈øty and his Commi≈ø≈øioners have already expre≈øt in their dealings with it. The Ju≈øtice and Equity whereof (if you do not) all good Men will Proclaim. I need not remind you of putting in ≈øome Papers under your hands, which would have been Aggravations of the former Contempts, which upon better thoughts you de≈øired, and we gave you leave to withdraw. What other Men, who are led by Populacy (which is the Fools Paradi≈øe, but the Wi≈øe Mans ≈øcorn) ≈øay of us while we are doing our Duty to God and the King, we value no no more than what they dream of us: For we ≈øet a greater e≈øtimate upon our own Duty than other Mens thoughts, and will di≈øcharge our Con≈øciences faithfully, what≈øoever becomes of our Credit. We can allow tho≈øe who are di≈ø-affected to the Crown and to the Church of England, to talk of us at their own Rate; we ≈øhall vindicate the Kings Authority, and redeem it from Contempt by all Ju≈øt and Lawful means; But yet Gentlemen, the great concern we have for you, and our earne≈øt de≈øign to re≈øcue you out of danger (if you are not ≈øturdily re≈øolved to ca≈øt away your ≈øelves) obliges us to offer you once for all, that if you will freely and pre≈øently make ≈øuch ≈øubmi≈ø≈øion to His Sacred Maje≈øty, as the Heinou≈øne≈øs of your Offences do's in our Judgment require, we will pa≈øs by your faults, and recommend you heartily to Gods and the Kings Mercy, and accordingly we require the Deputy Regi≈øter to Read the Form of ≈øuch a ≈øubmi≈ø≈øion to you, as the Court upon mature deliberation hath judged nece≈ø≈øary for them to expect,
and require in Point of Ju≈øtice as an expiation for all the former di≈ø-obedience and contempts, of which they have found you guilty; which they that are willing and well re≈øolved, may immediately Sign, and the re≈øt of you are Commanded to withdraw, excepting Dr. Thomas Smith and Mr. Charnock, with who≈øe good behaviour towards His Sacred Maje≈øty, in the concern before mentioned, we declare our ≈øelves to be well ≈øatisfied, and doubt not, but that His Maje≈øty will be ≈øo too when we ≈øhall have further occa≈øion to repre≈øent it to him.

div.head: ¬ß. 3.
div.p: After the Bi≈øhops Speech all were ordered to withdraw, Regi≈øter. except the Fellows, and the Form of a Submi≈ø≈øion was ordered to be Read to them, in the words following.

div.head: To the Kings Mo≈øt Excellent Maje≈øty.
The Humble Petition and Submi≈ø≈øion of the Fellows of St. Mary Magdalen College in the ∆≤niver≈øity of Oxford, who≈øe Names are Sub≈øcribed.
div.p:
WE your Maje≈øties mo≈øt humble Petitioners, having a deep ≈øen≈øe of being ju≈øtly fallen under your Maje≈øties di≈øplea≈øure, for our di≈øobedience and contempt to your Maje≈øty, and to the Authority of your Maje≈øties Commi≈ø≈øioners and Vi≈øitors; We do in all humility pro≈øtrate our ≈øelves at your Maje≈øties Feet, humbly begging your Pardon for our ≈øaid Offences, and promi≈øing that we will for the future behave our ≈øelves more Dutifully, and for a Te≈øtimony thereof, we do acknowledge the Authority
of your Maje≈øties ≈øaid Vi≈øitors, and the Ju≈øtice of their Proceedings, and we do declare our entire Submi≈ø≈øion to the Lord Bi≈øhop of Oxon as our Pre≈øident.

He then told them, that their Sub≈øcribing the ≈øame was the only means that could recommend them to His Maje≈øties favour. But all the Fellows to whom the ≈øaid ≈øubmi≈ø≈øion was propo≈øedDr. Thomas Smith had not the Que≈øtion propo≈øed to him, having been ab≈øent from the College during the heat of the conte≈øt, and wholly unconcerned in it, by which it appears how fal≈øe the Oxford Relation, p. 37. 38. is. (being ≈øeverally ask't the Que≈øtion) peremptorily refu≈øed to ≈øub≈øcribe. Mr. Thomp≈øon de≈øired to be excu≈øed from ≈øub≈øcribing, for that he had given his Vote for Mr. Farmer, and had not concurred with the Society in any thing they had done ≈øince in this bu≈øine≈øs, and declared that he never had been di≈øobedient nor ever would be, whereupon their Lord≈øhips excu≈øed him.

div.head: ¬ß. 4.
div.p: Dr. Aldworth de≈øired, The Oxford Relation is thus p. 37. 38. in the Name of him≈øelf and the Fellows, time to con≈øider of the ≈øubmi≈ø≈øion, and give their An≈øwer in Writing, to whom the Bi≈øhop of Che≈øter ≈øaid, they mu≈øt every one Sign or Refu≈øe as they were called; And Baron Jenner ≈øaid, there was no An≈øwer to be given, but Yea or No: They all moved again for time, but it was denyed; then Dr. Aldworth ≈øaid, My Lords, this is my fir≈øt appearance before your Lord≈øhips ≈øince your ≈øitting here, therefore I pray to be heard.

My Lords, I am as ready to comply with the Kings Plea≈øure as any Man living, neither do I know that we have ever in this place been di≈øobedient to the King, when ever 'twas in our Power to obey his Commands. Our Founder, in the fir≈øt Clau≈øe of the Oath we take at the Election, hath provided,
that no one ≈øhall be Pre≈øident of this College, but who was bred in this, or in the College wherein he him≈øelf was bred, now for us who have Elected Dr. Hough, a Per≈øon Qualified according to our Statutes, who hath been In≈øtalled, Sworn, Confirmed and Approved of in all the ways and manners pre≈øcribed in the Statutes: For us my Lord to accept and admit of a Stranger and a Forreigner in his place, is to the be≈øt of my under≈øtanding a giving up the Rights of the College to other u≈øes than the Founder de≈øigned it‚ÄîHere Dr. Aldworth was Interrupted by the Bi≈øhop of Che≈øter, ≈øaying, the Statutes were overruled by the Kings Authority, or words to that effect. To which the Dr. An≈øwered, your Lord≈øhips ≈øit here as Vi≈øitors, which Implies there are certain Laws, and Statutes which we are bound to ob≈øerve, and by which we are to be Governed, and if it ≈øhall appear to your Lord≈øhips, that we have Acted conformable to tho≈øe Statutes, I hope we ≈øhall neither incur the Kings di≈øplea≈øure nor your Lord≈øhips; The whole Tenor of our Statutes run, that we ≈øhould Inviolably maintain our Right, and ob≈øerve the Rules of our Founder. He has laid his Cur≈øe upon us if we vary from them, here he repeated the words; Ordinamus ≈øub poena Anathematis & Indignationis Omnipotentis Dei ne quis, &c. Item ≈øub Interminatione Divini Judicis Interdicimus.

To which the Bi≈øhop of Che≈øter reply'd, are you not to obey the King as well as your Founders Statutes? To this the Vice-Pre≈øident An≈øwered, I ever did obey the King, and ever will do: our Statutes which we are Sworn to are Confirmed by ≈øeveral Kings and Queens before and ≈øince the Reformation, and as we keep them are agreeable to the Kings Laws
both Eccle≈øia≈øtical and Civil,Whil≈øt we live up to them, ≈øaith the Printed Relation. and whil≈øt we keep up to 'em we obey the King. The Bi≈øhop of Che≈øter reply'd, the Statutes were never Confirmed by his pre≈øent Maje≈øty, to which Dr. John Smith ≈øaid, neither have they been Repealed by His Maje≈øty,The Mandate being an Inhibition repeals them for the pre≈øent time by Di≈øpen≈øation. and what is not Repealed is Confirmed; After this their Lord≈øhips pre≈ø≈øing either to Sign or Refu≈øe, Dr. Aldworth ≈øaid, My Lords I'll deal plainly in regard to my Oath and the Statutes, to the Right of all our Succe≈ø≈øors and of Dr. Hough, whom I believe to be as fairly ElectedThis was a bold A≈ø≈øertion and I hope to prove it as fal≈øe. and as Legally Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed as ever any ≈øince the Foundation of the College: I cannot ≈øubmit to the Bi≈øhop of Oxon as Pre≈øident, ≈øo he was ordered to withdraw.

After this, the ≈øame Que≈øtion was put to all the Fellows ≈øingly, who all refu≈øed to Sign the ≈øubmi≈ø≈øion except Dr. Thomas Smith and Mr. Charnock, who were not pre≈ø≈øed having as their Lord≈øhips ≈øaid behaved them≈øelves Dutifully towards the King Mr. Thomp≈øon de≈øired to be excu≈øed from ≈øub≈øcribing, for that he had given his Vote for Mr. Farmer, and had not concurred with the Society in any thing they had done ≈øince in this bu≈øine≈øs, and declared he never had been di≈øobedient nor ever would be. Then their Lord≈øhips produced a Petition ≈øent to the Earl of Sunderland upon the report of the Kings Mandate for Mr. Farmer, which he had Signed, therefore pre≈ø≈øed further his ≈øub≈øcribing the ≈øubmi≈ø≈øion. This he owned, but ≈øaid, it was before the Kings Mandate was produced, but after it was ≈øhewn at the Election he Voted for Mr. Farmer in obedience to the Kings Command, and promi≈øed to obey the Bi≈øhop of Oxford, whereupon their Lord≈øhips excu≈øed him.

div.head: ¬ß. 5.
div.p: Then the Lords called for the Buttry-Book and cau≈øed all the Names of tho≈øe Fellows, who refu≈øed to ≈øub≈øcribe, to be ≈øtruck out, and the Fellows ≈øo ≈øtruck out being called in, the Sentence of Expul≈øion was Read to them in this Form.

div.head: By His Maje≈øties Commi≈ø≈øioners for Eccle≈øia≈øtical Cau≈øes and for Vi≈øiting of the Univer≈øities, and all Cathedrals, and Collegiate Churches, Colleges, Grammar-Schools, Ho≈øpitals, and other the like Corporations or Foundations and Societies, and particularly impowered to Vi≈øit Magdalen College in the ∆≤niver≈øity of Oxford.
div.p:
WHereas in our Vi≈øitation of the ≈øaid College, it appeared to us, that Dr. Charles Aldworth, Dr. Alexander Pud≈øey, Dr. John Smith, Dr. Thomas Bayley, Dr. Thomas Stafford, Mr. Robert Almond, Mr. Mainwaring Hammond, Mr. John Rogers, Mr. Richard Strickland, Mr. Henry Dob≈øon, Mr. James Bayley, Mr. John Davies, Mr. Francis Bag≈øhaw, Mr. James Fayrer, Mr. Jo≈øeph Harwar, Mr. Thomas Bateman, Mr. George Hunt, Mr. William Cradock, Mr. John Gilman, Mr. George Fulham, Mr. Charles Peny≈øton, Mr. Robert Hyde, Mr. Edward Yerbury, Mr. Henry Holden, Mr. Stephen Weelks, Fellows of the ≈øaid College, have been ≈øeverally guilty of di≈øobedience to His Maje≈øties Command, and ob≈øtinately contemned His Maje≈øties Royal Authority, and do ≈øtill per≈øi≈øt in the ≈øame: We have thought fit, upon mature con≈øideration hereof, to declare, pronounce, and decree, that the ≈øaid Dr. Charles Aldworth, &c. and every of them be Deprived and Expelled from their re≈øpective Fellow≈øhips, and we do by this our Sentence and Decree, Deprive and Expel them from their ≈øaid
≈øeveral re≈øpective Fellow≈øhips.

closer.dateline: Given under our Seal the 16th. of November 1687.

div.p: About Twelve a Clock, as ≈øoon as their Lord≈øhips ro≈øe, the Decree for the Expul≈øion of the≈øe Twenty Five Fellows was fixed on the College Gates in the Form afore≈øaid.

div.head: ¬ß. 6. The Expelled Fellows give in their Prote≈øtation again≈øt the Lords Commi≈ø≈øioners Decree.
div.p: The Fellows under-named then gave in Papers ≈øub≈øcribed by them≈øelves to the Lords Commi≈ø≈øioners in this Form.

I Do profe≈øs all Duty to His Maje≈øty, and re≈øpect to your Lord≈øhips, but beg leave to declare that I think my ≈øelf injured in your Lord≈øhips Proceedings, and therefore Prote≈øt again≈øt them, and will u≈øe all Ju≈øt and Legal ways of being relieved.

signed.hi: Others de≈øired that the like Prote≈øtation might be entred for them

div.p:
Then their Lord≈øhips Ordered them to withdraw,Regi≈øter. and proceeded to Admit others into their places, and in order thereunto, called for tho≈øe who were recommended by His Maje≈øties Mandates,viz. Dated 11. November. Mr. Charles Goring, Mr. Thomas Higgons, Dated 12. Nov. 1687. Nov. 13. 1687. Mr.Fairfax, Mr. Robert Hill, Mr. John Warburton, Mr. Francis Ha≈ølewood and Mr. Lawrence Wood. But none
of them appeared except Mr. Thomas Higgons, whereupon their Lord≈øhips ≈øent for three of the Demys, viz. Mr. Samuel Jenefar, Mr. Mander and Mr. Han≈øon, and the two la≈øt de≈øiring to continue Demys, their Lord≈øhips Admitted Mr. Higgons and Mr. Jenefar Fellows, they taking the u≈øual Oath of a Fellow.

Then Mr. Bradley Whalley, Mr. Walter Wal≈øh and Mr. Midleton were called, but Mr. Midleton not appearing, Mr. Whalley and Mr. Wal≈øh were Admitted Demys and took the Oath of a Demy, and their Names were entred in the Buttry-Book.

Then their Lord≈øhips took into their con≈øideration the Ca≈øe of the ab≈øent Fellows; & the non-appearance of Mr. Maynard, Mr. Hicks and Mr. Goodwin ≈øeeming excu≈øable, by the Certificates produced and Oaths made in their behalfs, and al≈øo it appearing that they and Mr. Francis Smith (who is Travelling abroad) had not been any ways concerned in the whole Affair, their Lord≈øhips thought fit to excu≈øe them: And left the Expul≈øion of the re≈øt, viz. Mr. Hawks, Mr. Holt and Mr. Thornton to the Pre≈øident, who they conceived had full Power to Expell them, if hereafter at their return to the College they ≈øhould refu≈øe to make their ≈øubmi≈ø≈øion in the ≈øame manner as propo≈øed to the re≈øt of the Fellows, and ≈øo the Lords Commi≈ø≈øioners concluded.
What followed after their Lord≈øhips return to London.

div.head: ¬ß. 7. What was done by the Lords Commi≈ø≈øioners at Whitehall.
div.p: Out of the Regi≈øter.At a Court held in the Council Chamber at Whitehall the 28th. of November 1687. Pre≈øent the Lord Chancellor, Lord Pre≈øident, Lord Chamberlain, the Bi≈øhops of Dure≈øm, Roche≈øter and Che≈øter, the Lord Chief Ju≈øtice Wright, the Lord Chief Ju≈øtice Herbers and Mr. Baron Jenner.

The further Account of the Proceedings of the Vi≈øitation of St. Mary Magdalen College in Oxford was Read, upon which it was moved,The Lords Commi≈ø≈øioners re≈øolution to Incapacitate the Expelled Fellows, &c. that the Expelled Fellows ≈øhould be further proceeded again≈øt by a Sentence of Incapacity. The Lords upon debate were of Opinion, that the ≈øaid Fellows ought to be incapacitated from receiving any Eccle≈øia≈øtical Preferments for the future, and direct that Mr. Sollicitor General, Sir Robert Baldock, Sir Thomas Pinfold and Dr. Hedges ≈øhall Attend the next Morning at Nine of the Clock upon this matter.
At a Court, &c. the 29th. of November 1687. Mr. Sollicitor General, Sir Robert Baldock, Sir Thomas Pinfold and Dr. Hedges attend and have the following Paper delivered to them.

The Lords think it requi≈øite, that the Fellows lately Expelled out of St. Mary Magdalen College ≈øhould be Incapacitated from receiving any Eccle≈øia≈øtical Preferment for the time to come, and de≈øire you to con≈øider of the Method and be≈øt manner of proceeding herein.
Their Lord≈øhips appointed them to give them their Opinion upon the matter upon Munday next at Ten in the Morning, but the Meeting was put of till Thur≈øday the 8th. of December.

At a Court the 8th. of December 1687. Pre≈øent the Lord Chancellor, Lord Pre≈øident, Earl of Huntingdon, the Bi≈øhops of Dure≈øm, Roche≈øter and Che≈øter, the Lord Chief Ju≈øtice Wright and Baron Jenner.

Mr. Sollicitor General, Sir Robert Baldock, Sir Thomas Pinfold and Dr. Hedges, gave their An≈øwer
upon the Paper given them the 28th. of the la≈øt Month concerning the Fellows lately Expelled out of St. Mary Magdalen College, the Lords enter upon debate of the matter, and put off the further con≈øideration thereof till Saturday the 10th. In≈øtant, at Four in the Afternoon.
At a Court the 10th. of December 1687. The la≈øt mentioned Lords being pre≈øent.
The Lords re-a≈ø≈øume the Debate concerning the Fellows lately Expelled out of St. Mary Magdalen College, and agree upon the following Order.

div.head: ¬ß. 8.

opener.dateline: At a Council held in the Council Chamber at Whitehall the 10th. of December 1687.

Pre≈øent.

div.head: By His Maje≈øties Commi≈ø≈øioners for Eccle≈øia≈øtical Cau≈øes, and for the Vi≈øitation of the ∆≤niver≈øities, and of all and every Cathedral and Collegiate Churches, Colleges Grammar-Schools, Ho≈øpitals, and other the like Incorporations or Foundations and Societies.
div.p:
WHereas we thought fit by our Order of the 22d. The Sentence of Incapacitating. Day of June la≈øt to declare and decree that the pretended Election of Mr. John Hough (now Dr. John Hough) to the Pre≈øident≈øhip of St. Mary Magdalen College in the Univer≈øity of Oxon was void, and therefore did amove the ≈øaid Mr. Hough from the place of Pre≈øident of the ≈øaid College.
And whereas the Fellows of the ≈øame were likewi≈øe Convened before us for their di≈øobedience to and Contempt of His Maje≈øties Authority by making the ≈øaid pretended Election, and it now appearing unto us, that the ≈øaid Dr. John Hough, Dr. Charles Aldworth, Dr. Henry Fairfax, Dr. Alexander Pud≈øey, Dr. John Smith, Dr. Thomas Bayley, Dr. Thomas Stafford, Mr. Robert Almond, Mr. Mainwaring Hammond, Mr. John Rogers, Mr. Richard Strickland, Mr. Henry Dob≈øon, Mr. James Bayley, Mr. John Davys, Mr. Francis Bag≈øhaw, Mr. James Fayrer, Mr. Jo≈øeph Harwar, Mr. Thomas Bateman, Mr. George Hunt, Mr. William Cradock, Mr. John Gilman, Mr. George Fulham, Mr. Charles Penni≈øton, Mr. Robert Hyde, Mr. Edward Yerbury, Mr. Henry Holden and Mr. Stephen Weelks, lately Fellows of the ≈øaid College do per≈øi≈øt in their di≈øobedience and contempt, we have thought fit, upon mature con≈øideration of the matter, to Declare, Decree, and Pronounce, and we do accordingly Declare, Decree and Pronounce, that the ≈øaid Dr. John Hough, Dr. Charles Aldworth, &c. as before recited, and every of them ≈øhall be and from henceforth they are hereby declared and adjudged Incapable of Receiving or being Admitted to any Eccle≈øia≈øtical Dignity, Benefice or Promotion, and that ≈øuch and every of them who are not as yet in Holy Orders, ≈øhall be and are hereby declared and adjudged uncapable of Receiving and being Admitted into the ≈øame. And all Arch-Bi≈øhops, Bi≈øhops and other Eccle≈øia≈øtical Officers and Mini≈øters within the Realm of England are hereby required to take notice of this our Sentence, Order and Decree, and to yield Obedience thereunto.

closer.dateline: Given under our Seal the 10th. Day of December 1687.

div.p: The Lords agreed to ≈øend a Duplicate of the foregoing Order under their Seals to every Arch-Bi≈øhop and Bi≈øhop, which accordingly was done.

Thus I have drawn to a Conclu≈øion the whole Proceedings concerning this College, as to the Declaring Void the Election of Dr. Hough, and the Su≈øpending of Dr. Aldworth and Dr. Fairfax by the Lords Commi≈ø≈øioners at Whitehall, and the Expelling the forenamed Fellows by the Lords Vi≈øitors at Oxford, together with this Finall Decree of Incapacitating them by the Lords Commi≈ø≈øioners at Whitehall in Conjunction with the Lords Vi≈øitors at Oxford.
I ≈øhall now proceed to give an Hi≈øtorical Account of the Nature of the Societies, or Incorporations, called Colleges and Univer≈øities.

Secondly, Some Vi≈øitations of the Univer≈øities of Oxford, or particular Colleges by Legatine, Metropolitical, Epi≈øcopal, or Local Vi≈øitors, or by the Immediate Authority of the Kings of England from Age to Age.
Thirdly, Several In≈øtances of the Kings of Englands Di≈øpen≈øations with the Statutes of Univer≈øities or particular Colleges.
Fourthly, I ≈øhall An≈øwer the Objections.

div.head: CHAP. III.

argument.p: Of the Nature and Con≈øtitution of the Societies of the Liberal Arts, ≈øuch as Colleges and Univer≈øities are.

div.head: SECT. I.

argument.p: Concerning Incorporations in General and the Privileges granted to the ∆≤niver≈øities of Oxford and Cambridge by our Kings or the Popes.

div.head: ¬ß. 1. All ≈øorts of Societies and Corporations are Founded by the King.
div.p: BEfore I Treat of the Royal Foundation, or the particular Charters, or Bulls granted to the Univer≈øity of Oxford, I think it convenient, as a Preliminary, to give the Ingenuous Reader a ≈øhort abridgment of what our Common Lawyers have delivered how the Incorporations of this Kingdom are all Con≈øtituted by the Kings of England, Priviledged from the Crown, and are at the ≈øole Will and Plea≈øure of the Sovereign who may at his plea≈øure for mi≈ø-u≈øer, non-u≈øer, or abu≈øer di≈ø≈øolve them according to Common-Law. Fir≈øt of the Subject matter of ≈øuch Incorporations.

A Corporation is the ≈øame according to Lib. 2. fol. 5. 6. Coke 10 Rep. 29. The Ancient and Modern u≈øe of the word Univer≈øity. Bracton which the Civilians Style Collegium or Univer≈øity; Si Rex conce≈ø≈øerit, ≈øays he, alicui ∆≤niver≈øitati, ≈øicut Civibus & Burgen≈øibus, ≈øo that in his time an Incorporation by the Name of Citizens and Burge≈ø≈øes was called an Univer≈øity, in the ≈øame Sen≈øe that Communitas was Styled, ≈øignifying any Society that was
under ≈øome ≈øpecial Denomination, ≈øo Bodinns ≈øaith, by the word Collegium no particular Society is determined, but under that Name Corporations of ≈øeveral natures are contained, and whether Lay or Eccle≈øia≈øtical is ≈øpecified by the ends for which they are Con≈øtituted; but now the word is generally re≈øtrained to the Academies of the Liberal Arts.

‚òû All Natural per≈øons, Coke 10. Rep. fol. 14. Of the Con≈øtituting parts of a Corporation. as ≈øuch, are capable of holding or taking this Right of a Politic Capacity, and as all the natural per≈øons are an E≈ø≈øential part con≈øtituting the Body Politic21 E. 4. fol. 22. ≈øo all the operations and exerci≈øe of the Rights are only performed by the Natural per≈øons.

Therefore when the Que≈øtion is of non-u≈øer or abu≈øer of Franchi≈øes by a Corporation, it mu≈øt of nece≈ø≈øity be intended for ≈øome ActAtturny Generals Argument for Quo Warranto again≈øt London. fol. 2. or negligence of the Natural per≈øons, or tho≈øe Officers imployed by them: For whatever Franchi≈øes any per≈øons enjoy they do it as U≈øu-fructuaries.

div.head: ¬ß. 2. How all Colleges and Corporations are made ≈øuch by the Sovereign.
div.p: It is to be con≈øidered, that ≈øuch Societies ought to be Con≈øtituted by none but the Sovereign, otherwi≈øe the Government would be in danger, if Liberty were granted for per≈øons to enter into Combinations: For however ≈øpecious they might at fir≈øt make the end of their uniting, yet they might abu≈øe the Power to the detriment of the Common-weal, therefore in the Dige≈øts we find the Law thusLege neque Societas i. f. quod cuju≈øcum que ∆≤niver≈øitatis. neque Societas, neque Collegium, neque huju≈ømodi Corpus, pa≈ø≈øim omnibus habere conceditur nam & legibus & Senatus-con≈øultis & principalibus con≈øtitutionibus eares coercetur. Agreeable to which I find in the Letter from King Edward to the Pope in behalf of the Univer≈øity, that it enjoysIn Regia Benevolentia recumbit ≈øpeciali. Rot. Rom.11. E. 2. M. 14. Intus. it's Privileges by ≈øpecial Royal Benevolence.

By the Con≈øtitution of our Laws this Right, as all Juri≈ødiction and Franchi≈øes are, is Lodged in the Crown, and thence only derived; SoRex habet omnia Jura in manu ≈øu√¢e quae ad Coronam & ad Laitatem pertinent, pote≈øtatem, & Regni Gubernaculum. Habet etiam Ju≈øtitiam & Judicium quae ≈øunt Juri≈ødictiones; habet etiam ea quae ad pacem pertinent. Ea quae dicuntur privilegia, licet pertinent ad Coronam, po≈ø≈øunt ad privatas per≈øonas transferri, ≈øed de gratia ip≈øius Regis ≈øpeciali. Bracton upon the Que≈øtion quis concedere pote≈øt libertates & quibus, & qualiter referuntur, thus re≈øolves it. The King ≈øaith he, hath all the Rights in his own Hands which appertain to the Crown and his Lay-Power, and the Government of the Kingdom. He hath al≈øo Ju≈øtice, and Judgment, which are Juri≈ødictions, and tho≈øe things which appeartain to Peace.
He further ob≈øerves, that tho≈øe things which are called Privileges, tho' they appertain to the Crown, may be transferred to private per≈øons, but of the ≈øpecial Grace only of the King.

‚òû All the Law Books Unanimou≈øly agree, that none can make Corporations but the49 E. 3.4.49. A≈ø≈ø. 8. King, and ≈øuch Power cannot be pre≈øcribed, for it inherent in the Crown: Therefore Sir Edward Co. 10. Rep. f. 33. b. Coke calls them Creatures of the Crown.

The Nature of ≈øomeAtturny Generals Argument for the Quo Warranto Ms. p. 9. Corporations is to be Con≈øtituted by the King alone, as the Dean and Chapters, Majors and Commonality; ≈øome have been by the Popes alone, and ≈øome mixt by the King for the Temporal Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, by the Pope for their Spirituality. However the King is ≈øtill the Donor, Fountain, and Spring from whence the≈øe and all other Liberties flow.

div.head: ¬ß. 3. Things requi≈øite to a Corporation.
div.p:
My Suttons Ho≈øp. fol. 29. Lord Coke ≈øaith there are Four things, that are of the E≈ø≈øence of a Corporation: Fir≈øt a Legal Authority, which he ≈øaith is Four ways; Fir≈øt, By Common Law as by the King alone, which therefore
is ≈øaid to be by Common Law as the mo≈øt known and regular way; Secondly, By Authority of Parliament; Thirdly, by the Kings Charter; Fourthly, By pre≈øcription; which in effect are all by the King: for what is by Act of Parliament is certainly ≈øo, and what is by pre≈øcription is pre≈øumed to have obtained a Grant from the Crown, which in proce≈øs of time hath been lo≈øt and ≈øo by the Tacit allowance and con≈øent of Succe≈ø≈øive Kings acquires a Right. His other E≈ø≈øential parts are in the Operative words, of which there is no need to di≈øcour≈øe here.

‚òû By the Statute of Merton Id. p. 26. b. no Grant of Lands to Pious or Charitable u≈øes are good without the Kings Licence: For this purpo≈øe, the Kings Grant is ab≈øolutly nece≈ø≈øary, for that it was ≈øolely in his Power to Grant, and the Donor of the Lands without the King can do nothing to e≈øtabli≈øh a perpetuity.

Without capacitating, the Incorporating cannot be effected, for the Inhabitants of a Village or City are ≈øingle per≈øons, which are not in a Capacity to take any Lands in Succe≈ø≈øion (the like is to be ≈øaid of Liberties, Privileges and Immunities) but only to their Singular Heirs, but ≈øuch Inhabitants are in a Capacity to be Incorporated by the King, and after ≈øuch an Incorporation to have a Succe≈ø≈øion of Lands, Tenements and Hereditaments.

div.head: ¬ß. 4. The end of Corporations.
div.p: ‚òû The general intent and end of all Civil Incorporations, allowed by the Policy of the LawAtturny Generals Argument ut ≈øupra. is in order to better Government, ≈øub≈øervient to the Oeconomy of the whole by ≈øuch pre≈øcribed Rules as the Kings of England have been Graciou≈øly plea≈øed to limit them by, which as Emergences happened might be altered by the ≈øame Power that be≈øtowed them.

‚òû Bi≈øhop Saunder≈øon Quum ex conce≈ø≈øione principum, idque ex gratia ≈øpeciali corporentur i≈øti ‚Ä¢ s modi Societates, nec aliis gaudeant juribus privilegiis vel pote≈øtate extra ea quae vel ex diuturna temporis prae≈øcriptione vel ex chartis diplomatibu≈øque Regiis con≈øtare pote≈øt fui≈ø≈øe ≈øibi conce≈ø≈øa. De obligatione Con≈øcientiae praelect. 7. ≈øect. 28. according to his Judicious way of expre≈ø≈øing matters, ≈øaith the Sodalities, Bodies Corporate, or Colleges are as Members of the great Body the Kingdom or Common-wealth, and are contained in it as the Inferior Orbs of the Heavens are in the Superior. That the≈øe are Incorporated by the Grants of Princes of their ≈øpecial Grace; and enjoy not any Rights, Privileges or Powers be≈øides tho≈øe which by pre≈øcription of long time, or from Royal Charters, it appears they have had Granted to them. Therefore whatever Power they have of making any Laws for their Government, it is derivative and no way Primitive, and is ultimately re≈øolved into the Supreme Regal Power as it's true Original. Therefore ≈øuch like Societies or their Magi≈øtrates, cannot at their own Arbitrament con≈øtitue or exerci≈øe any Power in making Laws, but according to the manner and mea≈øure of the faculty Indulged to them by the Prince.

‚òû Hence it is, that whoever is the Founder of a College, the King calls it upon all occa≈øions Our College, and the Members likewi≈øe in all Applications to the King ≈øay Your College, for tho' the particular Founder give the Land, yet as it is a College, or Corporation the King is the Founder.

‚òû So it isPatrick Ca≈øe Trinit. 18. Car. 2. Keble Rep. 2d. St. fol. 65. vouched for Law, that the King without the Ordinary may Erect Univer≈øities, and this is not a Prerogative our Kings only enjoy, but we find it frequently in the Grants of the Modern Roman Emperors and Kings.

div.head: ¬ß. 5. The Power of conferring Degrees in Univer≈øities conferred on Subjects.
div.p:
Examples of the Emperors giving Power to Count Palatines, to make Doctors in Divinity, Law, Phy≈øic, and Philo≈øophy, (which are the peculiar Degrees conferred by Univer≈øities qu√¢ ∆≤niver≈øities by
the Grants of Privilege from their re≈øpective Sovereigns, may be found in Tho.
The≈øi. 22. &c. Sagittarius, cited by Mr. Selden.

‚òû So Rudolphus the ≈øecond Emperor of Germany Sacri Lateranen≈øis Palatii Aulaeque no≈øtrae Cae≈øariae & Imperialis, Con≈øi≈øtorii Comitu‚Äî Doctores, Licentiatos, & Baccalaureos in utreque Jure Magistros, item & Baccalaureos Liberalium Artium, & Philosophiae, nec non Poetas Laureatos Creare, Promovere Ordinare Con≈øtituere & facere Selden, Tit. Ho. ca. 1. ≈øect. 2. fol. 398. granted by Patent to George Obrichtus, and his Son Thomas, both Profe≈ø≈øors of Law at Strasburgh, the Father being Primar Profe≈ø≈øor there, that they ≈øhould be ≈øucce≈ø≈øively Counts of the Holy Lateran Palace, and of the Cae≈øarian hall and Imperial Con≈øi≈øtory, and that they have Authority to create, promote, ordain, and con≈øtitute and make Doctors, Licentiates, and Bachelors in both the Laws, Ma≈øters and Bachelors of the Liberal Arts, and Philo≈øophy, and likewi≈øe Poets Laureats, with all and ≈øingular Privileges, Prerogatives, Exemptions, Honors, Preeminences, Favors Indulgences, and Graces what≈øoever, the like Graduates in Vienna, Paris, &c. enjoy, &c. Dated at Prague the 19th. of November, 36 Regni 1610.

Maximilian the Second Emperor,Tho. Sagittarius ad The≈ø. 13. by his Letters Patents Dated at Prague the 9th. of May 1575. created Henry Julius the fir≈øt Rector of the Univer≈øity of Helme≈øtadt and his Succe≈ø≈øors to be cho≈øen into the ≈øaid Office and Dignity, and into the Titles of Counts Palatines, and made him the fir≈øt Rector.

So Rodulphus the Second GrantsIdem ad The≈ø. 22. to Nicholas Reu≈ønerus, Power of making Doctors as well in Divinity as in Law, Phy≈øick, and Philo≈øophy, and ≈øometimes the Clau≈øe is addedAdhibit is in cujus libit Doctoris creatione Doctoribus eximiis de profe≈ø≈øione creandi ad minus tribus, qui Doctorandum examini ≈øubiiciant. that ≈øuch Counts Palatines ≈øhall call to them at lea≈øt three Eminent
Doctors of the Faculty, that the Doctor to be Created Profe≈ø≈øeth, who ≈øhall examin him that is to be Created Doctor.
By all which it appears, that the Sovereign Impowers per≈øons to confer the Univer≈øity Degrees.

div.head: SECT. II.

argument.p: From whom the ∆≤niver≈øity of Oxford hath had all its Privileges.

div.head: ¬ß. 1. The Kings of England ≈øole Donors of the Privileges during the Saxons times.
div.p: HAving di≈øpatched what I thought fit to clear the point, that the Kings of England have the ≈øole prerogative in their Dominions to make all ≈øorts of Corporations: I now proceed to produce ≈øuch Te≈øtimonies as I have found, that the Univer≈øity of Oxford pimarily owe all their privileges qu√¢ an Univer≈øity to the King ≈øolely, as the Donor or allower of them.

King Alfred Reigned, according to our be≈øt Hi≈øtorians, 800 Years fince, and is owned by all to be the great Re≈øtorer of the Univer≈øity of Oxford. In the the MSS life of St. Neotus commonly called St. Needes, as Cited byAntiq. Gla≈øton. Malmsbury, Tom. 3. p. 11.
Leland and others, Alfred is ≈øaid to have Founded public Schools for Arts and Sciences, and Lodgings for the Students, and repleni≈øhed them with the Young Nobility: And John Lib. de Regibus. Ro≈øs of Warwick tells us, that he Founded one for Grammar, one for Arts, and a third for Divinity.

‚òû It is likewi≈øe RecordedGul. Malmsb. de Antiq. Mo. Gla≈øton. MSS Ranulph Hygden. lib. 2. of him, that he delivered to the Univer≈øity Laws and whole≈øome Statutes
for their Government, and adorned them with privileges, which he confirmed by his Royal Charter, and obtained from Pope Martin the Second about the Year 883. that they ≈øhould be confirmed according asLib. vita Neoti. To. 4. Balaeus Cent. 2. No. 23. St. Neotus had before reque≈øted from the Pope.
He was ≈øo great a Benefactor, that it is RecordedWood Antiq. Oxon. fol. 13. of him, that he gave an Eighth part of his Revenues to maintain Scholars and the Lectures in the Schools.

To pa≈øs by many Saxon Kings, who≈øe favors to this Univer≈øity are recited byId. a fol. 2. ad 42. Mr. Wood in his Elaborate Hi≈øtory of the University of Oxford; It is recordedScholas publicas per urbes oppidaque Regni con≈øtitutas e Fi≈øco Regio Stipendiis po≈øuerit. Hi≈øt. Aurea par. 2. lib. 22. c. 28. MSS. of Canutus, Succe≈ø≈øor to King Edmund, that he placed public Schools in the Cities and Borroughs of the Kingdom, appointing Stipends for them out of his Trea≈øury.

Altho' Harold the Fir≈øt took away from theLeland To. 4. p. 199. Schools the Stipends, and the Lands from the Univer≈øity about 1036. yet Edward the Confe≈ø≈øor about 1042. re≈øtored again the Goods of the Religious, and of the Profe≈ø≈øors of Ingenuous Arts by EdictGul. Lambard in Archainomia Edit. 1568. fol. 126. b. in who≈øe ≈øoever Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion they were. So that here is both an Example of a Kings ≈øeizing all the Revenues and con≈øequently the liberties, and anothers re≈øtoring them to the Univer≈øity.

div.head: ¬ß. 2.
div.p: King Henry the Fir≈øt Anno 1130. Built his Palace at Bellamont, and kept his Ea≈øter there,Privilegia tam varia ∆≤niver≈øitati ≈øimul urbique Indul≈øi≈ø≈øe creditur Heuricus quae deperdita quamvis olim funt, in Succe≈ø≈øirum tamen ejus Chartis aliquando memorantur, Wood Antiq. Oxon. fol. 49. My Author ≈øaith, he is believed to have granted ≈øeveral privileges to the Univer≈øity and City of Oxford, which tho' they be long ≈øince lo≈øt, yet they are remembred in his Succe≈ø≈øors Charters.

Anno 1134. Mr. Robert Pulleyn Leland To. 4. pa. 140. flouri≈øhed in that Univer≈øity, he was made Cardinal of St. Eu≈øebius by Pope Caele≈øtine the Second, and by Lucius the Seventh was Chancellor, and was, ≈øaith my Author, in ≈øo great e≈øteem with the King and the Pope,The Pope confirms the privileges granted by former Kings. that he obtained Bulls and Grants both for Defending the Univer≈øities privileges, and the Admini≈øtring the Univer≈øity it ≈øelf.

‚òû Anno 1229. 13 H. 3. There happening a great Sedition betwixt the Univer≈øity and Citizens of Paris, ≈øo that the Schollars ≈øhut up their Schools, and ≈øome withdrew them≈øelves to Anjou, others to Rhemes and Orleance,
∆≤nde Ve≈øtrae duximus ∆≤niver≈øitati ≈øignificandum quod ≈øi vobis placet ad Regnum no≈øtrum Angliae vos transferre, & in ea cau≈øa Studii moram facere. Civitates, Burgos, vel Villas qua≈øcunque velitis Elegere, vobis ad hoc a≈ø≈øignabimus, & omni mod√¢, ≈øicut decet, libertate & tranquilitate, qua deo placeri & vobis plene ≈øufficere debeat, vos gaudere faciamus. Rol. Pat. 13. H. 3. m. b. King Henry the third by his Letters Patents Dated at Reading the 14th. of July 1229. Invited them to come into England to Study and chu≈øe what Cities, Burroughs, or Villages they pleas'd, which the King would a≈ø≈øign to them, and cau≈øe them to enjoy all fitting Liberty and Tranquility which to the plea≈øure of God might be ≈øufficient for them, by which the Kings power of Founding new Univer≈øities is manife≈øt.

Anno 1242. 26 H. 3. The King being to go to Ga≈øcoign, having a care of the Univer≈øity of Oxford, Pote≈øtatem, datis ad eo≈ødem literis, fecit Querimonias clericorum accipiendi & quod ex u≈øu maxime ∆≤niver≈øitati e≈ø≈øet, Statuendi Pat 26 H. 3. m. 5. gave Power by his Letters Patents to Gualter Arch-Bi≈øhop of York, William de Cantilupe and William de Eboraco to receive complaints of the Clerks in the Univer≈øity, and to appoint what might be mo≈øt of u≈øe to the Univer≈øity. This Arch-Bi≈øhop of York was Walter Grey, who was ≈øuch a Benefactor to the Univer≈øity, that a Yearly Ma≈øs, with Placebo and Dirige was appointed for him on St. Martins
Day, at which all the Regents were to be pre≈øent.

From this Record we may learn that, notwith≈øtanding any Power the Arch-Bi≈øhop of Canterbury, or the Bi≈øhop of Lincoln might by the Canons claim to Govern the Univer≈øity, yet the King by his Prerogative appoints ≈øpecial Guardians for them in his ab≈øence.

div.head: ¬ß. 3. King Henry the 3d. grants privileges during his plea≈øure.
div.p: Anno 1244. 28 H. 3. The King Grants for the quiet of the Students of the Univer≈øity of Oxford of his ≈øpecial Grace to the Chancellor and Univer≈øity, that during his plea≈øure, they ≈øhould enjoy ≈øeveral privileges in the cau≈øes of the Clerks to hold Pleas in all moveable contracts, notwith≈øtanding his prohibition, which was, that Secular Judges ≈øhould have no Cognizance of Spiritual matters, or on the contrary. Dated at Reading the 10th. of May 28 Regni.

By this it appears,Nata bene. that if ≈øuch privileges were granted of the Kings ≈øpecial Grace, and only during his plea≈øure, how much more mu≈øt it be judged requi≈øite that Statutes, which were to Govern Elections, &c. ≈øhould be at the Kings Liberty to continue them or ≈øu≈øpend them at his plea≈øure, but of this I ≈øhall treat more fully afterwards.
This very Charter now mentioned, is Judged by ≈øome to be the Ba≈øis and Foundation of the Bull of Boniface the Eighth, obtained a few Years after from him.

‚òû Here once for all the Learned Reader is to ob≈øerve, that as the Kings of England Granted to the Univer≈øity ≈øeveral Secular privileges, ≈øo the Popes granted them other Religious privileges by vertue of their place, Dignity, and Right Inve≈øted in them by the
Canons according to what may be found in theHanc in ≈øuper ∆≤niver≈øitatem Romanarum Pontificum & Diaece≈øanorum privilegiia multi modis adornatam ≈øic cel≈øitudo Regis ≈øublimavit. A. fol. 8. a. B. fol. 1. b. C. fol. 1. b. Hi≈øtory in≈øerted into the old Book of Statutes appertaining to the Chancellor and Proctors of Oxford, which runs thus. ‚Äî The Kings Highne≈øs Exalted this Univer≈øity being adorned with many privileges of the Roman Bi≈øhops and of the Diaece≈øans.

However tho' the Popes and the Diaece≈øans granted the Univer≈øity ≈øeveral privileges, yet I ≈øhall ≈øhew hereafter how the Kings of England have exerci≈øed a Sovereign power in all Affairs of the Univer≈øity, re≈øcinding, di≈øpen≈øing with, or confirming Statutes at their plea≈øure.

‚òû Anno 1249.Clau≈ø. 42. H. 3. M. 9. Wood Antiq. Ox. fol. 95. lib. 1. Upon the 29th. of May 32 H. 3. The King being at Wood≈øtock granted to the Scholars of the Univer≈øity ≈øeveral privileges there recited, and by his Letters Commanded the Sheriff, Mayor and Bayliffs of Oxford, immediately to ob≈øerve and cau≈øe to be ob≈øerved the ≈øaid liberties, which he cau≈øed to be Enrolled the 33d. of his Reign, and it is ob≈øervable in this Grant, that Ralph Fitz-Nicholas, Steward to the King by the Kings Command, ≈øet his Seal as Witne≈øs to this Grant of the King, a practice long ≈øince laid a≈øide; the Kings Te≈øte me ip≈øo being now ≈øufficient.

div.head: ¬ß. 4.
div.p: Anno 1275. King Edward Pat. 3 R. 1. M. 6. the fir≈øt granted to the Univer≈øity many rights and privileges, which it would be tedious to recite, they may be ≈øeen in the Patent and clo≈øe Rolls, 3 E. 1. M. 18.

King Edward Ro. Pat. 8 E 2. part. 2 ‚Ä¢
M. 24. the Second Anno 1315. Granted to the Univer≈øity ≈øeveral privileges, confirming to them the Grants made, Anno 1244. 29 H. 3. and Anno 1255. 39 H. 3. and 1261. 46 H. 3.

‚òû Anno 1317. 11 Ed. 2. The KingRot. Rom. 11 E 2. M. 10. writes to the Pope, that whereas Boniface the Eighth had granted to the Univer≈øities of France that Grace, ∆≤tomnes qui Gradum Magi≈øtralis Honoris in quacunque facultate a≈ø≈øecuti ≈øunt‚Äî con≈øimili velitis privilegio Decorare. that all who had attained the Degree of Ma≈øters in whatever Faculty, might every where re≈øume Lectures in the ≈øame, and continue them at their plea≈øure without any new examining, beginning again, or craving Grace from any; ≈øo he de≈øires he will Adorn the Univer≈øity of Oxford with the like privileges. By this it appears, that the Pope cou ‚Ä¢ d grant the privilege, that whoever had attained to Degrees of Ma≈øters in this Univer≈øity might enjoy the like Honor in all others: But none can infer from hence that the Degrees they took here were by the Popes Grant ≈øolely.

In the ≈øame Year we find the King writes to the Pope in behalf of the Univer≈øity of Cambridge de≈øiring him,Dictam ∆≤niver≈øitatem perpetuare & privilegia quibus, &c. u≈øi ≈øunt hactenus & gavi≈ø ‚Ä¢ cum Augmentatione novorum condendorum, &c. Rot. Rom. 11 E. 2. that he would perpetuate it, and would augment with new privileges tho≈øe which the Chancellor, and Scholars of the ≈øame Univer≈øity, and their Predece≈ø≈øors had hitherto u≈øed and enjoyed. By which it ≈øeems ≈øome, or at lea≈øt ≈øome general privileges, in Forreign parts, were de≈øired, perhaps ≈øuch as were craved for the Ma≈øters in Oxford.

Anno 1327. KingPat. 1 E. 3. M. 8.
Edward the Third in the fir≈øt of his Reign, by in≈øpeximus, confirmed all the privileges which had been granted to the Univer≈øity of Oxford by his Ance≈øtors Kings of England, particularly tho≈øe which King Edward the Fir≈øt had granted, confirming the Charter of King Henry the Third.

‚òû Anno 1353. 27 E. 3. the KingPat. 27 E. 3. M. 5. Pat. 29 E. 3. No. 5. granted ≈øeveral privileges to the Univer≈øity, but the Ample≈øt Charter was granted by that King the 29th. of his Reign, wherein, be≈øides ≈øeveral privileges of a Secular
nature, theCancellarius po≈ø≈øit per cen≈øuras Eccle≈øia≈øticas compel≈øere‚Äî Jam ordinare non po≈ø≈øumus variis & arduis negotiis praepediti, Ordinationem huju≈ømodi nobis ≈øpecialiter re≈øervamus. Chancellor hath power to compel the Inhabitants of Oxford, and the Suburbs to the ob≈øervance of ≈øome of the≈øe privileges by Eccle≈øia≈øtical Cen≈øures, and appoints that the Sheriff of Oxford ≈øhould take an Oath yearly, to protect and defend the Ma≈øters and Scholars of the Univer≈øity, and their Servants from violence, and concludes that what by rea≈øon of various and tedious affairs he could not then, he ≈øpecially re≈øerved for him≈øelf to order. By which it appears, that the power of ordering all things relating to the Univer≈øity was ≈øolely in the King.

‚òû Anno 1375. 49 E. 3. The Chancellor, Ma≈øters, and Doctors of Divinity, and Ma≈øters of Arts (by power no doubt granted to them by ≈øome Kings of England) made ≈øeveral Statutes which ≈øeemed grievous to the Canon and Civil Law Bachellors and Profe≈ø≈øors, of which complaint being made to the King he declared them void. By which it appears, that the King hath the power of making the Statutes,Cu≈øus e≈øt condere ejus e≈øt de≈øtruere. for whoever hath the power of de≈øtroying, and abrogating, hath the power of con≈øtituting and appointing.

Anno 1378.Rot. Chart. 2. Ric. 2. No. 14. By a Famous Charter of In≈øpeximus, King Richard the Second Corroborated the privileges granted by his Ance≈øtors to the Univer≈øity,Clau≈ø. R. 2. M. 23. and relea≈øed them of a Sub≈øidy of 4 d. a Year, impo≈øed by King Edward the Third upon every Clerk not Benificed, remaining in the Univer≈øity, which hePat. 5 R. 2. par. 2. No. 28. confirmed by Patent the 5th. of his Reign, and Anno 1379. 30. Regni, he charged his Ju≈øtices, Sheriffs, &c. to permit the Chancellor to enjoy and u≈øe all their Liberties granted by the Charter of the Kings Progenitors.

div.head: ¬ß. 5. Inferences from the before recited Charters.
div.p: ‚òû By all which it appears mo≈øt manife≈øt, that the Univer≈øity owned the Original Donation of their privileges to the Crown, which extended even to the ordering the taking of Degrees, which is the more clear for that I find, that the Regent Ma≈øter, there being but one it ≈øeems at that time, and the Bachellors and Scholars of the Domicans complained to the King, that they wereCl. 2. R. 2. nu. 4. prohibited from tho≈øe Degrees with which they ought to be Adorned,Per Re≈øcripta guae privato ≈øigillo Regio per fraudem impetrato muniebantur prohibitos a Gradibus quibus ornari de buerunt. by ≈øome Re≈øcript or Mandate ≈øent to the Chancellor, and Scholars under the Kings Privy Seal, obtained by deceit, ≈øaith the Record, which ≈øhews, that if it had been otherwi≈øe obtained, they had been bound by them, for there is no mention as if any preceding Grants could have rendred them Illegal, but being proved it ≈øeems got by deceit, the King abrogated them upon their Petiton.

Anno 1401. King Henry the FourthRot. Chart. 2 H. 4. par. 1. No. 2. in the ≈øecond of his Reign not only confirmed the Antient privileges of the Univer≈øity, but added others to them and enlarged the Limits of the Chancellors Juri≈ødiction, within which they might determin Cau≈øes, notwith≈øtanding the Rights of the Ju≈øtices or other Magi≈øtrates.

‚òû Anno 1411. 12 H. 4. When the Chancellor,Fragment. vet. Regi≈øt. Wood lib. 1. Antiq. Oxon fol. 205. a. and Proctors, an Heads of the Univer≈øity had been ≈øummoned before the King to give an account of the Popes Bulls, which they pretended as the ground of their contumacy, and the Chancellor and Proctors were di≈øplaced, the King Commanded others to be Elected to Succeed in their offices for the remaining part of the Year, by which the Kings Juri≈ødiction over Magi≈øtrates of the Univer≈øity is very clear.

Another in≈øtance of the Kings ab≈øolute Juri≈ødiction over the Univer≈øity pro arbitrio isRo≈ø≈øus lib. de Regibus p. 257. what I find Anno 1420. 9 H. 5. That the King a year before his Death had de≈øigned to amend the Statutes of the Univer≈øity, which as they have their force only by the Kings plea≈øure may be Abrogated or Su≈øpended by the ≈øame.

div.head: ¬ß. 6.
div.p: I ≈øhall add to the≈øe one in≈øtance M≈ø. in the Cu≈øtody of Sir Thomas Powis Atturny General compo≈øed by his Father. of the Foundation of Queens College in Cambridge as I find it ≈øet out in a Plea 19 Car. 2. in Dr. Patricks Ca≈øe, viz. That King Henry the Sixth upon the 3d. of March 26 Regni, gave Licence to Margaret his Queen to Found a perpetual College of Fellows in the Univer≈øity of Cambridge, to remain there to Study and Pray, ad Studendum & Orandum, and the King willed that the Pre≈øident and Fellows ≈øhould be Cho≈øen, In≈øtituted, Regulated, Governed, and Deprived according to the Order and Statutes made by the Bi≈øhop of Coventry and Lichfield, and the College to be Governed, by a Pre≈øident and Four Fellows, and that the Pre≈øident and tho≈øe Four Fellows and their Succe≈ø≈øors, according to the Orders and Statutes, may Admit more Fellows, &c. An that the ≈øaid Queen Margaret by vertue of the ≈øame Licence the 15th. of April the 26th. of King Henry the Sixth, did accordingly Found the College, &c. as before ≈øpecified, and gave Licence to the Bi≈øhop of Coventry and Litchfield to make Ordinances, and Statutes, which he accordingly did; among which one is, that the College ≈øhould con≈øi≈øt of a Pre≈øident and Fourteen Fellows, every one of which after they were Regents in Arts ≈øhould enter into Holy Orders, unle≈øs the Pre≈øident and the greater part of the Fellows did permit longer time.

Concerning this College I find further in the plea, that King James the Fir≈øt upon the 9th. of March, the ≈øecond of his Reign confirmed all the Charters and Donations made to the Chancellor, Ma≈øters and Scholars of the Univer≈øity of Cambridge, and particularly granted that the Chancellor of the ≈øaid Univer≈øity, and in his ab≈øence the Vice-Chancellor ≈øhould be the Ordinary Vi≈øitor of all the Colleges within the ≈øaid Univer≈øity, in which no ≈øpecial Vi≈øitor was appointed, and that no ≈øpecial Vi≈øitor was nominated for this College.

‚òû By the≈øe Patents it appears plainly how the Foundation it ≈øelf, and the endowments thereupon were by the Kings ≈øpecial Licence, and tho' the King made not the Statutes for the Government of the ≈øame, yet it was by His ≈øpecial Appointment, that the Bi≈øhop of Coventry and Lichfield was ordered to make them.

I ≈øhall not need to recite any Grants of this King to the Univer≈øity of Oxford, becau≈øe they are much in the ≈øame Tenor as tho≈øe of his Predece≈ø≈øors, I ≈øhall therefore pa≈øs to what I find done by Pope Sixtus the Fourth; wherein it will appear what Confirmation and Corroboration of the Charters of the Kings of England were made by the Pope.

div.head: ¬ß. 7. The confirmation of Pope Sixtus 4th.
div.p:
‚òû Anno 1478. 18 E. 4. the Grants of the Popes being either Worm-eaten, or lo≈øt by ≈øome evil accident, e≈øpecially the Famous Bull of Boniface the Eighth, which had been Annulled in the times of King Richard the Second and H. 4. and was not ≈øince Confirmed; The Univer≈øity EmployWood Antiq. Oxon lib. 1. 230. b. F. F. fol. 74. John Abbot of Abingdon, going to Rome about the Affairs of his Mona≈øtery, to get their privileges confirmed and re≈øtored to their former vigor, which he effected, and brought the Bull
of Sixtus the Fourth to that purpo≈øe. Dated at Rome at St. Peters on the Ides of September, Anno 1479. and the 9th. Year of his Pontificat, which was the 19th. of Edward the Fourth.

In which Bull the Grant of Pope Boniface the Eighth is confirmed, and many particular privileges recited, after which follows that as he is informed, the pre≈øent Chancellor, Ma≈øters, Doctors, and all the Scholars of the ≈øaid Univer≈øity de≈øire to all tho≈øe privileges, for the firmerPermi≈ø≈øis omnibus pre illorum ≈øub≈øi≈øtentia firmiori, no≈øtri adiici muniminis firmitatem. Ibidem. ≈øub≈øi≈øtence of them, that he would add the firmne≈øs of his defence. The Pope who with ≈øpecial love re≈øpects the Chancellor, &c. For their fervor of pure Devotion, and of their Faith which they bear to him, and the Roman Church; by Apo≈øtolic Authority, of his proper motion, not at their In≈øtance, but of his own meer Liberality, by the Tenor of the≈øe pre≈øents confirms, and approves all the privileges granted by the pre≈øent King Edward, as well as by otherSingula tam in Regum, quam Praedece≈ø≈øoris praedicterum literis contenta Autheritate Apo≈øtolic ‚Ä¢ tenore prae≈øentium confirmamus & Approbamus, &c. Ibidem. Kings of England to the Univer≈øity and the Students in it, holding the Tenors of the granted privileges to the pre≈øents for expre≈øs, and Decreeing them to obtain the ≈øtrength of a perpetual firmne≈øs, he E≈øtabli≈øheth them by the Patronage of the pre≈øent Writing, ≈øupplying all and ≈øingular defects of Law as well as Fact, if by chance any have Intervened in them. Concerning the power the Pope gave to the Chancellor to Ab≈øolve from the guilt of perjury in breaking the Statutes, and the puni≈øhments appointed by them, and in ≈øome ca≈øes di≈øpen≈øing with them, I ≈øhall treat when I come to con≈øider the Kings di≈øpen≈øing with the Statutes.

There is another Bull of the ≈øame Pope, dated the 6th. of the Kalends of Augu≈øt the ≈øame Year,
wherein he confirms the Bull of Pope Innocent the 4th. Anno 1254. 38 H. 3.
I ≈øhall pa≈øs by the Confirmations of King Richard the Third and Henry the Seventh, who were both very favorable to the Univer≈øity.

div.head: ¬ß. 8. The Charters of King H. 8. and his power over the Univer≈øity.
div.p: Anno 1510. 2 H. 8. It being Cu≈øtomary for the Kings, when they begun their Reigns, to Grant privileges to the Univer≈øity, King H. 8. confirmedIn pixide longa 3. their privileges and encrea≈øed them, and among the re≈øt he Ratified the mo≈øt Ample Charter of King Edward the Fourth and all others, granting them a truly royal Charter exceeding all tho≈øe of his Predece≈ø≈øors, as the Record ≈øaith.

‚òû This Year the Univer≈øity was ≈øollicitous to retrieve the Bulls of Popes, which had been by evil Arts ≈øtolen by ≈øome that wi≈øhed evil to the Univer≈øity, upon which account theF.F. Ep. 30. Chancellor was de≈øired to get them Tran≈øcribed out of the Chancery of the Apo≈øtolic See; But my Author complains that ≈øome Men upon the Bani≈øhing the Popes Authority here, not warmed with a temperate zeal,Wood. antiq. Oxon. lib. 1. fol. 241. a. as they ought, but being all a Fire Committed to the Flames not only all the Bulls they could find, but what ever they could meet with that made any mention of the Roman Religion, by which many matters of great moment relating to Hi≈øtory are lo≈øt.

In the Year 1518. the 10th. of King H. 8th. Cardinal Wol≈øey being then not only a Favorite of the King but of the Pope, and attending the King and Queen to Oxford, Regi≈øt. Colli. Marton fol. 241. a. in the Convocation Hou≈øe, having told the Univer≈øity of his Study and mo≈øt propen≈øe affection to it, and that he intended to In≈øtitute certain Lectures there, he earne≈øtly intreated they would give him power to correct certain Statutes,
which concerned learning, of which, ≈øome being repugnant among them≈øelves, for the amending of which the Univer≈øity had formerly appointed Richard Fitz-James Bi≈øhop of London, and John Young Bi≈øhop of Calypole. The Univer≈øity received the Benevolence of the Cardinal, with all due re≈øpect, and Writ to theF.F. Ep. 5861. &c. Chancellor about it, who An≈øwered on the 2d. of May, that he did not approve that ≈øuch Authority ≈øhould be given to any be≈øides the Chancellor, and the Congregation of Regents and Non-Regents: But he after changed his mind, and the 1≈øt. of June, in the fullIbid. fol. 31. Convocation, it was Decreed that the Statutes ≈øhould be delivered to the Cardinal to be Corrected and changed at his plea≈øure, and it was likewi≈øe ordained that the Liberties, Rights, and Privileges of the Univer≈øity, ≈øaving to every College their peculiar Rights, ≈øhould be delivered to him, with full power to reduce the public Di≈øcipline into what Form he plea≈øed.

div.head: ¬ß. 10. The Kings retaining the privileges in his hands and re≈øtoring ≈øome particular ones at plea≈øure.
div.p: ‚òû In the Year 1520. The 12th. of H. 8. the Town≈ømen thinking by this ≈øurrender that the Univer≈øity was without their old privileges, took the occa≈øion to abu≈øe ≈øome Scholars; therefore the Univer≈øity thought fit that the matter of renewing and encrea≈øing their rights and Privileges ≈øhould be ha≈øtened, and the Cardinal being moved in it, appointed the two fore≈øaidH. fol. 56. a. Bi≈øhops to Expedit it, and the King granted whatever was de≈øired in this particular betwixt the Town≈ø-men and the Univer≈øity.
