Anno 1521. The 13th. of H. 8. I find the Univer≈øityWood Antiq. Oxon. lib. 1. fol. 247. b. apply to the Cardinal for the ha≈øting of the Grant of the Kings Charter, and the Recognition of the Statutes, and in the Year following I find
that the Cardinal having ≈øtill the Univer≈øity Statutes in his Hands, prorogued the Terms of the Proctors, and ordered other things in the Univer≈øity.

Anno 1523. the 14th. of King H. 8. The Cardinal obtainedPixide Long. N. 2. a Charter of mo≈øt Ample Privileges, ≈øo that however the Univer≈øity had committed their Statutes and Privileges to the Cardinal for Correction and Amendment, which they had rea≈øon to do, becau≈øe his Dignity, and power was no le≈øs great than his intended Benefaction in Founding and Endowing Chri≈øt-Church and ≈øettling ≈øeveral Lectures; yet all this is to be ≈øuppo≈øed to be in ≈øubordination to the King, for he alone Grants the Charter whichH. fol. 200. was ≈øent Anno 1528. the 20th. of H. 8. by Dr. Hygden Dean of the Cardinal College. It is al≈øo further to be ob≈øerved, that this Charter was upon ≈øome Command of the King Wood Antiq. lib. 1. fol. 253. a. re-delivered to the Cardinal, and after his precipitate ruin it was not re≈øtored to the Univer≈øity till the Year 1566. which was Forty two Years after.

div.head: ¬ß. 11. The King ≈øeizeth all their privileges.
div.p: ‚òû To clear the main point yet more. Anno 1532. 24 H. 8. The King Commanded, that both the Univer≈øity and City ≈øhould deliver into his Hands all their Rights, and in January it was Decreed inF. F. fol. 122. Vol. de Chartis Accadem. Oxon. Bib. Cotton. ≈øub fau≈øtina c. 7. F. F. 122. Convocation, that there ≈øhould be two In≈øtruments of ≈øubmi≈ø≈øion drawn up for the Univer≈øity, one containing the ≈øurrender of all the Regal and Epi≈øcopal privileges, and the other the Regal only, and that the Regal privileges ≈øhould be ≈øent to the King, but the Epi≈øcopal and Papal ≈øhould be kept, but my Author thinks the la≈øt were al≈øo ≈øent. After this when any office in the Univer≈øity was void, the King appointed the Succe≈ø≈øors, ≈øo that it is found that even one of the Bedles was ≈øo placed.

This In≈øtance doth ≈øufficiently manife≈øt the Kings ab≈øolute power over the Univer≈øities in taking into his hands at his plea≈øure all, or any part of their privileges, and re≈øtoring them when he thinks fit as he did the≈øe.
Anno 1541. 33 H. 8. The KingF. F. fol. 107.6. appointed Rules about the Election of the Proctors, and ordered ≈øeveral other things relating to the better Governing of the Univer≈øity.

Anno 1543.35 H. 8.The King re≈øtores their privileges conditionally. The King re≈øtored the Liberties to the Univer≈øity, which he had retained from the Year 1522. yet ≈øo as the Vice-Chancellor Tre≈øham entred into a Recognizance of 500 l. that the Univer≈øity ≈øhould exerci≈øe none of the privileges granted Anno 1523. by the means of Cardinal Wol≈øey.

Thus I have given an Abridgment of what the Laborious Mr. Wood hath related concerning the Kings or Popes Grants of privileges to the Univer≈øity, or what I have met with other where, relating to this bu≈øine≈øs, and ≈øhall now proceed in my de≈øigned Method; referring the Reader for later Charters to the Arcives of the Univer≈øity, and the Act of Parliament for Incorporating both Oxford and Cambridge.

div.head: CHAP. IV.

argument.p: Concerning the Vi≈øitations of the Univer≈øities, and particularly of that of Oxford.

div.head: SECT. I.

argument.p: Concerning the Kings Supremacy, and Power in Eccle≈øia≈øtical Cau≈øes and Vi≈øitations.

div.head: ¬ß. 1. Fir≈øt, what Authority the Kings of England u≈øed before the Reformation.
div.p: IT cannot be expected, that I ≈øhould di≈øcu≈øs the Controver≈øie here, how far the Popes power was exerci≈øed in England in matters Eccle≈øia≈øtical, or in things to be done in Ordine ad Spiritualia. The Curious may have recour≈øe to the Learned Marca de Regno & Sacerdotio, the Concordata, the Regalia of France, and Sir Roger Twi≈ødens Hi≈øtorical Vindication, if he would be ≈øatisfied in the bundaries of the Eccle≈øia≈øtical and Secular power.

‚òû It will be ≈øufficient for my purpo≈øe to ≈øhew fir≈øt, that long before the Reformation, ≈øeveral Kings of England permitted no Canons, or Con≈øtitutions of the Church, or Breves and Bulls of the Apo≈øtolic See, to be executed here without their Allowance, and that in ≈øeveral particulars, wherein the Pope in other places by the Canons, or the Plenitudo pote≈øtatis, exerci≈øed a ≈øpecial Juri≈ødiction, either ≈øome of our Anciente≈øt Kings did the ≈øame, or if they apprehended any diminution of their Crown or Dignity to attend their exerci≈øe by any power not derived from their ≈øelves, they prohibited them.

‚òû And Secondly,Secondly, What power they have exerci≈øed ≈øince the Reformation. That ≈øince the Supremacy hath been E≈øtabli≈øhed by Acts of Parliament in the Crown; The Kings of England may, according to the Laws in force, not only exerci≈øe all the powers they could, as Sovereign Princes, but likewi≈øe whatever the Pope de Jure, if not de facto could or did do, in the outward Regiment of Eccle≈øia≈øtical matters: and con≈øequently whatever was done in Vi≈øitations by the Authority of the Popes, Metrpolitans, or Dioece≈øan Bi≈øhops, may now be done by the Kings of England as Supreme Ordinary.

div.head: ¬ß. 2.
div.p: Before I enter upon this Subject, I de≈øire it may be noted,The≈øe In≈øtances are produced to Induce the Subjects obedience to the King who≈øe Authority ought to be well con≈øidered. that I bring not the In≈øtances to induce a belief, that the Popes according to the Canons of the Church did not oppo≈øe ≈øome of the practices of the Kings I mention: But to ≈øhew how Incongruou≈øly the Fellows of St. Mary Magdalen College acted, who knowing the≈øe things, and that later Laws had devolved upon the King even the power of the Pope exerci≈øed here inforo externo, ≈øhould di≈øpute the Kings Authority, in a matter ≈øo manife≈øtly appertaining to his Royal Dignity.

‚òû For Brevities ≈øake I pa≈øs the Saxon times. King William the 1≈øt. for the ≈øure E≈øtabli≈øhing his Conque≈øt, is noted by Eadmerus Hi≈øtor. novorum lib. 1. fol. 6. to which he adds de huju≈ømodi per≈øonis Epi≈øcopes, Abbates, & alies principes per totam tenam Ju≈øtituit, de quibus Indignum Judicaretur, ≈øi per omnia ≈øuis legibus non obedirent. Idem. to have Introduced the Norman u≈øages of his Ance≈øtors, tho' he calls them new here. Among which he reckons, that none in his Dominions ≈øhould own the Pope but by his Command, nor receive his Letters unle≈øs ≈øhewed fir≈øt to him, and if the Arch-Bi≈øhop of Canterbury called and prae≈øided in a General Council of the Bi≈øhops, he allowed nothing to be appointed or forbid, unle≈øs they were accommodated to his Will, and were fir≈øt ordained by him, nor ≈øuffered any of his Barons or Officers to undergo any Eccle≈øia≈øtical Cen≈øure but by his precepts.

So that I think it not ≈øo ≈øtrange,What King William Rufus did. Upon the Shi≈øm none more fit then the King to re≈øolve whom to adhere to. that during the Schi≈øm his Son William Rufus claimed as other Princes did, a Right to declare to which Pope he would adhere, ≈øome con≈øenting to Pope ∆≤rban, others to Clement. Therefore the King demanded of An≈øelm from which of tho≈øe Popes he would
receive his Pall, and the Arch-Bi≈øhop An≈øwered him, he would receive it from Pope ∆≤rban. But the KingRex dixit illum proÃÑ Apo≈øtelico nondum accepi≈ø≈øe, nec ≈øuae vel paternae Con≈øuetudinis eatenus extiti≈ø≈øe ut praeter ≈øuam licentiam aut Electionem Aliquis in Regno Angliae Papam nominaret; & quicunque ≈øibi hujus dignitatis Pote≈øtatem vell√Æt praeripere, Unum foret ac ≈øi coronam ≈øuam ≈øibi conaretur Auferre. Eadm. fol. 25.47. told him, that he had not yet received him for Pope, nor had it been his, or his Fathers Cu≈øtom hitherto, that any ≈øhould be received as Pope in England without his Licence and Election, and whoever would take from him this Power of his Dignity, ≈øhould be e≈øteemed by him as one that endeavored to take from him his Crown. And when An≈øelm An≈øwered, that he would not in any thing depart from obedience and ≈øubjection to Pope ∆≤rban. The King in great wrath prote≈øted,Nequaquam fidem quam ≈øibi debebat ≈øimul & Apo≈øtolicae ≈øedis obedientiam, contra ≈øuam voluntatem, po≈ø≈øe ≈øervari. fol. 26. N. 1. None to go to Rome but with the Kings leave. that the Arch-Bi≈øhop could not keep alike, or together, the Faith which he ought to the King, and the obedience to the Apo≈øtolic See, contrary to the Kings Will.

When in the ≈øame Kings Reign the Arch-Bi≈øhop was ≈øollicitous to have leave to go to Rome and Vi≈øit the Succe≈ø≈øor of St. Peter, for the being better in≈øtructed in the Government of the Church. He received An≈øwerSed ≈øi, Iverit pro certo noverit, quod totum Archiepi≈øcopatum in Dominium meum Redigam, nec illum pro Archiepi≈øcapo ultra recipiam Idem. fol. 38.10. from the King, that if he went he ≈øhould for certain know, that he would ≈øeize his whole Arch-Bi≈øhopric into his hands, nor would he receive him for Arch-Bi≈øhop any more, like as now the Writ no exeat Regno, is u≈øed with a Penalty ≈øpecified.

After this the Bi≈øhops of Winche≈øter, Lincoln, Salisbury and Bathe with ≈øeveral Barons, ≈øent to him by the King, tell him, that he had troubled the King with many complaints; How that at the Parliament held at Rockingham he hadPollicitus es per te, u≈øus ac leges ≈øuas u≈øque quaque deinceps ≈øervaturum, & cas ≈øibi contra emnes homines fideliter defen≈øurum. Idem fol. 39.27. In this whole Relation of matter of Fact, it is to be owned, that it was the per≈øonal repair of a Peer or great Man to Rome, to Appeal, that was forbid without the Kings leave, but Appeals by Proctors were Anciently u≈øed in ≈øeveral Ca≈øes. promi≈øed for the future,The promi≈øe of an Arch-Bi≈øhop. in all re≈øpects to keep and ob≈øerve the Cu≈øtoms, and the Kings Laws, and to defend them faithfully again≈øt all Men [which was an Oath of Fidelity u≈øed in that Age, and bound him in Allegiance, by rea≈øon of his Temporalities, but no ways like the
pre≈øent Oath of Supremacy] upon which they tell him the King believed he would have been quiet for the future. But, that he had openly contravened his promi≈øe and Faith, by threatning to go to Rome without the Kings leave: Which was a thing altogether unheard of before, and again≈øt the u≈øages of the Kingdom, that any of the Great Men, and e≈øpecially him≈øelf, ≈øhould pre≈øume any ≈øuch thing, and le≈øt the King ≈øhould either be wearied, or importun'd with him any more, or with any other, who being aggrieved might follow his Example; The KingJubet ut quatenus jure jurando promittas quod nunquam amplius ≈øedem St. Petri vel ejus Vicarsum pro quavis, quae tibi queat ingeri, cau≈øa Appellas, aut ≈øi, ≈øub omni celeritate de terra ≈øu√¢ recedat. Idem 39.36. Commands that by Oath he ≈øhould promi≈øe, that he would never Appeal to the See of St. Peter or his Vicar, for any cau≈øe that might befall him, or if he did, that he ≈øhould ≈øpeedily depart out of the Kings Territories: But the Arch-Bi≈øhop per≈øi≈øting in his re≈øolution to go, had not only his Arch-Bi≈øhopric ≈øeized; but the Pope being ≈øhewed how his Carriage here was re≈øented, did not afford him either Idem fol. 52.17, 53, 28. Con≈øilium or Auxilium; yet the Writers of that Age cen≈øure that as an exorbitance of the Kings power, however it may be a Document to ≈øome not ob≈øtinately to oppo≈øe their Prince.

‚òû By this Relation of matter of Fact it is evident,The Inference from this Hi≈øtory. The≈øe are to be under≈øtood of matters Political and of Government, not in matters of Doctrin and Faith. that in the time of the≈øe two Kings, whatever was directed from Rome hither, or was done by the Arch-Bi≈øhop was to have the Kings Approbation, otherwi≈øe it was not ≈øuffered to be executed, ≈øo that the Kings allowance before made public as now u≈øed in France was requi≈øite to give them a practicablene≈øs here.

div.head: ¬ß. 3. Of the Inve≈øtitures of Bi≈øhops.
div.p:
It is allowed by our Hi≈øtoriansIngulphus fol. 500. vid. literas Pa≈øcha ‚Ä¢
lis 2 Henrico 2. apud Eadmerum fol. 113. & 115. generally, that the Receiving Inve≈øtitures of Churches from our Princes, their calling of Synods, determining Cau≈øes Eccle≈øia≈øtical without Appeal to Rome, their Tran≈ølating
of Bi≈øhops, &c. have been practi≈øed here in Ancient times, the Canons and Popes reclaiming, ≈øometimes quitted and re≈øumed by our Kings as State Intere≈øt required.

It is clear in Hi≈øtory, This was no conferring holy Orders, but in relation to their Baronies. that Bi≈øhops received Inve≈øtitures from the King by delivery of a Staff, as an acknowledgment of a ≈øubjection to the King, at lea≈øt for their Baronies which was after yielded not to be done by Lay Hands: yet King Henry the Fir≈øt at one time Writ to the Pope, that he wouldNec pro Ami≈ø≈øione Regni ≈øui pa≈ø≈øurum ≈øe perdere Inve≈øtituras Eccle≈øiarum. Idem fol. 73.13. not for the lo≈øs of his Kingdom, lo≈øe the Inve≈øtiture of Churches and another time he threatned, that without doubt he would re≈øume his Inve≈øtitures, becau≈øe he held them in Peace: However I do not find, that this went any further then Swearing Fealty to the King,Oath of Fidelity. which ≈øeems to have long continued, and which was a ≈øufficient badge of ≈øubjection. So we find a WritGervac. Dorob. 4.1187. Col. 1503.36. from R. de Glanvil to the Abbot of Batle, &c. wherein he Commands him on the part of the King by the Faith which he owes him, and by the Oath which he made to him, to do what he then enjoyned.

‚òû As to the Legatine Power,Concerning the power of Legats. it is apparent by ≈øeveral In≈øtances, that none Exerci≈øed any here without the Kings leave, whether by the Grant of Pope Nicholas to Edward the Confe≈ø≈øor, I di≈øpute not. I ≈øhall only note ≈øome few. King Henry the Fir≈øt had an Interview at Gi≈øors with Pope Calixtus, and obtained of him, that he ≈øhould Grant him all the Cu≈øtoms which his Father King William the Fir≈øt had in England and Normandy, and e≈øpeciallyMaxime ut neminemaliquando Legati Officio in Anglia fungi‚Äîpermitteret, ≈øi non ip≈øa aliqu√¢ praecipu√¢ quaerel√¢ exigentur, quae ab Archiepi≈øcopo Cantuariorum Caeteri≈øque Epi≈øcopis Regni terminari non po≈ø≈øint, hoc fieri a Papa po≈øtularet. Kidm. fol. 125.53. that he would permit none at any time, to exerci≈øe the Office of Legat in England, unle≈øs the King upon any ≈øpecial Plea ≈øhould require it, and the thing could not be determined by the Arch-Bi≈øhop of Canterbury and the Re≈øt
of the Bi≈øhops of the Kingdom, and that the King ≈øhould de≈øire it of the Pope.

How the Popes Legats were received may be be≈øt known by ≈øome In≈øtances.In≈øtances how the Popes Legats were received. The Wars betwixt France, Scotland & England might make this caution. When Guido Arch-Bi≈øhop of Vienna Anno 1100. In the beginning of King Henry the Fir≈øt's Reign, by the Popes Authority was appointed Legat as he gave it out. Eadmerus ≈øaith, that it was an admiration to all in England, for all knew that it wasInauditum ≈øcilicet in Brittannia cuncti Scientes quemlibet hominum ≈øuper ≈øe vices Apo≈øtolicas Gerere ni≈øi ≈øolum Archiepi≈øcopum Cantuarierum. Idem fol. 58.40. unheard of in Brittain, that any Man, except the Bi≈øhop of Canterbury, had the Popes power. Therefore as he came ≈øo he returned, being received by none as Legat, neither did he perform the Office of a Legat while here. The words of my Author are,‚Äî a nemine pro Legato ≈øu≈øceptus, nec in aliquo Legati officio functus.

‚òû In the Letters of Pa≈øchalis the Second of the 30th. of March and the 1≈øt. of April, Fourteen Years after the returning of the Legat Guido, the Pope Expo≈øtulats with the King about ≈øeveral matters; one of which is, his admitting neither Me≈ø≈øenger,Sedis Apo≈øtolicae Nuncii vel litterae praeter Ju≈ø≈øum Regiae Maje≈øto tis nullam in Pote≈øtate tuae ≈øu≈øceptionem aut aditum promerentur, nullus inde clamor, nullum inde Judicium ad ≈øedem Apo≈øtolicam de≈øtinantur. Idem. fol. 113. & 116. nor Letter to be received but by his leave, and the Year following An≈øelm (Nephew to the late Arch-Bi≈øhop, and after Abbot of St. Edmundsbury) ≈øhewed by Letters, that he had Committed to his Admini≈øtration, Vices Apo≈øtolicas in Anglia. This made known here, the Queen, Clergy, and Nobility gather'd in Council at London concluded, that the Arch-Bi≈øhop ≈øhould go to the King to Normandy, and make known to him the Ancient Cu≈øtom of the Realm, and by his Advice to Rome, that the≈øe new things might be Annihilated, haec Nova annihilaret. So the Arch-Bi≈øhop went to the King to Roan, and met An≈øelm there, de≈øigning his Journey for England, but King Henry not ≈øuffering that any prejudice, ≈øaith my Author, ≈øhould
be brought upon the Ancient Cu≈øtoms of England, deteined An≈øelm from going to England.

div.head: ¬ß. 4. The Subjects repine at the Legats Praecedence of the Arch-Bi≈øhop Canterbury.
div.p: ‚òû Soon after we find Legats ≈øent, and particularly John Cremen≈øis Anno 1125. 25 H. 1. Who being but a Prie≈øt Cardinal, yet u≈øing the Habit of a Bi≈øhop, and performing the Office on Ea≈øter Day in a more Eminent Chair as an Arch-Bi≈øhop, gave offence. But in a Council which he held and pre≈øided in at London the Kingdom took more offence, ≈øaith my Author, for then,Videres enim rem hactenus regno Anglorum inauditam, Clericum ≈øcilicet, Presbyterii tantum Gradu perfunctum, Archiepi≈øcopis, Epi≈øcopis, Abbatibus, totiu≈øque Regni Nobilibus qui confluxerant in ≈øublimi ≈øolio prae≈øidere illos autem deor≈øum ≈øedentes ad nutum ejus, vultu & auribus animum ≈øu≈øpen≈øum habentes Gerv. Dorob. Acta. Pontif. Col. 1663.42. ≈øaith he, we might ≈øee a thing hitherto unheard of in the Kingdom of England. A Clerk, only having the Degree of a Prie≈øt, pre≈øide in a lofty Throne above the Arch-Bi≈øhops, Bi≈øhops, Abbots and all the Nobles of the Kingdom that A≈ø≈øembled there, they ≈øitting below with Countenances and Ears attending his plea≈øure.

‚òû In this I take not ≈øo much notice, that he a≈ø≈øumed ≈øuch a place, that being due according to the Dignity of the Per≈øon he Repre≈øented, and is no more to be wondered at, then that the Lord Cromwell as Vicar General had place before the Arch-Bi≈øhop of Canterbury; but I cannot but ob≈øerve, that it was looked upon as ≈øuch a Novelty, and a thing not u≈øed before, even as the Vicar Generals place was in the latter Ages: And it is ≈øuppo≈øed by ≈øome to be the fir≈øt Pre≈øident of any Clergy Mans having Precedence here of the Arch-Bi≈øhop of Canterbury, who was Styled, Alterius Orbis Papa, as having Vices Apo≈øtolicas here.

But in Anno 1127. To take off this Envy, the Arch-Bi≈øhop of Canterbury William Corbet was declared Legat, and in May following held a Council at Wind≈øor, whereinCui prae≈øidet ≈øicut Apo≈øtolicae ≈øedis Legatus Florent. Wigorn An. 1126.1127. he pre≈øided as Legat of the Apo≈øtolic See, and it mu≈øt be owned, that tho' the≈øe fir≈øt three Kings after the Conque≈øt Conte≈øted with
Popes in the≈øe matters, yet afterwards Kings yielded more to the Canons of the Church.

div.head: ¬ß. 5. Further power exerci≈øed by Legats.
div.p:
‚òû Anno 1138. 3 Steph. Albert or Alberic Cardinal of Ho≈øtia was the Popes Legat, and Con≈øecrated Theobald Arch-Bi≈øhop of Canterbury, and called the Clergy to aGerv. Dorob. Col. 1346.58.
Colloquium by Apo≈øtolic Authority, by which it appears, that the Canons of the Church now obtained, and the King a≈ø≈øented to the powers the Legat had, ≈øo that what was Decreed had the Kings Allowance. InEadmerus fol. 24.11. this Council he Commanded the Prior and Convent of Canterbury to choo≈øe ≈øuch an Arch-Bi≈øhop, whom the Authority of the Holy Canons in nothing might ob≈øtruct, and to whom the Bi≈øhops of his Province likewi≈øe ought to ≈øubmit,Here is to be noted, that the Kings A≈ø≈øent was required. and to whom the King neither might, nor ought ju≈øtly to deny his A≈ø≈øent, and that if anyGerv. Dorob. can. 9. Col. 1348. injured any Eccle≈øia≈øtical per≈øon, and did not give ≈øatisfaction, after three Admonitions he might be Excommunicated, and that none be≈øides the Pope, unle≈øs the danger of Death were Imminent, might enjoyn the manner of his final Penance, which my Author Sir Roger Twi≈øden ut ≈øupra. ≈øays was the fir≈øt Canon that was made whereby any thing done in England was referred to Rome; but of this I doubt.

Anno 1139.39. H. 1. Pope Innocent the Third Conferred the Legatine power upon Henry Bi≈øhop of Winche≈øter, King Stephens Brother; his FacultiesMalmsbury fol. 103. a. 31. were Read at a Council he called at Winche≈øter bearing Date March the 1≈øt.

There being ≈øome differences betwixt the Arch-Bi≈øhop and Monks of Canterbury, Di≈øputes betwixt the Arch-Bi≈øhop of Canterbury and the Legat. they were referred from Rome to his Deci≈øions ≈øo that he cau≈øed both Parties the ≈øecond time to appear before him 1143. as Lagat, and CommandedWilli. Thor ‚Ä¢ s Col. 1853.32. Arch-Bi≈øhop Theobald
to re≈øtore one Jeremy whom he had removed. By the≈øe and other Carriages, there grew great di≈øta≈øts betwixt the≈øe two great Prelates. The Arch-BiNop prohibitedJo. Hagul≈øt. Col. 275. H. 4.
Winche≈øter all Eccle≈øia≈øtical Functions tho' he were the Popes Legat, and both apply them≈øelves to the Pope: Whence, a Learned Sir Roger Twi≈øden, Vindi≈ø. p. 27. Per≈øon ≈øaith, our Hi≈øtorians do ≈øetch the u≈øe of Appeals to Rome, tho' it may be Ancienter.

div.head: ¬ß. 6. The Arch-Bi≈øhop of Canterbury Created Legatus Natus.
div.p: ‚òû The≈øe two great Prelates being before Lucius the Second, Anno 1144. the Bi≈øhop of Winche≈øter Willi. Thorn Col. 1804.44. J. Hagul≈øt Col. 273.61. Anno 1145. was di≈ømi≈ø≈øed his Legatine Commi≈ø≈øion, and the Pope finding with how great difficulty the Eccle≈øia≈øtic Affairs of the Kingdom could be managed by any Legate, without the Arch-Bi≈øhop of Canterbury, Created him and his Succe≈ø≈øors Legati Nati, by which ≈øuch things as the Arch-BiNops did before, and which ≈øeemed to Interfere with the Popes plenitude of power, the exerci≈øe of which the Arch-Bi≈øhop was not ≈øo ea≈øily to be dive≈øted of, he might be ≈øaid to make u≈øe of by a Legatine power.

After this our Hi≈øtories are full of Appeals to Rome, Greater ≈øubjection to the Pope. and of the Authority Exerci≈øed by Legats, and we find ≈øome things allowed by the Decrees of Popes to be Tran≈øacted by the Arch-Bi≈øhop of Canterbury qu√¢ Archibi≈øhop and others qu√¢ Legate, as appears in the Decretals whereDe Officio Legati cap. 1.
Alexander the Third re≈øolves, that the Arch-Bi≈øhop could not hear, Jure Metropolitico, matters Epi≈øcopal, that came not to him per Appellationem, that is, by a Legal way, but Jure Legationis he might, ≈øuch as were brought unto him only per quaerimoniam.

div.head: ¬ß. 7. The Style of Legates a Latare when fir≈øt u≈øed.
div.p:
‚òû The Name of Legatus a Latere, is fir≈øt found in our Hi≈øtorians to be given to Johannes Hoveden Anno 1189.177. a. 10.
Anagninus Cardinalis Anno 1189, and altho' the power of the≈øe
Legates was great, yet it is manife≈øt, that what they did was only ≈øo far as they had the Kings permi≈ø≈øion, ≈øo that in ≈øome re≈øpects it may be ≈øaid, whatever they did in Vi≈øitations and other matters, was by the Kings Authority and ≈øufferance, for which purpo≈øe we have that Memorable LetterVita Hen. Chichel≈øey ab Ant. Duck Edit. 1617. p. 79. from Henry Chichel≈øey to King Henry the Fifth, which I ≈øhall give in the words it was Writ in. Be In≈øpection of Laws and Chronicles,The Legatines power by our Kings permi≈ø≈øion, was exerci≈øed in mo≈øt Ca≈øes. was there no Legate a Latere ≈øent into no Lond and e≈øpecially into your Reagm of Yngland, witoute great and notable cau≈øe. And that when thei came, after thei had done her Legacie, abiden but litul wyle, not over a yer, &c. And yet evir that, was tretyd with or he cam into the Lond, whon he ≈øhould have exerci≈øe of his power, and how mych ≈øhold be put in Execution, an a venture after he had bee re≈øeyved, he whold have u≈øed it too largely to great oppre≈ø≈øion of your peple.
A further proof that Legates here could do nothing contrary to the Laws and Cu≈øtoms of the Land appears in this particular I ≈øhall now recite.

‚òû Henry Beaufort the Rich Bi≈øhop of Winche≈øter, The fir≈øt Cardinal that was a Privy Councellor. who was Cardinal of St. Eu≈øebius, Son of John a Gaunt, and ≈øo of the Kings Blood, and was employed by Martin the Fifth as General again≈øt the Bohemians, and to that end Erected his Cro≈øs Anno 1429. 8 H. 6. was ≈øent Legate into England, and was made one of the Kings Privy Council, and is noted to be the fir≈øt that of that Order was ≈øo Admitted: Yet we find that he was to R ‚Ä¢ t. parl ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
8 H. 6. N. 17. His prote≈øtation to ab≈øent him≈øelf when matters of difference betwixt the King and Pope were debnted. make a prote≈øtation, that as often as any matter, cau≈øe or bu≈øine≈øs, did concern the King, his Kingdom, or Dominions on the one part; and the Apo≈øtolic See on the other, which was to be Communed and Treated of in the Kings Council the
Cardinal ≈øhould ab≈øent him≈øelf, and no ways be pre≈øent at the Communication of the ≈øame.

It further appears how Legates Executed by the Kings Allowance or Connivance the powers given them by the Pope; becau≈øe if they did otherwi≈øe, no per≈øon, being the Kings Subject, was ≈øo great, but he was forced to gain his pardon for the Offence, if he Committed any.

Hence we find, that even this Rot. Parl. 10 H. 6. N. 16. He Petitions for pardon if he had done any thing again≈øt the Laws, being the Kings Subject. great Cardinal cau≈øed a Petition to be Exhibited in Parliament, That he the ≈øaid Cardinal, nor none other, ≈øhould be pur≈øued, vexed, impleaded, or grieved by the King his Heirs or Succe≈ø≈øors, nor by any other per≈øon for cau≈øe of any provi≈øion, or offence, or Mi≈øpri≈øion done by the ≈øaid Cardinal again≈øt any Statute of provi≈øions, or per cau≈øe of any Exemption, Receipt, acceptation, admi≈ø≈øion or execution of any Bulls Papal to him in any manner.

By all this I hope the Ingenuous Reader will ≈øind,The Inference hence, that what the Popes Legats did in Vi≈øitation, or otherwi≈øe, was by the Kings ≈øuperadded Authority. that what Vi≈øitations were made of the Univer≈øity of Oxford by the Popes Legats (whereof I ≈øhall give ≈øeveral In≈øtances in the ≈øollowing Section) doth no ways Infer, that thereby the Kings power of Vi≈øiting was exauctorated, but that whatever they did was in ≈øubordination to the Kings plea≈øure or as allowed by his Laws.

div.head: ¬ß. 8. Concerning the Arch-Bi≈øhop, or Bi≈øhops Vi≈øitations.
div.p:
The other Vi≈øitors of the Univer≈øity were either the Arch-Bi≈øhops of Canterbury as Metropolitans, or the Bi≈øhops of Lincoln as Dioece≈øans, or the Local Vi≈øitors; I ≈øhall now endeavor to prove, that whatever they did in Vi≈øitation, as well as other External Regiment, was by order, allowance, or connivance of the Kings of England; ≈øo that though I ≈øhall here after produce their Vi≈øitations, yet it will appear
that the Kings Supreme Authority was thereby no ways prejudiced.

I need not here enter into the claims our Ancient Kings made to the Inve≈øtitures of Bi≈øhops, having touched it before, nor how for their Baronies Homage is required of them. It is mo≈øt manife≈øt, that our Kings have Interpo≈øed their Authority even in allowing or di≈ø-allowing of their per≈øons.

This is clear by the Speech of Wol≈øtan
Ailred de Miraculis Edw. Col. 406.37. Here we may note, that the Alteration was by agreement. at the Confe≈ø≈øors Tomb,Bi≈øhops allowed by the King. that he had compelled him to take the Pa≈øtoral Staff. So King Edward the Third wrote to Pope Clement the Sixth, that his Progenitors long ≈øince upon Vacancies, by their Kingly Right, conferred the Cathedral Churches freely on fit per≈øons, and afterwards at the In≈øtance of the See of Rome under certain Forms and Conditions, granted that Elections ≈øhould be in the ≈øaid Churches by their Chapters.

div.head: ¬ß. 9.
div.p: I need not in≈øi≈øt upon the Kings of England ≈øeizing the Temporalities of Bi≈øhops into their hands, and ≈øo Su≈øpending them a Beneficio; for tho≈øe who will take the pains to look into Mr. Pryns Hi≈øtorical Collections will find many In≈øtances thereof.

‚òû The Statutes of Provi≈øions, the complaints again≈øt the Popes Provi≈øions in Mat. Anno 1240. fol. 532.43. fol. 549.18.22. Anno 1246. fol. 669.9.
Paris and the Parliaments of King Edward the Third, and Richard the Second clear this point: And when Anno 1349. the Pope wrote to the King, that he would not hinder or permit the≈øe to be hindered to receive the Benefices, who were by the Court of Rome by Bulls promoted. The King An≈øwered, that he well would accept tho≈øe Clerks, ≈øo provided which were of good condition, and were worthy of Promotion, but others he would not. If then the very admitting the per≈øons to the Dignity and Office were in the Kings power, as by the Conge d'e≈ølire is well known, it cannot be doubted, but that the Exerci≈øe of their Government, I ≈øpeak not here of their Sacerdotal Function, was according to the Kings Laws.

div.head: ¬ß. 10. How far the Canons were allowed in England.
div.p: We may therefore now con≈øider how far the Eccle≈øia≈øtical Canons were allowed by our Kings, and how called his Laws.

‚òû Ralph de Diceto An. 1175. Col. 597.21. ob≈øerves, that our Kings did in ≈øuch ≈øort follow the Eccle≈øia≈øtical Canons, as they had a care to
Con≈øerve their own Rights: hence it is, that in the Saxon Laws we find the Kings extending their Commands to the enjoyning of tho≈øe things in Eccle≈øia≈øtical matters, which by Canons of Councils were agreed to, as Sir Roger Cap. 5. N. 6.
Twi≈øden hath ≈øummed up in Ten particulars.‚òû In one of which King Alfred
L. L. Aluredi C. 8. pa. 25. Jourval. c. 9. Coll. 823. The Decrees of ≈øuch Councils mu≈øt be well obeyed when Kings were pre≈øent. re≈øerves to him≈øelf the liberty of di≈øpen≈øing event with the Marriage of Nuns. In another it appears, that the Kings cau≈øed the Clergy of their Kingdom to meet in Council, and ≈øometimes pre≈øided them≈øelves in them, tho' the, Popes Legat were pre≈øent, as may be ≈øeen in Sir Henry Spelmans Councils, Page. 292.293.189. & pa≈øim Ibid. vita Lanfranci C. 6. Col. 1. pa. 7. Florent. Wigorn. 1070. p. 434.

‚òû It is likewi≈øe certain, that beforeTwi≈øden Vindica. c. 5. N. 7. p. 99.
William the Conquerors time, the Engli≈øh Bi≈øhops had no Ordinary Courts di≈øtingui≈øhed from the Lay, but both Secular and Eccle≈øia≈øtical Magi≈øtrates ≈øat and Judged together: but he finding the≈øe proceedingsNon bene neque ≈øecundum Sanctorum Canonum praeceta. not good, nor according to the precept of the Holy Canons, did by his Charter make a di≈øtinction of the Courts, that ≈øuch as were Convented by the Bi≈øhop ≈øhould not An≈øwer accordingNon ≈øecundum hundred ≈øed ≈øecundum Canones & Epi≈øcopales Leges, &c. to the Hundred, but according to the Canons and Epi≈øcopal Laws. So that in this appears the Foundation of the Tryals in Eccle≈øia≈øtical Courts, according to the Eccle≈øia≈øtical Laws, which yet by our Lawyers are called the Kings Laws.

div.head: ¬ß. 11. The Kings Secular Courts determined what matters were to be tryed in Eccle≈øia≈øtical Courts.
div.p:
And it further appears, that in Controver≈øies betwixt parties where it hath been di≈øputable, whether the Tryal of them appertained to the Kings Eccle≈øia≈øtical, or Secular Courts; The Kings Secular Courts have ever been Judges, to which Court the cau≈øe did belong, therefore Bracton Lib. 5. de exceptionib. cap. 15. ≈øect. 3. fol. 412. a. ≈øaith, Judex Eccle≈øia≈øticus, cum prohibitionem a Rege ≈øu≈øceperit, ≈øuper≈øedere debet in omni ca≈øu, ≈øaltem donec con≈øtiterit in Curia Regis ad quam pertineat Juri≈ødictio, quia ≈øi Judex Eccle≈øia≈øticus ae≈øtimare po≈ø≈øit an ≈øua e≈ø≈øec Juri≈ødictio, in omni ca≈øu indifferenter procederet, non ob≈øtunte Regi√¢ prohibitione. Which is agreeable to what we find King William the Fir≈øt did in a Council at Illibon in Normandy Anno 1080. when by the advice of both the States Eccle≈øia≈øtic and Secular, he did ≈øettle many particulars to belong to the Cognizance of the Spiritual Judges, and concludes, that if any thing were further claimed
by them, they ≈øhould not enter upon itDonec in Curia Regis mon≈øtrent quod Epi≈øcopi inde habere debeant. till they had ≈øhewed in the Court of the King, that the Bi≈øhops thereupon ought to have it belong to them.

Whoever de≈øires to be ≈øatisfied in the Juri≈ødiction of the Kings of England in Eccle≈øia≈øtical matters, may ≈øind an Abridgment of them in Sir Roger Twi≈øden Vindicat. c. 5. N. 17. enforced with ≈øufficient Te≈øtimonies out of our mo≈øt Authentic Hi≈øtorians in Eighteen particulars.

div.head: ¬ß. 12. The application of the≈øe Hi≈øtorical Collections.
div.p:
‚òû Upon the whole matter we may conclude, that what was done by Archiepi≈øcopal or Epi≈øcopal Vi≈øitation of the Univer≈øity, was by the Kings Authority; ≈øo that tho' we find not that by Immediate Commi≈ø≈øion the Kings of England Vi≈øited before King Henry the Eighth's time, yet we have ≈øufficient grounds to Judge, that whatever was done, was by the Kings power, and Authority. Therefore Sir Edward
Cawdryes Ca≈øe 5 Reports p. 8. b. How the Temporal and Eccle≈øia≈øtical Courts were ≈øubordinate to the King according to the Opinion of our Modern Lawyers. Cooke lays it down for a Rule, that as in Temporal Cau≈øes, the King by the Mouth of the Judges in his Courts of Ju≈øtice doth Judge and determin the ≈øame by the Temporal Laws of England, ≈øo in Cau≈øes Eccle≈øia≈øtical and Spiritual by his Eccle≈øia≈øtical Judges according to the Eccle≈øia≈øtical Laws of the Realm; and that ≈øo many of the Eccle≈øia≈øtical Laws as were proved, approved, and allowed here, by and with General Con≈øent, are aptly and rightly called the Kings Eccle≈øia≈øtical Laws of England; and who≈øoever denyeth this, denyeth the King to have full and plenary power to deliver Ju≈øtice in all Ca≈øes to all his Subjects, without which he were not a compleat Monarch or head of the whole and entire Body of the Realm according to the words of the Statute, Stat. 24 H. 8. c. 12. The King the Fountain of Ju≈øtice. that the Kingly Head of this Body Politic is In≈øtituted and furni≈øhed with plenary, whole and intire Power, Preheminence, Authority, Prerogative and Juri≈øidiction, to render and yield Ju≈øtice and final determination to all manner of Folke, Re≈øiants or Subjects within the Realm in all cau≈øes, matters, debates and contentions happening to occur, in≈øurge, or begin within the limits thereof, &c.

div.head: ¬ß. 13. In what particulars our Kings claimed not Eccle≈øia≈øtical Admini≈øtration.
div.p:
It mu≈øt be likewi≈øe con≈øidered, that whatever power our Kings Exerci≈øed in Eccle≈øia≈øtical Affairs, they never claimed any in tho≈øe things the School men call Ordinis, as the Admini≈øtration of Sacraments, Celebrating Divine Offices, &c.
but in that which is called Juri≈ødictionis; and that being either Internal, where the Divine by per≈øua≈øion, whol≈øom In≈øtructions, Gho≈øtly Coun≈øel, and the like, convinceth the Con≈øcience,This is Sir Roger Twi≈ødens ob≈øervation. whereby it is obedient: or External, where the Church in Foro exteriori compels the Chri≈øtians obedience. As to the fir≈øt and ≈øecond, none of our Kings, either before or ≈øince the Reformation, took upon them at all to medle, either by a≈ø≈øuming to them≈øelves a power of Preaching, Teaching, Binding or loo≈øing in foro Animae, Admini≈øtring the Holy Sacraments, Conferring Orders, &c. But they took upon them the Ordering of ≈øuch things as were of outward Policy of the Church, as what Men were fit to Exerci≈øe them, and what ≈øubjection the Subjects ≈øhould yield to Decrees and Con≈øtitutions made abroad, and what Doctrins were publicly to be Taught, which might conduce to the quiet Peace and Tranquility of the Subject, and their living in Piety and Vertue.

div.head: ¬ß. 14. How the Popes obtained greater powers after the Canon Laws were owned here.
div.p: It is further to be noted, that the Popes power was enlarged after the Canon Law was received, more than it had been before; but if we believe Wal≈øingham Wal≈øingham ad Ann. 1297. it was not Read in our Univer≈øities publicly till the 25th. of Edward the Fir≈øt, by one Simon a Monk of Walden.

‚òû It is likewi≈øe to be noted, that altho', as I have ≈øhewn before, the fir≈øt Race of our Kings did frequently oppo≈øe ≈øome Rights the Popes claimed by Canons, yet within the compa≈øs of an Hundred Years after the Conque≈øt,The Popes Juri≈ødiction in four particulars by the Canons. or little more, the Court of Rome obtained four great points of Juri≈ødiction: Fir≈øt of ≈øending Legats into England. Secondly drawing Appeals to Rome. Thirdly, the Donation of Bi≈øhoprics and other Dignities in the Church. Fourthly the Exemption of the Clergy from Secular Power. Notwith≈øtanding all which, ≈øeveral Kings rea≈ø≈øumed their Rights and Juri≈ødiction as occa≈øions offered, until the Reign of King Henry the Eighth, as the Statutes of Mortmain, Provi≈øoes, &c. do manife≈øt.

div.head: ¬ß. 15. The Kings Supremacy a≈ø≈øerted by King Henry the 8th.
div.p:
But in King Henry the Eighth's time, a Total Rout was given to them all. In the Twenty fourth of his Reign all Appeals to Rome were taken away, and E≈øtabli≈øhed in the King, and all Sentences made or to be made with England declared to be Authentical, notwith≈øtanding any Act from Rome. The grounds of which Act are ≈øet forth in theStat. 24. H. 8. c. 12. Parag. 1. Preamble.
That this Realm of England is an Empire Governed by one Supreme Head and King,The Lawyers Judge this Statute not to be Introductory of any new power but declatory of the Ancient: Rights of the Crown. having Dignity and Royal E≈øtate of the Imperial Crown of the ≈øame, unto whom a Body Politic Compact of all ≈øorts and Degrees of People, divided in Terms by Names of Spirituality and Temporality, been bounden, and own to bear next to God a Natural, and humble obedience. Then follows the plenitude of the Kings power, as before I have related, after which follows, That the Body Spiritual hath power, when any cau≈øe of the Law Divine happens to come in que≈øtion, or of Spiritual Learning,This Statute was made to exclude the Popes power which King Henry the 8th. rejected. that it was declared Interpreted and ≈øhewed by that part of the Body Politic called the Spirituality, without the Intermedling of any exterior per≈øon, or per≈øons [by which the See of Rome is intended to be utterly Excluded, and all Canons of Council likewi≈øe not allowed of by the King and his Laws] to declare and detemin all ≈øuch doubts, and to Admini≈øter all ≈øuch Offices and Duties, as to their Rooms Spiritual doth appertain,‚Äî and the Laws Temporal for Tryal of property of Lands and Goods, and for the Con≈øervation of the people of this Realm in Unity and Peace, without Rapine and Spoil, was and yet is Admini≈øtred, Adjudged, and Executed by ≈øundry Judges and Mini≈øters of the other part of the Body Politic called the Temporality, and both the Authorities and Juri≈ødictions do conjoyn together in the due Admini≈øtration of Ju≈øtice, the one to help the other.

By which it is ea≈øie to infer, that this Statute exterminates and aboli≈øheth all Forreign power, ≈øo that whatever before this was Tran≈øacted here by the Popes or their Legats, is now to be declared and determined by the King, or ≈øuch as by Law are appointed to hear and determin ≈øuch matters under him.

div.head: ¬ß. 16. The Kings power of Vi≈øiting, &c.
div.p: In the Twenty-≈øixth of the ≈øame King, it is enacted, That the King, his Heirs and Succe≈ø≈øors ≈øhall have full Power and Authority from time to time to Stat. 26 H. 8 c. 1. The Kings power of Vi≈øiting. Vi≈øit, Repre≈øs, Redre≈øs, Reform, Order, Correct, Re≈øtrain and Amend all ≈øuch Errors, Here≈øies, Abu≈øes, Offences, Contempts and Enormities, what ≈øoever they be, which by any manner of Spiritual Authority or Juri≈øidiction ought or may lawfully be Reformed, Repre≈ø≈øed, Ordered, Redre≈ø≈øed, Corrected, Re≈øtrained, or Amended, mo≈øt to the plea≈øure of Almighty God, the increa≈øe of Virtue in Chri≈øts Religion, and for the Con≈øervation of the Peace, Unity and Tranquility of this Realm, any U≈øes, Cu≈øtoms, Forreign Laws, Forreign Authority, Pre≈øcription, or any thing or things to the contrary hereof notwith≈øtanding.

It is known, that the Title of Supreme Head of the Church, given by that Act to the King his Heirs and Succe≈ø≈øors was Repealed by
Queen Mary, The Title of Supreme Head changed. and was never re≈øtored: but in the Fir≈øt of Queen Elizabeth all the powers given by the Act of 26 H. 8. are re≈øtored to the Crown under the Name of Supreme Governor.

For in the fir≈øt of Queen Elizabeth ≈øuch Ancient Juri≈ødictions over the E≈øtate Eccle≈øia≈øtical are re≈øtored to the Crown,The re≈øtoring of Ancient Juri≈ødiction. as by Queen Mary had been Repealed, and all Foreign powers repugnant to the ≈øame are aboli≈øhed, I ≈øhall only in≈øert what relates to the pre≈øent matter.Stat. 1. Eliz. Parag. 17.
Parag. 17. It is thus Enacted, That ≈øuch Juri≈ødiction, Privileges, Superiorities, and Prehemenences Spiritual and Eccle≈øia≈øtical, as by any Spiritual and Eccle≈øia≈øtical power, or Authority hath heretofore been, or may lawfully be exerci≈øed, or u≈øed for the Vi≈øitation of the Eccle≈øia≈øtical State, and per≈øons, and for Reformation, Order, and Correction of the ≈øame and all manner of Errors, Here≈øies, Schi≈øms, Abu≈øes, Offences, Contempts, and Enormities ≈øhall for ever by Authority of this pre≈øent Parliament be ∆≤nited and Annexed to the Imperial Crown of this Realm.
Parag. 18. The Kings power in Eccle≈øia≈øtical matters. And in the 18th. Paragraph, The Queen, her Heirs and Succe≈ø≈øors, ≈øhall have full Power and Authority by Letters Patents under the Great Seal, to A≈ø≈øign, Name and Authorize, &c. ≈øuch per≈øon or per≈øons, &c. as the Queen her Heirs and Succe≈ø≈øors ≈øhall think meet, to exerci≈øe, u≈øe, occupy, and execute under them, all manner of Juri≈ødictions, Privileges, and Preheminences in any wi≈øe touching or concerning any Spiritual or Eccle≈øia≈øtical Juri≈ødiction within their Dominions, to Vi≈øit, Reform, Redre≈øs, Order, Correct, and Amend all ≈øuch Errors, Here≈øies, Schi≈øms, Abu≈øes, Offences, Contempts, and Enormities what≈øoever, which by any manner of Spiritual or Eccle≈øia≈øtical Power, Authority, or Juri≈ødiction can or may lawfully be Reformed, Ordered, Redre≈ø≈øed, Corrected, Re≈øtrained or Amended, &c.

Which ≈øeems to me,25 H. 8. c. 21. Parag. 20. The King Supreme Vi≈øitor. notwith≈øtanding Mr. Pryns exceptions, clear by another Act of Parliament, the words of which are,‚ÄîProvided that the ≈øaid Arch-Bi≈øhop of Canterbury, or any other per≈øon or per≈øons, ≈øhall have no power or Authority, by rea≈øon of this Act, to Vi≈øit or Vex any Mona≈øteries, Abbys, Priories, Colleges, Ho≈øpitals, Hou≈øes or other places Religious, which be or were Exempt before the making of this Act, &c. But that Redre≈øs, Vi≈øitation, and Confirmation ≈øhall be had by the Kings Highne≈øs, his Heirs and Succe≈ø≈øors, by Commi≈ø≈øion under the Great Seal to be directed to ≈øuch per≈øons as ≈øhall be appointed requi≈øite for the ≈øame.

In fine whoever con≈øiders the Accumulated power of our Kings mo≈øt, own √† fortiori, that whatever Vi≈øitatorial Power was excerci≈øed before King H. 8ths. time, was by the Kings allowance, and all ≈øince is ≈øolely derivative from the King as Sovereign Monarch and Supreme Governor.

div.head: SECT. II.

argument.p: Who Exerci≈øed Juri≈ødiction, by way of Vi≈øitation or otherways, over the ∆≤niver≈øities, from the 11th. of King John, to the Year 1390.14 Ric. 2.

div.head: ¬ß. 1. The Pope and his Legate Su≈øpend offenders.
div.p: HAving ≈øhown in a General way what Prerogatives the Kings of England have exerci≈øed in Eccle≈øia≈øtical Affairs before the Reformation, and how all the power the Pope claimed or exerci≈øed in point of Government is now by our Laws Inve≈øted in the Sovereign. I ≈øhall proceed to give an Account, how till the Reformation the Univer≈øity was Vi≈øited puni≈øhed and governed by the Arch-Bi≈øhop of Canterbury, ≈øome Popes, Legats, or the Bi≈øhop of Lincoln their Dioece≈øan: Yet all the≈øe were by the appointment, Approbation, or con≈øent of the re≈øpective Kings; the mo≈øt evident Ve≈øtigia of who≈øe Supreme power appeared, in the admitting, or making void exemptions and privileges even granted by the Apo≈øtolic See; ≈øo that it is not to be thought ≈øtrange, that ≈øince the Reformation (the whole Ecele≈øia≈øtical Government being declaredly derivative from the Crown, and the Authority of the Pope being by the Laws in force devolved upon our Princes) they have excerci≈øed a more De≈øpotical Authority over the Univer≈øities then over other Incorporations.

‚òû The Fir≈øt In≈øtance I find of the Popes Su≈øpending and the Kings Recalling the Lectures in the Univer≈øity was Anno 1209. the 11th. of King John; The
occa≈øion of which in ≈øhort was this.Wendover ≈øub. Anno 1209. M≈ø. Upon themi≈ø-information of the Burge≈ø≈øes of Oxford to the King, then at Wood≈øtock, that a Clerk had killed a Woman; two or three Innocent Clerks were ≈øeized and Executed,Wood Antiq. Oxon. lib. 1. fol. 59. upon which ≈øeverity, and the dete≈øtation of the Burge≈ø≈øes Malice, the Ma≈øters and Scholars removed out of the Inho≈øpitable Town; and Anno 1210. The Pope Intere≈øting him≈øelf becau≈øe they were Clerks, Commands the Scholars to Read no Lectures, and Anno 1213. ≈øends over Nicholas Bi≈øhop of Tu≈øculum his Legate, who Anno 1214.In Turri Schol. in pixide P. P. fa≈øci. c. 12. N. 2. & 3. publi≈øhed his Bull at Ram≈øey the 7th. of the Kalends of July. in which be≈øides the ≈øevere puni≈øhment inflicted on the Burge≈ø≈øes, it is plainly expre≈ø≈øed, that the Bi≈øhop of Lincoln, the Arch-Deacon of the place, his Official, the Chancellor, or any other Deputy of the Bi≈øhop, ≈øhould ≈øee to the performance of what was enjoyned; and tho≈øeMagi≈øtri vero qui po≈øt Scholarium rece≈ø≈øum Irreverenter legerunt Oxoniae, ≈øu≈øpendentur per Triennium ab officio Legendi. Ibid. Ma≈øters who Irreverently, after the rece≈øs of the Scholars, had Read Lectures contrary to the Popes Orders, ≈øhould be Su≈øpended from the Office of Reading for three Years. But I find, that the King gave leave to all to return to the Univer≈øity, and upon this occa≈øion, being willing to ≈øhew ≈øome ≈øpecial favor to it, and prevent the like mi≈øchiefs for the future, ob≈øerving where in their privileges were defective, Grants that the Chancellor ≈øhould have Cognizance of Cau≈øes where one party was a Scholar, or his Servant.

In this account it may be ob≈øerved,Inferences from this Hi≈øtory. that for contempt of the Popes Order the Legate Su≈øpends the Offenders for three Years, that the King Grants the leave for their return, and gives them new privileges.

div.head: ¬ß. 2. Cardinal Otho Vi≈øits by Legatin√© Authority.
div.p:
‚òû Anno 1238. 13 H. 3. Mat. Paris ad Annum 1238. Cardinal Otho came to Vi≈øit the Univer≈øity of Oxford as Legate a Latere; But had an unfortunate Journy, for the Scholars coming in great numbers to pay their re≈øpects to him, the uncivil PorterChron. Abendon M≈ø. would not permit them to enter till they forced their pa≈ø≈øage, and a Scholar going to the Legates Kitchin, a Ladle full of ≈øcalding broth was ca≈øt upon him, which the Scholars took ≈øo heinou≈øly, that one of them Slew the Legates Brother, and the Legate thereupon Fled with ≈øome danger to his per≈øon. Of all which the King being Informed, ≈øent Peter
Pat. 22 H. 3. M. 7. The Kings Commi≈ø≈øioners Interdict Divine Service. de Rupibus Bi≈øhop of Winche≈øter, Ralph Nevil Bi≈øhop of Che≈øter then Chancellor of England, and others, who met the Day after May day, in the Church of St. Fridi≈øwyde,
Flovileg. ≈øub hoc Anno. And Su≈øpend Lectures and Exerci≈øes. and Su≈øpended the Univer≈øity from Celebrating Divine Service, and from performing their Exerci≈øes and u≈øual Lectures. And the Legate Excommunicated the Univer≈øity, upon which many left the Univer≈øity, but the King Pat. 22 H. 3. M. 15. Cla. 22 H. 3. M. 15. Commanded that none ≈øhould depart without his leave, and ≈øeveral were Impri≈øoned and their GoodsId. fol. 90. a. ≈øeized into the Kings Hands but by the 15th. of May, upon Cl. Pat. 22 H. 3. M. 7. The King recalls the Students. Sureties given for appearing, mo≈øt were ≈øet at Liberty, and their Goods re≈øtored, and tho≈øe upon this occa≈øion Impri≈øoned in the Tower of London were relea≈øed, and the Sheriffs Cl. 22 H. 3. M. 13. of ≈øeveral Counties had the Kings Writ to return the Names of tho≈øe that had retired from Oxford, and of the Sureties of tho≈øe that were to abide the Tryal, and other Gl. 22 H. 3. M. 13. Writs I≈ø≈øued out to the Chancellor and the Arch-Deacon of Oxford, to warn all others that were in that Riot to return to the Univer≈øity to expect the Eccle≈øia≈øtical Ab≈øolution for their faults, and the Legate ≈øummoned theMat. Paris ≈øub An. 1238. Arch-Bi≈øhop of
York and all the Bi≈øhops to con≈øult about this Matter.

Anno 1239.14 H. 3. The LegateWood Antiq. fol. 91. a. The Legate gives leave to the Students to return. ≈øent an account likewi≈øe to the Pope and Cardinals, and after di≈ømi≈ø≈øing the Council the Legate Writ to the Chancellor, that he Exhorting the Academians to repentance ≈øhould give them all leave to return to the Univer≈øity from whence they had been ab≈øent above a Year, and had been Interdicted of their Exerci≈øes, Lectures, &c. And the puni≈øhment Impo≈øed was, that the ClerksIdem fol. 48. a. ≈øhould go from St. Pauls to Dure≈øme Hou≈øe on Foot, and after that all the Academians ≈øhould go bare Foot without Caps or Mantles and ≈øhould humbly ask the Legate Pardon:Appointeth a Pennance. which being done the Interdict was taken off, and the Scholars returned to Oxford to attend their wonted Lectures and Exerci≈øes; Thus were they puni≈øhed, there being Murther of the Legates-Brother in the Ca≈øe, the Bi≈øhop Robert Gro≈øthead defended the Clerks, In≈øi≈øting, that the Legats People gave the occa≈øion.

However, even in this ca≈øe when the Pope was ≈øo much concerned for the affront done to his Mini≈øters, yet we clearly find, that the King by his Commi≈ø≈øioners Su≈øpends the Univer≈øity from Celebrating Divine Service and performing their Lectures: Which are ≈øufficient badges of his prerogative in puni≈øhing Offenders, in ≈øuch manner as it was done, by his Commi≈ø≈øioners.

div.head: ¬ß. 3. The Bi≈øhop of Lincoln the Ordinary Vi≈øitor before Oxford was made a Bi≈øhops
div.p:
I now proceed to ≈øhew, See by King Hen. 8. that the Bi≈øhop of Lincoln was the Ordinary Vi≈øitor. In the Vi≈øitation by the Bi≈øhop of Tu≈øculum it appears, that the Legate Impowered the Bi≈øhop of Lincoln, or his Arch-Deacon, or the Chancellor, or others the Bi≈øhops Deputies
to ≈øee to the performance of what he had Decreed. By which ≈øome ≈øhow of Juri≈ødiction was left to him who was the Dioece≈øan, and by the Canons of the Church had the Vi≈øitation in Ordinary of all under his Juri≈ødiction, which by ≈øucceeding Councils I ≈øhall ≈øhewCap. 4. Sect. 4. ¬ß. 10. hereafter was his Right, and declared ≈øuch, even without Appeals from him, or any Exemption, and that they executed it appears by many examples in the Bi≈øhop of Lincolns Regi≈øter, yet by the In≈øtances following we find it, was often di≈øputed, e≈øpecially if they attempted to do any Exorbitant Act.

Robert Gro≈øthead Bi≈øhop of Lincoln
Wood Antiq. lib. 1. fol. 106. a ≈øingular Patron of the Univer≈øity being Dead, Henry Lexinton Succeeded, who not being content with the u≈øual power exerci≈øed by his Predece≈ø≈øors de≈øigned to enlarge his Juri≈ødiction, ≈øo that the Univer≈øity was forced to defend it ≈øelf by ≈øhewing the Bull of Pope Innocent the Fourth, granted to them a little before his Death, Dated at Avignion
Wood Antiq. A. fol. 48. b. and in Harus de Privilegiis fol. 4. a. the 5th. Kalend of October, the 12th. of his Pontificate, wherein he Confirms and Defends their Liberties and Immunities granted top them by Bi≈øhops, Kings, Noble-men and others; A 2d. wasA. & D. 24. a. granted by the ≈øaid Pope directed to the Bi≈øhops of London and Salisbury, for the Con≈øervation of the per≈øons, Liberties and Immunities of the Univer≈øity; A 3d. Dated 11th. November the ≈øameFarus de privil. 4. A. & D. 23. b. Year Confirming their Immunities Liberties and Cu≈øtoms; And a 4th. DatedF. F. 75. the ≈øame day and place in Confirmation of their Statutes, and this was Confirmed after by the Bull of Sixtus the Fourth.

div.head: ¬ß. 4. The Bi≈øhop of Lincolns complaint to the Pope again≈øt the di≈øobedience of the Univer≈øity.
div.p: But it ≈øeems, that the Bi≈øhop of Lincoln Complained to Alexander the Fourth, Succe≈ø≈øor to Innocent, that the Clerks in the Ca≈øtle of Oxford refu≈øed to obey the Authority his Predece≈ø≈øors had Enjoyed: upon which the Pope, by his Bull Dated Lib. Taxation. per Dominum Norwych, &c. Bulla 14. The Pope confirmes the Bi≈øhops claim. at Naples the 5th. of the Kalends of February, 1o. Pontificatus Decreed, that the Bi≈øhop might Exerci≈øe his Authority, notwith≈øtanding any Letters to the contrary heretofore obtained, from the Apo≈øtolic See, or to be obtained unle≈øs full mention of the pre≈øent Bull was In≈øerted. And it Chron. O≈ønil ≈øub An. 1258. The Bi≈øhop Vi≈øits. appears Anno 1258. 42 H. 3. That this Bi≈øhop Lexinton, made an Inqui≈øition into the Rights of the Univer≈øity, and by his Delegates examined in the Chappel of the Infirmaries the In≈øtruments and Charters of their Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions and Rights appertaining to the Church of O≈øney, concerning the Church of St. Greg. Situated in the Ca≈øtle of Oxford.

This Bi≈øhop Lexinton per≈øi≈øted in this Claim of Juri≈ødiction,Bi≈øhop of Lincoln changeth the Lectures and Statutes, and complaint of it is made to the King. ≈øo that on the 17th. of the Ides of March about Nine Ma≈øters of Arts came to St. Albans where they made their complaint before the King in the Chappel of St. O≈øwin again≈øt the Bi≈øhop of Lincoln, Venerunt ad St. Alban. quidum Magi≈øtri Oxoniae Circiter 9 Arti≈øtae qui querula voce coram Rege‚Äî Repo≈øuerunt querimoniam de Epi≈øcopo Lincolnien≈øi qui contra Statuta Univer≈øitatis Antiqua & Approbata nitebatur Libertates Scholarium enervare, & Statutus e≈øt dies re≈øpon≈øionis ad in≈øtans Magnum Parliamentum. Mat. Paris ad An. 1257. that he endeavored to enervate the Liberties of the Scholars again≈øt the Ancient and approved Statutes of the Univer≈øity; and a Day for An≈øwering was appointed at the Great parliament, that the Rea≈øons of both Parties being heard they might be appea≈øed.

It appears not how the matter was determined, yet it is manife≈øt that they had re≈øort to the Kings Authority in the matter, and his referring it to the
Parliament is no more then as in Arduous Cau≈øes the Kings refering a matter to his Supreme Court of Judicature the Hou≈øe of Lords, which give the Kings Judgment, and not, as Mr. Pryn mi≈øtakingly or willfully applys all ≈øuch things to the Sovereign power of the two Hou≈øes; Tho' the King Anno 1257.41 H. 3. compo≈øed the bu≈øine≈øs, yet the Bi≈øhop kept his Official there, thatAnnales Me. Bu≈øtonen≈øes M≈ø. when any Statutes were made by the Chancellor and Univer≈øity, he might ≈øee that the Bi≈øhops Authority was not Infringed, as we find that David Arch-Deacon of Derby Canon of Lincoln did that Year the: 4th. of the Nones of June enter his Prote≈øt, that they ≈øhould do nothing in prejudice of the Bi≈øhop or his Succe≈ø≈øor.

‚òû Here we cannot but ob≈øerve, that the Statutes are changed by a Vi≈øitor, and how the Members of the Univer≈øity finding them≈øelves aggrieved by their Ordinary Vi≈øitor, have recour≈øe to the King as their Supreme Judge and Vi≈øitor: Yet the Bi≈øhop of Lincoln as Dioce≈øan In≈øi≈øts on his Privilege to ≈øee that no Statutes were made without his Approbation, all which power our Kings now have.

div.head: ¬ß. 5. The Arch-Bi≈øhop of Canterbury Vi≈øits.
div.p:
The fir≈øt Vi≈øitation I find of the Univer≈øity by the Arch-Bi≈øhop of Canterbury, was Wood Antiq. Oxon. lib. 1. fol. 205. In hac Vi≈øitatione Academias ip≈øas Metropolitica Authoritate ingre≈ø≈øus e≈øt. M. Parker Antiq. Eccleae Brit. Fol. 198.
Anno 1278. 6 E.
‚Ä¢ . At which time Stephen Bi≈øhop of Paris Vi≈øited that Univer≈øity. But this ≈øeems de≈øigned principally to Refute and Condemn ≈øome Errors crept into the Schools, which in Theology, philo≈øophy and Logic he di≈øputed again≈øt, and with the con≈øent of the Ma≈øters Regents and non Regents, he Exploded and Condemned with this Cen≈øure, viz. That if he were a Ma≈øter of Art that Defended them, he he ≈øhould be Degraded, and if a Bachelor of Art,
≈øhould be uncapable of any other Degree,The Arch-Bi≈øhop appoints Statutes to Degrade and Incapacitate Students from taking Degrees. and ≈øhould be Expelled. From hence we may find ≈øome Foot≈øteps of a Vi≈øitors Incapacitating ≈øome, be≈øides Degrading and Expelling.

div.head: ¬ß. 6.
div.p: Anno 1281. 9 E. 1. The Chancellor of the Univer≈øity having a≈ø≈øumed ≈øome Eccle≈øia≈øtical Harus de privil. Oxon. fol. 13. b. Oliver Sutton Bi≈øhop of Lincoln Que≈øtions the Chancellors Authority. Rights and u≈øed to take Cognizance of the faults of Clerks that belonged to the Court Chri≈øtian, Oliver Sutton being made Bi≈øhop of Lincoln exacted an account of the≈øe things from the Chancellor and Proctors, intending to Deprive theIn Turri. Scholar. pix. 2. N. 5.6, &c. Univer≈øity of that Right: And after ≈øome debate, it was agreed, that when he appointed a Vi≈øitation of the Univer≈øity, if any Ma≈øters, Scholars or any Members of the Univer≈øity were faulty in any thing which appertained to the Eccle≈øia≈øtical Court, they ≈øhould be referred to the Chancellors Di≈øqui≈øition and Sentence, but in greater faults, or where any ≈øubmitted not to the Chancellors Sentence, their Names ≈øhould be ≈øent to the Bi≈øhop who promi≈øed not to promote them till they had ≈øatisfied the Chancellor. However I findWood fol. 128. that the Regents and non-Regents in Convocation declared, that the Univer≈øity was in full Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of certain Rights and Cu≈øtoms there expre≈ø≈øed.

And this I ≈øuppo≈øe they wereWood fol. 125. b. encouraged to do, becau≈øe the Year foregoing, viz. 1279.Turri. Scholar pix. 2. M. 2. The Arch-Bi≈øhop of Canterbury defends the Univer≈øity again≈øt the Bi≈øhop of Lincoln. John Peckam Arch-Bi≈øhop of Canterbury at a Synod held at Reading (moved by rea≈øon of Complaints made to him by the Chancellor) determined to defend the Privileges of the Univer≈øity and take the Goods of the Univer≈øity into his protection. For which purpo≈øe he Ratified the Sentence of Su≈øpen≈øion and Excommunication
made by the Chancellor or his Deputy again≈øt the Scholars that were Delinquents, or that Appealed to any Dioece≈øan, Subject to the Archiepi≈øcopal See.

HereuponWood. Ant. Fol. 127. a. The Arch-Bi≈øhop of Canterbury Vi≈øits. Anno 1284. 11 E. 1. The Arch-Bi≈øhop Vi≈øited the Univer≈øity about the end of October, and interpo≈øed his de≈øires and Authority, having Writ to the Univer≈øity not to be di≈øobedient to their Dioece≈øan and to the Bi≈øhop of Lincoln to u≈øe moderation,Oxonien≈øem Academiamjure Metropolitico Vi≈øitaturus adiit. Parker Antiq. fol. 204. tho' I find the mo≈øt of what he did was, as his Predece≈ø≈øor Kilwardly had done, to Condemn certain Erroneous Po≈øitions u≈øed to be maintained in the Schools by the the Minorite Fryers Preachers, and oppo≈øed by the Augu≈øtins, yet I findRegi≈øt. Peckham. Richard Knapwell a Dominican, Appealed to the Pope Anno 1285. Again≈øt the Arch-Bi≈øhops Sentence.

Anno 1287.Si in jure contenderent vinci, eos & ≈øuperari nece≈ø≈øe e≈ø≈øe, pre≈øertim cum his quibus uterentur privilegiis a Juri≈ødictione Epi≈øcopali jure communi ≈øtabilita eximi nequaquam potui≈ø≈øent Antiq. Brit. p. 204. In the life of John Peckham Arch-Bi≈øhop of Canterbury, Arch-Bi≈øhop Parker Writes, that there was a conte≈øt betwixt the Bi≈øhop of Lincoln, Oliver Sutton, and the Univer≈øity of Oxon for ≈øome Years concerning the Juri≈ødiction of the Bi≈øhop over the Scholars, in which when the Arch-Bi≈øhop under≈øtood the Cau≈øe of the Scholars to be feeble and not able to be Defended by the Laws, he Writ to them, that if they continued the Suit they ≈øhould undoubtedly be overcome, while they no ways could exempt the privileges they u≈øed from the Epi≈øcopal Juri≈ødiction E≈øtabli≈øhed by Common Law; that is, the univer≈øally received Canons.

By which we may Judge,The Univer≈øity ≈øubject to ≈øeveral Vi≈øitations. that the Arch-Bi≈øhop of Canterbury allowed the Ordinary Juri≈ødiction of the Bi≈øhop of Lincoln, in who≈øe power Oxford then was; yet this hinders not, but that they might be
≈øubject to other Superior Vi≈øitations as the Kings or the Popes Legates.

div.head: ¬ß. 7.
div.p:
Anno 1301.30 E. 1. Pope Boniface the Eighth the 11th. of the Ides of June 1o. Pontificatus
A. fol. 95. & Twynus lib. 3. ≈øect. 19. Pope Boniface the 8th. grants ≈øeveral privileges and exempts the Univer≈øity from Archiepi≈øcopal and Epi≈øcopal Vi≈øitation. grants to the Chancellor, Ma≈øters, Doctors and Scholars of the Univer≈øity of Oxford a Bull, wherein is expre≈ø≈øed that they had ≈øet forth in their Petition that ≈øeveral Kings of England of Famous Memory had granted them ≈øeveral privileges confirmed after by the pre≈øent King, and did humbly ≈øupplicate him, that he would make to them the like Conce≈ø≈øion and by his Apo≈øtolical Dignity would vouch≈øafe to exempt them from all Juri≈ødiction and power of what≈øoever Arch-Bi≈øhop, Bi≈øhops and other Ordinary Judges, which he grants, and Confirms their Exemption made by Pope Innocent the Fourth.

Mr. Wood gives many Rea≈øons why this Bull ≈øhould rather be a≈øcribed to Pope Boniface the Ninth Anno 1389. almo≈øt an Hundred Years after, but I need not enter into that enquiry, ≈øince all that I infer from this, or any other account I give of this matter, is, that the Kings of England were the fir≈øt be≈øtowers of the Secular privileges at the lea≈øt, and the Popes of the Spiritual and Eccle≈øia≈øtical, and and what the Arch-Bi≈øhop of Canterbury as Metropolitan, and the Bi≈øhop of Lincoln as Dioece≈øan did was by the Ordinary power of Vi≈øiting their Dioece≈øs which the Canons gave them as I ≈øhall ≈øhew hereafter.

div.head: ¬ß. 9. The Dominicans make di≈øturbances.
div.p:
This leads me before I proceed further to give an account of a difference that happned betwixt the Univer≈øity and the Dominicans, wherein it will appear, wherein it will appear, that matters relating to the Ordering the manner and Method of taking Degrees, and E≈øtabli≈øhing
and performing Exerci≈øes and Lectures were di≈øpo≈øed by the King or the Pope.

There having been a differenceWood Antiq Oxon fol. 150. b. betwixt the Dominicans and the Univer≈øity of Paris about the Ob≈øervance of Statutes of the Univer≈øity, the Dominicans claiming an Exemption from it's Juri≈ødiction, and denying that the Inceptors in Theology ≈øhould ask Licence of the Chancellor, or undergoe any Examination, but from tho≈øe of their own Family, after an Appeal to Rome the cau≈øe was adjudged in favor of the Fryers, which the Univer≈øity took ≈øo ill that they ab≈øtained from public Lectures.

The Dominicans in Oxford Anno 1211. Cavilled at the Statutes of that Univer≈øity, Wood ut ≈øupra. which for brevity ≈øake I ≈øhall refer the Reader to peru≈øe in my Author, but generally they were about taking their Degrees in Philo≈øophy and Divinity according to the pre≈øcripts of the Statutes, and that they ≈øhould be Admitted to no Degrees unle≈øs they Swore to the Ob≈øervation of the Statutes, and that they ≈øhould perform ≈øome Exerci≈øe in the Schools, and Preach in St. Maries, whereas they would Execute them in their own Fraternity: Upon which they fixed their Appeal, the Chancellor having refu≈øed it, upon the Gates of St. Maries Church.

Anno 1312.Id. fol. 151 ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ . Clau≈ø. 2. Ed. 2. M. 12. The Dominicans apply them≈øelves to the King who orders, that they ≈øhall enjoy their privileges, and that at the next Parliament the Univer≈øity by their Atturny ≈øhall An≈øwer to their Allegations, and bring their Charters and Privileges granted by the King or his Predece≈ø≈øors.

By which it appears how the King was their proper Judge, and what is called Parliamentary Judgment was before the Lords as the Kings Supreme Court, where differences among his Subjects were to receive their final determination.Idem. fol. 152. a. But it ≈øeems here it was not ended, for both Parties cho≈øe their Advocates, who appeared at Avignion or Rome, but the Pope to ≈øave Expences refers them back to have the matter determined in England.

The next Year Anno 1313. I find Arch-Bi≈øhopReg. Reynold, fol. 32.
Gualter Reynolds Writes to the Univer≈øity in their favor, and the Year following Anno 1314. They put the matter to Arbitration,Compo≈øitione ad Regem, ut ab eo firmaretur, tran≈ømi≈ø≈ø√¢ Pat. 7. E. 2. part. 2. M. 10. and ≈øend the Compo≈øition to be Confirmed by the King. Still it is the Royal Authority that is requi≈øite to make any Act binding.

The Dominicans were an Order then in great e≈øteem, for I find that they were mo≈øtly the Kings Confe≈ø≈øors, and ≈øo Anno 1316. They obtained the Kings Letter in their favors to the Pope, and Anno 1318. They obtained from the Pope a Privilege of Exemption from the Juri≈ødiction of the Univer≈øity.

By all the≈øe it appears,The ob≈øervation upon the forecited Records. that the ordering of all matters appertaining to the very taking Degrees, &c. were ≈øettled by the Kings A≈ø≈øent, and Confirmation of Popes. I now proceed.

div.head: ¬ß. 10.
div.p:
Wood fol. 160. b.
Anno 1325. 19 E. 2. Gulhardus Cardinal of St. Lucy in Celice, then Arch-Deacon of Oxford claimed theHarpsfield Hi≈øtor. Eccl. Sec. 14. c. 28. Cognizance of Eccle≈øia≈øtical Juri≈ødiction andReg. Reynold fol. 145.
Henry Gower the Chancellor, the Proctors, &c. re≈øi≈øted. And the Pope directed his Bull to the Arch-Bi≈øhop of Canterbury to be Publi≈øhed by the Abbots of O≈øney and Rewley, to Cite the Chancellor
and Proctors to appear in 60 Days at Rome, The Bi≈øhop of Lincolns Archdeacon of Oxford, claimes Eccle≈øia≈øtical Juri≈ødiction and the Pope cites the Chancellor. and complaint being made to the King Rot. Rom. 19. Ed. 3. The King writes to the Pope, that the matter may be heard in England. he Writes to the Pope to Nominate per≈øons here to determine and compo≈øe the Controver≈øie, which was accordingly done. By which it appears how Appeals were made to the Pope in ≈øuch ca≈øes, yet the King of England were not willing to have their Subjects grieved with chargable Appeals and Journies to Rome.

div.head: ¬ß. 11.
div.p:
Anno. 1350.24 E. 3. John Wood, &c. fol. 172. b. The King removes a Chancellor, the Bi≈øhop of Lincoln denies to Confirm the Kings Chancellor. The Univer≈øity Appeals to the Arch-Bi≈øhop. Wyllyot being unduely cho≈øen Chancellor the Year before, and removed by the King; Mr. William Palmorna was cho≈øen Chancellor, and John Synwell Bi≈øhop of Lincoln delaying to Confirm him, the Univer≈øity apply them≈øelves to the Arch-Bi≈øhop of Canterbury, Simon I≈ølip, who Commanded the Bi≈øhop to Confirm him within Seven Days, after the Receipt of his Mandate, or Five Days after to ≈øhew cau≈øe why he did not; who not Confirming or appearing, upon a ≈øecond complaint the Arch-Bi≈øhopVide Mat. Parker Antiq. Brit. fol. 268. ≈øent Commi≈ø≈øioners to whom he gave power to Confirm the Chancellor, and he deputed others Regi≈øt. I≈ølip fol. 20.28, 35. Conte≈øts betwixt the Arch-Bi≈øhop of Canterbury and Bi≈øhop of Lincoln about confirming the Chancellor of Oxford. Judicially to determin concerning the Election and Confirmation, and of the injury done by the Bi≈øhop of Lincoln: Who thereupon Appealed to the Pope, and for Contempt being Excommunicated by the Arch-Bi≈øhop, he Appealed again, and thus the Suits depended before the Pope till, ≈øaith Arch-Bi≈øhop Parker, Vide Parker Antiq. Brit. fol. 283. the Bi≈øhop renounced his privileges, and yielded to the Arch-Bi≈øhop, and thus the matter ≈øtood till Willi. Witt≈øley Arch-Bi≈øhop of Canterbury. Anno 1375.49 E. 3. obtained, from Pope ∆≤rban the Fifth, that the Univer≈øity ≈øhould be exempt from the Bi≈øhop of Lincolns Juri≈ødiction,
and that the Scholars ≈øhould have free liberty to Elect their Chancellor, who thereby might enter upon his Magi≈øtracy, without any farther Ceremony of Admi≈ø≈øion.

I have In≈øerted this to note, that when the Vi≈øitatorial power was claimed, the Confirmation of the Chancellor was then required, but the Election was always in the Regents and non-Regents as it is now. In this particular only it varies, that ≈øince Sir John Ma≈øons time Anno 1553. Excepting Cardinal Pool and the two late Arch-Bi≈øhops, Laud, and Shelden, the Chancellors have been Noble men and commonly the re≈øpective Kings have recommended the per≈øon by a kind of Conge d'e≈ølire of which I ≈øhall give one in≈øtance hereafter.

Anno 1376. 50 E. 3. Di≈ø≈øentions ≈øtill continuing betwixt the Chancellor, &c. And the Civil and Common Lawyer, the KingPat. 50 E. 3. part 1. M. 13. Commi≈ø≈øionated William Courtney Bi≈øhop of London, Thomas Arundel Bi≈øhop of Ely, Adam Howton Bi≈øhop of St. Davids, Ralph Ergham Bi≈øhop of Salisbury, and William Read Bi≈øhop of Cice≈øter or four or three of them, and gave them power to take cognizance and determin all matters in difference. By Command Id. M. 14. The matter commanded before the Parliament and determined by the Kings Commi≈ø≈øioners. likewi≈øe the Deputies or Proctors from the Doctors and Ma≈øters of Arts, and the Canon and Civil Lawyers, offered the State of the ca≈øe to the Parliament, and from thence to the Bi≈øhops, who meeting in St. Pauls London,
Wood Antiq. lib. 1. fol. 185. b. Abrogated the Statutes which occa≈øioned the di≈øagreements, and Decreed other two Statutes in favor of the Civilians, yet thus the Controver≈øie, by the ob≈øtinacy of the Parties, cea≈øed not, and tho' other Commi≈ø≈øioners were appointed, yet King Edward dying, his Grand≈øon King Richard the
Second ≈øuceeding, tho≈øe Acted nothing; and fre≈øh broyles and tumults ari≈øing, the Chancellor, Proctors, and three Monks Clau≈ø. 1. R. 2. M. 4. & 28. The King Su≈øpends their privileges. were cited to give an account of them, and in the interim the Univer≈øity was Mulcted by the Su≈øpen≈øion of their privileges, but by ≈øubmitting them≈øelves to the Kings Clemency, they were pardoned, and a Tribute,Pixide P. P. N. 17. lately ≈øot upon them, was taken off.

In the≈øe proceedings we find the King Abrogating Statutes and appointing new ones by his Commi≈ø≈øioners,What is to be noted from hence. and the privileges of the Univer≈øity Su≈øpended: which are ≈øufficient pre≈øidents of the Kings power.

div.head: ¬ß. 12. Di≈øturbances in Queens College and the proceedings of the Local Vi≈øitor, and the King thereupon.
div.p: Anno 1379. 3 Ric. 2. The King having granted ≈øeveral Immunities to the Univer≈øity and ≈øettled matters betwixt the Univer≈øity and Dominicans, he took into con≈øideration a matter which had been three Years in Debate. The ca≈øe was this, there having been di≈øturbances in Queens College, whether upon the Election of a Provo≈øt, or upon occa≈øion of new opinions, it is not certain which; there had been Suites and Appeals to Alexander Nevil Arch-Bi≈øhop of York their Local Vi≈øitor, and he ≈øent per≈øons deputed by him with power to determin the matters: But the≈øe were received ≈øo ≈øharply at Oxford, that they could not exerci≈øe their Vi≈øitatorial Authority, till the King ≈øent his Breve or WritChartophyl. Civit. Oxon. to the Chancellor and Major to a≈ø≈øi≈øt the Vi≈øitors in executing their Office; by which at pre≈øent things were quieted. But it broke out again, till by a ≈øecond Vi≈øitation, or Peculiar Mandate ≈øent to the College, Mr. Henry Whylefield the Provo≈øt, Mr. William French, Robert Lydeford, and John Trevis Fellows were Expelled.

The≈øe by private con≈øultation among them≈øelves took away the Charters, Books, the Jewels, Mony and other Goods of the College till the Chancellor and Proctors upon the KingsIu≈ø≈øu Regio 13. R. 2. M. 40. Mandate cau≈øed them to be re≈øtored by Whitefield, the Expelled, to Thomas Carvel the new Provo≈øt. But ≈øtill all was not quiet, tho≈øe Expelled e≈øpecially making di≈øturbances, therefore on the Seventh of February the King i≈ø≈øued out hisPat. 3 R. 2. par. 2. M. 12. Letters Patents to Mr. Berton the Chancellor, John Sherburn, Thomas Swindon and Robert Bixy under the Great Seal to examin and determin the matters.

By this it appears,What is to be Inferred from this. that either by the Local Vi≈øitor or the Kings ab≈øolute Authority, the Provo≈øt and ≈øeveral Fellows were Expelled, That the King Commi≈ø≈øionated ≈øome under the Broad Seal to hear and determin the matters which no doubt was by ≈øome one way and demon≈øtrates the Kings ab≈øolute power in Expelling and by Commi≈ø≈øion determining matters in the Univer≈øity, without other Vi≈øitations, and we may note when ever the Vi≈øitations were performed by the Ordinary Vi≈øitors, viz. The Arch-Bi≈øhop or Bi≈øhops, it was about ≈øome things relating to their Function, ≈øettled by the Canons and allowed by the Laws of the Land; but ≈øtill the la≈øt re≈øort was made to the King, be≈øides his fir≈øt giving leave as in many particulars is very clear.

div.head: ¬ß. 13. Arch-Bi≈øhop Courtneys Vi≈øitation.
div.p:
Anno 1389. William Courtney Arch-Bi≈øhop of Canterbury Vi≈øited his Province, and the Scholars were troubledWal≈øingham Hi≈øt. Angliaead Annu. 1389. fol. 341. for that they had never ≈øeen nor heard ≈øuch a Mandate of Vi≈øitation, that both Exempted and not Exempted ≈øhould be Vi≈øited. Therefore the Black Monks urged theirThe≈øe were the Black Monks of Glouce≈øter College. Exemptions, and applyed them≈øelves to the Abbots of We≈øtmin≈øter
and St. Albans, who advi≈ø≈øed them not to yield to the Arch-Bi≈øhops Vi≈øitation,Wood Antiq. Oxon lib. 1. fol. 196.a. and Letters were ≈øent from the Abbot of ≈øt. Albans, to the Arch-Bi≈øhop to de≈øire him to de≈øi≈øt, to which the Arch Bi≈øhop replyed, that ≈øaving the Right of his Church, he would willingly do what he could for his ≈øpecial friend the Abbot, but faid, he could not any ways de≈øi≈øt, ≈øaving that Right from Vi≈øiting the Prior and Black Monks Studying in Oxford, even tho' theEtiam≈øi Rex Angliae pro praedictis In≈øtaret. King ≈øhould intreat for them, becau≈øe they were a College, and had a Prior and Chapter, and lived in Common. The Monk ≈øent from St. Albans ≈øaid they were not a College,Non fuit ibi Collegium cum ibi morantes ≈øigillum Commune non habent nec locus ≈øit donatus Terr poralibus & Spiritualibus, &c. for that they had not a Common Seal, or were Endowed with Spiritualities or Temporalities, and wanted many other things which were required to Con≈øtitute a College. The Arch-Bi≈øhop An≈øwered, therefore he would Vi≈øit, to enquire how it was with them. Then the Monk reply'd, if he came to Vi≈øit them he had no Juri≈ødiction to enquire of ≈øuch things, By this appears what are of the E≈ø≈øence of a College, and that in this Age Monks of ≈øeveral Orders had their Schools here, ‚Ä¢ nd yet were reckoned as Members of the Convent they were ≈øent from, rather than of any Incorporate Society of the Univer≈øity. but only to Vi≈øit ≈øuch as were not Exempt, for tho≈øe that were Exempt were Vi≈øitable in their proper Mona≈øteries by the Arch-Bi≈øhop and ≈øo not to be Vi≈øited a ≈øecond time. To this Allegation the Arch-Bi≈øhop An≈øwered, that they were not Vi≈øited by him in their proper Mona≈øteries, for the Abbots excu≈øed them, for that they were in the Schools, therefore he would Vi≈øit them there. And then a Monk and Lawyer, who came with the Arch-Bi≈øhop, willing to enlarge the Arch-Bi≈øhops Juri≈ødiction, ≈øaid, that the Arch-Bi≈øhop might Vi≈øit even the ExemptsExempti ibi ita ≈øunt privilegiati, quod ubicunque fuerint non ≈øunt ≈øub Juri≈ødistione alicujus Epi≈øcopi, ni≈øi Romani Pontificis, vel Legati a Latere mi≈ø≈øi. as long as they were in the Schools, for that they were under the Juri≈ødiction of the Chancellor: to this the Monk of St. Albans replyed,
that the Exempt are ≈øo privileged, that wherever they were they might not be under the Juri≈ødiction of any Bi≈øhop unle≈øs of the Bi≈øhop of Rome, or his Legate a Latere ≈øent hither. To which the Arch-Bi≈øhop ≈øaid, if it were ≈øo, he neither could nor would mole≈øt them in any thing.

A while after Simon de Southerey pre≈øented him≈øelf to the Arch-Bi≈øhop in the Church of St. Fridi≈øwyde, whith all the Monks Exempt and not Exempt, and the Arch-Bi≈øhop asked them if they ≈øubmitted to his Vi≈øitation, and it was an≈øwered, that they came to obtainAd Captandam ejus Benevolentiam advenerunt. his favor, and the Arch Bi≈øhop told them, that he excu≈øed them, and never intended to burthen them, ≈øo there was an end of this matter.

By all which it appears, that the Di≈øpute was about the privilege of Exemption: But that the power of Metropolitical Vi≈øitation was allowed, and that power was by the then Laws, and is now, derivative from the King.

div.head: SECT. III.

argument.p: Who Vi≈øited the ∆≤niver≈øity of Oxford after the 13th. of King Richard the Seconds time to the beginning of King Henry the 8ths. Reign.

div.head: ¬ß. 1. The King redre≈ø≈øeth certain grievences complained of by both Univer≈øities.
div.p: HOw far the King Intere≈øted him≈øelf in Ordering the Affairs of the Univer≈øity appears in what King Richard the Second did Anno 1390. 14 Regni of which I ≈øhall give a ≈øhort account.

The Fryers Preachers, or Dominicans were complained of by both the Univer≈øities, that ≈øeveral of them, Students there, declined the Examination of the Univer≈øity, in order to the taking their Degrees, and going beyond Sea obtained the Titles of Ma≈øters, not without Infamy to the Brothers or Fryers, and the great lo≈øs of the Univer≈øity. Thereupon the King writes to the Prior Provincial, and all the Priors in England.

div.head: ¬ß. 2. What is to be ob≈øerved from hence.
div.p: ‚òû What is worthy noting from hence is, that altho' this Order had many privileges and Exemptions from Vi≈øitations and ≈øubjection: Yet we find the King under the penalty of the forfeiture of all they could, enjoyns them to obey what he commands, and tho' it is not to be doubted that ≈øome of the≈øe Men might receive Degrees in ≈øome Univer≈øities who had from the Pope privileges, that whoever received Degrees there, ≈øhould enjoy all the Liberties, Honors, &c. which tho≈øe did of our own Univer≈øities; yet the King di≈ø allows all ≈øo that by this one In≈øtance it appears, that the Kings of England allowed or di≈ø allowed at their plea≈øure Immunities, Exemptions, privileges, &c. which were granted by the Popes Emperors or Forreign Kings; for from ≈øuch tho≈øe privileges to Graduates only could be granted.

From which it is manife≈øt that the King challenged a power of being Supreme Judge of what Exemptions ≈øhould be allowed in his Univer≈øities, and by con≈øequence was always to be reputed the Supreme Vi≈øitor.

Hereby al≈øo will appear the true Rea≈øon of the Application to the King, in the conte≈øts I ≈øhall pre≈øently
