give an account of, which happened betwixt the Arch-Bi≈øhop of Canterbury, and the Univer≈øity about his Vi≈øitation, which by the Popes Bulls they were Exempted from.

div.head: ¬ß. 3.
div.p: ‚òû Anno 1395. 19 Ric. 2. The Lollards, that is, the favorers of Wickliffs Doctrin, greatly increa≈øed, ≈øowing (as the Writers of that time and others Style it) TaresZizanium inter Triticum pro≈øeminantes. among the Wheat, choaking the Catholic Doctrin. Upon which many complaints are made to the King, and e≈øpecially by the Bi≈øhops, by which being moved, he Writ to the ChancellorCl. 19 R. 2. M. 24. Commanding him, as the words are, utterly to Root out tho≈øe wickede≈øtUt nequi≈ø≈øimos, fidel Ever≈øores. overturners of the Faith, and at the ≈øame time Writ to the Chancellor and Doctors by his Mandare, enjoyning them to examin the Book of Wickliff called the Triolog ‚Ä¢ s, The Kings Mandate to extirpate what then was reputed Here≈øic. and to ≈øend the heads of the Errors therein contained under the Seal of the Univer≈øity into the Chancery, and it is noted forther, that the Univel≈øity ≈øubmitted it ≈øelf to the King, promi≈øing to ≈øtand to his Arbitrament, for which purpo≈øe they ≈øent an In≈øtrument by their Chancellor Thomas Hindyman, Thomas Merk, Thomas Crawley, &c. to the King.

By which it appears manife≈øtly,Inferences from hence. that the King by his ab≈øolute power Commanded matters to be ordered in the Univer≈øity, and that it ≈øubmitted to his determination notwith≈øtanding other Metropolitical Vi≈øitations, which, as ≈øuch, mu≈øt be looked upon as done by the power of the King Eccle≈øia≈øtical Laws as the mo≈øt Learned of the Long Robe do maintain.

In the Year 1396. The 20th of Richard the Second a great conte≈øt was beowixt the Doctors of Divinity, Masters of Arts, and the Civil and Canon
Lawyers: The whole proce≈øs of which may be ≈øeen in myWood Antiq. Oxon lib. 1. fol. 197. New conte≈øts betwixt Graduates and Lawyers. Author, the ≈øumm of which was, that ≈øeveral Statutes were made to their prejudice, and that the Chancellor pretended Bulls of Exemption from the Archiepi≈øcopal Vi≈øitation of the Univer≈øity, The conclu≈øion of all which was, that as King Edward the Third had Anno 1376. 50 Regni appointed Five Bi≈øhops to enquire into the matter and order it, ≈øo thePat. 20 R. 2. part. 3. M. 26. King the next April by his Royal Authority confirms their doom.

By which it ≈øtill appears how the la≈øt re≈øort was made to the King which will yet more fully be cleared by what I ≈øhall now relate as to the Vi≈øitation of Arch-Bi≈øhop Arundel under King Richard the Second and King Henry the Fourth;The rea≈øon why the Author enlargeth upon the Vi≈øitations by Arch-Bi≈øhop Arundel. which becau≈øe they have been ≈øo much in≈øi≈øted upon, as pregnant proofs, even in King Charles the Fir≈øts time, that the Arch-Bi≈øhop of Canterbury by Right is the Vi≈øitor of the Univer≈øities, I think it nece≈ø≈øary to take notice of, that I may ≈øhew the grounds upon which tho≈øe Kings allowed the Arch Bi≈øhops Vi≈øitation, and how it no ways prejudices the Kings Vi≈øitatorial power.

div.head: ¬ß 4. the Arch-Bi≈øhop Arundel Vi≈øiting by the Kings leave commands the Univer≈øity to obey.
div.p:
‚òû Anno 1397. 21 Ric. 2. The Arch-Bi≈øhop of Canterbury determining to Vi≈øit for the ≈øuppre≈ø≈øing of Here≈øies as then they were called, and compo≈øing affairs of the Univer≈øity, and under≈øtanding that the Chancellor and Proctors ≈øupported by the Popes Bull of Exemption, intended to ob≈øtruct it. He ≈øignifies this to the King. Here I hope is a craving the Kings leave and and aid; what doth the King in this ca≈øe? He pre≈øently Writes to the Chancellor and Scholars, and forbidsLiteris praecepit ut in juris Regii detrimentum, Haereticorum vero & Lollardorum patrocinium, Archiepi≈øcopali ≈øe≈øe, aut Epi≈øcopali Authoritati nequaquam ‚Ä¢ ubtraherent. them, that to the dammage of his Kingly Right, or Patronage of Heretics and Lollards, they no ways withdraw them≈øelves from Archiepi≈øcopal
or Epi≈øcopal Juri≈ødiction,Id. pat. 21 R. 2. part. 3. M. 32. or produce any Bull of the Pope to that purpo≈øe. But that they renounce the ≈øaid Bull before the Kings Me≈ø≈øenger, and te≈øtifie ≈øuch their Renunciation by public In≈øtruments.
I know not wherein the King could di≈øcover his power more plainly than in Abrogating the very Bulls of Popes: ≈øurely he that can do this may Su≈øpend a Statute.
I know it will be here replyed, that the King upon the Controver≈øies betwixt the Arch-Bi≈øhop, and the Univer≈øity about the Right of Vi≈øitation, declared for the Arch-Bi≈øhop.

To which at pre≈øent I ≈øhall only reply, that the King here was not as a party, but as a Judge in a Controver≈øie depending, declaring his own plea≈øure, which ≈øurely manife≈øts his Supreme Juri≈ødiction, and that appears from the very words of the Parliament,Cum quaedam de≈ø≈øentiones, lites & debatae nuper motae fuerunt inter, &c. ≈øuper u≈øu, & excercitio Juri≈ødictionis & Vi≈øitationis dictae Univer≈øitatis &c. nos volentes huju≈ømodi di≈ø≈øentiones, &c. (prout Regiae convenit Maje≈øtati, attentis damnis & periculis quae inde ver≈øimiliter evenire po≈ø≈øent) ≈øedare & pacificare, ac pacem quietem & tranquillitatem inter partes praedictas pro viribus confovere, &c. Pat. 20 R. 2. part. 3. M. 9. that whereas ≈øome di≈ø≈øentions, ≈øtrifes, and debates of late were moved and ri≈øen betwixt the Arch-Bi≈øhop, &c. on the one part, and the Chancellor of the Univer≈øity of Oxford, and ≈øeveral others of the ≈øaid Univer≈øity on the other part, about the u≈øe and exerci≈øe of Juri≈ødiction and Vi≈øitation, the Arch-Bi≈øhop claiming it, &c. as appertaining to his Church of Canterbury, &c. The King willing to quiet and pacifie the ≈øaid Di≈ø≈øentions, Suites, and Debates, and to pre≈øerve peace, quiet, and tranquility among≈øt the parties, as it agrees with his Kingly Maje≈øty, attending the damage and danger which in probability might happen thereupon, con≈øidering that Jure Communi the Vi≈øitation belonged to the Arch-Bi≈øhop, &c. therefore determins it for him.

Surely Jus Commune mu≈øt here be taken as that by Canon Law, Common Right, or by our Common
Law of England this appertained to the Arch-Bi≈øhop of Canterbury; and then it can be under≈øtood no otherways then that virtute officii he might Vi≈øit, correct and reform all within his Dioce≈øs, and that Exemptions were breaches of that Common Right, and whatever he did quatenus Arch-Bi≈øhop, or as Leg ‚Ä¢ us natus he did by Authority from the King or the Pope, and from either of which ≈øoever he had them, or by the Canons; yet none of the≈øe can deprive a more Soveraign power, from vi≈øiting by it's ≈øelf, or it's delegates; and the la≈øt clau≈øeSalvis nobis & Haeredibus no≈øtris, onmibus aliis quibus in Univer≈øitate praeaicta nos & progenitores no≈øtri-uti con≈øue vimus temporibus retroactis Id. Pat. of the Patent is therefore to be ob≈øerved heedfully, which is, ≈øaving to our ≈øelves and our Heirs all other [Rights or Prerogatives] which we and our Progenitors in by pa≈øt times, have been wont to u≈øe in the ≈øaid Univer≈øities.

This further appears, if we credit Mr. Woods note upon it, that this did not touch the Popes Exemption; for if not that, it much le≈øs effected the Kings Prerogative in general, for tho' one King by his Charter may yield it, yet he cannot in prejudice to his Succe≈ø≈øor make it binding to him, to which we may add what he further ≈øaith, that, whatever was done, it is certain that that Vi≈øitation did not then ≈øucceed.

Before I leave this head I mu≈øt de≈øire the Reader to con≈øider, that the Arguments of tho≈øe who oppo≈øed the Exemption were, that this Immunity granted by the Pope was not only to the prejudice and grievance of the Metropolitan and Ordinary, but likewi≈øe to the whole Univer≈øity, and was rather a ≈øervitude then liberty to them, for without that, if they had been oppre≈ø≈øed by their Chancellor, or Vice-Chancellor, they might have been redre≈ø≈øed by Appeals
to the Arch-Bi≈øhop, but now, being reduced under the power of one, they were ≈øubject to perpetual ≈øervitude.

div.head: ¬ß. 5. The Arch-Bi≈øhops Vi≈øitation re≈øi≈øted.
div.p:
‚òû Anno 1411. Thomas Arundel the Arch-Bi≈øhop intending to Vi≈øit the Univer≈øity ≈øent his Letters of CitationHarus in memorabilibus fol. 106. b. to the Chancellor, Doctors, Ma≈øters and Scholars to be ready again≈øt his coming, and was received by the Chancellor and Proctors and a great conflux of the Univer≈øity, and the Chancellor Richard Dum nititur vi≈øitare Univer≈øitatem Oxoniarum Repul≈øam pa≈ø≈øus e≈øt. Wal≈øing Ypodegma neu≈øt. ad Ann. 1411. The Kings Authority.
Courtney told him, that if he came as a Gue≈øt he was mo≈øt Welcome, but if he came as a Vi≈øitor the Univer≈øity was long ≈øince by the Popes Bull freed from Archiepi≈øcopal and Epi≈øcopal Vi≈øitation: at which the Arch-Bi≈øhop was much di≈øplea≈øed, and after a Day or two ≈øtay he went away, and ≈øent the King an account by Letter, ≈øo the King CommandedFragmenta veteris Regi≈øtri Univer≈øitatis Oxon Bib. Cotton ≈øub fau≈øtina c. 7. the Heads of the Univer≈øity to appear the Day after our Ladies Day to give an account of the Popes Bull which they pretended. What followed upon it appears by the Chancellor and Proctors laying down their Offices at Lambeth, The Chancellors and Proctors quit their places. The King appoints the Senior Theologue to Officiate in the Chancellors ≈øtead. whether voluntarily or compelled appears not. And the King writes to the Univer≈øity, that the Cancellarius Natus or Senior of the Theologues ≈øhould exerci≈øe the Office till there ≈øhould be an Election of another in his place, and Commanded that the Papal Exemption ≈øhould be brought to him. Upon this there was ≈øuch a ≈øadne≈øs ≈øurprized the Students that the Lectures cea≈øed, and they were di≈øper≈øed,The Students leave the Univer≈øity and de≈øi≈øt from Lectures. and an end ≈øeemed to be put to the Univer≈øity according to a Statute made to that purpo≈øe, that they ≈øhould u≈øe that Remedy if any invaded their Liberties and Privileges. Which being imparted to the King he Writ fir≈øt C. fol. 31. a. di≈øplea≈øedly at the Fact of the Heads, and in a
≈øecond Letter C. fol. 55. b. exhorts them in ≈øofter Language to revoke their Lectures, and after a while, le≈øt the Univer≈øity ≈øhould receive damage,The King gives leave to choo≈øe Chancellors, &c. about October the King Commanded that ≈øuch ≈øhould be cho≈øen as might Execute the Offices of tho≈øe removed for the remainder of theFrag. vet. Regi≈øt. ≈øupra. Year, and the Univer≈øity cho≈øe the la≈øt Chancellor and Proctors, which being certified to the King he took it very ill.The King di≈øplea≈øed with the Election. After which, Law Suites being Commenced betwixt the Arch-Bi≈øhop and Univer≈øity,The King hears the cau≈øe and determins for the Arch-Bi≈øhop. it was agreed, that all parties ≈øhould ≈øtand to the Kings Judgment, and about the middle of December the King heard it, and he appointed, that the SentenceIbid. which King Richard the Second had given ≈øhould ≈øtand.

div.head: ¬ß. 6. An account of the whole matter as in the Parliament Roll.
div.p: I ≈øhall now give an account of the matter as it appears in the ParliamentRot. Parl. 13 H. 4. N. 15. Roll.

Fir≈øt, there is the Arch-Bi≈øhops Petition to the King, that with the A≈ø≈øent of the Lords Spiritual and Temporal and the Commons A≈ø≈øembled in the ≈øaid Parliament, the Schedule Annexed might be confirmed.

Which Schedule contains the Declaration of King Richard the Second, as it is to be found in Mr. Pryn, wherein it appears, that the ground of the Conte≈øt and differences was about a Bull of Exemption pretending to exclude the Arch-Bi≈øhop of Canterbury and his Succe≈ø≈øors, and all other Ordinaries and Founders of the ≈øaid Univer≈øity and Colleges from Vi≈øiting, and all other Ordinary Juri≈ødiction, which Bull by a venire facias was brought into the Chancery at We≈øtmin≈øter, and the Chancellor and Proctors ≈øhewed a ≈øufficient Warrant under the Univer≈øities Seal to produce the Bull in Chancery, and to an≈øwer there, and to do and receive what ≈øhould be ordered and determined
by the late King Richard the Second and his Council as appears by the Records of the Chancery, and after the Chancellor and Proctors for them≈øelves and the Univer≈øity ≈øubmitted them≈øelves in the fore≈øaid mattersOrdinationi & definis ioni dicti nuper Regis. to the Ordinance and Determination of the ≈øaid King.

‚òû The King after mature and fuller deliberation with his Council, clearly con≈øidering that the Bull was procured in prejudice of his Crown, and to the revoking or enervating of the Laws and Cu≈øtoms of his Realm, and in favor and emboldning of Heretics and Lollards, Murtherers and other Malefactors, Ordained, and by his Breve orIn fide Logeancia & dilectione quibus ≈øibi tencbantur. Ac ≈øub poena ami≈ø≈øionis privilegiorum Univer≈øitatis praedictae & ≈øub forfeitura omnium aliorum quae ≈øibi foris facere potuerunt, ne dictam Bullam in aliqua ≈øui parte exequi ≈øeu excercere ≈øeu Beneficium quoddam Exemptionis per Bullam illam aliqualiter reportare ≈øeu recipere pre≈øumerent. Mandate Commanded and forbid the Chancellor, Ma≈øters, Doctors and Scholars of the ≈øaid Univer≈øity on their Faith, Allegiance and the love that they ought him, and under the penalty of lo≈øing the privileges of the ≈øaid Univer≈øity, & the forfeiture of all other things which they could forfeit, that they pre≈øumed not to execute or exerci≈øe the ≈øaid Bull in any part of it, or any ways to pre≈øume to enjoy or receive any benefit of Exemption by the ≈øaid Bull: But to renounce all the Exemptions and Privileges contained in it before Richard Kendall the Kings Clerk and Notary, and ≈øhould tran≈ømit an In≈øtrument for that purpo≈øe under the Seal of the ≈øaid Univer≈øity by the ≈øaid Clerk under the Penalties afore≈øaid. After which follows the Kings Sentence as before.

In this part it may be ob≈øerved how the King di≈øcovers his Authority and Prerogative over the Univer≈øity, in injoyning them to renounce the Popes Bull and not to Execute, &c. The King may deprive the Univer≈øity of all privileges for di≈øobedience. it under the penalty there mentioned, which demon≈øtrates that for contempt and di≈ø-obedience the King may not only Su≈øpend
and Deprive any Member of the Univer≈øity, but take away all their Privileges, &c. which would be well con≈øidered by tho≈øe who ob≈øtinately refu≈øe to obey the Mandate of a King of England.

div.head: ¬ß. 7. The account of the latter Vi≈øitation
div.p: Then follows the account of the later Vi≈øitation of the Arch-Bi≈øhop in the 12th. 12. H. 4. of Henry the Fourth as before related, where Richard Courtney the Chancellor, and Benedict Brent and John Birch the Proctors oppo≈øed him, and he and the Univer≈øity ≈øubmited them≈øelves to the Arbitrament, Judgment, Ordination and Decree of the King, and the King Summoned them to appear before him at Lambeth upon the 17th. of September, where hearing all things and having con≈øideration of the Submi≈ø≈øion made to King Richard, and the Ordination, Judgment and Determination of the ≈øame, the King Confirmed and Ratified the ≈øame: And further ordered if they obeyed not the Arch-Bi≈øhop, &c. all their Franchi≈øes, Liberties, and all the Privileges of the ≈øame Univer≈øity ≈øhould be ≈øeized into the hands of the King and his Heirs till they performed it, and the Chancellor and Vice-Chancellor and Proctors of the Univer≈øity for the time being and their Succe≈ø≈øors and the Univer≈øity ≈øhall pay to the King and his Heirs 1000 l.

Then follows that this Schedule being ≈øeen and examined and under≈øtood with mature and diligent deliberation:Note here the Kings peculiar power in pa≈ø≈øing an Act of Parliament. The King in full Parliament affirmed and declared, that all and every thing contained in the ≈øame Schedule were done, Arbitrated, Ordered, Con≈øidered, Decreed and Adjudged by him. And the Lords Spiritual and Temporal, and the Commons in the ≈øaid Parliament who had full deliberation likewi≈øe of the ≈øame, approved, ratified and confirmed it.

Upon the whole matter of this great conte≈øt about the Arch-Bi≈øhops Vi≈øitation, I think the King and the Parliament were at that time the more Inclined to confirm the Arch-Bi≈øhops power, becau≈øe that kept the Vi≈øitatorial power within the Kings Dominions, and Excluded Exemptions, which the State of England was rarely inclined to favor, as being mo≈øtly as prejudicial to the Crown as the Bi≈øhops. And Wickliffs Doctrin ≈øpreading, the King was more willing the Arch-Bi≈øhop ≈øhould Vi≈øit the Univer≈øity, becau≈øe it was his proper Office to ≈øee to the pre≈øervation of the E≈øtabli≈øh'd Religion, and if the Univer≈øity had been left to the Vi≈øitation of the Chancellor, the opinion of Mr. Wickliff might have the more encrea≈øed, ≈øince the temper of the Members might have been changed from the Doctrin profe≈ø≈øed ≈øince ≈øo many in the Univer≈øity were then ≈øaid to have embraced it.

div.head: ¬ß. 8. The rea≈øons why the Author hath given ≈øo large an account of this.
div.p: I have in≈øi≈øted the longer upon this particular for two Rea≈øons, fir≈øt to ≈øhew that the Government, ordering, and reforming of Univer≈øities were then Judged to be of Eccle≈øia≈øtical Cognizance; e≈øpecially in tho≈øe matters which appertain to the Doctrins taught in them, which even in their Philo≈øophical Di≈øputes in ≈øome mea≈øure effected Religion, even the taking of Degrees, except in the faculty of Phy≈øic, was in Ordine ad Spiritualia; as appears in tho≈øe Con≈øtitutions which prohibit any from having Benefices but ≈øuch as had taken Degrees in Univer≈øities; a further Illu≈øtration of the former of the≈øe Inferences I ≈øhall clear when I ≈øpeak of Bi≈øhop Rippingdons Vi≈øitation.

Secondly,The mi≈øapplication of Mr. Pryn. To ≈øhew the mi≈ø-application of Mr. Pryn, who finding by the Tran≈øactions of King
Richard the Second, and King Henry the Fourth, and tho≈øe of King Charles the Fir≈øt concerning Arch-Bi≈øhop Lauds Vi≈øitation, that tho≈øe Kings determined the matter in favor of the Arch-Bi≈øhops, thereby would Infer, that the Vi≈øitation of the Univer≈øity of Oxford appertained to the Black Parliament, and neither to the King, even when there was no Arch-Bi≈øhop in being, nor to any other but the Committee and Delegates of that Parliament: whereas he ought to have con≈øidered, that the true rea≈øon why the fir≈øt two Kings determined for the Arch-Bi≈øhops Vi≈øitation was, becau≈øe the Univer≈øities were at that time favorable to the Doctrin of Wickliff, which it was the Intere≈øt of the Church to oppo≈øe; and might very well induce the Kings to Commit the care of ≈øuppre≈ø≈øing it, rather to the Arch-Bi≈øhop than the Chancellor, and if we con≈øider that the ≈øuppre≈ø≈øing the Non-Conformi≈øts was the care of King Charles the Fir≈øt, & that Arch-Bi≈øhop Laud was ≈øo bent to effect it, we are not to wonder that His Maje≈øty determined in favor of the Arch-Bi≈øhop, as Arch-Bi≈øhop, rather then as Chancellor; e≈øpecially when it was known that the Earl of Holland then Chancellor of Cambridge was a favorer and Partron of Non-Conformi≈øts.

And Mr. Pryn ought further to have noted, that in the two-Roman Catholic Kings times the Original of the Controver≈øie was, whether by the Exemptions of the Pope, the Univer≈øity ≈øhould be Vi≈øited by the Chancellor only, or by the Arch-Bi≈øhop as Metropolitan, who by the Canons had the Vi≈øitation of his whole Province, as al≈øo the Dioece≈øan had in matters at lea≈øt of Religion, as in Bi≈øhop Rippingdons Vi≈øitation I ≈øhall ≈øhew: ≈øo that the Cardo Controver≈øiae was upon the validity of the Popes Exemption, and
in all the Ca≈øes there is a Salvo of the Kings Right; and ≈øuch application was made to him as ≈øhews, that the la≈øt re≈øort was to the Sovereign even to Judge of the Popes Bulls as before I have hinted.

div.head: ¬ß. 9. The King gives Sentence for the Arch-Bi≈øhop of York again≈øt the Aruch-Bi≈øhop of Canterbury about Queens College.
div.p: ‚òû I ≈øhall now proceed in the Series of my Hi≈øtory. About Anno 1412. 14 H. 4. Great conte≈øtsRot. Parl. We≈øtm. Cra≈øtino. Anima. 13. H. 5. N. 15. aro≈øe betwixt the Arch-Bi≈øhops of Canterbury and York about Vi≈øiting Queens College, the Arch-Bi≈øhop of Canterbury affirming it to be his Right as Metropolitan, and by the Grant of King Richard the Second. And the Arch-Bi≈øhop of York claimed it as his peculiar Right, as Local Vi≈øitor. The Deci≈øion of this was referred to the King, who having heard the Arguments on both ≈øides gave Sentence for York. By which in≈øtance it is apparent that this King determined the point again≈øt the Judgement of his Predece≈ø≈øors and abridged the Metropolitan.

Anno 1414. 2 H. 5.The King gives leave to the Bi≈øhop of the Lincoln to Vi≈øit. According to the example of the Arch-Bi≈øhop of Canterbury, Philip Rippingdon Bi≈øhop of Lincoln, the King giving him leave, Publi≈øhed his Programma of Citation much after the Arch-Bi≈øhop's Form, Dated Feb. 12. To which the Univer≈øity An≈øwered,Who is admited to enquire by Vi≈øitation about Here≈øie, but not in other matters. that they intended to make per≈øonal appearance to his Summons at the time and place appointed, to receive only tho≈øe things which are known to appertain to the Office of Inqui≈øition of Haeretical pravity, but notwith≈øtanding, under that Prote≈øtation, that by that per≈øonal appearance they intend not to con≈øent to the Vi≈øitation of what Articles ≈øoever: this is Dated the 4th. of March following.

div.head: ¬ß. 10. How both the Vi≈øitations by the Metropolitan and Dioece≈øan were excerci≈øed by Eccle≈øia≈øtical Canons.
div.p:
By this it ≈øeems clear, that the Univen≈øity was Subject to divers Vi≈øitors for ≈øeveral purpo≈øes, and tho' the Metropolitical Vi≈øitation was owned, yet their Dioece≈øan
was ≈øubmited to in point of Haere≈øie, which further appears in that I find this very Year 1413. Arch-Bi≈øhop Arund√©l Parkers Antiq. Eccl. Brit. p. 309. made certain Statutes for the Government of the Univer≈øities of Oxford and Cambridge.

‚òû That this power of Vi≈øiting by the Bi≈øhops was a ≈øettlement by Eccle≈øia≈øtical Canons is very manife≈øt, ≈øo that the general occa≈øion of Conte≈øts about it was by rea≈øon of ≈øome privileges granted by Popes, or re≈øtrictions laid upon the Univer≈øities by their Sovereigns, or ≈øome Exorbitances in the Vi≈øitors, in Re≈øcinding u≈øeful Statutes, or altering old ones or Cu≈øtoms.

Therefore in the fir≈øt Council of Aquileia INec in his ubi de Vi≈øitatione ac morum Correctione agitur, exemptio aut ulla Inhibitio, Appellatio, ≈øeu Querela; etiam ad ≈øedem Apo≈øtolicam Interpo≈øita, Executionem eorum quae decret a aut Judicata fuerint quoquo modo Impediunt aut ≈øu≈øpendunt. Binnius To. 9. fol. 709. c. 2. A. find it thus Decreed. Let Bi≈øhops have the Right and Power, even as Delegates of the Apo≈øtolic See, of Ordering, Moderating, and Executing, according to the Sanction of the Canons, tho≈øe things which in their prudence to them ≈øhall ≈øeem nece≈ø≈øary for the amendment of their Subjects, and the profit of their Dioece≈øs. Neither let Exemptions or any Inhibition Appeal or Complaint even to the Apo≈øtolic See, in any manner hinder or Su≈øpend the Execution of tho≈øe things Commanded, Decreed, or Adjudged in tho≈øe things which appertain to their Vi≈øitation and the correction of manners.

The Council of Trent likewi≈øeIdem fol. 424. c. 2. B. Decreed, that all tho≈øe, to whom the Vi≈øitation and Reformation of Univer≈øities, and General Studies did appertain, ≈øhould diligently take care, that the Univer≈øities ≈øhould receive their Canons, and if any thing in the Univer≈øities was worthy of Correction and Reformation they ≈øhould be amended, and appointed by tho≈øe to whom it appertained for the increa≈øe of Religion and Eccle≈øia≈øtical Di≈øcipline.

The≈øe things I only note to clear the point, that in former Ages the In≈øpection into the Government of the Univer≈øities was Judged to be of Eccle≈øia≈øtical Cognizance, and by con≈øequence fall under the Kings Vi≈øitatorial power by his Commi≈ø≈øioners.

div.head: CHAP. V.

argument.p: Concerning the Vi≈øitations of the Univer≈øity of Oxford ≈øince the Renouncing the Popes Supremacy in England.

div.head: SECT. I.

argument.p: Concerning the Vi≈øitations in the Reigns of King Henry the 8th. and King Edward the 6th.

div.p:
¬ß. 1 AFter the Bull of Pope Sixtus the 4th. was granted to the Univer≈øity Anno 1479. the 19th. of Edward the 4th. whereby it was Exempted from Archiepi≈øcopal or Dioece≈øan Vi≈øitations; all power of Regulation of it ≈øeemed to be Lodged in the Chancellor and Senate, and other Vi≈øitations to lie a≈øleep till King Henry the 8th. had ca≈øt off the Popes Supremacy: ≈øome while before which, as I have before related, their Statutes were delivered to Cardinal Wol≈øey to be corrected and altered,Cap. 3. Sect. 2. ¬ß. 8. and afterwards all their Charters and Bulls ≈øurrendred to the King; ≈øo that I find nothing material in this matter
during his Reign, be≈øides what I have there related, but in the≈øe two particulars following.

Anno 1535. 26 H. 8. 30. Jan. The King appointed Dr. William Tre≈øham
Lib. conc. Civit. Oxon. fol. 59. Commi≈ø≈øioners Survey all the Temporal and Spiritual Lands belonging to the Univer≈øity. Vice-Chancellor, William Freer Major of Oxford, William Barentyne, Simon Hare-court, Walter Stonor, John Clerk, Thomas Elyot and John Brome Knights to Survey all the Temporal and Spiritual Lands and Tythes and enter them into a Book like Doom≈ø-day Book.

And in the ≈øame Year Richard Layton Coll. Charter &c. Acad. Oxon. Bib. Cotton ≈øub fau≈øtina c. 7. alias Leighton Bachellor of Divinity, John London Doctor of Laws Warden of New-College, Dr. Lee and others were ≈øent from the King to Vi≈øit the Univer≈øity, their Liberties and Privileges being then in the Kings hands:The Kings Vi≈øitation of the Univer≈øity. The≈øe Vi≈øitors Erected new Lectures, Cha≈øtned ill Manners, and by the account they gave to Cromwel it appears they ridiculed all the School-mens Learning, e≈øpecially that of Duns Scotus. They did little in Merton College, becau≈øe Dr. Richard Gwent the Commi≈ø≈øioner for Thomas Cranmer Arch-Bi≈øhop of Canterbury, had Vi≈øited it the Year before and endeavored to aboli≈øh the Ancient commendable Cu≈øtoms of the College, Wood ad Annam. as the Author ≈øaith, and it was thought by ≈øome, that they came with the ≈øame Intention to the Univer≈øity as they did to Mona≈øteries which they al≈øo Vi≈øited.

Before I proceed further,The u≈øual Method of proceeding in Vi≈øitations of the Univer≈øities. I think it fit to give an account of the ordinary Method of proceeding in Vi≈øitations in the≈øe following particulars.

Fir≈øt, Some of the Commi≈ø≈øioners were u≈øually per≈øons of great Dignity and Employment, to create e≈øteem and Authority to the Action; others of meaner Quality, who were at more lei≈øure to attend the work; but always ≈øome of them were Members of the Univer≈øity.
Secondly, Their proceedings Ordinarily were after the manner of the Bi≈øhops or Arch-Deacons Vi≈øitations, propo≈øing and delivering Articles upon which to examin, whereof ≈øome are yet extant.

Thirdly, That there was, praevious to ≈øuch Vi≈øitation, a Command from the King not to choo≈øe any into places of profit (and ≈øometimes not to Lett Lea≈øes) without leave of the King or Arch-Bi≈øhops.
Fourthly, That public notice was given to the Vice-Chancellor, and by him to the Univer≈øity in Convocation.
Fifthly, They were Commanded to bring in their Statutes, Charters, Repo≈øitories, and all their public Muniments to be examined.
Sixthly, They commonly fir≈øt Cited all the Univer≈øity to appear before them in the Convocationhou≈øe to publi≈øh their Commi≈ø≈øion, &c.
Seventhly, In Vi≈øiting they examined every Man (or at lea≈øt ≈øuch as they thought good) particularly and privately upon their Articles, and ≈øet down their An≈øwer in Writing.
Eighthly, They puni≈øhed with Eccle≈øia≈øtical cen≈øures as well as Secular.

¬ß. 2 Having found nothing further concerning the Vi≈øitation of Oxford in King Henry the 8ths. Reign I pa≈øs on to that of King Edward the 6th. wherein the Reader will find a more particular and full di≈øcovery of the Vi≈øitatorial power, and having obtained, by the favor of Sir Thomas Powis the Kings Atturny General, a Copy of the Commi≈ø≈øion granted by that King, I ≈øhall here in≈øert it at length in the Latin.

Agno≈øcimus ut Nobiles & praeclarae ≈øcientiae Virtute≈øque ac boni Mores in illa cre≈øcerent per Regiam Culturam & augerentur, nulla ratio prius in mentem venit quam ut primos & praecipuos Fontes Eruditionis & virtutis, vitiis, (≈øi quae in illis e≈ø≈øent,) purgatos, favore no≈øtro & Regia Munificentia pro≈øequentes, aliqua commoda ratione auctos am plificat o≈øque redderemus. Societatum ac Officiorum ≈øuorum, privationem, & Stipendiorum, proventuum & Emolumentorum ≈øuorum quorumcunque ≈øeque≈øtrationem, vel quamcunque aliam congruam & Competentem Coercionem puniendos & coercendos atque ad probatiores vivendi mores, modis omnibus quibu≈øcunque id melius & efficacius poteritis reducendos;By Eccle≈øia≈øtical cen≈øures, impri≈øonment, recognizances. conditionis fuerint, (≈øi quos inveneritis,) tam per cen≈øuras Eccle≈øia≈øticas quam etiam Incarcerationem, ac Recognitionum acceptationem, & quaecunque alia Juris Regni no≈øtri remedia compo≈øcendos. Pecunias impendendas quot-annis in exequias & Convivia,To change Monies, to be expended for Exequies and the Fea≈øts, to public or private Lectures, or to other u≈øes. in Lectiones publicas vel privatas ad alios u≈øus magis convenientes aut in alias formas convertendas.
