Et fructus redditus ac proventus dictarum Cantariarum, ad Scholariam Exhibitionem a≈ø≈øignandos, & dictae Univer≈øitatis no≈øtrae, & Collegiorum, & Aularum Incorporationes, Fundationes, Statuta, Ordinationes,To examin all Foundations, Statutes, &c. Privilegia, Compo≈øitiones, Computus, & alia munimenta quaecunque exigenda, & recipienda,To change forms of Divine Offices, di≈øputations, public Lectures, Collation of Degrees, &c. eaque diligenter examinanda & di≈øcutienda, formas Divinorum Officiorum, Di≈øputationum, & publicarum Lectionum, Collationes quoque graduum & Honorum, qui Eruditionis erg√† proponuntur Studio≈øis, immutandas,To introduce and a≈ø≈øign new injunctions and Statutes. & in Commodiorem rationem in≈øtituendam, nec non Injunctiones, & Statuta, quae vobis pro Commodiore Ordine videbuntur idonea, Per≈øonis in ei≈ødem degentibus nomine no≈øtro tradenda & vice & Authoritate no≈øtris inducenda & a≈ø≈øignanda poena≈øque convenientes,To inflict puni≈øhments on the violators of them. in eorum violatores infligendas, & irrogandas, Statutaque, Ordinationes,To annihilate contrary Statutes, Ordinances, Cu≈øtoms and Compo≈øitions. Con≈øuetudines, Compo≈øitiones, ≈øi quas comperitis ei≈ødem Contrarias, ≈øive repugnantes tollendas & penitus annihilandas, Juramentum in≈øuper obedientiae & fidelitatis nobis & Haeredibus no≈øtris debitis, ¬ß. 6 To aboli≈øh the Popes Authority. deque renuenda, penitu≈øque abneganda Epi≈øcopi Romani praeten≈øa, u≈øurpata, & fict√¢ Authoritate, & quaecunque alia Juramenta ex Statutis hujus Regni no≈øtri prae≈øtari requi≈øita,To enjoyn Oaths appointed by the Statutes of the Kingdom. ab omnibus infra Loca praedicta con≈øtitutis exigenda & recipienda; Congregationes
& Convocationes Praepo≈øitorum,To call Convocations for the execution of the premi≈øes or any Reformation. Gardianorum, Studentium, & Mini≈øtrorum huju≈ømodi, pro Executione praemi≈ø≈øorum, aut Reformatione quacunque facienda; Conciendas & Convocandas. Cau≈øas etiam In≈øtantiarum Examinandas, & fine debito terminandas, ac omnia & ≈øingula alia quae circa huju≈ømodi Vi≈øitationis,To examin and determin cau≈øes of in≈øtances. Inqui≈øitionis, ≈øeu Reformationis totius Academiae Negotia,To do all other things requi≈øite in ≈øuch like Inqui≈øitions and Reformations tho' not expre≈ø≈øed, or ≈øpecial words were requi≈øite. ≈øive hic expre≈ø≈øa fuerint ≈øive non expre≈ø≈øa, quae nece≈ø≈øaria fuerint, ≈øeu quomodolibet opportune facienda & exequenda, vobis & ≈øingulis ve≈øtrum, de quorum doctrina, Morum & Concilii gravitate, ac in rebus gerendis fide, & Indu≈øtria, plurimum confidimus, Vices no≈øtras Commitimus, ac plenam,For performing all which the King grants them his full power and Authority. tenore prae≈øentium, Concedimus Pote≈øtatem, etiam≈øi eju≈ømodi ≈øunt quae ≈øpecialia verba requiruntur; cum cuju≈ølibet congrue & legitime coercionis pote≈øtate. Et quoniam Studium Juris Civilis non ≈øolum, jam aliquot Annos deferbui≈ø≈øe in Academia no≈øtra Oxonien≈øi,
¬ß. 7 To promote the ≈øtudy of the Civil Law. verum etiam propemodum extinctum e≈ø≈øe nobis Indicatum e≈øt, praecipuam vobis omnibus curam, & ≈øollicitudinem imponimus, ut quibus poteritis viis & modis illud excitetis,‚òû The King gives them his fulle≈øt and high Authority by his Ab≈øolute and Royal power to change the number of Students in Civil Law in New-College to All-Souls College and the Students of Arts in All-Souls to New-College. & amplificetis cui ≈øtudio, ut po≈ø≈øitis, amplius mederi & fructu laboris ac diligentiae Juventutem ad illud accendere, pleni≈ø≈øimam ac Summam Authoritatem, per Ab≈øolutam & Regiam no≈øtram Pote≈øtatem vobis Conce≈ø≈øimus; Univer≈øum numerum in Lege Civili Studentium in Collegiis Beatae Mariae, Vocato The New College of Oxford in Collegium Animarum, & univer≈øum numerum in Artibus Studentium in Collegio Animarum, in Collegia praedictum Beatae Mariae commutandum tranferendum & Con≈øtituendum, prout vobis commodi≈ø≈øimum fore videbitur, ≈øic ut in Collegio Animarum tantum illi ≈øint qui
Legis Civilis Studio vacabunt, & in Collegio Beatae Mariae praedicto,So that in All-Souls College none be but Students of Civil Law, and New-College Students in Arts. illi tantum ≈øint qui Artium & Verbi Dei Studio po≈øthac ≈øemper incumbent: Dedimus quoque vobis Authoritatem, Collegium Medicinae in aliquo idoneo loco dictae Univer≈øitatis Con≈øtituendi; ac Deputandi aliquod unum Collegium illi Studio quodcunque vobis videbitur,To Depute a College for Phy≈øicians. & eos Socios in illo Collegio ≈øic Medicinae deputandos, qui ad Medicinam Studium ≈øuum velint convertere, ≈øi ad hoc per vos idonei Judicabuntur, Socios Collegii no≈øtri Medicinae faciendos; Eos vero qui nolount ≈øequi illam Artem vel ad eandem minus idonei judicabuntur, in alia Collegia transferendos vel pen≈øiones Magi≈øtro ≈øive Sociis illius Collegii a≈ø≈øignandas. ¬ß. 8 Command to all Sheriffs, Majors, Bailiffs and other Officers and Subjects to a≈ø≈øi≈øt the Commi≈ø≈øioners, &c. in the Execution of the premi≈øes. Mandantes omnibus & ≈øingulis Vice-comitibus, Majoribus ac Ballivis ac quibu≈øcunque aliis Officiariis, Mini≈øtris, & ≈øubditis no≈øtris, quatenus vobis, & cuilibet ve≈øtrum, in & circa Praemi≈ø≈øorum Executionem, effectualiter a≈ø≈øi≈øtent, auxilientur, & ≈øuffragentur: Aliquo Actu, Statuto, Ordinatione, Provi≈øione, Proclamatione,Non ob≈øtante of any Act, Statute, Ordinance, Provi≈øion, Proclamation or Re≈øtriction whatever to the contrary. ≈øive Re≈øtrictione inde in Contrarium factis, Editis, Ordinatis, Proclamatis, ≈øive Provi≈øis, aut aliqua alia re, Cau≈ø√¢, vel Materia quacunque in aliquo non ob≈øtante. In cujus rei Te≈øtimonum, &c. Te≈øte Rege apud We≈øtmona≈øterium Octavo Die Maii Anno Regni Edvardi Sexti Tertio.
Per ip≈øum Regem, &c.

¬ß. 9 In this Commi≈ø≈øion the≈øe particulars may be ob≈øerved; The Authority of the Commi≈ø≈øion. Fir≈øt, that in the Preamble, the King lays as a Foundation, that he is the Supreme Head under Chri≈øt in Earth of the Church of England and Ireland,
≈øo that by vertue of that Supremacy, and by his Ab≈øolute and Supreme Authority, which in other places of the Commi≈ø≈øion are expre≈ø≈øed, he appoints this Vi≈øitation, and the per≈øons within Named his Delegates, and Commi≈ø≈øioners: which of it ≈øelf, if there were not mo≈øt numerous other Pre≈øidents, and the nece≈ø≈øity of Executing Ju≈øtice which the King cannot per≈øonally do in all places, is ≈øufficient to Confute that Ignorant A≈ø≈øertion of a Philonomus, that the King cannot Commi≈ø≈øionate others to Execute his Authority.

Secondly, What pl√†ces are to be Vi≈øited. As to the Subject Matter of the Vi≈øitation, it is for the Colleges of Wind≈øor and Winche≈øter and the Dioece≈øs of Oxford, and the Univer≈øity, and all the Colleges of the ≈øame, and by parity of Rea≈øon ≈øuch Commi≈ø≈øions may be Extended to any Lay or Religious Per≈øons, Members of Societies, and Corporations within the Kingdoms of England and Ireland, that are of the ≈øame kinds of Foundation.

Thirdly, The per≈øons to be Vi≈øited. As to the per≈øons, the Univer≈øity is to be Vi≈øited in the Head and Members, ≈øo taht the Vice-Chancellor and all the Heads of Hou≈øes, as al≈øo Fellows, Scholars, Students, and all that bear any Office, and all per≈øons re≈øiding in the Colleges, &c. are within the purlieu of this Vi≈øitation.

Fourthly, The matters to be enquired after. The matters to be ensquired of an Regulated are, the State of the Colleges, which word is very Comprehen≈øive, as in ≈øeveral particulars are after branched out. Al≈øo the Study, Life, Manners, Conver≈øation, and Qualification of the per≈øons. And this Enquiry is to be made by all the Methods or Ways, that the Commi≈ø≈øioners can be≈øt effect it by.

Fifthly, The nature of the Crimes to be puni≈øhed. The pre≈øons puni≈øhable are reckoned up the Ciriminals, and Delinquents; words of a large Extent, as Comprehending Offenders again≈øt the Laws of God, and the King; to the≈øe are added the Idle and Slothful Students, and generally all who do any thing blame-worthy.

Sixthly, The puni≈øhments, Deprivation and Seque≈øtration. The puni≈øhments the Commi≈ø≈øioners may inflict, are the Deprivation of their places as Ma≈øter≈øhips, Pre≈øident≈øhips, &c. their Fellow≈øhips and other Offices, and the Seque≈øtration of their Stipends, Profits and Emoluments what≈øoever; the good ends for which ≈øuch puni≈øhments are inflicted are expre≈ø≈øed, to compell them to more upright manners of living.

Seventhly, Contumaces & Rebelles. We may al≈øo note the ≈øpecial puni≈øhment of ≈øuch as are contumacious and ob≈øtinate or Rebellious, as it is expre≈ø≈øed. The≈øe of whatever ≈øtate or condition they be are to be compelled to obedience by Eccle≈øia≈øtical Cen≈øures, as al≈øo by Impri≈øonment,Puni≈øhment by Eccle≈øia≈øtical cen≈øures, impri≈øonments, &c. Recognizances and all other remedies the Laws of the Kingdom appoint.

Eighthly, Changing of Charities to other u≈øes than at fir≈øt de≈øigned Then follows a power to Convert the Monies Yearly Expended for Exequies and Fea≈øts, that is, ≈øuch as had been given for Obits, Diriges, &c. to the maintainance of public or private Lectures, or other more convenient Forms of U≈øes.

Ninthly, The Monies al≈øo to be di≈øpended by the Founders appointment upon the Chori≈øters, Singing Men, and other matters relating to the Dayly Eccle≈øia≈øtical Service, ≈øhall be Converted to the Teaching the Grammar Youth, the Commons of the Fellows or Scholars, to the Learning of Philo≈øophy or other Arts, &c.

Tenthly, Power of Expelling and ≈øub≈øtituting others in their places. To Expel and Amove all Ma≈øters, Provo≈øts, Pre≈øidents, Fellows or Scholars what≈øoever, that are not worthy of their Offices, or not proficients: If the Commi≈ø≈øioners could do it by colour of the breach of the Statutes of the College, or Judged it to be for the benefit of the Common-weal, or of Learning; and power to prefer and ≈øub≈øtitute another and others in the place of the per≈øon removed, and to admit the re≈øignations of whatever Provo≈øt≈øhip, Ma≈øter≈øhip, Pre≈øident≈øhip, Guardian≈øhip, Fellow≈øhips, or Office in the ≈øaid places, and to Vacate or declare void the ≈øame, and to ≈øub≈øtitute others in their places.

Eleventhly, To unite Golleges and tran≈ølate Students of one faculty from one College to another. Then they have power to unite two or more Colleges into one, whether of the Kings or any others Foundation, if it appear to them to be for the profit of the Univer≈øity, and this by the Kings Ab≈øolute Authority. As likewi≈øe to Tran≈ølate Students of one faculty from one College to another.

Twelfthly, Altering form of Di≈øputations, Statutes, &c. Al≈øo the power of altering Forms of Di≈øputations, conferring Degrees, and of Divine Offices, to Introduce and A≈ø≈øign Injunctions and Statutes, and wholly to Annihilate Statutes, Ordinances, Cu≈øtoms, and Compo≈øitions contrary to them, and this as to the Commi≈ø≈øioners ≈øhall ≈øeem fit for the Regulating, Reformation and good order, &c. of the Univer≈øity.

‚òû Thirteenthly, Note this. Yea to exerci≈øe all and ≈øingular other things concerning Vi≈øitation, Inqui≈øition and Reformation, which may be nece≈ø≈øary, or in any wi≈øe fit to be done, altho' not expre≈ø≈øed, yea tho' the power might require ≈øpecial words.

La≈øtly, It is to be con≈øidered,The Kings di≈øpen≈øing power a≈ø≈øerted by this Commi≈ø≈øion. that all the≈øe powers are given them, notwith≈øtanding any Act, Statute, Ordinance, Provi≈øion, Proclamation, or Re≈øtriction to the contrary; ≈øo that in this one In≈øtance the Kings di≈øpen≈øing power to be put in Execution by Commi≈ø≈øioners is mo≈øt amply manife≈øted,Under≈øtand it in matters wherein Mandates have been u≈øed. and whatever power the King can give to Commi≈ø≈øioners, he may Execute him≈øelf by his Royal Mandate, and if he can di≈øpen≈øe with the Statute, ≈øurely the obligation of an Oath to ob≈øerve that Statute cea≈øeth, as I ≈øhall largely ≈øhew hereafter.

‚òû By the Execution of this Commi≈ø≈øion, whereof I ≈øhall now treat, it will be apparent, that the de≈øign of this Vi≈øitation was to aboli≈øh the Catholic Religion there, and plant the Reformation in the Univer≈øity, which they did by changing the Magi≈øtrates or Governing part of the Colleges, di≈øannulling the old, and making new Statutes, cen≈øuring and puni≈øhing all whom they found culpable, according to the Articles which they publi≈øhed, to aboli≈øh the power of the Bi≈øhop of Rome and pre≈øent Clergy, and ≈øet up the Kings Supremacy. Which Articles I am informed are extant tho' I have not yet been ≈øo fortunate as to have procured any Copy of them.

¬ß. 10 I ≈øhall now Abreviate the proceedings of the Commi≈ø≈øioners in that Vi≈øitation by which it will appear, What the Commi≈ø≈øioners did in this Vi≈øitation. how merciful our King hath been in this la≈øt Vi≈øitation comparatively to what was then done.

‚òû Fir≈øt, The King, praevious to this Vi≈øitation,Wood Antiq. Oxon. fol. 269. a. In Turri Schol. N. 17. The Su≈øpen≈øion of Elections and College Acts during the Vi≈øitation. in his Mandate to the Univer≈øity Commanded, that no Graduate ≈øhould proceed to the Election of a Pre≈øident, or Fellow of any College, or do any Act that ≈øhould hinder the Vi≈øitation, ≈øo that during the Vi≈øitation no Statutes were ob≈øerved, and none of the
Univer≈øity could attain any Office without con≈øulting the Vi≈øitors: and my Author ≈øaith, that the Commi≈ø≈øioners, e≈øpecially Cox, put in their Friends and Dependents every where into places, as he In≈øtanceth in Maurice Ley an Iri≈øh Man,Fellows made contrary to Statutes. who was made a Fellow of Exeter College contrary to their Statutes, and Edmund Cooke E≈øquire, wholly Ignorant of Univer≈øity Learning, made Fellow of the ≈øame College; ≈øo George Cartwright Born in Nottingham≈øhire, thereby Secluded by the Statutes, was made Fellow of Corpus Chri≈øti College. And by the Mandate afore≈øaid the Execution of the Statutes of the Univer≈øity were Su≈øpended,The Execution of the Statutes Su≈øpended. by which means, the Juri≈ødiction of the Ma≈øters of Colleges and other Univer≈øity Magi≈øtrates being in a manner Abrogated, it might remain in the Vi≈øitors power only to inflict puni≈øhments.

When the Commi≈ø≈øioners had deprived the Chori≈øters and Singing Boys of their Stipends, Id. fol. 270. b. Concerning Chori≈øters and Signing-Boys. the Towns-men repre≈øenting the dammage it would be to them by rea≈øon their Children were thereby provided for, This was ≈øomething mitigated.

Some of the Chantries were converted to Stipends, but mo≈øtly tho≈øe in Pari≈øh Churches, whereof ≈øome were of the Patronages of Colleges, were ≈øold away. But of the≈øe things and the change of Divine Service I ≈øhall not ≈øpeak becau≈øe they were according to the Reformation through the Kingdom, after the Book of Common Prayer was E≈øtabli≈øhed.

¬ß. 11 ‚òû The Vi≈øitors made a new Book of Statutes which were called King Edward the Sixth's Statutes, Id. fol. 271. a. Anno 1549. The Vi≈øitors make a new Book of Statutes. which altho' in the mo≈øt part they were contrary to the Ancient Statutes of the Univer≈øity, yet they were in force till tho≈øe were made which now are u≈øed.

I pa≈øs by the great de≈øtruction made of Books in the public and private Libraries, Id. fol. 271. b. The de≈øtruction of Books. where few that had any Red Letters, or were Writ by any in the two la≈øt Centuries e≈øcaped the Fire or wor≈øe u≈øes, tho' they were Books of Divinity, A≈øtronomy, or Mathematics: The Books being brought in great heaps into the Market places, and publickly burnt; of which the Reader may peru≈øe a ≈øad Account in Dr. Heylin and Mr. Wood.
I ≈øhall omit the Ca≈øes of Ralph Skinner and Gualter Haddon, till I come to Treat of the Kings di≈øpen≈øing with Statutes.

¬ß. 12 ‚òû The ≈øeverity of the Vi≈øitors continued from the Year 1549. to th Year 1553. 10. Mariae,
Id. fol. 272.273, 274. The ≈øevere proceedings of the Commi≈ø≈øioners. in which time by the ab≈øenting them≈øelves, or Expul≈øion of ≈øo many Fellows, the Colleges were left very thin, the Writings, Bulls, Charters, and other Muniments, e≈øpecially tho≈øe granted from Rome were ≈øeized; the Regi≈øters and Repo≈øitories ≈øearched; the Monies taken from the Che≈øts, where lodged in former Ages, to be in readine≈øs upon any Streights the Hou≈øes might be reduced to. Yea they ≈øold four or five public Schools to Town≈ø-men, who pulled them down and converted the Materials to their own u≈øes, and annexed the Grounds to their Gardens.

So great was the ≈øubver≈øion, that the Terms were altered from the periods u≈øed in former times,Terms and Lectures altered, and Degrees neglected. the Ancient Exerci≈øes, &c. as Lectures, ≈øcorned, and the taking of Degrees by ≈øome thought Anti-Chri≈øtian, and others neglected to take any by the apprehen≈øion, that there ≈øhould be no u≈øe of them, and becau≈øe the Stipends were withdrawn. But, ≈øays my Author, we are not to complain of the Violating of the Honors and Degrees in Learning, ≈øince Learning it ≈øelf was
Expiring and drawing it's la≈øt breath, the Schools being ruined and the Philo≈øophy Exerci≈øes being taken away. Tho≈øe who have a mind to Read the Ravage then made by the Vi≈øitors, either by their Covetou≈øne≈øs or Connivance, may find them fully related in the foregoing Authors. For, a Reformation being de≈øigned by the King, there was no place in the Univer≈øity for the Unconformable.

div.head: SECT. II.

argument.p: The Vi≈øitation in Queen Maries Reign.

div.head: ¬ß. 1. Queen Maries Vi≈øitation.
div.p: ANno 1553. Wood fol. 274. & 275. Wood Antiq. Oxon lib. 1. fol. 274.275. Pat. 1. Maria part. 6. When Queen Mary came to the Crown, ≈øhe took great Compa≈ø≈øion on the Univer≈øity, as appears by her Letter, in which ≈øhe ≈øets forth the grievou≈øne≈øs of the former Vi≈øitation, and ≈øhe be≈øtowed ≈øome Rectories upon it by her Charter. May 11.1o. Regni.

Neither did ≈øhe omit to Exerci≈øe her Authority in Vi≈øiting the Univer≈øity in re≈øtoring the Roman Catholic Religion, as ≈øhe did through the Kingdom. The fir≈øt that Vi≈øited was Steven Gardiner Bi≈øhop of Winche≈øter, See for the Vi≈øitation of Cardinal Pool Anno 1557. a. who was Local Vi≈øitor of New-College and Corpus Chri≈øti and St. Mary Magdalen College: He appointed for his Deputies Sir Richard Read Kt. and Dr. George Wright Arch-Deacon of Oxford: Large account in Fox Act sand Mon. Vol. 3. Edit. 1640. fal. 762. to 780. Upon the 26th. of October they Vi≈øited St. Mary Magdalen College, and Dr. Haddon the late Pre≈øident, of his own accord did quit the Pre≈øident≈øhip. Thomas Bentham the Dean, and ≈øeveral others were Expelled as had been done in New-College. And
the Society of Magdalen College were ≈øo aver≈øe from the Roman Catholic Religion, that not only they got neither Altar or Holy Ve≈øtments, but none of the Fellows came to Ma≈øs, and the very Clerks and Chori≈øters would not perform their Offices, ≈øo that the Vi≈øitors were forced to have all Holy Offices performed by their own Prie≈øts:Ibid. fol. 13. b. they puni≈øhed the Juniors that refu≈øed,Puni≈øhments inflicted by the Vi≈øitors. either with ≈øtriking them out of Commons, or Scourging them: and one Aldworth Bachellor of Art for Contumelious U≈øage of Prie≈øts, and coming in un≈øea≈øonably to the Ma≈øs of the Exequies of King Henry the Sixth, was Commanded, that every Day he ≈øhould be at Ma≈øs, and kneeling at the South Pillar in the middle of the Church, ≈øhould perform his Prayers to the Example of others.

The ≈øame Commi≈ø≈øioners found the Pre≈øident of Corpus Chri≈øti College Robert Morwent and the Senior Fellow Henry Wal≈øh very ob≈øervant,Id. fol. 276. a. who brought to light the Holy Ve≈øtments, Cu≈øhions, Silver Ve≈ø≈øels, Candle≈øtics, and other Ornaments which they had hid in King Edward the Sixth's time, and excepting John Juel after Bi≈øhop, I find none left that College: but from the other two, be≈øides the Fellows Ejected in Edward the Sixth's time, about Eighteen or Twenty this Year and the next were removed.

div.head: ¬ß. 2. Cardinal Pools Vi≈øitation.
div.p:
Anno 1556. Id. fol. 278. b. 3 & 4 Ph. Mar. Cardinal Pool appointed and entire Vi≈øitation of the Univer≈øity of Oxford, and the Vi≈øitors were James Brooks Bi≈øhop of Glouce≈øter, Nicholas Ormanet of Padua, in good e≈øteem with Julius the Third,Pix. M. M. n. 22. and Dator to him or Marcellus the Second, Henry Cole Doctor of Laws, Provo≈øt of Eaton, Robert Morwent Doctor in Divinity
Pre≈øident of Corpus Chri≈øti College and Walter Wright Arch Deacon of Oxford. The≈øe proceeded upon Thirty Two Que≈øtions,Two Que≈øtions propo≈øed by the Vi≈øitors, Fir≈øt, whether their Statutes were ob≈øerved. two of which were the mo≈øt Material. Fir≈øt, Whether the Foundations, Statutes, and Laudable Cu≈øtoms of the Univer≈øity, and of every College and Hall, were ob≈øerved by all and ≈øingular that were concerned, and if it were an≈øwered Negatively, they were required ≈øpecially to expre≈øs, which were not ob≈øerved and for what cau≈øe.

The Second was,Second, whether after the Reformation any things were u≈øed contrary to the Canons, &c. whether in the time of the Schi≈øm any thing was appointed or brought into u≈øe, which was again≈øt the Ancient Canons or Ancient Foundations, Statutes, Privileges and Cu≈øtoms; and to this, if they An≈øwered Affirmatively, they were to expre≈øs particularly, what they were, and for what cau≈øe.

div.head: ¬ß. 3. The Cardinal appoints Statutes.
div.p:
The Vi≈øitors following the Example of tho≈øe that Vi≈øited in King Edward the Sixths Reign purged out of all public Libraries all Books which maintained the Prote≈øtant Doctrin, and tho≈øe in private Libraries they burnt, and either Puni≈øhed or Expelled the Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øors.In E. p. 38. They certified the Cardinal, e≈øpecially of the Defects of the Univer≈øity Statutes, and he being Chancellor, in≈øtead of Ma≈øon, that laid down the Office, ≈øent a Book of Statutes to Mr. Raynolds the Vice-Chancellor, and Commanded him, that they might be in force, till there being joyned with him ≈øome in every Faculty, they might determin which were to be Antiquated, and which to be retained, which being ≈øo Revi≈øed had the Sanction of the Chancellor and Convocation, which being ≈øtrict again≈øt the Reformed, drove many from the Univer≈øity. Our Author Notes, that the Lectures
were le≈øs frequent in this Queens time, as well as in King Edward the Sixths, and fewer received Degrees, which may be Imputed to the Changes made in Religion in their ≈øhort Reigns: but he ≈øaith the great care of the Magi≈øtrates of the Univer≈øities in this Queens Reign, was to recover the profits of the Societies and to Repair their Buildings and the Schools.

In this Third and Fourth Year of King Philip and Queen Mary, Cui Papa commi≈øit Vi≈øitationem & Reformationem Studiorum Generalium. Cardinal Pool Vi≈øited the Univer≈øity of Cambridge as he was Legate, to whom the Pope Committed the Vi≈øitation and Reformation of the Univer≈øities, called General Studies. This Vi≈øitation the Cardinal performed by Delegates, and I find one Robert Bra≈ø≈øy, Ma≈øter of Kings College, urged, that his Hou≈øe was wholly referved to the Di≈øcretion of the Bi≈øhop of Lincoln, not only by the Kings Letters Patents,
Fox Acts and Monuments, Vol. 3. p. 763.766. but al≈øo by the Grant of Confirmation of the Bi≈øhop of Rome him≈øelf, under a Penalty, if he ≈øhould ≈øuffer any Stranger to Intermedle; But the Commi≈ø≈øioners An≈øwered, that they were fully Authorized for the Order of the matter by the Cardinal, out of who≈øe Juri≈ødiction no place nor per≈øon was Exempted. So that tho' he per≈øi≈øted the next Day in his Allegation, yet he and the Students ≈øubmitted, and were all Sworn and Examined to the Interrogatories propounded to them, yet ≈øome of them Swore conditionally, ≈øo as their Faith given to the College were not Impeached thereby. Something like the Salvo of ≈øome Members of St. Mary Magdalen College, that they would yield obedience, ≈øaving the Right of Dr. Hough, which was prudently denyed to be Admitted by the Lords Vi≈øitors.
I now pa≈øs to the Reign of Queen Elizabeth.

div.head: SECT. III.

argument.p: The Vi≈øitations in Queen Elizabeths Reign.

div.head: ¬ß. 1. Queen Elizabeths Inhibition
div.p: ANno 1559. Fol. 281. b. Queen Elizabeth intending to Vi≈øit the Univer≈øity of Oxford Writ to the Magi≈øtrates of the ≈øame,not to Elect any heads of Hou≈øes, Fellows, Scholars, &c. forbidding them to proceed to the Election of any Pre≈øident, Fellow or Scholar, or of any Officer of the Univer≈øity, and forbid all Alienations or Changes of Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions, and all other things to be done by the Univer≈øity, except what was nece≈ø≈øary for the Cultivating their Lands, till the Vi≈øitation: and this ≈øhe did becau≈øe ≈øome were ≈øo forward to begin a Re≈øtoring things to the condition they were in, in King Edward the Sixth's time before her Order. By which the Queens Authority and Circum≈øpection are clearly di≈øcovered.

div.head: ¬ß. 2. Queen Elizabeth appoints Vi≈øitors.
div.p:
After ≈øome few Months ≈øhe appointed her Vi≈øitors, Wood lib. 1. fol. 282. viz. Richard Cox Bi≈øhop of Ely, John Williams Baron of Thame, but he Died in October, John Ma≈øon Kt. ≈øometimes Fellow of All-Souls, and ≈øeveral Years after Chancellor, Thomas Benger Kt. William Kingsmyll E≈øq John Warner Cu≈øtos of All-Souls College, Walter Wright Doctor of Laws, Arch-Deacon of Oxford, John Wat≈øon Ma≈øter of Arts, Chancellor of St. Pauls London, Robert Benger E≈øq &c. to whom ≈øhe Commands they ≈øhould Act with all Humanity, and ab≈øtain from all Roughne≈øs. The≈øe Vi≈øitors coming to Oxford ca≈øt out of the Chappels of the Colleges and Pari≈øh Churches all things that related to Super≈øtitious Wor≈øhip, as it was Styled, that
is, the u≈øe of the Roman Wor≈øhip, recalled tho≈øe that were bani≈øhed, or put out in Queen Maries time for Religion, and Aboli≈øhed mo≈øt of the Statutes made by Cardinal Pool, and re≈øtored tho≈øe of King Edward the Sixth.

To omit other things in the Vi≈øitation, Earl of Arundel Chancellor quits his Office. be≈øides that the Earl of Arundel did quit the Chancellor≈øhip, the≈øe following Heads of Colleges or principal Members, were removed and ≈øome of them Impri≈øoned.

div.head: ¬ß. 3. The Heads of Colleges and others Expelled of Chri≈øt-Church.
div.p: As Dr. Richard Mar≈øhal Dean of Chri≈øt-Church, for denying to own the Authority of the Vi≈øitors, was not only Expelled, but ≈øent Pri≈øoner to London.

Al≈øo Dr. William Tre≈øham Canon of the ≈øame, for denying the Oath of Supremacy was Expelled, as al≈øo Dr. Richard Smith Canon there,Of Merton College. Dr. Thomas Raynolds Warden of Merton College, was by the Queen, then at Hampton Court, deprived of his Warden≈øhip 4o. September and three Days after, the Sentence was declared by three of the Commi≈ø≈øioners, and after a ≈øhort time he Died in Pri≈øon.

Thomas Coveney Pre≈øident of Magdalen College was Expelled,Of St. Mary Magdalen College. for that he was not entred into Orders, and Dr. William Chead≈øey Pre≈øident of Corpus Chri≈øti College was Expelled from that, and his Canon≈øhip of Chri≈øt Church, and Robert Banks, who had been Ejected in Queen Maries Reign becau≈øe he was Married, was ≈øub≈øtituted in his place.
Al≈øo Dr. William Wright, Of Baliol College. Ma≈øter or Pre≈øident of Baliol College, was Expelled, and Dr. Babington ≈øub≈øtituted in his place.

Mr. John Smith Provo≈øt of Oriel College was Ejected,Of Oriel College. tho' he had liberty to live in the Hou≈øe after, but in the next Year he lo≈øt the Lady Margarets
Lecture≈øhip,Of Queens College. and Mr. Hugh Hodg≈øon Provo≈øt of Queens College, two Years after, either relinqui≈øhed the place,Of Trinity College. or was Expelled: Mr. Thomas Slythur≈øt, Pre≈øident of Trinity College, was Expelled, and Mr. Yeldard placed in his room.

Mr. Alexander Bel≈øyre Ma≈øter of St. Johns College and Canon of Chri≈øt-Church was al≈øo Expelled, Fol. 283. a. St. Johns College. and Mr. William Ely, lately put in his place, a little while after was Expelled: ≈øo a few Years after Mr. William Mar≈øhal Principal of St. Albans Hall was forced to ≈øurrender, and ≈øo Mr. William Alan Principal of St. Mary Hall, as al≈øo George Ethridge, Regius Greek Profe≈ø≈øor, and James Dugdale, Ma≈øter of Univer≈øity College, two Years after was Expelled by the Vi≈øitors and Thomas Key put in his place.

Be≈øides the≈øe Heads of Colleges in New College, Fol. 283. b. two Doctors and three Bachellors of Civil Law, one Doctor of Phy≈øic, one Bachellor of Divinity, and fourteen Fellows were Expelled, ≈øome removing to Religious Hou≈øes beyond the Sea, and Mr. John Munden returning, being di≈øcovered to Secretary Wal≈øingham, was Executed at Tyburn.
In St. Johns College ≈øeven Fellows were Expelled, be≈øides ≈øeveral others Impri≈øoned at Wisbich, and many others not named.

Tho≈øe that have a mind to ≈øee the Names of Great numbers of the re≈øt Expelled from other Colleges,Reg. G. G. fol. .26. Reg. I. fol. 198. & 199. & Reg. Coll. Magd. fol. 29. and ≈øuffering Death for returning into England may con≈øult the Regi≈øter.
I ≈øhall now give a ≈øhort account of what Dr. Parker advi≈øed from Cambridge concerning the Vi≈øitation there.

div.head: ¬ß. 4. Paper Office Eccle≈øia≈øtica 1550. to 1559.
div.p: I find Two Letters from Dr. Mathew Parker, afterwards Arch-Bi≈øhop, to Sir William Cecyl then Secretary and Chancellor of the Univer≈øity of Cambridge, Dated 1o. March, and Endor≈øed on the back Dr. Parker 1o. Martii 1559.

Among other Expre≈ø≈øions he hath the≈øe words, The Colleges needed a Vi≈øitation that Queen Mary immediately upon her quyet gave out Authority to the Chancellor (Bi≈øhop Gardiner:) he forthwith ≈øent his Chaplain (Wat≈øon) with In≈øtruction to every College, and as then I could gather, to report to him in what State every College ≈øtood, and further peradventure upon cau≈øe, to have the Ma≈øters and others a≈ø≈øured de coram ≈øi≈øtendo & Interim bene gerendo till further Order.

By this and ≈øome other Letters I find, to and from Sir William Cecyl, who was the great Mini≈øter of State in Queen Elizabeths time, I ob≈øerve that what was done in Oxford by the Vi≈øitors was likewi≈øe pur≈øued in Cambridge, and that the Ma≈øters, Governors and Fellows had a very hard time in the Reigns of King Edward the Sixth, Queen Mary, and Queen Elizabeth. Conformablene≈øs to the Religion of the Prince, being the Touch-≈øtone and the prime Capacitating Qualification that ≈øecured Honors and Places in the Univer≈øities.

The other Letter is Dated March the 30th. and Ticketed 30 Martii 1559. Dr. Parker to Mr. Secretary. Which I ≈øhall Tran≈øcribe at length that the Reader may take notice of his way of Writing, and the Dialect of that Age.

body.p:
Plea≈øeth yt your Honorables goodnes upon th' occa≈øion of ≈øending up to your Honor for the matter which Mr. Vice-Chancellor Wryteth of, I thought
it good to ≈øignifie to you, that the matter which ye have Delegated to us is in hand, with as good Expedition as we can make by rea≈øon of th' ab≈øence of ≈øome who were meet to be Commoned with. Though ≈øome dout is made, whether your Authority of Chancellor≈øhip extendeth to College Statutes for any beyond Lymitation conteyned in them, ≈øo may they dout of your Delegatum. Though Bi≈øhop Gardyner wold not ≈øo be re≈øtreyned in his doyings whether upon warrant of the Quenys Letters of Commi≈ø≈øion (the CopyThis I cannot find tho' I have ≈øearched diligently. whereof I ≈øent to you) or by Authorytie of his Office I leave that to your Prudence to Expond. Our Statutes and Charters Pre≈øcribe here to Officers, that they mu≈øt in Plees proceed ≈øummari√® & de plano ≈øince ≈øtrepitu Judiciali, that Scholars may be ≈øoner re≈øtored to their Bokes. Yet here be Wytts which being thereto admitted w'd entangle matters extremis Juris apicibus, that Controver≈øies might be Infynyte and perpetual never to have an end, but according to our old Ancyent Cu≈øtomys, we ≈øhall procede to hearyng with cutting of, all ≈øuch ≈øuperfluous and perplex Solemnyties of their Cavillations, and ≈øo refer the matter to your under≈øtanding to be re≈øolutely determyned as the la≈øt Clau≈øe of your Letter pretendeth to wil us. And yff I ≈øhall perceyve any like Incydent to be ≈øignified to your Honorable wi≈ødom, I ≈øhall be bold in ≈øecretys to Wright it. Le≈øs things borne bi parcyalyties might prevayle under your Authorytie not rightly in≈øtructed, and to avoid ≈øom Stomake that ellys might be taken. Without dout Sir th' Univer≈øitie is wonderfully decayed, and if your Vi≈øitation entendyd be too ≈øtoutly Executed in ≈øome like ≈øorts as hath been
practi≈øed, that wil I fear ≈øo much ru≈øtle the State thereof, that it will be hardly recovered in Years, and yet Authorytie mu≈øt bridel willfull and ≈øtubborn Natures and hie time it is here. I tru≈øt the prudence of the Vi≈øitors, for good wil toward you, wil diligently note how ye receyved the Univer≈øities after others, for compari≈øon of the ≈øequel, wel hoped for at your hands. Except that be loked to in time the Quenys Maje≈øtie ≈øhal not have half ≈øuffycient Myni≈øters for hir yeres (which I pray God may be many to uphold Chri≈øtes Fayth in her Realms) Youth here is of ≈øome Inclination if they had but three or four good Hedys Re≈øident to lean unto, to comfort them, again≈øt ≈øom fower talkers in their ≈øtoutne≈øs, but time mu≈øt be expected and Godys furderance craved: Sir I pray you pardon my boldnes and not to be offendyd though I wright thus homly and in Engli≈øh Letters, while paraventure I might bu≈øye my head to wright Latinius, ≈øomewhat to avoyd offending of your exact and exquy≈øite gift in your Latin Tonge, I might chance to wright ob≈øcurius not ≈øignificancius, and ≈øo the longer to deteyn your peru≈øing the≈øe ≈ømal Cau≈øes to hynder your others much more weighty, which I be≈øeche Almighty God to pro≈øper.

closer.dateline: From Corpus Chri≈øti Collage in Camboige the 30th. Day of March.
closer.signed: Your onfeyned and bownd Bede≈øman. M. P.

div.p:
¬ß. 4 I have Tran≈øcribed this according to the ≈øpelling of this noted Prelate, Antiquitates Britannicae, &c. who hath ≈øhewn his Learning in Antiquities, and his Zeal for the prote≈øtant Religion
in his Books. Yet I doubt not but this Age will think his way of expre≈ø≈øing him≈øelf in Engli≈øh not very Polite. I ≈øhall not Comment upon his Letter, which tho' in ≈øomethings ob≈øcure, yet is plain enough to be under≈øtood, as to what was his General intent and de≈øign.

This Vi≈øitation of Cambridge, in the fir≈øt Year of Queen Elizabeth was by Commi≈ø≈øion under the Great Seal to Sir William Cecyl then Chancellor of the Univer≈øity of Cambridge, and to others, as Mr. Pryn in his Oxford Plea refuted, pag. 34. hath given a ≈øhort account of.

‚òû In the Queens Letters before the ≈øaid Vi≈øitation to Sir William Cecyl are the≈øe expre≈ø≈øions. Becau≈øe the chief Order and Government of Our Univer≈øity of Cambridge appertaineth to you, being the Chancellor of the ≈øame, &c. We thought meet to will you in Our Name to give ≈øignification, that We mean very ≈øhortly, with your Advice, to Vi≈øit the ≈øame by ≈øome di≈øcreet and Meet per≈øons.

So that here we find whatever power the Chancellor hath, it is in ≈øubordination to the Sovereign, and tho' they may take the advice of their Subjects in places of Government under them, yet the power of Vi≈øiting ≈øtill proceeds, and is derived from them, as all along I hope I have proved.

div.head: ¬ß. 5. An account of the Vi≈øitation of Merton College in Oxford.
div.p:
Anno 1562. Wood Antiq. Oxon. lib. 1. fol. 284. b. 4o. Eliz. There happened a Sedition in Merton College. In January Dr. James Gervace the Cu≈øtos or Warden having voluntarily quit his place, the Fellows gave in the Names of five to the Arch-Bi≈øhop their Vi≈øitor, whereof two or three had never been of their Society, whereas Anciently according to their Statutes they had u≈øed to name only three bred in the College, whereof one was
to be put into the place of him that was Dead or Re≈øigned.

The Arch-Bi≈øhop re≈øented this, and rejected all tho≈øe named by the Fellows, and before the end of March Nominated John Man ≈øometime Fellow of New College to be the Warden, who came to Oxford the 30th. of March accompanyed with Dr. Babington the Vice-Chancellor, Dr. White Warden of New College, but the Fellows refu≈øed to Admit him, ≈øo that on the 2d. of April he came accompanyed with the Vice-Chancellor, and Henry Norris of Witham, and Anthony Fo≈øter of Cumnor, and with much difficulty the Gate was opened, Mr. Willi. Hawle the Senior Fellow and others oppo≈øing, upon this the Arch-Bi≈øhop, upon the 26th. of May following Cited them all to appear in their Church, to be Vi≈øited by him≈øelf or his Vicar General and by the ≈øaid Vicar General of the Arch-Bi≈øhop, Man was Confirmed and Hawle was Ejected out of his Fellow≈øhip.

By this it appears what power the Local Vi≈øitor had to Nominate and ≈øettle the Head of the College at his plea≈øure even contrary to the Ancient Statutes of the Society,The ob≈øervation upon it. how much more may we conceive, that the King hath power by his Mandate to Nominate and appoint the Head of any College as Sovereign and Supreme Vi≈øitor.

The Commi≈ø≈øion for Vi≈øitation continued ≈øtill, and in it great changes were made till all were reduced to a Conformity to the Queens Laws and plea≈øures, ≈øeveral Statutes were revoked, others amended or explained, all which great changes were by vertue of the Queens Commi≈ø≈øion.

div.head: ¬ß. 6. Secretary Cecyls Letter about Non-conformi≈øts in Cambridge threatning a Vi≈øitation.
div.p: Before I proceed to any other Vi≈øitations I ≈øhall give a ≈øhort account of the great States-man Sir William Cecyls proceeding, Wood Antiq. Oxon. lib. 1.286. upon a di≈øorder in St. Johns College in Cambridge, wherein we may note by what Steps he being Chancellor thought fit to proceed by the ≈øubordinate Governors with a ≈øufficient Menace, that, if that would not be effectual, he would obtain the Queens Authority for a Vi≈øitation.

‚òû December the 13th. 1565. Bundel Eccle≈øia≈øtica 1560. ad 1569. In the Paper Office. Secretary Cecyl Writes to Dr. Stoke Vice-Chancellor of Cambridge concerning ≈øome of the Younger Fellows, that in St. Johns College Chappelleft off the u≈øe of the Surplice, That the Vice-Chancellor Confer with the Pre≈øident, and if they can do it by their Ordinary Authority then to proceed; if not, then he Writes a Letter to the Bi≈øhop of Ely Vi≈øitor in Ordinary to rectifie it, then follows.

If there ≈øhall no good come of tho≈øe two means, then I am determined to re≈øort to the Authority of our Sovereign Lady the Queens Maje≈øty. In who≈øe power by Prerogative the Government of all manner of Subjects doth belong to reduce them by ≈øharpne≈øs to the Obedience of her Laws and Commandment.
This was the Judgment of the Great State≈ø-man who may be pre≈øumed to have well under≈øtood the Law and the Prerogative in that Ca≈øe.

In his Letter to the Bi≈øhop of Ely he Writes, that he had privately imparted the matter to her Maje≈øty for his di≈øcharge by whom he hath been ≈øtraightly charged to ≈øee Reformation, and with ≈øpeed and ≈øeverity, which he hath promi≈øed her Maje≈øty to do, altho' he will fir≈øt ≈øeek it by ordinary means.‚ÄîIf
otherwi≈øe it ≈øhould fall out he would for his di≈øcharge refer the whole to the Queens Supreme Authority,Here note the Authority of the Prince. whereupon mu≈øt needs follow Cau≈øe of Repentance to the Authors of that Garboyle.

By which it is manife≈øt, that whatever Ordinary power was lodged in the Bi≈øhop of Ely as Dioece≈øan Vi≈øitor, or the Chancellor and other Magi≈øtrates of the Univer≈øity, yet the Queen, Jure Regio ≈øuper≈øedes all and takes Cognizance of the whole matter by her Commi≈ø≈øioners, as occa≈øion might require.

div.head: ¬ß. 7. Di≈øturbance about Election of a Pre≈øident in Corpus Chri≈øti College.
div.p:
‚òû In the Year 1568. Wood Antiq. Oxon. lib. 1. fol. 290. a. The Queens Mand√†te refu≈øed at fir≈øt, but after obeyed. The College of Corpus Chri≈øti made ≈øome di≈øturbance about the Election of a Pre≈øident, the Story in ≈øhort is thus. One Mr. Robert Hary≈øon ≈øometimes Fellow of the College there, was Expelled in King Edward the Sixth's time, Anno 1552. and Thomas Greenway was made Pre≈øident, who re≈øigning, the Fellows Elected Hary≈øon for their Pre≈øident, tho' the Queen by her Mandate appointed Mr. William Cole who had been Fellow there, and bani≈øhed in Queen Maries time. This Mandate they ≈ølighted, and Elected as afore≈øaid, with which the Queen being acquainted, ≈øhe declared the Election void, and expre≈øly Commanded them to Admit Cole. The Fellows reply'd, that they had done nothing but according to their Oath,The Queens Mandate to the Bi≈øhop of Winche≈øter to Admit Cole Pre≈øident of Corpus Chri≈øti College contrary to the Election of the Fellows. upon which the Queen being provoked that her Mandate was not obeyed, ≈øhe ≈øent Dr. Horn Bi≈øhop of Winche≈øter their Local Vi≈øitor, and Commanded him to ≈øee Cole Admitted. The College ≈øhut their Gates again≈øt the Bi≈øhop, who cau≈øed them to be opened, and going to the Chappel and calling the Senior Fellows Admoni≈øhed them forthwith to Admit Cole, and they re≈øi≈øting he openly pronounced them Expelled putting others in their places, who he knew would obey the Queens Command,
and ≈øo placed him Pre≈øident, and the Queen Commanded the Chancellor of the Univer≈øity,In fa≈øciculo Chartarum in Abba Aula. the Bi≈øhop of Winche≈øter Sir William Cecyl Secretary of State,The Queen appoints Vi≈øitors. Thomas Cooper, and Lawrence Humphrey Doctor of Divinity, and George Achworth Doctor of Laws, that they ≈øhould Vi≈øit the College, and again≈øt the ill de≈øerving they ≈øhould proceed either by lighter puni≈øhments or by Expul≈øion, by which they Ejected the Romani≈øts, and placed Prote≈øtants in their Rooms, ≈øaith my Author.

The like method the Vi≈øitors took in other Colleges, Expelling all that Renounced not the Roman Religion, Su≈øpending or Impri≈øoning others who offended le≈øs,Reg. Coll. Exon fol. 96. and Mr. Wyot Sub-prior of Excetor College was expelled and Impri≈øoned, Mr. John Neal Rector Expelled.

div.head: ¬ß. 8. What the Earl of Leyce≈øter did as Chancellor.
div.p: Anno 1569. K. K. fol. 8. Regimen Academicum omni propemodum ex parte Immutavit non nullos quidem in meliorem, rebus vero plerilque in pejorem formam redactis. Wood Antiq. Oxon lib. 1. fol. 290. b. & 291. a. 12 Eliz. Robert Dudley Earl of Leyce≈øter, being Chancellor he altered much of the Government of the Univer≈øity, ≈øaith my Author, changing ≈øomething for better, but mo≈øt what for the wor≈øe, he aboli≈øhed the old Form of choo≈øing Proctors, he Named the Vice-Chancellor, not con≈øulting the Convocation, which ≈øeldom was done in Ancient times, he was the fir≈øt that appointed, that the Vice-Chancellor, Proctors and Heads of Hou≈øes ≈øhould Convene and Confer about any matter that was under con≈øideration, before it was propo≈øed to the Senate of the Univer≈øity, and Decreed, that all public matters, e≈øpecially tho≈øe of greate≈øt moment, ≈øhould be expedited ≈øecretly by Scrutiny, and not as Anciently openly and by Suffrages before the Proctors.

In this particular it is to be noted, that Mr. Wood ≈øaith, the Vi≈øitation is to be a≈øcribed to this Earl, and it is mo≈øt clear, that whatever the Chancellor
did or could do, was only as his power was derived from the Crown.

div.head: SECT. IV.

argument.p: A further Account of the Vi≈øitations of the ∆≤niver≈øities or ≈øingle Colleges; together with the Alteration, Abrogating, or new Impo≈øing of Statutes of the ∆≤niver≈øities by the Sovereigns.

div.head: ¬ß. 1 The account of what is to be Treated of in this Section.
div.p: IN pur≈øuance of my de≈øigned Method, I ≈øhall with what brevity I can give an account of the more Modern Vi≈øitations of the Univer≈øities, or ≈øingle Colleges, ≈øo far as I Judge they may conduce to the matter under con≈øideration.

The Critical Reader is however de≈øired not to cen≈øure me tho' in this Section I intermix ≈øome ob≈øervations of the Royal power in Abrogating, Correcting, Amending or new framing of Statutes accordingly as it was Judged more convenient to the better ordering of the Body of the Univer≈øity, as to their di≈øtinct Oeconomy, or the conformablene≈øs of their Members to the public Laws of the Realm, or the Political Government of the Prince. Upon all which con≈øiderations, be≈øides the Influence of private Councils, tho≈øe that are conver≈øant in the Hi≈øtories of former Ages will find, that not only Vi≈øitations have been appointed, but that ≈øeveral Princes have been Induced to alter the Statutes.

‚òû The true and adaequate Rea≈øon of all which hath been and ever will be, becau≈øe the Influence that the Univer≈øities have over the whole Kingdom is ≈øo
great, upon the account that they are the Nur≈øeries not only of the Divines, but al≈øo of the Eminente≈øt Gentry, and of the Profe≈ø≈øors of the Laws. So that if tho≈øe In≈øtructors, of the Learned hopes of the after Ages, be not conformable to the Laws of the Government, they may Create great di≈øturbances to it, which it is the Wi≈ødom of all Princes to avoid. Whence the fundamental Rea≈øon may be given why the Sovereigns have re≈øerved this power, of Vi≈øitation of the Univer≈øities, and giving Laws, to them≈øelves ≈øolely, as being mo≈øt conducible to the Tranquility of their Reigns

The Judicious Reader is likewi≈øe de≈øired to con≈øider why I intermix not only this particular ≈øuper-intendency of the Prince over the Statutes of the Univer≈øities with the Vi≈øitation of them or the Colleges, but likewi≈øe ≈øome matters more particularly relating to St. Mary Magdalen College: the rea≈øon of which is, becau≈øe I would not di≈øorder the Series of time, and likewi≈øe, that I would render this Section as Introductory to the next Chapter, wherein I ≈øhall particularly Treat of the Kings di≈øpen≈øing with Univer≈øity Statutes, for it ≈øeems to me a very natural con≈øequence, that ≈øince the Sovereign can di≈øannul, alter or amend Statutes, he may ju≈øtly upon Emergencies Su≈øpend the Execution of them by Mandate; There being no greater difference betwixt the Will and Plea≈øure of the Prince in both, but that in the one he declares his plea≈øure under his Broad Seal, by Commi≈ø≈øioners of his own ≈øole appointment to in≈øpect and alter them; and in the other he by his Royal Fiat Commands the Execution of his plea≈øure. And what I bring in as to St. Mary Magdalen College I do that the unrea≈øonablene≈øs of ≈øome of their Statutes
may appear if there were no di≈øpen≈øing power in the Crown.
Having promi≈øed this, I now proceed.

div.head: ¬ß. 2.
Queen Elizabeths Letters Patents for confirming the Statutes of the ∆≤niver≈øity of Cambridge.

opener.signed:
ELizabetha Dei Gratia Angliae, A Tran≈øcript of Queen Elizabeths Letters Patents, Communicated to me by the Learned Dr. Brady.
Franciae & Hiberniae Regina, fidei Defendor,
opener.salute: dilectis nobis Cancellario Magi≈øtris & Scholaribus Univer≈øitatis Cantabrigien. Salutem.

div.p:
Quanta rerum ve≈øtrarum cura nos perpetuo ≈øollicitat, dum utilitati Academiae ve≈øtrae Studemus, non tam privilegia a no≈øtra benignitate vobis conce≈ø≈øa, quam legum & Statutorum ve≈øtrorum nova quaedam di≈øpo≈øitio manife≈øt√© declarant.The Queens care of the Univer≈øity, and her new di≈øpo≈øing of their Statutes. Quorum altero injuriis ob≈øi≈øtere, quieteque Studiis ve≈øtris incumbere, altero concordiae rectaeque reipub. ve≈øtrae gubernationi con≈øulere po≈ø≈øitis. De illo abunde ≈øatis a nobis e≈øt pro≈øpectum. I≈øtud quidem licet jam diu a nobis inchoatum e≈ø≈øe non ignoramus, ac leges interea exercendas vobis dederimus: u≈øu tamen atque experientia optima Efficacique rerum Magi≈øtra edocti animadvertimus in illis aliqua e≈ø≈øe correctione digna. Rur≈øus cre≈øcente hominum audacia nimiaque licentia aliquas novas prioribus e≈ø≈øe adjiciendas duximus,The Rea≈øons for the need of correcting the Statutes. negotia enim quae de novo emer≈øerunt, novo indigere auxilio facile cernimus. Nunc vero cum i≈øta. Omnia accurate ut ≈øperamus ≈øunt ab≈øoluta & perfecta: ea a vobis omnibus cum ea qua decet obedientia, atque animi alacritate recipienda ≈øunt.The Queen appoints the Statutes by her Supreme and Royal Authority. Leges igitur ac Statuta hoc libello con≈øcripta, atque ≈øumma no≈øtra regia Authoritate Sancita vobis in ve≈øtrum commodum mittimus ac promulgamus, diligenterque atque fideliter a vobis ob≈øervanda proponimus.
Quod dum feceritis illi≈øque ut oportet ex animo parueritis, non ≈øolum a Deo optimo maximo & a nobis laudem & praemium expectabitis, verum etiam, una cum pietate atque optimarum artium non modico incremento, omnes gradus Academiae in pulcherrimum Ordinem adducetis, illiu≈øque famae atque dignitati optime pro≈øpicientes florenti≈ø≈øimam efficietis. At tandem, quod apud nos non minimi e≈øt momenti, exemplo ve≈øtro tanquam in omnium oculis & mente po≈øiti, reliquum populum no≈øtrum ad con≈øimilem legum no≈øtrarum ob≈øervationem ac ad pacem concordiam veramque obedientiam trahetis atque perducetis;The Queens Command to ob≈øerve them. digni regio favore, digni virtutis ac literarum praemio. Sed quoniam Exhortatio Liberorum excitat voluntatem, Mandatum Nece≈ø≈øitatem facit nec omnes virtutis amore, ≈øed plures poenae metu ad leges cu≈øtodiendas coguntur: Omnibus igitur quibus juri≈ødictio in hac parte competit, maximeque vobis qui pote≈øtatem publicam Academiae exercetis vel Singulorum Collegiorum gubernacula tenetis. Mandamus ut & vos ip≈øi Statuta i≈øta quatenus ad vos pertineant ob≈øervetis, & a reliquis omnibus diligentiam in eiv≈ødem ob≈øervandis exigatis illarumque executioni totis viribus incumbatis.The Queen will exact an account of the Governors of the Colleges if they ob≈øerve not the Statutes and take not care they be ob≈øerved by others. Si vero (quod ab≈øit) ≈øavore, gratia, lenitate, vel incuria ve≈øtra eas contemni, negligi, vel non ob≈øervari aliquando contigerit, Vos quibus illarum executio demandata e≈øt, quique aliorum gubernationem ≈øu≈øcepi≈øtis, hujus trangre≈ø≈øionis reos indicabimus, atque a vobis exactam rationem illius rei expo≈øcemus. Dominus Je≈øus, & voluntatem in vobis has leges cu≈øtodiendi, bona≈øque literas pietatemque di≈øcendi, & facultate ea≈ødem ad ip≈øius gloriam exercendi & exequendi concedat.

Regni no≈øtri duodecimo & Anno Chri≈øti 1570.
In cujus rei Te≈øtimonium has literas no≈øtras manu no≈øtra ≈øignatas magno ≈øigillo no≈øtro Angliae muniri fecimus, die & Anno ≈øupradicto.

div.head: ¬ß. 3. The State of the Controver≈øie betwixt the Pre≈øident and ≈øome of the Fellows in St. Mary Magdalen College in Oxford.
div.p: I ≈øhall now according to the Order of time give an Hi≈øtorical Account of an extraordinary Ca≈øe, that happened in St. Mary Magdalen College of Oxford occa≈øioned by the po≈øitivene≈øs or Ambiguity of the Statutes of the ≈øaid College, which I the rather in≈øert, becau≈øe Fir≈øt I have found no mention of it in Mr. Woods Collection of the Antiquities of Oxford, and Secondly, it will give an In≈øpection into the Statutable Con≈øtitution of that College; The Ca≈øe was this.

Mr. Jud≈øon one of the Deans being Dead,In the Paper Office Bundel. Dr. Humfrys Conte≈øts. Anno 1175. Anno 17 Eliz. the Pre≈øident Dr. Humfrey called a Meeting of the Thirteen Senior Fellows in order to proceed to an Election of a new Dean; Tho≈øe being met Mr. Thomas Cole, Mr. William Powel, Mr. Henry We≈øt, Mr. Nicholas Lumbard, Mr. Walter Enderby and Mr. Ralph Smith, denyed to take the u≈øual Oath praevious to the Election, for which they Alledged that Mr. Gregory, Mr. Brichenden, Mr. Ichforbis, Mr. Wade and Mr. Lilly, were not Statutable Fellows, as having neither taken Holy Orders nor taken Degrees in Law or Phy≈øic, as they were obliged in a certain time to do by the Founders Statutes; ≈øo that they being non Socii could not be Electors; ≈øo that the fore≈øaid Six denyed to proceed, unle≈øs Four at lea≈øt of the Five before Named, either would prove their Right to their Fellow≈øhips pre≈øently by the Statutes, or ≈øpeedily by Interpretation of the Bi≈øhop of Winche≈øter their Vi≈øitor, and the Six ≈øaid, they did not deny to proceed
to Election, which was not nece≈ø≈øary to be made at that time, but by their Statutes might be Po≈øtponed till the end of their Audit, if the Lawful Electors were pre≈øent.

The Pre≈øident Dr. Humfry finding the Six In≈øi≈øted upon the Plea, the third day he Summoned them; having cau≈øed the Statute to be Read to them of Expul≈øion, if they denyed to proceed to Election, pronounced them Expelled, and ≈øo went his way out of the Hall without Naming or Electing any Dean.

This was about July Anno 1575. There are ≈øeveral Papers which give an account of the Rea≈øons why the Six In≈øi≈øted on the Plea, Two of which, as containing the matter mo≈øt fully I ≈øhall annex, together with the Tran≈øcript of the Statutes Alledged, becau≈øe the matter ≈øeems to me ≈øomething curious, and gives ≈øome light into the Con≈øtitution of the College.
The following Paper is a ju≈øtification of the Expelled Fellows, which I could not ≈øo fully expre≈øs as in their own words.

div.head: ¬ß. 4. The account given in one of the Papers of the matter of Fact. The Pre≈øident in danger of perjury by the Statute. The Fir≈øt PAPER.
div.p: THis is the Order of proceeding again≈øt us, which we prove to be mo≈øt unju≈øt, and the Form of Election to be none by the≈øe Rea≈øons.

Fir≈øt, The Pre≈øident is as much bound to Swear by our Statutes as we, becau≈øe he is an Elector, therefore he is in as much danger as we, and his proceeding again≈øt us in mo≈øt unju≈øt, ¬ß Hoc tamen provi≈øo, &c. ≈øub finem. except he Expel him≈øelf: this is proved in every part by the Statute de Electione Prae≈øidentis.

Secondly, Where the time of Election by Statute appointed is not ob≈øerved, but another time taken not mentioned by Statute: There the Election is not of nece≈ø≈øity, nor the Tran≈øgre≈ø≈øion puni≈øhable by Statute. But this Election is not at the appointed time by Statute. Therefore this Election is not of nece≈ø≈øity, nor the Tran≈øgre≈ø≈øion puni≈øhable by Statute.
The Minor is proved, Statuto de finali computo Mini≈øtrorum, becau≈øe that Election is appointed at no other time, but only at the Audits end.

Thirdly, Where the E≈ø≈øential and material parts of an Election are wanting, there is no Lawful Election nor Lawful puni≈øhment for Tran≈øgre≈ø≈øion thereof. But this Election wanted the Lawful Thirteen Electors as E≈ø≈øential parts, becau≈øe non Socii are no Electors. Therefore this Election is neither Lawful, nor the Tran≈øgre≈ø≈øion thereof Lawfully puni≈øhable.
The Minor is proved before in Mr. Gregories, Brickendons, &c. Ca≈øes.

Fourthly, Dr. Coveney being Pre≈øident Pronounced Expul≈øion again≈øt Nine Fellows, Namely, Perry, Wil≈øon, Flower, Kingsmill, Purfoy, Mancel, Garbrand, Smith and Hallowaye, for refu≈øing an Extraordinary Election, but notwith≈øtanding they were re≈øtored by Sir John Ma≈øon and the Bi≈øhop of Ely, The≈øe were Vi≈øitors, and of this ca≈øe I may probably write ≈øomething when I An≈øwer the Objections. and Dr. Wright, affirming their Expul≈øion to be unju≈øt; and their refu≈øal to ≈øtand rather with Statute then the Pre≈øidents proceedings, therefore we tru≈øt our Cau≈øe being like, the like effect by ju≈øtice will en≈øue.

And the rather, for that Mr. Pre≈øident at the place and time of his Sentence of Expul≈øion again≈øt
us,Statuto 26 Unom. proveditur contra Socios, &c. ¬ß. A≈ø≈øi≈øtentibus, &c. neither required nor u≈øed the a≈ø≈øent of any the Officers of the College, which are requi≈øite by the≈øe expre≈øs words of our Statutes, A≈ø≈øi≈øtentibus ≈øibi Vice-Prae≈øidente, duobus Decanis & Bur≈øariis. Neither yet about a Sennight after the end of this Unju≈øt Action again≈øt us, attempting to get the Con≈øents of the ≈øaid Officers, could he obtain the Dean of Divinities A≈ø≈øent to our Expul≈øion, which is mo≈øt nece≈ø≈øary in every puni≈øhment of a Divine ≈øuch as we are,Conclu≈øio Statutorum ≈øub. finem. ¬ß. volumus praeterea, &c. and e≈øpecially at this time, when as there are but two Deans only, and both their Voices in an Expul≈øion nece≈ø≈øarily required as is before ≈øaid.

As they have proceeded in this matter according to their Oath, for the Maintenance of Statute, ≈øo will we, as bound in Con≈øcience before God by rea≈øon of the Oath we have taken, ≈øtand in the ≈øame, and make claim again≈øt them, never minding to joyn in an Act with them, Incident and proper to the per≈øon of a Fellow, but upon nece≈ø≈øity, until the ≈øaid per≈øons who≈øe places we make claim again≈øt be clean removed, or an Order ≈øet down by the Bi≈øhop, and In-regi≈øtered for the Confirmation of their places to the clean cutting off of all Controver≈øie hereof ari≈øing; and therefore we prote≈øt hereby, that this is not ≈øo much the proper Ca≈øe of the≈øe our Six Fellows, but generally ours, taking our ≈øelves as much prejudiced as the≈øe, being per≈øwaded we may in no wi≈øe ≈øuffer it without willful Perjury to us, and therefore purpo≈øe for ever, until it be fully ended according to our Oath to re≈øi≈øt their unju≈øt deten≈øion, viis & modis quibus Sciverimus quoad po≈ø≈øe; In Witne≈øs whereof, we Fellows have in the fear of God, all partiality ≈øet a part, Sub≈øcribed with our own hands hereunto.
This is Sub≈øcribed by the Six Fellows Expelled, and ≈øome others of the ≈øame Society, who joyned with them.
I ≈øhall now In≈øert the Second Paper, which contains the Vindication of the proceedings of Dr. Humphrey, and the Fellows An≈øwer to it.

div.head: ¬ß. 5. The Second PAPER.
div.p: A Declaration made to the Right Honorable Mr. Francis Wal≈øingham the fir≈øt of July 1575. by Mr. Wade, Gregory, and Sir Cotton, ≈øent by Dr. Humfrey Pre≈øident of Magdalen College in Oxford, upon the Ca≈øe of Mr. Cole and Five other Preachers Expelled by the ≈øaid Dr. Humfrey, for not yielding to an Election of a Dean, and Apo≈øtilled by the ≈øaid Mr. Cole and the other, at the Commandment of the Right Honorable Mr. Francis Wal≈øingham the 4th. of July 1575. at Ea≈øton.

div.head: Dr. Humfreys Defence.
div.p:
IT happened, that God by Death took away Mr. Jud≈øon one of our Deans, whereupon it was 1. Decreed and thought 2. nece≈ø≈øary by Statute, Mr. Powel, Mr. Cole, Mr. Lumbard and the re≈øt, that another ≈øhould be cho≈øen in his Room. Mr. Doctor Humfrey, the next Day called together 3. ≈øuch as
had any thing to do in the Election, what time Mr. Powel, Cole, Lumbard, 4. denyed to proceed in the Election, to 5. give any voices, which was flat again≈øt our Statutes, and 6. de≈øerved incontinently the Sentence of Expul≈øion. Yet Mr. Dr. Humfrey hath, not to deal extreamly, ≈øtayed, and declared unto them the danger they incurred, exhorted them to con≈øider the pain of their 7. contumacy, deferred the Election until another ≈øea≈øon, at what time, 8. becau≈øe they would not be found, they went a Mile out of the Town to Bowles.

The next Day they were again ≈øent for, where Mr. Pre≈øident yet again Coun≈øelled them to beware, who per≈øi≈øting in their former mind and purpo≈øe 9. cau≈øing others to intermedle them≈øelves in that which pertained not unto them, by ru≈øhing very trouble≈øomely into the Common Hall
of purpo≈øe to interrupt the Election, did 10. force Mr. Pre≈øident to pronounce the Statute again≈øt them, which is, that who≈øoever being called to the Election of any Officer, having to do in the ≈øame, ≈øhall 11. deny to give his voice, mu≈øt be removed from his Fellow≈øhip forthwith.

div.head: The Defence of Mr. Powel, Mr. Cole, and Mr. Lumbard.
div.p: THey were per≈øwaded that they ought to give no Voices, 12. until certain of the Fellows were removed out of the College whom they did not Account of their Company.

div.head: The An≈øwer of their Defence.
div.p:
ALL places that the Challenged were allowed by 13. Statute, con≈øent of Mr. Pre≈øident and Confirmation of the
Bi≈øhop of Winton or el≈øe were commenced as doubts, and referred to the Arbitrament and determination of the Bi≈øhop; who≈øe 14. Interpretation they would neither ≈øtand unto as given, or 15. ≈øtay for as by occa≈øion of his 16. bu≈øine≈øs deferred: but again≈øt all Law and Rea≈øon would have certain removed before the 17. Sentence were given of them from their Judge the Bi≈øhop of Winton.

All the 18. doubts and Rea≈øons that they could allege for their re≈øtoring were an≈øwered and 18. refuted by the Bi≈øhop him≈øelf, who in the end gave a 19. definitive Sentence again≈øt them, and allowed the places by them called in que≈øtion at that time as good and ≈øufficient.

div.head: The Fellows An≈øwer.
div.p: 1. FIr≈øt, it was not Decreed,Note in this the Numeral Figures in the Fellows An≈øwer, refer to the like in Dr. Humfreys Defence. but only con≈øulted on.

2. Secondly, it was thought of ≈øome expedient asIt ≈øeems that for Di≈øcipline ≈øake their Statutes might be di≈øpen≈øed with in their Opinion. nece≈ø≈øary for Di≈øcipline, but not by nece≈ø≈øity of Statute.
3. All that had to do were not called, and tho≈øe that had not to do were called and admitted to choo≈øe.
4. We denyed not ≈øimply but upon divers and ju≈øt cau≈øes, e≈øpecially becau≈øe the Form of Statute was not ob≈øerved, that is, the 13 Senior Fellows called.
5. It is not again≈øt Statute but nece≈ø≈øary by Statute, contradicere, re≈øi≈øtere, expre≈ø≈øe impedire viis & modis quibus ≈øciverimus, every Act that is contrary or derogating from Statute.
6. We de≈øerved no puni≈øhment for that which we did by Statute.
7. Yet it is not contumacy to ≈øtay where Statute commandeth us to ≈øtay.
8. We ≈øtayed at home that day till two of the Clock at Afternoon, not being called; and then went with other Ancients and Godly Preachers to excerci≈øe our ≈øelves.
9. We neither cau≈øed them to come nor knew of their comeing, nor ≈øpake to them when they were come.
10. Our Fact forced him not to do that which by Statute and Con≈øcience ≈øhould have been left undone.
11. We denyed not to give our Voices, neither was it urged, but u≈øed ≈øilence again≈øt Extremity of power.
12. Until certain not Fellows were removed out of the Number of Electors, or the Bi≈øhop of Winton had been con≈øulted, which ≈øhould be within 15 Days as our Statute requires.
13. Neither by Statute nor con≈øent of the Pre≈øident, nor Confirmation of the Bi≈øhop, nor all commenced as denotes.
14. We could not ≈øtand to that which the Bi≈øhop had not given. A dilation is no Interpretation.
15. Our de≈øire was to ≈øtay a not nece≈ø≈øary Election, to the end we might receive the Bi≈øhops re≈øolution, which we had long de≈øired & looked for.
16. The Bi≈øhop deferred not his determination for his bu≈øine≈øs, but, as he confe≈ø≈øed at Mr. Pre≈øidents reque≈øt.
17. Our Statute ≈øaith, habeantur non Socii ip≈øo facto: by the which we mu≈øt be Ruled, and maketh no mention of any Sentence to be pronounced of the Bi≈øhop or any other.
18. They were not an≈øwered, re≈øolved or refuted.
19. The Bi≈øhop gave no Sentence, either again≈øt us, or for them, but left all in ≈øu≈øpence, & de≈øired Mr. Pre≈øident to re≈øtore us.

This Po≈øtillation which we have ≈øeen and Read, being faithfully done according to the Truth of the proceeding of things here, and the ≈øincere Grammar meaning of our Statutes, we the beneath Written approve and allow of both in Con≈øcience before God, and humble Duty to Man, as Witne≈ø≈øes of the ≈øame, who were here pre≈øent at the dealing, and in no wi≈øe con≈øenting or likeing of the Pre≈øidents proceeding again≈øt them therein, being fully per≈øwaded in Con≈øcience he doth them, and the re≈øt of the ≈øame cau≈øe wrong, and did in that his determination as much again≈øt Statute as might be. Which he ≈øufficiently declared in ≈øending ≈øuch to follow the matter who≈øe places are in Controver≈øie, & are part of the very Subject of all this trouble, joyning with them a Bachellor of Art, the Younge≈øt of all the Fellows, a thing not u≈øual at any time, the Grave≈øt and Elde≈øt, and be≈øt ≈øu≈øpect of all our Company thought always ≈øcar≈øe ≈øufficient enough to deal in the weighty Affairs of our College.
I ≈øhall now In≈øert the Statutes which were alledged in the Defence of the Expelled Fellows and give ≈øome Inferences from them in the Conclu≈øion.

div.head: ¬ß. 6. The Statutes produced in Defence of the Expelled Fellows. The Third PAPER.
Juramentum no≈øtrum.
div.p: IT.I. The Oath to ob≈øerve the Statutes. Omnia Statuta & ≈øingula in 2a. Sectione contenta quatenus per≈øonam no≈øtram concernunt vel concernere poterunt, ≈øecundum planum literalem & Grammaticalem ≈øen≈øum & intellectum Inviolabiliter tenebo & ob≈øervabo, & quantum in me fuerit teneri faciam ab aliis & etiam ob≈øervari.

It.II. To admit, &c. no Statutes contrary to tho≈øe made by any but by William Waynfleet. Nulla Statuta, Ordinationes, interpretationes, immutationes, injunctiones velglo≈ø≈øas, qualitercunque vero ≈øen≈øui & intellectui eorum etiam repugnantes derogantes contrarias, per quemcunque vel quo≈øcunque, quam per William Waynfleet edita & edenda quomodolibet acceptabo, aut Con≈øentiam aut aliqualiter admittam vel ii≈ødem parebo ullo tempore, ≈øed eis contradicam & re≈øi≈øtam expre≈ø≈øe, ip≈øaque fieri, viis & modis omnibus quibus ≈øcivero, impediam juxta po≈ø≈øe.

list.item: Eadem habentur in juramento Scholarium probationum.
Eadem habentur de Juramento Scholarium 15 annum excedentium.

div.p:
It.III. Anathema again≈øt the violators of the Statutes. Ordinamus & Statiumus ≈øub poena Anathematis & Indignationis Omnipotentis Dei, nequis Scholarium aut ≈øociorum dicti Collegii, cuju≈øcunque gradus, conditionis, Status, Scientiae, Facultatis extiterit, pro ≈øua voluntat√® aut odio aut occa≈øione quacunque
Ordinationum & Statutorum no≈øtrorum, quid quam de ≈øen≈øu no≈øtrae Intentionis aliqua Interpretatione, excitante ≈øini≈øtra ac quocunque ≈øuadente colore, arte vel ingenio, occa≈øione data vel procurata affirmet con≈øtruat aut defendat, aut quovis alio modo per ≈øe vel alium quemcunque aliter quam quod no≈øtrae Intentionis exi≈øtit, con≈øtrui, interpretari ≈øeu etiam affirmari quacunque ex cau≈øa procuret. Siquis vero, antiquo ≈øuadente ≈øerpente, quicquam contra praemi≈ø≈øa verbo vel facto pre≈øump≈øerit attemptare a no≈øtro Collegio ≈øi per te≈øtes idoneos convictus fuerit, tanquam in hac parte perjurus penitus excludatur.

It.IV. Neither Pre≈øident or Fellows or any other of what Dignity ≈øoever, to make new Statutes. Sequitur (praeter verba in juramentis propo≈øita) nullo in ullo tempore liceat Prae≈øidenti aut Sociis Collegialiter conjunctim vel divi≈øim nec alteri cuju≈øcunque dignitatis, exi≈øtat nova Statuta, &c. (≈øupra in juramentis po≈øita) condere Ordinare, Statuere, dictare nec praemi≈ø≈øa Statuta vel eorum aliqua, quocunque quae≈øito colore, infringere vel alicujus Statuti tenorem aut ≈øub≈øtantiam demere nec circa ea quomodo libet di≈øpen≈øare.

It.V. Here note, that he had the Authority by which he made the≈øe Statutes from the King. Si talia fuerint per aliquem Epi≈øcopum Succe≈ø≈øorem, vel alios quo≈øcunque, ip≈øa nolumus ligare Socios vel alias per≈øonas no≈øtri Collegii quovi≈ømodo ≈øed ab ob≈øervantia eorundem omnes no≈øtri Collegii Authoritate no≈øtra vobis commi≈ø≈øa eximimus. Interpretationes tum declarationes circa dubia permittimus Domino Epi≈øcopo Winton; cui in his obtemperare debent omnes & ≈øinguli ≈øub ip≈øorum debito juramento, dummodo interpretatio fiat de ii≈ødem juxta planum ≈øen≈øum eorum intellectum & expo≈øitionem Grammaticalem & literalem magis & aptius ad praeten≈øum dubium applaudentem.

It.VI. Neither Pre≈øident or Fellows to make any Orders, Declarations, Interpretations, &c. contrary to the pre≈øent Orders, Statutes, &c. Inhibemus ≈øpecialiter & expre≈ø≈øe & ≈øub interminatione Divini judicii interdicimus Collegii no≈øtri Prae≈øidenti & Scholaribus Univer≈øis & ≈øingulis, ac in virtute Juramenti per ip≈øos & eorum quemlibet in ip≈øorum admi≈ø≈øione ad Collegium no≈øtrum pre≈øtiti, admonemus & hortamur in Domino ne ip≈øi Collegialiter conjunctim vel divi≈øim alias Ordinationes, declarationes, Interpretationes, immunitiones, injunctiones, expo≈øitiones vel glo≈ø≈øas prae≈øentibus Ordinationibus, & Statutis vel ip≈øorum, plano, ≈øano Grammaticali ex literali intellectui, quomodolibet adver≈øantes repugnantes, derogantes acceptent, nec huju≈ømodi fieri procurent, aut ii≈øem utantur, publice, vel occult√®, direct√® velindirecte.

It.VII. None to admit di≈øpen≈øations contrary to the≈øe Statutes. Si autem praemi≈ø≈øa vel contra intentionem no≈øtram in praemi≈ø≈øis vel eorum aliquo per aliquem vel aliquos (quod ab≈øit) aliquid vel aliquam Statui Ordinari, fieri aut dictari vel di≈øpen≈øationem aliquam ≈øcienter vel ignoranter concedi vel haberi contigerit in futurum, Authoritate prae≈øentis Statuti decernimus pronunciamus & declaramus dictos, Prae≈øidentem, Vice-Prae≈øidentem, Socios, & Scholares dicti no≈øtri Collegii (quibus omnibus & ≈øingulis, in ea parte omnem & omni modam adimimus pote≈øtatem) ad ip≈øa ob≈øervanda non teneri quomodolibet vel a≈øtringi, ≈øed ea vacuamus omnino & carere volumus omni robore firmitatis.

Volumus quod Socius quilibet dicti Collegii Mr. Artium infra unum annum po≈øt nece≈ø≈øariam regentiam ≈øuam completam continue numerandam,I. The Statutes that prove tho≈øe that were objected again≈øt to be no Fellows, and particularly again≈øt Inkforbes and Gregory. ni≈øi ad ≈øtudium juris civilis vel Medicinarum ≈øe transferat ad ≈øacerdotium, impedimento ce≈ø≈øante legitimo, per Prae≈øidentem,
Decanos & Bur≈øarios approbandos ≈øe faciat promoveri.
Hinc ≈øequitur Wadum, Inckforbeum, minorem Gregorium Socios non e≈ø≈øe.

Provi≈øio quod de dicto numero Quadrage≈øimo ex ≈øpeciali providentia Prae≈øidentis, Vice-Prae≈øidentis, Decanorum & trium aliorum Seniorum duo vel tres in jure Canonico, & Civili: Alii duo vel tres in Medicinis, quos ad hoc ip≈øi aptos habiles & idoneos decreverint, ≈øtudere poterint.

Non Impetrabo di≈øpen≈øationem aliquam contra juramenta no≈øtra praedicta nec aliquam particulam eorumdem,II. The Statute again≈øt Mr. Wade. nec contra Ordinationes & Statuta aut ip≈øorum aliqua nec Di≈øpen≈øationem huju≈ømodi per alium vel alios public√® vel occult√® impetrari vel fieri procurabo direct√® vel indirect√®. Et ≈øi fort√® Di≈øpen≈øationem huju≈ømodi impetrari aut gratis Concedi vel acquiri contigerit cujuscunque fuerit Authoritatis ≈øeu ≈øi generaliter vel ≈øpecialiter aut alias ≈øub quacunque forma verborum conce≈ø≈øa ≈øit: ip≈øa non utar nec eidem con≈øentiam quovi≈ømodo ≈øicut Deus me adjuvet & Sacro Sancta Dei Evangelia, Hinc concluditur Wadum perjurio teneri & per con≈øequens non Socium, &c.

p.hi: De Sociis & Scholaribus, Beneficiatis, &c. contra Brickentonum.

div.p:
Si aliquis Sociorum vel Scholarium praedictorum,III. The Statute again≈øt Brichenton. Beneficium Eccle≈øia≈øticum cum Cura vel ≈øine Cur√¢, cujus fructus redditus & provenctus 80. Librarum valorem annum, ≈øi in eodem per≈øonaliter re≈øideat, excedunt, adeptus fureit per unum annum, & non ultra, in dicto Collegio Socium vel Scholarem ≈øtare
permittimus; volentes, ac etiam decernentes quod po≈øt lap≈øum huju≈ømodi anni ni≈øi infra annum eundem, ip≈øum Beneficium, effectualiter dimi≈øerit vel ni≈øi ce≈ø≈øantibus, dolo, fraude ac malo Ingenio litigio≈øum ≈øit; ip≈øo facto pro non Scholari & non Socio penitus habeatur.

p.hi: De tempore a≈ø≈øumendi gradus in qualibet facultate.

div.p: Artitum Magi≈øtri omnes & ≈øinguli,The Statute again≈øt Gregory. nece≈ø≈øaria ≈øua regentia completa, exceptis his qui ad Jura, Leges, vel ad Artes Medicinales Licentiati ≈øunt ≈øe transferre: Statim ad facultatem Sacrae Theologiae, ≈øe divertant. ‚Äî Contra Gregorium.

Si lis de & ≈øuper aliquo Articulo no≈øtrorum Statutorum & Ordinationum inter Prae≈øidentem aut Socios aut Scholares aut aliquas alias per≈øonas no≈øtri Collegii ≈øupradicti,The Bi≈øhop of Winche≈øter to be con≈øulted upon any doubts ari≈øing betwixt the Pre≈øident, Fellows, or Scholars, but he is not permitted to make any Interpretation contrary to the plain ≈øen≈øe. dubium aliquod, ≈øeu di≈øcors Opinio oriatur, cujus deci≈øio planus & ≈øanus Intellectus intra quindenam, a tempore emergentis dubii computandam, nequiverit haberi, tunc volumus quod Prae≈øidens no≈øtri Collegii quam citius poterit Dominum Epi≈øcopum Winton pro tempore exi≈øtentem (in quo ≈øinceram fiduciam ponimus) con≈øulat.

Nolentes in≈øuper aliquam Interpretationem fieri de ei≈ødem aut circa ea ni≈øi juxta planum ≈øen≈øum Communem intellectum & expo≈øitionem Grammaticalem & literalem magis & aptius ad cau≈øam ≈øeu preten≈øum dubium de quo queritur & Agitur applaudentem.

div.head: ¬ß. 7.
div.p: I ≈øhall now ab≈øtract ≈øome parts of Secretary Wal≈øinghams Letter, and the Bi≈øhop of Winche≈øters reply about this matter.

The Secretary Writes thus inter alia ‚Äî If I can Judge of any thing, methinks the≈øe, [the Expul≈øed Fellows] have more re≈øemblance of Truth on their ≈øide than the other hath. They have ≈øet it down ≈øo plainly, and in ≈øo good order, that if Truth be not there, I mu≈øt needs Confe≈øs my ≈øelf as much deceived in this matter as ever was Man in any ‚Äî your Lord≈øhip knows the Statutes, and I doubt not, but you will ≈øee by this their An≈øwer and Depo≈øition, that the Statutes are more for them than the other‚Äî becau≈øe the Election draweth nigh and ≈øome ≈øtir perhaps may be about them; I pray you take ≈øuch Order, that either they may be fully ≈øettled, or el≈øe the other Five who≈øe places are not re≈øolved of, may be Su≈øpended from all Voice, as well as the≈øe. ‚Äî Then Concludes ‚Äî Therefore I pray you my Lord take ≈øuch Order in the matter as Rea≈øon and Con≈øcience would, and relieve the oppre≈ø≈øed again≈øt the wrong; a≈ø≈øuring your Lord≈øhip, that if they cannot obtain it at your Hands they ≈øhall be heard, and I tru≈øt obtain it el≈øewhere. Dated at Killingworth July the 11th. 1575.

The Bi≈øhop of Winche≈øter An≈øwers July the 16th. following, thus ‚Äî I have received your Honors Letter, &c. to the which I may now An≈øwer but in brief. I will willingly do what lyeth in me to quench the Fiery Coales kindled in the Society of Magdalen College, the Smoak whereof I perceive doth trouble your Honor and others. But I hope within a ≈øhort time to cool the heat, ≈øo as the Smoak ≈øhall vani≈øh away, &c.

The ≈øame Bi≈øhop Writes another Letter to the Pre≈øident, Informing him of the Receipt of the Secretaries Letter, and adds ‚Äî I continue in my former
Opinion towards them, to wit, that I would be loth that they ≈øhould be Expelled, if by any means the Statutes may relieve them; and therefore I require you Mr. Pre≈øident and the Fellows, that you choo≈øe none now at the next Election into their Rooms,Here Obedience is payed to the Secretaries Letter of advice. but that their places may ≈øtand in the ≈øame Terms as they are, till I may hear what by you and them may further be ≈øpoken and con≈øidered by the Statutes, to the end the Statutes may be truly ob≈øerved, and in the mean ≈øea≈øon no Men be of that Calling wronged ‚Äî I have willed them to ab≈øent them≈øelves from the next Election, for good con≈øideration, and my hopes is, that none of that Society will move any troubles in or about the Election, for any matter now hanging in doubt and not decided, for that will breed ≈ølander to the Calling, and danger to them≈øelves; ≈øo he orders the Pre≈øident and others to attend him the Fir≈øt of Augu≈øt about the Controver≈øie. Dated at Lo≈øely the ≈øame day and Year with the former.
I have not found among the≈øe Papers what was the I≈ø≈øue of this great Controver≈øie, but from what doth appear, make the≈øe following remarks.

div.head: ¬ß. 8. The fir≈øt ob≈øervable from the≈øe ≈øhort Statutes.
div.p:
Upon the whole matter we may ob≈øerve, Fir≈øt, That the≈øe ≈øtrict and Indi≈øpen≈øable Statutes in former times as well as now, and in all times to come, have and will Create great troubles in this College, unle≈øs there be in the Sovereign a Vi≈øitatorial as well as Di≈øpen≈øing Power to Terminate endle≈øs Quarrels, when, as in this Ca≈øe, both Parties ≈øhall in≈øi≈øt upon Grammatical and Literal ≈øen≈øe of the Statutes, and tho' the Bi≈øhop of Winche≈øtr hath a power of Interpretation, yet he is ≈øo tyed up to the Literal and Grammatical ≈øen≈øe, that he mu≈øt unavoidably be
put ≈øome times to great ≈øtreights to determin matters.

‚òû Secondly, However Rigidly the Statutes ≈øeem to be worded, yet none can Judge, that the Kings Di≈øpen≈øing Power can be re≈øtrained, ≈øince neither the Founder could ≈øo bind either his Sovereign or the Pope, nor could any of tho≈øe bind their Succe≈ø≈øors by any Charter or Grant from ≈øuch inhaerent Prerogatives annexed to their very Offices; as I ≈øhall make clear when I come to con≈øider the Arguments u≈øed concerning the force of the≈øe Statutes.

‚òû Therefore Thirdly, I rather Judge, that the Founder (as Entaylers of E≈øtates upon their Po≈øterity to pre≈øerve nodo≈øam Aeternitatem often do) had a great de≈øire that his Statutes ≈øhould be perpetually ob≈øerved, but he could not be ≈øuppo≈øed to have ≈øuch an over weening Opinion of his own prudence, but that ≈øome Ca≈øes might happen whereby the Kings of England might Judge it convenient to alter them; ≈øo that I Rea≈øonably think the utmo≈øt of his de≈øign and hopes might be, that the Society it ≈øelf ≈øhould not have the power of altering them; but to Exclude the Sovereign, by their Prerogative or Acts of Parliament to Su≈øpend, alter, or Abrogate them, was as much beyond his power to enjoyn, as it was vanity in him to pre≈øume would thereby be effected.

Fourthly, In the Secretaries Letter we may ob≈øerve, that he threatens the Queens Authority, if the Bi≈øhop of Winche≈øter, their Vi≈øitor, would not do the Fellows Ju≈øtice, and in the Bi≈øhops Letter to the Pre≈øident he Su≈øpends all tho≈øe on both parties, from giving their Voices in the next Election, which mu≈øt be a force upon the Statutes for Election, if the Bi≈øhop
could not Interpret their Statutes but in the Literal and Grammatical ≈øen≈øe; for it is very probable it might be known by a Literal and Grammatical ≈øen≈øe whether they were Fellows or not, and if they were Fellows the Pre≈øident was as much bound by Oath to Admit their Voices as they obliged to give them, and if the per≈øons excepted again≈øt were no Fellows, then the Five were unlawfully Expelled, and ≈øo ought to have had Voices, ≈øo that whether way ≈øoever the matter were determined, I cannot conceive the Statutes or Interpretation was Literally and Grammatically ob≈øerved, which is the great plea of the Magdalen Fellows.

div.head: ¬ß. 9. The Ca≈øe of Mr. Wil≈øon.
div.p: I ≈øhall now ≈øhew that in the Controver≈øie about the matter of the Head of a ≈øingle College, the Queen appointed Commi≈ø≈øioners in a ≈øummary way to determin it Anno 1577. 19 Regni. The Ca≈øe was this.

A Controver≈øie ari≈øing betwixt William Wil≈øon Bachellor of Divinity,In the Paper Office Bundel.
