Anno 1577. 19 Eliz. and Thomas Bi≈øhop of Lincoln, for that the Bi≈øhop refu≈øed to Admit him as cho≈øen Rector of Lincoln College in Oxford, the ≈øaid Wil≈øon Appealed to Edmund Grindal Arch-Bi≈øhop of Canterbury, who≈øe Official Dr. Bartholomew Clerk Admoni≈øhed and Commanded the Bi≈øhop to Admit him, and that the Bi≈øhops Commi≈ø≈øioners ≈øhould not under the pain of contempt do any thing to the prejudice of the ≈øaid Wil≈øon, and the Arch-Bi≈øhop committed the determining the matter to certain Commi≈ø≈øioners. And Thomas Underhil Proctor of the Univer≈øity prote≈øted again≈øt the Commi≈ø≈øioners of the Arch Bi≈øhop as not competent Judges, and that the Examination of the matter belonged to the Chancellor of the Univer≈øity. Upon all which,

The Queen takes the Cau≈øe out of all their hands, and Grants a Commi≈ø≈øion to the Bi≈øhop of London and Roche≈øter, Sir Chri≈øtopher Wray Knight, Chief Baron of the Exchequer, Sir William Cordel Knight, Ma≈øter of the Rolls, Thomas Wil≈øon, John Gib≈øon and John Griffith Doctors of Law, upon the Petition of Robert Earl of Leyce≈øter Chancellor, the Doctors, Ma≈øters and Scholars of the Univer≈øity; of her certain knowledge and ≈øole motion, and of the plenitude of her power, Commanding them Eight, Seven, Six, Four, Three or Two of them, calling the Reverend Bi≈øhop of Lincoln and William Wil≈øon in per≈øon, and all others by Law to be called, in General, Summarily, and in plain Form without noi≈øe and Form of Tryals, only ≈øeeing to the truth of the thing and the Fact,Summarie in plano ≈øinc ≈øtrepitu & forma Judicii. and attending ≈øolely the aequity by all Manners and Forms by which they can better and more efficaciou≈øly proceed in and upon the Truth of the Premi≈ø≈øes according to the Privileges and Exemptions of the ≈øaid Univer≈øity, and in the Cau≈øe or Cau≈øes afore≈øaid, with their Incidents Emerging, Depending, Annexed or Connexed what≈øoever, and to determin it with a due end, removing all Appeals and Complaints, Nullity and Petition what≈øoever, and notwith≈øtanding any Statutes, Canons and Cu≈øtoms, on the contrary publi≈øhed or the Law Suit depending, cau≈øing all that in the premi≈ø≈øes they ≈øhall Ordain to be firmly ob≈øerved by Lawful remedies of the Law. Dated the 23d. of April, the 19th. of her Reign 1557.

By this it is apparent, that the Kings of England may Su≈øpend the power of the Arch Bi≈øhop and of the Chancellor and Local Vi≈øitor, and by Commi≈ø≈øion appoint others in a Summary way, not according
to Form of proceedings in Courts Eccle≈øia≈øtical, to determin differences in the Univer≈øities among the Society.

div.head: ¬ß. 10.
div.p: In the Year 1582.In the Paper Office Bundel. Eccl. Academica ab Anno 1580. to Anno 1589. 25 Eliz. I find a Letter Writ from Dr. William Fulk Vice-Chancellor of Cambridge to the Lord Trea≈øurer Cecyl, Endor≈øed Dr. Fulks Opinion, that not only Gonvil and Cajus College, but the other Colleges of Cambridge ≈øhould by further Authority from the Queen be Vi≈øited and Reformed, it is Dated the 10th. of October Anno 1582.

I ≈øhall In≈øert ≈øome of the expre≈ø≈øions, that the di≈ø-qui≈øitive Reader may know what was the Judgment of the Queens power then, and the nece≈ø≈øity of the Crowns having an ab≈øolute power over the Univer≈øities, for Reforming matters agreeable to the good likeing of the Prince. His words are ‚Äî According to your Lord≈øhips Letter I have con≈øulted the Heads of ≈øeveral Colleges, ‚Äî we are of Opinion that your Honor ≈øhould do a Charitable Deed to procure a Commi≈ø≈øion from her Maje≈øty to Reform the whole State and Statutes of that Hou≈øe, viz. Gonvil and Cajus College, of which ≈øome are meer Papi≈øtical, newly made by Dr. Cajus, appointing Ma≈øs and Dirige to be ≈øaid for him, ≈øome be Ambiguous and Imperfect, as the Vi≈øitors al≈øo have Certified your Honor, &c. Furthermore fora≈ø-much as the Reformation of one College is not ≈øufficient where the whole Body of the Univer≈øity is out of Frame; it is not mine Opinion only, but al≈øo of others of Wi≈ødom and great Experience, of whom I may name Dr. Harvey for one,The nece≈ø≈øity by Vi≈øitation to alter Statutes altho' the Univer≈øity hath Authority to make Statutes. that it were mo≈øt expedient the ≈øame were Reformed in the whole, and in divers Colleges ≈øpecially by a General Commi≈ø≈øion or Vi≈øitation, in which your Honor
might have an Ab≈øolute and Principal Authority, to ≈øupply the Imperfections of all Statutes both of the Univer≈øity and of ≈øundry Colleges wherein the ≈øame is needful. For ≈øo great is the multitude of Licenciou≈øne≈øs and di≈øordered per≈øons, which cannot be Bridled by our pre≈øent Statutes, that altho' the Univer≈øity hath Authority to make Statutes for the maintenance of good Order and quietne≈øs, yet nothing can be Decreed by the greater part, which will not con≈øent to any thing, which may re≈øtrain their di≈øordered Licenciou≈øne≈øs as was notably tryed within the≈øe two Years, when your Honor gave in charge to the Heads of Colleges to ≈øee the Reformation for exce≈øs in Apparel, who devi≈øed as well as they could, but nothing to this day can be Decreed, albeit the exce≈øs doth not dimini≈øh, but dayly encrea≈øe, &c.

The Clau≈øe about Apparel puts me in mind of the Regulation made in Oxford as to that particular ≈øome Years before; which I ≈øhall here In≈øert, that the Curious may note how unrea≈øonable it would be to bind the Members of the Univer≈øities to the ob≈øerving of all Statutes promi≈øcuou≈øly, if there were not a di≈øpen≈øing power, both in the Sovereign and Senates of the Univer≈øity.

div.head: ¬ß. 11.
div.p:
Anno 1564. 6 Eliz.
Wood Antiq. Oxon lib. 1. fol. 286. K. K. fol. 5. a. b. a. I find Statutes made like the Roman Sumptuary Laws, whereby the Pre≈øidents, Graduated Fellows and Scholars of the Societies, and every one that had any Office, or enjoyed Yearly Stipend or Eccle≈øia≈øtic Benefice in any College or Hall, ≈øhould wear no Shirt larger than to be plaited at the Collar and Wri≈øts, the plates not exceeding half a Thumb breadth, and ≈øhould have no Embroidery of Gold or Silver. That their Bands ≈øhould not be
turned back above a Thumb breadth broad, none ≈øhould wear Stockings but of plain Cloth clo≈øe to the Leg, neither Adorned with Buttons or Lace e≈øpecially not with Silk, none to wear Blew, White or Yellow Doublets. To which he adds out of the ≈øame Statutes, that the Univer≈øity con≈øidered of the re≈øtoring, mending, and explaining the Statutes. I hope all that Swore to the ob≈øerving the≈øe Statutes, would not have thought them≈øelves Perjured if either the King or the Chancellor had di≈øpen≈øed with them, or if any of them be unrepealed think not them≈øelves in Con≈øcience bound to ob≈øerve them, but that they may wear Silk Stockings, and larger Bands if not Cravats; and I doubt not but there are ≈øeveral ob≈øolete Statutes, that many who Swear Implicitly to ob≈øerve the Statutes in general never heard of.

It ≈øeems either the former Di≈øputes about Gonvil and Cajus College were continued, or ≈øome new ones were ari≈øen, as will appear by the Extract of the following Letter. If there be no mi≈øtake in the Copyer of the Date, that it ≈øhould have been 1582.

Anno 1592.Paper Office Eccle≈øia≈øtica Academ. Anno 1590. to 1599. 34 Eliz. Dr. Perne Vice-Chancellor of Cambridge Writes thus to my Lord Trea≈øurer Burlegh about the grief of the Univer≈øity, for his Lord≈øhips Offence at the dealing, touching Gonvil and Cajus College, and hath the≈øe expre≈ø≈øions.

p.q: I ≈øend your Lord≈øhip a Copy of the Privileges of the Univer≈øity, &c. The weake≈øt part therein in mine Opinion is the want of the Confirmation of the Spiritual Juri≈ødiction to the Chancellor of the Univer≈øity, for that we do now exerci≈øe, was fir≈øt granted by the Bi≈øhop of Rome, and Confirmed by pre≈øcription.

div.p: In this I ob≈øerve only, that the Vice-Chancellor hath recour≈øe to the Queens Power, to have the Eccle≈øia≈øtical Juri≈ødiction Granted to the Univer≈øity, owning they had the like from the Pope.

div.head: ¬ß. 12.
div.p: I could add many things more relating to the Univer≈øity or private Colleges, wherein the Kings power of Vi≈øiting by Commi≈ø≈øion is cleared, but I ≈øhall ha≈øten to a Conclu≈øion of this Head, and in the next place ≈øhew in one In≈øtance how King Charles the Fir≈øt, without the formality of a Vi≈øitation, ordered ≈øuch matters as he thought fit in the Univer≈øity of Oxford, by a Letter directed to the Vice-Chancellor of the ≈øaid Univer≈øity. Dated at Wood≈øtock the 26th. of Augu≈øt 1631. as followeth.

TRu≈øty and Well beloved, We Greet you Well,Paper Office Bundel. Eccle≈øia≈øtica Univer≈øitatis. having at full Length, and with good Delibration heard the Cau≈øe concerning the late Di≈øorders and Di≈øobediences to Government in that Univer≈øity of Oxford, The ends for which the Univer≈øities are ≈øubject to the King. and being moved by the greatne≈øs of the Offence to puni≈øh ≈øome per≈øons according to their ≈øeveral Demerits, and to Order ≈øomethings for the more ≈øettled and con≈øtant Government in that Our Univer≈øity hereafter, Our Will and Plea≈øure is,The Kings plea≈øure ratified in a Convocation, as in a Parliament of France. That you forthwith upon Receipt hereof call a Convocation for performing and Regi≈øtring tho≈øe our Sentences and Decrees as followeth.
Fir≈øt, That Three be Bani≈øhed out of the Univer≈øity, The Proctors to Re≈øign their Offices in Convocation, and Two others be cho≈øen in their Rooms.

Secondly, For the things which we think fit to ≈øettle pre≈øently in that Government they are, that as to Sermons the Vice-Chancellor to have Copies upon
Oath, That as to any whom the Vice-Chancellor Commands to Pri≈øon, the Me≈ø≈øage be ≈øent by the Beadle, and he that refu≈øeth ≈øhall be judged a breaker of the Peace, and not to have any Appeal.

Thirdly, A Command that the Delegates who at this pre≈øent are in hand with the Statutes, make ha≈øt and lay all other Statutes a≈øide till they have drawn up two perfect and ≈øufficient Statutes for Cau≈øes of Appeal, the one in matters of In≈øtances, and tho≈øe things which belong to the Chancellors Court, the other for all kind of Appeals in other Cau≈øes what≈øoever.

Anno 1632.E Collectionibus Dni. Jo≈øephi William≈øon, olim Secretarii Regis primarii. 8 Car. 1. The King Granted a Commi≈ø≈øion to the Earl of Holland then Chancellor of Cambridge, the Arch-Bi≈øhop of York, and Sir John Crook to Vi≈øit Pembrook Hall in Cambridge.

Anno 1634. 10 King Charles the Fir≈øt, the King Impowered under the Great Seal the Arch-Bi≈øhop of Canterbury, the Bi≈øhop of Roche≈øter, Sir Nathaniel Brent and others, to Vi≈øit all Colleges, Churches, Ho≈øpitals, &c. and to make Laws and Statutes, and this is expre≈ø≈øed to be ex Suprema no≈øtra Authoritate Regia, by the Kings Supreme Authority.

I have not found any perfect Copies of the≈øe Vi≈øitations,Wood Antiq. Oxon lib. 1. ad Annum 1633. but find in Mr. Wood, that the Regulating of the Univer≈øity Statutes of Oxford, which had been begun to be dige≈øted 1629. by Delegates appointed for that purpo≈øe, were brought to a good forwardne≈øs, Anno 1633. Arch-Bi≈øhop Laud then Chancellor being very Intent upon it.

When the ≈øame Arch-Bi≈øhop Vi≈øited the Univer≈øities by his Metropolitical Right, he was oppo≈øed in it, and the matter came to be heard before the King and Council, of which I ≈øhall pre≈øently give an account,
and whoever de≈øires a more full Relation may ≈øee the whole proceedings in the Annals of Mr. Francklane. I ≈øhall only In≈øert here an extract of what I found in the Paper Office Relating to Merton College in Oxford, which endeavored to decline the Arch-Bi≈øhops Authority in that Vi≈øitation, the principal Rea≈øons produced for it being the≈øe.

Fir≈øt, Paper Office. Academica Mi≈øcellania. Rea≈øons why the King is Vi≈øitor of Merton College. That King Henry the Third at the Foundation of the College Styles him≈øelf Patronus and con≈øequently was Vi≈øitor in the≈øe Words ‚Äî A≈ø≈øignavit Maneria praedicta in ≈øuis manibus nomine no≈øtro velut nomine Patroni.

Secondly, The Anciente≈øt Copy of Statutes is, that which is Confirmed by the Bi≈øhop of Lincoln, with a Re≈øervation of ≈øuch Privileges as belonged to the Dioece≈øan, and is Confirmed by the Arch-Bi≈øhop as Provincial, without any Re≈øervation at all; which in rea≈øon he would not have done if he had been Vi≈øitor.
Thirdly, The Bi≈øhop of Lincoln ≈øent Monition to the College, Intimating a purpo≈øe to Vi≈øit. From whom the Fellows Appealed to Rome.

Fourthly, The Statutes of Walter Merton have the word Patronus often, which cannot in rea≈øon be applyed to the Arch Bi≈øhop, to whom he had no Relation, but rather to the King who≈øe Chaplain and Chancellor he was.

By this it appears what the Opinion of the Society was then, that the King was Supreme Vi≈øitor, and that the Bi≈øhop of Lincoln re≈øerved his Dioece≈øan Right, yet when he de≈øigned an extraordinary Vi≈øitation the Fellows Appealed to the Apo≈øtolic See as Supreme, and I have cleared that what power that See had, is now in the King, according to the Laws.

div.head: ¬ß. 13.
div.p: I now proceed to give an Account of King Charles the Fir≈øts Order of Council, the 12 Regni, which hath been ≈øo much urged as if the King had Decreed in Council, that none but the Arch-Bi≈øhop of Canterbury ≈øhould Vi≈øit the Univer≈øities being Scituate in his Province, but by the whole ≈øcope of the Record it appears, that the Controver≈øie was betwixt the Arch Bi≈øhop of Canterbury and the Univer≈øities of Oxford and Cambridge, concerning the Right and Title of the Metropolitical Vi≈øitation of the ≈øame, and that the Univer≈øities did pretend they were Exempt from the ≈øame, and the matter in Di≈øpute was referred to the King and his Royal Judgment and Sentence,Lit ‚Ä¢ que & Controver≈øia praedictis ad nos & Judicium & Sententiam no≈øtram d ‚Ä¢ latis. who calling the Arch-Bi≈øhop of Canterbury Chancellor of the Univer≈øity of Oxford, and the Earl of Holland Chancellor of Cambridge, and others to come before him and his Council at Hampton-Court, and having heard the Arguments of both the Parties,Primo & ante omnia per probationes Legitimas & per conce≈ø≈øionem utriu≈øque partis nobis con≈øtabat nos jure Coronae no≈øtrae Regni Augliae habui≈ø≈øe & habere pote≈øtatem Vi≈øitandi Univer≈øitates praedictas quoties & quandecunque nobis & Succe≈ø≈øoribus no≈øtris Vi≈øum fuerit. &c. Fir≈øt and before all things by Legal proof, and the Confe≈ø≈øion of both Parties, It appeared that the King in Right of his Crown of England hath had and hath the power of Vi≈øiting the ≈øaid Univer≈øities as often and when≈øoever it ≈øhould ≈øeem fit to the King and his Succe≈ø≈øors. And that the Arch-Bi≈øhop of Canterbury by the Right of his Metropolitical Church hath had and hath power of Vi≈øiting all his Province of Canterbury, in which the ≈øaid Univer≈øities are Scituate.

Then follows that on the part of the Univer≈øities, it was propo≈øed that by certain Charters of the King and his Prdece≈ø≈øors and Papal Bulls, they were Exempt and freed from all Vi≈øitation and Juri≈ødiction of the ≈øaid Arch-Bi≈øhop, and that Immunity by u≈øe of time they now enjoyed by pre≈øcription, and on the Arch-Bi≈øhops part it was ≈øhewn, that King Richard
the Second and King Henry the Fourth had Judged the cau≈øe in favor of the Arch-Bi≈øhop, as before related, therefore the King Judgeth and determineth the Right of Vi≈øitation to belong to the Arch-Bi≈øhop and his Succe≈ø≈øors and his ≈øaid Metropolitical Church;Quibus unnibus per nos con≈øideratis habitaque deliberatione cum praefatis Conciliariis no≈øtris, Judicavimus & determinavimus, &c. and that not only once in his Life as in other Parts of his Province of Canterbury, but that it might be Lawful to the Arch Bi≈øhop and his Succe≈ø≈øors, after the fir≈øt Metropolitical Vi≈øitation ended, to Vi≈øit the ≈øaid Univer≈øity by him≈øelf or his Commi≈ø≈øaries,The Arch-Bi≈øhops Vi≈øitation not allowed, but by the Kings con≈øent. as often as it ≈øhould appear nece≈ø≈øary to the ≈øaid Arch-Bi≈øhops, on a rea≈øonable and Lawful Cau≈øe, fir≈øt by the King and his Succe≈ø≈øors to be approved. Dated the 30th. of January 12 Car. 1.

By this Record under the Broad Seal it is apparent, fir≈øt, that there was a Controver≈øie only betwixt the Arch-Bi≈øhop and the Univer≈øities, whether the Arch-Bi≈øhop as their Metropolitan might Vi≈øit, or they were Exempted from it. Secondly, That it was yeilded on all ≈øides, that the Kings Vi≈øitation was in no manner hereby di≈øputed, but it is po≈øitively a≈ø≈øerted, that the King and his Succe≈ø≈øors might Vi≈øit as often as they thought fit. Thirdly, That this Controver≈øie was wholly determined and adjudged by the King and his Council. So that there was not the lea≈øt Argument could be grounded from hence, that the power was devolved upon the long Parliament to Vi≈øit the Univer≈øity of Oxford by their Commi≈ø≈øioners,Pryns Oxford Plea Refuted. as Mr. Pryn confidently but mo≈øt unconclu≈øively a≈ø≈øerts. Fourthly, The whole matter was determined by the King and his Council, and ≈øo, that it is in the power of any of his Royal Succe≈ø≈øors to alter the ≈øame, if to them it ≈øhould ≈øeem meet.

As to other Vi≈øitations, there was one 1647. by Ordinances of the long Parliament, which being no ways conduceing to my purpo≈øe unle≈øs it were to ≈øhew, that what power ≈øoever claimed any ≈øort of Sovereignty as that Parliament did only a co-ordinate power, yet they would a≈ø≈øume the power of Vi≈øiting the Univer≈øities as a Prerogative annexed and in≈øeparable from the Sovereignty, and it being ≈øo largely Treated of by Mr. Wood I ≈øhall not In≈øi≈øt upon it, nor of that which followed,Antiq. Oxon. lib. 1. a. fol. 369. ad fol. 414.
Anno 1660. upon the Re≈øtauration of King Charles the 2d. which was mo≈øt nece≈ø≈øary for the Re≈øtoring of tho≈øe who had been Ejected by the long Parliament, and the purging out of the Univer≈øity the per≈øons who had been Active in the time of U≈øurpation, and were not like to comply with the Monarchy and the Church of England then re≈øtored.

div.head: ¬ß. 14. The Form of a Commi≈ø≈øion to the Bi≈øhop of London to Vi≈øit the Chappel of All-Saints, &c. in Minories London.
div.p:
I ≈øhall annex to the≈øe an extract of the material parts of a Commi≈ø≈øion granted to Humfrey Bi≈øhop of London, to Vi≈øit the Chappel of All-Saints, and the Individed Trinity, in the Minories in the City of London. ‚Äî The words are, In omnibus & ≈øingulis Criminibus & delictis Ibidem, & infra praecinctum, ≈øive Juri≈ødictionem dictae Capellae, per Vi≈øitationem Corrigibilibus, & ad punitionem & Correctionem eorundem, & per≈øonarum delinquentium, quae & qualiacunque fuerint juxta eorum demerita: Sive per amotionem, Deprivationem, Su≈øpen≈øionem, Excommunicationem, vel aliam Correctionem debitam prout vobis videtur congruum, & juri & aequitati con≈øentaneum, & juxta ≈øanam Di≈øcretionem ve≈øtram procedendo: nec non ad quaecunque Juramenta licita, & in Vi≈øitationibus prae≈øtari con≈øueta Mini≈øtranda; & in omnibus & ≈øingulis ≈øummarie, & de plano, &
≈øine ≈øtrepitu, & Figur√¢ Judicii, ≈øol√¢ rei veritate in≈øpect√¢ procedendo, & generaliter omnia & ≈øingula alia facienda, exercenda, & expedienda quae ad Officium Vi≈øitatoris in praemi≈ø≈øis,Here the Kings full and ab≈øolute power is declared. aut circa ea nece≈ø≈øaria fuerint, ≈øeu quomodolibet opportuna. Vobis praefato Do. Epi≈øcopo plenam & ab≈øolutam damus, & concedimus per prae≈øentes prote≈øtatem, vice≈øque no≈øtras Committimus; cum cuju≈ølibet corecionis Legitima pote≈øtate, Dated Junii 2d. Anno 1671.

‚òû From this we may ob≈øerve,Inferences from the Record. that the King Impowers a Bi≈øhop to Vi≈øit, even in his own Dioce≈øs, a place Exempt from ordinary Juri≈ødiction as this Chappel claims to be by former Grants from the Pope; ≈øo that this is a pregnant in≈øtance, that the Supreme Sovereign power is to be re≈øtrained by no Exemption, pre≈øcription or other claims.

To draw this matter to a Conclu≈øion;The Conclu≈øion of this Section. I ≈øhall In≈øert the Opinion of an Eminent Lawyer concerning the Kings power over Corporations in general, and ≈øo over the Univer≈øities and private Colleges. The per≈øon is of the long Robe, and eminent in his Character, who tho' he de≈øires not to have his Name made u≈øe of, yet hath been plea≈øed to give me his Judgment in Writing as followeth.

p.q:
The Body Natural is Created by God. Bodies Politic are Created by the King, and as they are Created and receive their Being, Life, and Strength from the King; ≈øo they are Governed by him, and by him are corrected and puni≈øhed for their Irregularities or mi≈ø-behaviors, either by ≈øeizure of their Liberties for a time: Or upon le≈øs occa≈øions than commonly are imagined for their Omi≈ø≈øions or Commi≈ø≈øions, they may be Annihilated and di≈øolved at his Maje≈øties Suit in a Quo
Warranto; as lately was done in the Ca≈øe of the City of London, which was not only the greate≈øt, and perhaps the Anciente≈øt Corporation in the Kingdom; but was fortified al≈øo by many Acts of Parliament, and Ancient pre≈øcription and cu≈øtom, and yet not all ≈øufficient to defend them again≈øt the King, tho' the Offences for which they were di≈ø≈øolved, were not of the greate≈øt Magnitude.

There is no Corporation what≈øoever, Lay or Spiritual, ≈øaith the ≈øame Judici√≤us per≈øon, but is lyable to a Quo Warranto. Therefore the King was merciful to Magdalen College, that he did not proceed again≈øt them by that Method.

There are no Corporations, which are the Kings Creatures, but have ≈øinned again≈øt him to their own de≈øtruction, if they ≈øhould narrowly be looked into; as there are no Men but have ≈øinned again≈øt God: and if the King had not power, upon ju≈øt provocation, to di≈ø≈øolve them, every Corporation would be in the nature of an Independent Common-wealth.

The King is Supreme Ordinary, Vi≈øitor, Almoner and Regulator of all Charities; Therefore every day in Chancery he doth by his Chancellor in the Name of his Atturny General Regulate, Correct, and ≈øettle Charities, and when any per≈øon, of Charitable Intention, is mi≈øtaken in the end, or object of his Charity, the mi≈øtake in Chancery is frequently corrected, and that which the Donor intended one way is there applyed or di≈øpo≈øed another way, and to another per≈øon, of which there are frequent In≈øtances.

div.p:
Not doubting but all this is according to Law; how can it be thought, that the King hath not the
≈øame power over Univer≈øities and Colleges, only in other Corporations the Tryal is before the Judges of the Kings Bench, who are his Mini≈øterial Officers; and in Univer≈øities and Colleges it is done by the Kings Mandate, or his Commi≈ø≈øioners, which are but various methods of exerting the Kings power? and I think the Judgment of another great Lawyer, will be granted, that where Statutes are made upon branches of the Kings Prerogative, they are remedial and take not away the Kings concurrent power, as may be ≈øeen in Colt and Glovers Ca≈øe in my Lord Hoberts Reports, fol. 146.

div.head: ¬ß. 15. The opinions of ≈øeveral Judges in this matter.
div.p: Having met with ≈øome particulars in Judge Keebles Reports, in Dr. Patricks Ca≈øe after my Intention to clo≈øe this Section, I could not omit the giving a ≈øhort account of ≈øuch material parts as may ≈øatisfie the Curious Reader, that what I have delivered on this head is according to Law.

‚òû Fir≈øt, ThereKeebles Reports 2d. part, King and Bryan again≈øt Patrick, Trin. 18 Car. 2. fol. 65. and 66. it is a≈ø≈øerted, that the King without the Ordinary may properly Erect an Univer≈øity, and give them power to ≈øend Burge≈ø≈øes to Parliament.

Secondly, That the King by Patent may appoint Vi≈øitors, and the giving this power to the King is Cumlative not Privative, as appears 2 H. 7.6. B. 5 Coke 5 B. and it leaves a concurrent Juri≈ødiction, as is clear in F. N. B. 21 C. and 51 B. and 80. which is ≈øufficient to An≈øwer the Objection of the Fellows of St. Mary Magdalen College, that the Bi≈øhop of Winton being their Local Vi≈øitor, if he were ≈øatisfied to confirm the Election, they could not be adjudged faulty, by any other Vi≈øitors, Here cap. 7. & ≈øect. 3. of which point I ≈øhall have occa≈øion to Treat hereafter.

‚òû But to proceed,Idem. Patricks Ca≈øe Hill. 18 & 19 Car. 2. Keebles Reports fol. 164. 2d. part. Thirdly, By 10 H. 7.18. and the Bi≈øhop of Winche≈øters Ca≈øe, the King may exempt any Eccle≈øia≈øtical Corporation from Ordinary Vi≈øitation, and con≈øequently hath the power in him≈øelf.

‚òû Fourthly, If there be noIdem fol. 166. Vi≈øitor properly appointed by the Founder, the Chancellor and Vice-Chancellor have the Government of any College, who are the proper Officers of that di≈øtinct Common-wealth of Learning, and they are E≈øtabli≈øhed or fortified in that by the Kings Letters Patents.

Fifthly, Altho' King James the Fir≈øt,Id. fol. 168. 3 Regni gave the Chancellor of Cambridge power of Vi≈øiting. Queens College there, yet the King remains Vi≈øitor as Heir to King H. 6. Husband to Queen Margaret that Founded it, as the Judge there A≈ø≈øerts; but if it had been a private Founder, the King ≈øhall not lo≈øe the Right of Vi≈øitor as Sovereign, ≈øince the Licence for the Foundation is from the King of what private Foundation ≈øoever; ≈øo if there were no Vi≈øitor appointed by the Charter of a Founder, the Chancellor is Vi≈øitor, and Superior to him is the King.

Sixthly, In the ≈øame Ca≈øe it is laid downIdem fo. 169. Statutum de as Argument, that there is a Vi≈øitor Temporal as the Founder, and Eccle≈øia≈øtical to examin, correct and amend things done contrary to the Rules of their Order, which were declared by the Canons of the Church, whereof the Bi≈øhops were the Natural Vi≈øitors, and it is plain thatA≈øportatis Religio≈øorum 35 E. 1. Anno 1307. cap. 2. no Abbot, Prior, Ma≈øter, Warden, or any other Religious per≈øon of what≈øoever condition State or Religion he was, being under the Kings power or Juri≈ødiction, ≈øhould depart into any other Country for Vi≈øitation, or upon any other color, by that means to carry the Goods of their Mona≈øteries
or Hou≈øes out of the Kingdom. It is al≈øo in the Argument laid down as the Rea≈øon why the claim was made in the time of King Richard 2d. and the Act 13 H. 4. for the Arch-Bi≈øhop of Canterburies Vi≈øitation of the Univer≈øity of Oxford, that it was only about matters of Faith by Rea≈øon of Here≈øie and Lollardi≈øm. But in matters of breach of Statutes, &c. the Founder or Vi≈øitor Communi Jure had the right; and tho' the King granted the power which the Founder had, yet he never intended to grant away his own Supreme Authority thereby, or could grant the Right of his Succe≈ø≈øors.

‚òû The≈øe matters I have noted in this Ca≈øe, that the Ingenuous Reader may know, that what I have di≈øcour≈øed of in this Section is agreeable to the ≈øentiments of the Reverend Judges an expre≈ø≈øion of Judge Windham. Patricks Ca≈øe fol. 166. ut ≈øupra. one of whom I find in the≈øe words, Both Juri≈ødictions, Lay and Spiritual, are derived from the King, as the Sun and Moon take light of God. I lay no ≈øtre≈øs upon any Analogy of the compari≈øon further than that it thereby appears how fundamental a matter it is in our Laws, that all exerci≈øe of Authority, Di≈øcipline, Government, and external Oeconomy in Church and State are derived from the King, as having a Creative and annihilating power in ≈øeveral things that depend ≈øolely upon his good plea≈øure, which if any thing do in his whole Dominions it is in the di≈øpo≈øal of matters of the Univer≈øities, as I now ≈øhall make more evident in the following Chapter.

div.head: CHAP. VI.

argument.p: Concerning the Kings of Englands di≈øpen≈øing with the Statutes of the Univer≈øities by their Mandates.

div.head: SECT. I.

argument.p: Concerning the Kings di≈øpen≈øing Power in General, and in ≈øeveral particulars to the beginning of King Charles the Seconds Reign.

div.head: ¬ß. 1. Concerning the Kings di≈øpen≈øing power in General.
div.p: HAving given a large account of the Kings power in Vi≈øiting the Univer≈øities, and in Abrogating old and making new Statutes by his ab≈øolute and Supreme Authority: To clear the point yet more, I ≈øhall ≈øhew, by particular In≈øtances, wherein our Kings have di≈øpen≈øed with the Statutes of the Univer≈øities, or particular Colleges: For there can be no greater Argument of the Right and Prerogative of any power than the un-interrupted excerci≈øe and u≈øage of the ≈øame.

Before I de≈øcend to particulars, it may be expected that I ≈øhould di≈øcour≈øe ≈øomething of the Kings di≈øpen≈øing power in General; but the point being determined by the Judges, and the Arguments for it being ≈øo generally known, I ≈øhall be the ≈øhorter upon this head.

‚òû This power of di≈øpen≈øing ≈øeems to be a mo≈øt nece≈ø≈øary Prerogative, that no Sovereign, whether Eccle≈øia≈øtical or Civil can want: whence we find in aOmnibus autem √† nobis dictis Imperatoris excipiatur fortuna: Cui & ip≈øas Deus Leges ≈øubjecit, Legem animatam committens hominibus. Novel. 105. circa finem. Con≈øtitution of Ju≈øtinian de Con≈øulibus a re≈øervation
of that power which he thus expre≈ø≈øeth from all the≈øe things which have been ≈øaid by us, Let the Emperors State be excepted, whereunto God hath ≈øubjected the very Laws them≈øelves, ≈øending him as a living Law to Men as it is Tran≈ølated from the Greek.

Agreeable to which is what Aeneas Sylvius Convenit Imperatori Juris Rigorem Aequitatis fraeno Temperari cui ≈øoli Inter aequitatem ju≈øque interpo≈øitam interpretationem licet & incumbit In≈øpicere. de Ortu & Authoribus Imperii. ob≈øerves, that it is the part of the Emperor or Sovereign to attemper the Rigor of Law with the Bridle of Equity, to whom alone it is lawful, and a duty, to ≈øee to the Interpretation which lyeth Inter≈øper≈øed betwixt Law and Equity; ≈øince no Law can ≈øufficiently An≈øwer the varieties and un-thought on plottings of Mans nature, and in Tract of time, Laws at fir≈øt ju≈øt and equitable, become unprofitable and har≈øh, and this moderating of Laws, ≈øaith he, is ≈øo annexed to the Prince, that by no Decree of Man it can be taken from him.

This is al≈øo agreeable to the Opinion of the mo≈øt Learned Primate U≈øhers power of Princes pag. 76. of Ireland, who≈øe Judgment mo≈øt of our Judicious Prote≈øtant Divines have ever held in high e≈øteem. His words are ‚Äî po≈øitive Laws, as other works of Men, are imperfect, and not free from di≈ø-commodities, if the ≈øtrict ob≈øervation of them ≈øhould be pur≈øued in every particular: Therefore he ≈øaith, it is fit that the Supreme Governor, ≈øhould not him≈øelf only be exempted from ≈øubjection thereunto, but al≈øo be ≈øo far Lord over them, that when he ≈øeeth cau≈øe he may abate, or totally remit the Penalty Incurred by the breach of them, and di≈øpen≈øe with others for not ob≈øerving of them at all, yea generally Su≈øpend the Execution of them, &c.

div.head: ¬ß. 2. Why the Author Treats not largely on this ≈øubject.
div.p:
But I fore≈øee it will be alleged that what is urged thus in General and in Theory, is to be applyed to the
„Äà1 page duplicate„Äâ
„Äà1 page duplicate„Äâ
Con≈øtitution of the Government of England, otherwi≈øe it reacheth not the point in Que≈øtion concerning the Kings power of di≈øpen≈øing with College Statutes.

To which I An≈øwer fir≈øt, That the Kings power in di≈øpen≈øing with Penal Laws in General having by Solemn Judgment in the Kings Bench been determined, and ≈øeveral Treati≈øes publi≈øhed to clear the point of Law, and there being ≈øo lately aJus Coronae. Treati≈øe Writ by a Judicious per≈øon, wherein the Kings power in that matter is Learnedly di≈øcu≈ø≈øed, I may be excu≈øed from treating more particularly of that.

div.head: ¬ß 3. Ob≈øervations on the 25 H. 8. C. 21.
div.p: I ≈øhall therefore only note a few ob≈øervables from the Statute of the 25 of King H. 8. Chapter the 21. Entituled in Kebles Edition 1684. An Act concerning Peter-pence and Di≈øpen≈øations, but Originally Entituled otherwi≈øe, as may be ≈øeen in the 1 & 2 Phil. & M. c. 8. ≈øect. 10. Act of Repeal in Queen Maries time, and the 1 Eliz. c. 1. ≈øect. 8. Act of re≈øtoring it in Queen Elizabeths time, to which I ≈øhall add the explication of another Act 8 Eliz. Cap. 1. and ≈øome few other remarks upon that Head.

The Foundation of this Act is grounded upon an Hypothe≈øis,The Statute 25 H. 8. c. 21. is founded upon the u≈øage of a di≈øpen≈øing power. that a di≈øpen≈øing power is needful in Government, and altho' it be the con≈øtant Opinion and Judgment of the Courts of Law, and all Lawyers, that the principal intendment of that Act was to Aboli≈øh the Popes power and Authority in England, in granting Licences, Di≈øpen≈øations, Faculties, &c. Yet from this Act many particulars may be ob≈øerved,I mu≈øt refer the Reader to the Act it ≈øelf. which will ≈øhew, not only the allowed u≈øage of a di≈øpen≈øing power by the Popes and Prelates in matters of Eccle≈øia≈øtical Cognizance by ≈øufferance, as the Act Styles it of our Kings, but that the Original Right of ≈øuch di≈øpen≈øations was in the King and ≈øo continues.

It is then Fir≈øt to be noted from the Act,The Pope excerci≈øed a di≈øpen≈øing power. that the Pope claimed by U≈øurpation, as it is there Styled, and per≈øuaded the Subjects that he had a power to di≈øpen≈øe with all Human Laws, yea, and Cu≈øtoms of all Realms in all Cau≈øes which he called Spiritual. But the ≈øame Act ≈øaith, that ≈øuch claim of the Pope was in Derogation of the Kings Imperial Crown and Authority Royal, contrary to Right and Rea≈øon.The power excerci≈øed by the ≈øufferance of the King and in derogation of the Royal Authority. Therefore in the clo≈øe of this Section it is added ‚Äî that becau≈øe it is now in the≈øe days pre≈øent ≈øeen, that the State, Dignity, Superiority, Reputation, and Authority of the ≈øaid Imperial Crown of this Realm, by the long ≈øufferance of the ≈øaid unrea≈øonable, and un-charitable u≈øurpations and exactions, practi≈øed in the times of the Kings mo≈øt Noble Progenitors is much and ≈øore decayed, and dimini≈øhed, &c. Therefore remedy is provided, &c.

From hence I think with ≈øubmi≈ø≈øion,Nota. it mu≈øt be owned, that if the Pope u≈øurped this power, in derogation of the Authority Royal, then that power mu≈øt be owned to be originally in the King, otherwi≈øe in the Con≈øtruction of the Act it could be no U≈øurpation.

div.head: ¬ß. 4. The Eccle≈øia≈øtical power originally in the King according to this Act.
div.p:
‚òû Be≈øides, it's the general Opinion of the greate≈øt Lawyers of England, that according to the Con≈øtitution of our Laws, all Eccle≈øia≈øtical power and Authority in England is Originally in the King, & ≈øo derived from him, or if otherwi≈øe it is adjudged U≈øurpation, and encroachment. It being an undeniable Maxim, That no per≈øon hath power or Juri≈ødiction in England but the King, or what is derived from him, and this power of the King cannot be di≈øpo≈øed away, nor aboli≈øhed, but by expre≈øs words in an Act of Parliament. Yea, ≈øo Sacred are the Prerogatives of the Crown, that
tho' in ≈øome Ca≈øes the Kings of England have by Act of Parliament departed with their Prerogatives,So the Statutes of the 23 H. 6. about Sheriffs and 31 H. 6. about Ju≈øtices of A≈ø≈øize are frequently di≈øpen≈øed with, Coke 12 Rep. 14. Hoberts Reports, Colt and Glovers Ca≈øe, p. 146. and yielded not to di≈øpen≈øe with the contrary by a non-ob≈øtante; yet ≈øuch Acts have been judged void.

So my Lord Hobert upon this very Statute ≈øaith, that he holds it clear, that tho' this Statute ≈øays, that all Di≈øpen≈øations, &c. ≈øhall be granted in manner, and form following, and not otherwi≈øe, yet the King is not thereby re≈øtrained,The Kings prerogative not re≈øtrained by Acts of Parliament on ≈øeveral Ca≈øes. but his power remains full and perfect as before, and he may ≈øtill grant them as King; for all Acts of Ju≈øtice, and Grace, flow from him, as 4 Eliz. Dyer 211. The Commi≈ø≈øion of Tryal of Pyracy, upon the Statute of 28 H. 8. cap. 53. is good, tho' the Chancellor do not nominate the Commi≈ø≈øioners as that Statute appoints, yet it is a new Law; and Mich. 5. and 6 Eliz. Dyer 225. the Queen made Sheriffs without the Judges, notwith≈øtanding the Statute of 9 E. 2. and Mich. 13. and 14 Eliz. Dyer 303. The Office of Aulnage granted by the Queen without the Bill of the Trea≈øurer, is good with a non-ob≈øtante again≈øt the Statute 31 H. 6. cap. 5. For the≈øe Statutes and the like, ≈øaith the Reverend Judge, were made to put things in Ordinary Form, and to ea≈øe that Sovereign of Labor, but not to deprive him of Power.

He further adds, that notwith≈øtanding the excerci≈øe of the Popes Authority, yet the Crown always kept a Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of it's Natural power of Di≈øpen≈øations in Spiratualibus, as 11 H. 4. ≈øo to retain Benefices with Bi≈øhoprics, and 11 H. 7. to have double Benefices.

I might add to the≈øe to Re≈øervation in the Statute 2 R. 1 Hen. 4. cap. 6. 2. c. 4. ≈øaving to the King his Regality to be found in the Parliament Roll in the Kings Confirmation of Liberties, which Sir Ed. Coke 4. In≈øtit. 51.
complain of for being un-printed, as al≈øo of King Henry the 4th. that he will by the A≈ø≈øent of the Lords Spiritual and Temporal afore≈øaid, and at the reque≈øt of the ≈øaid Commons be Coun≈øelled by the Wi≈øe Men of his Council, in things touching the E≈øtate of him and of his Realm, ≈øaving always his liberty, that is, his Prerogative, for that is properly the King Liberty.

div.head: ¬ß. 5. Where to find Arguments for the di≈øpen≈øing power
div.p: I ≈øhall not trouble the Reader with the many Authorities might be brought to prove this more particularly, pa. 129. to 137. here. the curious may find ≈øeveral Collected by the Author of the Church of England's Behavior under a Roman Catholic King; to which may be added the Act declaring the making and Con≈øecrating of the Arch-Bi≈øhops and Bi≈øhops of this Realm to be good, lawful, and perfect. The ground of which Statute was ≈øome Mens que≈øtioning whether the ≈øame were duly and orderly done according to Law or not. The Act lays this for a Foundation,Some Paragraphs in the Act 8 Eliz. c. 1. explained 26 H. 8.1. That King Henry the 8th. was ju≈øtly and rightly re-cognized and acknowledged to have the Supreme Power, Juri≈ødiction, Order, Rule, and Authority over all the E≈øtate Eccle≈øia≈øtical of the Realm; and after Recites how the Kings and Queens of this Realm, had full power, and Authority by Letters Patents, &c. from time to time to A≈ø≈øign, Name and Authorize ≈øuch per≈øon, or per≈øons as they ≈øhall think meet, and convenient to excerci≈øe, u≈øe, occupy, and execute, &c. all manner of Juri≈ødictions, Privileges, Preheminences and Authorities, in any wi≈øe touching, or concerning Spiritual or Eccle≈øia≈øtical power, or Juri≈ødiction within this Realm, &c.

Then follows, That the Queen being lawfully Inve≈øted in the Imperial Crown of this Realm, &c. and
having in her Maje≈øties Order and di≈øpo≈øition all the ≈øaid Juri≈ødictions, Powers and Authorities over the State Eccle≈øia≈øtical and Temporal,The Queens power in matters Eccle≈øia≈øtical, Supreme and ab≈øolute. &c. hath by her Supreme Authority at divers times ≈øithence the beginning of her Reign, caus'd divers and ≈øundry grave and well Learned Men to be duly Elected, Made and Con≈øecrated Arch-Bi≈øhops and Bi≈øhops, &c. and after Fellows, which is to be noted, that in her Letters Patents for the ≈øame, ≈øhe hath not only u≈øed ≈øuch words, and Sentences, as were accu≈øtomed to be u≈øed by King Henry the 8th. and King Edw. the 6th. in their Letters Patents made for ≈øuch Cau≈øes, but al≈øo hath u≈øed and put into her Letters Patents divers other general words and Sentences; whereby her Highne≈øs, by her Supreme Power and Authority, hath di≈øpen≈øed with all Cau≈øes or doubts of any Imperfection or di≈ø-ability that can or may in any wi≈øe be objected again≈øt the ≈øame, &c. ≈øo that to all tho≈øe that will well con≈øider of the effect and true intent of the ≈øaid Laws and Statutes, and the Supreme and ab≈øolute Authority of the Queens Highne≈øs, and which ≈øhe by her Maje≈øties ≈øaid Letters Patents hath u≈øed, and put in Ure, &c. it is and may be very evident, and apparent that no cau≈øe of ≈øimple ambiguity or doubt, can or may ju≈øtly be objected.

From hence it is ea≈øie to infer,Con≈øiderable Inferences re≈øulting from this Statute. that there is in the Crown ≈øuch a Supreme and ab≈øolute power in Eccle≈øia≈øtical matters, as the King may di≈øpen≈øe with Acts of Parliament, even in ≈øuch a concern as Con≈øecration, Confirmation or Inve≈øting of any per≈øon, &c. Elected to the Office or Dignity of any Arch-Bi≈øhop or Bi≈øhop within this Realm; for if there had been no variation by the Queens Letters Patents from the Form and Methods in the Acts of King25 H. 8. c. 20.5 & 6 E. 6. c. 16. ≈øect. 3. u. 4. Hen. the 8th.
or Edw. the 6th. or that of Queen Elizabeth 1o. Cap. 2. there had been no need of In≈øerting general words or di≈øpen≈øations in the Queens Letters Patents.This Note An≈øwers all that can be alleged concerning Mr. Farmers Incapacity. Hence may be noted, if the Queen could by her Supreme power and Authority, thus di≈øpen≈øe with di≈ø-ability in Bi≈øhops, much more may the King with di≈ø-abilities occa≈øioned by College Statutes, which at plea≈øure he can alter and aboli≈øh.

But to return to the 25th. of H. 8.Ob≈øervations upon this Statute by Judge Hoberts Reports, fol. 156. The power granted to the Arch-Bi≈øhop by the Act, is in Ordinary matters ≈øuch as u≈øually the Pope or Prelates of the Realm di≈øpen≈øed with; and in un-wonted Ca≈øes al≈øo, which it ≈øeems by the Letter of the Act, to be of va≈øt extent, ≈øo that my Lord Hobert ≈øaith, that tho' it ≈øeems to give power over all Di≈øpen≈øations granted from Rome, wonted and un-wonted, and all di≈øpen≈øations generally: Yet it mu≈øt have con≈øtruction, ≈øuch as were allowable and allowed by the Laws and Practice of this Realm; for el≈øe it ≈øhould make our Yoke heavier than before. Yet I cannot conceive but the power may be extended further than the ordinary power the Popes or Prelates practi≈øed,See the Statute ≈øect. 17.18. where greater power ≈øeems to be implyed, worthy con≈øideration. otherwi≈øe there needed not to have been ≈øuch provi≈øion made, that in un-wonted Ca≈øes, the King or Council ≈øhould allow them; and if the Arch-Bi≈øhop refu≈øed, the King might appoint two Prelates or other per≈øons to grant them; and it is probable, that this Act may be con≈øtrued to other purpo≈øes than a Faculty-Office only.

div.head: ¬ß. 6. Some further ob≈øervations upon the Statute 25 H. 8. c. 21.
div.p: But I ≈øhall conclude this matter with the following Ob≈øervations upon this Statute, which I take to be clear and undeniable.

Fir≈øt, That the Pope did here, by his Bulls and Breves grant Di≈øpen≈øations in various Ca≈øes, Erected,
Con≈øtituted and Vi≈øited Colleges, and Abrogated their Statutes, as I have cleared in the foregoing Chapter.
Secondly, That by this Act the Popes General or Univer≈øal power and Authority in England in all Ca≈øes was Totally aboli≈øhed and taken away from him, as to the excerci≈øe of it.

Thirdly, That ≈øome part only of that general power and Authority, which was excerci≈øed by the Pope, was by that Act Ve≈øted, Lodged, and Delegated in and to the Arch-Bi≈øhop, as the di≈øpen≈øing power for Marriages, Ba≈øtardy, &c. and other matters there expre≈ø≈øed, which was properly to be called the Popes ordinary power; and was ≈øo lodged, and delegated in the Arch-Bi≈øhop, to ≈øave the King from trouble in ≈øuch ordinary and common Ca≈øes, but not to take away the Kings ordinary power & Supremacy.

Fourthly, That the Popes extraordinary power, which he exerci≈øed in England, is as well aboli≈øhed here, by this and other Acts, as his ordinary power: But ≈øo much of the Popes Authority and power, either ordinary or extraordinary, as was at any time excerci≈øed by him here in England, and which is not by the ≈øaid Statute Ve≈øted, and Delegated in the Arch-Bi≈øhop, is by a nece≈ø≈øary Con≈øtruction revived and reve≈øted in the King, and re-united to the Crown, by all tho≈øe Acts which declare the KingsSee. Stat. 24 H. 8. cap. 12.25 H. 8. c. 20. & 21.26 H. 8. c. 1. c. 3. c. 13.31 H. 8. cap. 9.37 H. 8. c. 17.1 Eliz. c. 1. c. 4.8. Eliz. c. 1. Supremacy; yea tho' the Statutes had been ≈øilent therein, for that the Crown by this and other Acts, is entirely remitted and re≈øtored to all it's Ancient Juri≈ødictions and Prerogatives exerci≈øed by the Popes, from whence our Law Books ≈øay, it was Robbed or derived. Becau≈øe ≈øuch powers being taken away from the Pope, and ≈øuch as had Authority under him, and neither ≈øettled in any Court or per≈øon by the Statute, can re-ve≈øt or
re-≈øult to none other but the King as Supreme in all Eccle≈øia≈øtical, as well as Temporal Cau≈øes, which by Sufferance or U≈øurpation, as the Act ≈øaith, the Pope had excerci≈øed.

Fifthly, By the ≈øeveral Acts and In≈øtances, whereby the Kings of England ≈øince the making of this Act of the 25th. King Henry the 8th. have exerted their Supreme Authority, it is clear that the Crowns Re-a≈ø≈øumption of what the Pope had exerci≈øed, hath been according to the Laws in being; of which I now proceed to give In≈øtances in the Kings di≈øpen≈øing with College Statutes, of which I ≈øhall give ≈øome few, in ≈øeveral Ca≈øes, of many hundreds which are to be found in the Paper Office, or Secretaries Books.

div.head: ¬ß. 7. An account of the Queens Mandate about Electing of a Ma≈øter of St. Johns College in Cambridge
div.p: The fir≈øt In≈øtance I think fit to In≈øert, is as followeth.
The Cour≈øe that was held in the la≈øt Election of the Ma≈øter≈øhip of St. Johns College in Cambridge.

p.q: Fir≈øt, Bundel Eccle≈øia≈øtic, Univer≈øities Paper-Office. The Statute of that College appointeth the Twelfth day after the Vacation to be the day of their Election, and no other.
Secondly, The greater part of the Fellows of the College were made for Mr. Alvey, a Senior Fellow.
Thirdly, The Lord Trea≈øurer being Informed that Alvey was an unfit Man, ≈øet down an Inhibition in the Queens Name to defer the Election, which Inhibition was obeyed.

Fourthly, The 12th. day being pa≈ø≈øed, and no further power left to the Fellows to Elect, The Lord Trea≈øurer ≈øent a Letter the ≈øecond time in the Queens Name, Nominating Dr. Clayton and Dr. Stainton, Commanding the Fellows to choo≈øe one of them, and no other.
Fifthly, By Authority of tho≈øe Letters they choo≈øe Dr. Clayton.

div.p: By this proceeding it is manife≈øt, that the King may not only by a Mandate of Inhibition ≈øtay the Electors from making any choice, but nominate the per≈øon to be Elected, altho' by College Statutes the day of the Election and the Electors were appointed.

div.head: ¬ß. 8. The Bi≈øhop of Londons Te≈øtimony, that the King hath di≈øpen≈øed with College Statutes.
div.p: Before I enter upon the particular Mandates, I ≈øhall produce the Te≈øtimony of George Montague Bi≈øhop of London, in his Letter, a Copy of which the Honorable Sir Jo≈øeph William≈øon afforded me out of the Paper-Office, directed to Sir Edward Conway Principal Secretary of State, as followeth.

body.p: THe Noble, and Vertuous Lady, the Lady Denbigh hath layed a Command upon me, to deliver my knowledge, whether the King hath at any time by his Letters, di≈øpen≈øed with the Local Statutes of any College by a Non-ob≈øtante; and upon a ≈øearch it appears, that his Maje≈øty hath ≈øent Letters of that nature to divers Colleges. If this Information may promote her de≈øires, and give you ≈øatisfaction, I ≈øhall be right glad, and will ever remain

closer.signed: Your Honors Friend to Command, and humble Servant. Geo. London.

div.head: ¬ß. 9. A Mandate di≈øpen≈øing with Incapacities to receive Degrees.
div.p: I now proceed to give ≈øome Extracts of Mandates, wherein the King di≈øpen≈øeth with College Statutes, in one of which Dated December the 11th. Anno 1624. the per≈øons within named being ≈øome ways Incapacitated to take their re≈øpective Degrees, were di≈øpen≈øed with as followeth.

p.q: Tru≈øty and Well-beloved We Great you well.In a Bundel Docketed, Eccle≈øia≈øtic. Univer≈øities, in the Paper-Office at Whitehall. We are Graciou≈øly plea≈øe of Our Royal Favor to Gabriel More, Harrington Butler, George Bur≈øey, and Michael Gilbert, to advance them to ≈øuch Degrees as they are capable of, and well de≈øerve by their Learning and diligent Studies, tho' in ≈øome re≈øpects not qualified. Therefore Our plea≈øure is, that notwith≈øtanding any Statute or other Ordinance to the contrary, you forthwith Create Gabriel More a Dr. in Divinity, and you al≈øo admit Harrington Butler and George Bur≈øey to the Degree of Ma≈øter of Arts, and Michael Gibert Bachellor of Arts, in ≈øuch Form as is u≈øual in like Ca≈øe, and the≈øe Letters ≈øhall be your Warrant.

div.p: In a Mandate for one William Morley to be a Schollar of the College of St.A Mandate for a Schollar of St. Mary Winton College, without examination. Mary of Winton College Oxon without Examination, are the≈øe words‚Äîand tho' we have a favorable Eye to your freedom that are the Electors, yet in this Our ≈øo Extraordinary Recommendation, We expect your Dutiful re≈øpects to this Our Princely Plea≈øure and Command, ≈øo that this Our Will be not di≈ø-appointed for any re≈øpet what≈øoever.

Directed to Our Tru≈øty and Well-belove Dr. Princock, Warden of St. Mary Winton College in Our Univer≈øity of Oxford, and Our Tru≈øty and Well-beloved Dr. Love, Warden of St. Mary Winton College near Winche≈øter, the under Warden, School-Ma≈øter of the College, and two Po≈øers of the Schollars for the Election.

In a Mandate Dated 3o. Regni Caroli 1.A Mandate di≈øpen≈øing with the Incapacity by rea≈øon of the County. For one Gregory I≈øham, I find the≈øe words ‚ÄîBut becau≈øe We under≈øtand that the Country where he was Born layeth ≈øome formal Incapacity upon him, We are plea≈øed hereby to Di≈øpen≈øe therewith, and do
require that his Country may not be any Impediment to him in that Election,Ibid. notwith≈øtanding any Statute or Order to the contrary: And the≈øe Our Letters ≈øhall be ≈øufficient Warrant in that behalf.

div.head: ¬ß. 10. The acknowlegement from St. Johns College in Cambridge of the Kings power in di≈øpen≈øing with College Statutes.
div.p: March the 28th. Bundel Eccle≈ø. Univer≈øities, 1630. &c. 1633. In a Letter of the Ma≈øter and Fellows of St. Johns College, to the Earl of Holland the Chancellor, about their choo≈øing Dr. Digby according to his Maje≈øties Letters, Dr. Beale being then Ma≈øter, I find they allege, that he was not capable by ≈øome Statutes, having not performed ≈øome things the Statutes required. ‚Äî They write thus ‚ÄîYet his Sacred Maje≈øties Reque≈øt would have been tye enough upon his mo≈øt Dutiful and Obedient Servants, to have endeavored the accompli≈øhment of his Royal de≈øire, had we been enabled thereunto by Di≈øpen≈øation with tho≈øe oppo≈øite Statutes, which otherwi≈øe we ≈øtand obliged by Oath to ob≈øerve: Which plainly ≈øhews, that if a Di≈øpen≈øation had been obtained or in≈øerted in the Mandate, the King had been obeyed.

I find that the Ma≈øter and Fellows of Chri≈øt College in Cambridge, In the Paper Office, Eccle≈øia≈øtica Academica without date. being de≈øirous to Capacitate one Norton, then but Senior Sophi≈øter, for a Fellow≈øhip, ≈øent him with Letters Te≈øtimonial to Oxford, whereupon he obtained his Bachellors Degree, and ≈øo was Elected Fellow.A Senior Sophi≈øter may take Bachellor of Arts Degree by di≈øpen≈øation. The Relation ≈øaith, that the Arch-Bi≈øhop hearing of it, expre≈ø≈øed ≈øome di≈øplea≈øure, and ≈øaid he would call him to an Account for his taking the Oath for Bachellor, having not full time, and being not di≈øpen≈øed with. To which it was An≈øwered, that the Oaths of both Univer≈øities were in effect the ≈øame, yet they Commenced every year, ≈øome at three years ≈øtanding, ≈øome at 3 & a half, yet do not think them≈øelves for-≈øworn, altho' they have no di≈øpen≈øation; becau≈øe they ≈øuppo≈øe the granting of the Grace, do's Include a Tacit di≈øpen≈øation.

By this it is mo≈øt apparent, that not only the Kings di≈øpen≈øation had ab≈øolved from Perjury; but that the Univer≈øity al≈øo by an Act of the Senate may di≈øpen≈øe with a Statute, and tho' it be but a di≈øpen≈øation Implyed, it is valid.

div.head: SECT. II.

argument.p: Concerning Di≈øpen≈øations with the Statutes of the ∆≤niver≈øities, or particular Colleges, from the Year 1670. 22d. of King Charles the Second, to this pre≈øent time.

div.head: ¬ß. 1. A Mandate for a Di≈øpen≈øation for Mr. William Lloid, having the Degree of Dr. of Divinity two years before the time limited by the Statutes of the Univer≈øity, 23. June 1670.
div.p: I Have in this following part culled out of the Books of Mandates for Arch-Bi≈øhoprics, Bi≈øhoprics, Deaneries, Prebends, Rectories, and Ma≈øters or Fellows of Colleges, &c. ≈øome few Pre≈øidents which may ≈øhew the u≈øuage of the latter times, touching the Kings di≈øpen≈øing with College or Univer≈øity Statutes; which I might have begun at the late Kings Re≈øtauration, but that the Books of the then Secretaries of State are mo≈øtly wanting, or they are not dige≈øted into Order in the Paper Office. However tho≈øe few In≈øtances of ≈øeveral kinds may ≈øerve to clear the point beyond di≈øpute.
By this following Mandate will appear the rea≈øon, why the power of Di≈øpen≈øation with Statutes may be nece≈ø≈øary.

The Mandate runs thus.‚Äî William Lloid [of St. Johns College in Cambridge] Ma≈øter of Arts, one of Our Chaplains, wanting two Years of his full ≈øtanding to take the Degree of Doctor of Divinity, being ≈øhortly to return to his Charge to Portugal, where he may probably remain longer than the ≈øaid two Years, and ≈øo be hindred from taking the ≈øaid Degree at his due time, &c. We having the Approbation
and con≈øent of Edward Earl of Manche≈øter Chancellor of that Our Univer≈øity, have thought fit to ≈øignifie Our plea≈øure unto you in his behalf, hereby requiring that you Create and Admit him the ≈øaid William Lloid Doctor in Divinity, at the Commencement next coming, any Statute or Cu≈øtom of our ≈øaid Univer≈øity or direction from Us to the contrary notwith≈øtanding. Dated 23d. of June 1670. Directed to Our Tru≈øty and Well-beloved the Vice-Chancellor of Our Univer≈øity of Cambridge.

div.head: ¬ß. 2. In all the Mandates the expre≈øs words of Di≈øpen≈øation are to be noted.
div.p: In the Book for the Years 1675. and 1676. Sir Jo≈øeph William≈øon, being then one of the Principal Secretaries of State, I find among many other, the≈øe Di≈øpen≈øations with Statutes of Colleges.
July the 15th. 1675. Henry More Doctor of Divinity and Fellow of Chri≈øt College in Cambridge, hath Liberty by Di≈øpen≈øation to be ab≈øent from the College.

December the 20th. 1675. Richard Lake Ma≈øter of Arts of Sidney Su≈ø≈øex College, obtains a Mandate for the fir≈øt Foundation Fellow≈øhip that ≈øhall be Vacant, re≈øerving his Seniority according to his ≈øtanding with this clau≈øe. ‚Äî Any Statute, Cu≈øtom, Order, or Letter from Us to the contrary in any wi≈øe notwith≈øtanding, with which We are Graciou≈øly plea≈øed to Di≈øpen≈øe for this time in his behalf.

December the 29th. 1675. In the Mandate for Thomas Chapman Bachellor of Arts, to have the Degree of Ma≈øter of Arts, the operative words are without any con≈øideration of performing any previous or ≈øub≈øequent Exerci≈øes for the ≈øame; Any Statute, &c. as in the former.

February the 12th. 1675.Mandate for Sir John Otways Son, not capable, either as to the County or his Years. There is a Memorable Di≈øpen≈øation for Charles Otway Son to Sir John Otway in con≈øideration of the Services of the Father, ≈øometimes Fellow of St. John's College. ‚Äî The Expre≈ø≈øions are, That whereas a Fellow≈øhip in St. Johns College in Cambridge, was void by the Death of Robert Clark, which was Founded by the Lady Roke≈øby, and given to the Town of Beverley, and for want of a Scholar there to Our County of York at large, with a Provi≈øo, that they enter into Prie≈øts Orders within ≈øix Months after Admi≈ø≈øion. There being none of that Town Qualified, the ≈øaid Sir John Otway hath be≈øought Us to Grant Our Di≈øpen≈øation in behalf of his Son Charles Otway, who being not Born within the ≈øaid County of York, nor Capable to be Ordained Prie≈øt within the time prefixed by the ≈øaid Statutes after Admi≈ø≈øion, by rea≈øon of his want of Age, without Our Royal Di≈øpen≈øation; We have thought fit, and accordingly do hereby Di≈øpen≈øe with tho≈øe particulars in his favor, ≈øo as to Capacitate the ≈øaid Charles Otway to ≈øtand for and be Elected into the ≈øaid Vacant Fellow≈øhip, notwith≈øtanding his not being Born within the County of York, and not being of Age.

May the 17th. 1675.Mandate for Mr. Jo≈øuah Ratcliff, contrary to the Statutes of the College. I find a Mandate in the≈øe Terms, ‚Äî Whereas Jo≈øuah Ratcliff Senior Bachellor of Arts, and Scholar of Emanuel College in Cambridge, hath by his humble Petition Informed us, that by rea≈øon of a certain Statute which provides, that there ≈øhall not be more than one per≈øon of any particular County of England at one time Fellow of the ≈øaid College, he is render'd uncapable of being Elected into a Fellow≈øhip, tho' in all other re≈øpects he is fitly Qualified for the ≈øame. We have thought
fit to conde≈øcend to his Reque≈øt herein, and do accordingly by the≈øe Our Letters Patents, Di≈øpen≈øe with the forementioned Statute, Granting you full Power and Liberty, that in ca≈øe of Examination you find the ≈øaid Jo≈øuah Ratcliff in all other re≈øpects fully Qualified for Preferment among≈øt you, you may choo≈øe and Admit him into any Vacant Fellow≈øhip. Directed to Our Tru≈øty and Well-beloved Ma≈øter and Fellows of Emanuel College in the the Univer≈øity of Cambridge.

closer.signed: H. COVENTRY.

div.head: ¬ß. 3. Di≈øpen≈øation for Mr. Edward Finch, not being of the County required by the Statutes.
div.p: I ≈øhall now add ≈øome I find in the Books in my Lord Sunderlands Office.

The Mandate for Edward Finch runs thus. ‚Äî Have therefore thought fit to recommend him in very Effectual manner, hereby requiring, that notwith≈øtanding any ob≈øtruction or Impediment that may be in his way by rea≈øon of his County, you Admit him to the fir≈øt Fellow≈øhip that may become Vacant in Chri≈øt College in Cambridge. Dated May the 21≈øt. 1679.

So the Chancellor of Cambridge is Commanded to Confer the Degree of Doctor of Divinity upon Mr. Francis Hawkins, Mandate for Dr. Hawkins not to perform Exerci≈øes. Ma≈øter of Arts, formerly of Peterhou≈øe in Cambridge, by Accumulation, without obliging him to perform the Exerci≈øes requi≈øite thereto or Cautioning or Compounding for the ≈øame, any Statute or Statutes, or Con≈øtitution of that Our Univer≈øity, to the contrary notwith≈øtanding. Dated June the 27th. 1679.

So the Mandate for Mr. Cradock Bachellor of Arts to have the Fellow≈øhip void by the Death of Thomas Cradock his Brother in St. Mary Magdalen College in Oxon runs thus,Di≈øpen≈øing with any Statutes or Con≈øtitutions to the contrary, in St. Mary Magdalen College it ≈øelf. ‚Äî Any Statute, Con≈øtitution or
Order, to the contrary notwith≈øtanding, with which We are pleas'd to Di≈øpen≈øe at this time. Dated July the 19th. 1679.

div.head: ¬ß. 4. A Statute of the Founder di≈øpen≈øed with concerning the Lady Margarets Preachers.
div.p: An Example of a statute of a Founder Abrogated by the King, appears in this following directed to the Chancellor of Cambridge.

Whereas the Lady Margaret late Counte≈øs of Richmond and Derby, in her Foundation for a Preacher in the Univer≈øity of Cambridge, did oblige him to Preach at Twelve or Thirteen ≈øeveral Towns in ≈øeveral Counties, and accordingly did allow him what was in tho≈øe days a Competent ≈øalary, and ≈øufficient for the di≈øcharge of the Expence of his Journey, We under≈øtanding that the ≈øalary for the ≈øaid Preacher is now very ≈ømall and incon≈øiderable. Therefore being di≈øpo≈øed to free the ≈øaid Expen≈øive Duty, have thought fit, and accordingly do hereby Di≈øpen≈øe with all tho≈øe that ≈øhall be her Preachers for the future, for their not Preaching at the places, provided they do all other Exerci≈øes in the Univer≈øity, unto which by the ≈øaid Foundation or Cu≈øtom they are obliged; and Our plea≈øure is,The Kings plea≈øure that the Oath be altered. that you alter the Oath which the ≈øaid Preachers at their Entrance were to take according to the≈øe premi≈øes, and to cau≈øe the≈øe Letters of Di≈øpen≈øation to be Regi≈øtred, &c. Dated October the 30th. 1679.
In another Mandate Directed to the Chancellor of Cambridge I find as followeth.

Tru≈øty,Concerning conferring Honorary Degrees. &c. Whereas We have been given to under≈øtand, that ≈øeveral Di≈øputes have heretofore ri≈øen in that Our Univer≈øity about Conferring Honorary Degrees without time or exerci≈øe upon Baronets and Knights, who were Members of Our ≈øaid Univer≈øity, We have thought fit in order to the ≈øettling of
that matter for the time to come hereby to ≈øignifie to you, that we are Graciou≈øly plea≈øed to allow it, &c. with a Clau≈øe that the Letters be Regi≈øtred. Dated October the 30th. 1679.

div.head: ¬ß. 5. Di≈øpen≈øation with Statutes, that oblige to enter into Deacons Orders, after being two Years Ma≈øter of Arts.
div.p: There being a Statute in Queens College Cambridge, Another of the like nature. That every Fellow after being two Years Ma≈øter of Arts mu≈øt Enter into Deacons Orders, or el≈øe quit his Fellow≈øhip. ‚Äî Mr. Charles Palmer is Di≈øpen≈øed with. Dated November the 18th. 1679.

In another Mandate I find, that John Cudworth B. A. is allowed to Travel for ≈øeven Years, whereas by the Statutes of Chri≈øts College in Cambridge, he is obliged to Enter into Holy Orders before that time is Expired, which he cannot do now in regard of his being under the Age required in ≈øuch Ca≈øes, We do Di≈øpen≈øe with his not Entring into Holy Orders till after his return. Dated December the 31≈øt. 1679.

Mr. John Lytcote is Di≈øpen≈øed with,Another for Mr. Lytcote, now Sir John Lytcote. for not entering into Holy Orders for Four Years, and yet enjoy his Fellow≈øhip, any Statute, &c. notwith≈øtanding. Dated January the 13th. 1679.
But upon the 20th. of December 1680. after reciting the fore≈øaid Mandate it ≈øaith, the King for particular rea≈øons revokes it.

The cau≈øe was, for that John Lytcote now Sir John, Secretary to the Earl of Ca≈øtlemain, and now Re≈øident at Rome, upon his Travels having Di≈øcovered ≈øome of Oates his Pranks, and brought ≈øeveral of St. Omers Youths for Witne≈ø≈øes, the late King was Induced to withdraw his Di≈øpen≈øation, whereby he might be either bound to quit his Fellow≈øhip or to enter into Orders, ≈øo that it was pre≈øumed he would either declare him≈øelf a R. Catholic or quit his Fellow≈øhip.

div.head: ¬ß. 6. The re-inforcing of a Mandate, not pre≈øently obeyed.
div.p: This next is an In≈øtance of a Mandate endeavored to be eluded, which was re-inforced by a ≈øub≈øequent Mandate, directed to the Ma≈øter and Fellows of Trinity College in Cambridge, March the 12th. 1680.

Tru≈øty, &c. Whereas We were Graciou≈øly plea≈øed by Our Letters Mandatory, bearing Date the 8th. of November la≈øt, to require you to Admit John Couper Bachellor of Arts of that our College into the fir≈øt Fellow≈øhip that ≈øhould become void after the Date thereof, and upon ≈øome difficulty made, Our Right Tru≈øty, &c. Cou≈øin, &c. Robert Earl of Sunderland, then Our Principal Secretary of State, did the 29th. of November following, by Our particular Direction, ≈øignifie Our plea≈øure in behalf of the ≈øaid John Couper, that you ≈øhould Immediately choo≈øe him a Fellow according to the Intent of Our ≈øaid Letter, notwith≈øtanding which We are Informed, that you have not yet cho≈øen him, Whereas the Mo≈øt Reverend Father in God William Lord Arch-Bi≈øhop of Canterbury hath Certified, that he is acquainted with the State of this Ca≈øe, and humbly conceives, that he doth de≈øerve ≈øome relief from Our Favor and Goodne≈øs; We have thought fit hereby to require you to Admit him the ≈øaid John Couper into the fir≈øt Fellow≈øhip that is, or ≈øhall become void pur≈øuant to Our ≈øaid Letter, whereby We expect your ready Complyance, as having been induced to it upon particular con≈øiderations, any Statute or Statutes of that Our College, as to the time of Election, or as to the Degree of Ma≈øter of Arts, which he hath taken or ought to take, or any other Statute, Cu≈øtom, or Con≈øtitution to the contrary notwith≈øtanding.

div.head: ¬ß. 7. The Mandate for removing the Duke of Monmouth from being Chancellor of Cambridge, and appointing the Duke of Albemarle Chancellor.
div.p: There is another power in the Crown, which becau≈øe it is conteined in the following Mandate, I ≈øhall Tran≈øcribe at length as I find it directed to the Vice-Chancellor of Cambridge to be Communicated to the Senate.

‚òû Tru≈øty, &c. We Greet you Well. Whereas the Undutiful Behavior of Our Natural Son James Duke of Monmouth, hath given Us great Cau≈øe to Remove him from Our Service, and any further Attendance on Our Per≈øon, whereby he is rendered uncapable of di≈øcharging any longer the Office of Chancellor of that Univer≈øity either to Our ≈øatisfaction or profit, and whereas We are given to under≈øtand, that by the Ancient Statutes thereof the Chancellor was cho≈øen to his Office but for Three Years, and by a late Statute of Queen Elizabeth, The King re≈øerves to him≈øelf the power of Interpreting Statutes of the Univer≈øity. but for Two Years only; and whereas We have ever re≈øerved to Our Self the power of Interpreting the Statutes, referring to the Election of your Chancellor; We think fit to Declare the Chancellors place void, and the Senate thereof to be in full Liberty to proceed to a New Election, and that you may not want a fit Per≈øon to remind Us from time to time of all things that may tend to the Encouragement of good Litterature,The advantages to the Univer≈øity by the Kings Nominating a Chancellor. and all things el≈øe that may maintain that Our Univer≈øity in the ≈øplendor and pro≈øperity it hath ever enjoyed; We have thought fit hereby to require you to proceed to a New Election of a Chancellor, within the time limited by the Statutes, and whereas as well the Integrity and con≈øtant Loyalty of Our Right Tru≈øty and Right Entirely Beloved Cou≈øin and Coun≈øellor Chri≈øtopher Duke of Albemarle, as the remembrance of the Great and Eminent Services performed for Us by the late Duke of Albemarle his Father, hath ju≈øtly
Entitled him to be near Our Per≈øon and render him every way Qualified for the Di≈øcharge of ≈øo high a Tru≈øt, and who≈øe Nomination thereunto will therefore be mo≈øt agreeable unto Us, We further hereby recommend him to your Choice as a Mark of Our Indulgent care of your pro≈øperity. Dated April the 4th. 1682.

‚òû What is here expre≈ø≈øed of the Kings re≈øerving to him≈øelf the Interpretation of the Statutes,The Kings power to Interpret Statutes of the Univer≈øity. referring to the Election of a Chancellor, in altering the number of Years of their Duration, may be under≈øtood of the Prerogative the Kings of England have in all other Statutes of either Univer≈øity and of every College within them.

div.head: ¬ß. 8. The King grants power to the Univer≈øity to confer Degrees upon ≈øuch as the Chancellor or Vice-Chancellor ≈øhall recommend.
div.p: In the following Mandate there being manife≈øt Indicias of the Kings power in ordering the Qualifications of tho≈øe on whom Degrees were to be Conferred, I ≈øhall In≈øert the material parts of it, as it is directed to the Vice-Chancellor of Cambridge to be Communicated to the Senate. Dated June the 8th. 1682.

Tru≈øty, &c. Having taken notice of the ≈øeveral Te≈øtimonies you have lately given of the particular Honor and Affection you have for the Per≈øon of Our Right Tru≈øty, &c. Chri≈øtopher Duke of Albemarle, & being ≈øatisfied of the de≈øire that his late Admi≈ø≈øion to the Office of Our Chancellor, may be attended with more re≈øpect than hath been u≈øually ≈øhewn to other Per≈øons on a like occa≈øion; We do Graciou≈øly accept your Intimation in that part, and are willing to comply with it in what depends on Us, ≈øo as you may not want the ≈øatisfaction of doing all the Honor to his Per≈øon which you may de≈øire, We have therefore thought fit hereby, ≈øufficiently to Authorize and
Enable you to Confer ≈øuch Degrees as the ≈øaid Duke your Chancellor ≈øhall think fit on ≈øuch per≈øons as he ≈øhall recommend to you,This was a di≈øpen≈øation at the reque≈øt of the Univeri≈øity it ≈øelf. and al≈øo to Confer the Degrees of Ma≈øters of Arts on ≈øuch and ≈øo many Per≈øons of Birth and E≈øtate, and none others, as you Our Vice-Chancellor ≈øhall Nominate.

It ≈øeems,A Re-inforcing of a Mandate delayed. that ≈øome of tho≈øe Per≈øons Nominated for Degrees were delayed, which occa≈øioned a Second Mandate the 7th. of Augu≈øt 1682. reciting the ≈øub≈øtance of the former and then proceeding thus, ‚Äî We are well ≈øatisfied, that the Per≈øons by him, viz. the Vice-Chancellor Nominated, were duely Qualified for the ≈øaid Degrees according to the Tenor of Our Letter, but contrary to Our Will and Plea≈øure, were refu≈øed by one or two of the Caput Senatus. The≈øe are therefore to Authorize you Our Vice-Chancellor to Admit the per≈øons formerly by you Nominated to the Degree of Ma≈øter of Arts.

closer.signed: L. JENKINS.

div.head: ¬ß. 9. The Kings Mandate for making new Statutes for Regulating of Degrees.
div.p: In the next Mandate the Kings power in making Statutes for the Regulating of Degrees, is mo≈øt con≈øpicuous.
This is Directed to the Chancellor of the Univer≈øity of Cambridge to be Communicated to the Senate there the 19th. of March 1683/4. Dated at New-Market.

Tru≈øty,The Univer≈øity prays the King to appoint Statutes to be ob≈øerved. &c. Whereas it hath been humbly repre≈øented to us by you Our Chancellor, with the Con≈øent and Approbation of the Heads of Colleges and the Proctors of that Our Univer≈øity, that the puni≈øhments already made by Statute for the due performance of Exerci≈øes required in Order to the
Degree of Ma≈øter of Arts in our ≈øaid Univer≈øity have not proved ≈øo effectual as were to be de≈øired, We have thought fit as a further Te≈øtimony of Our principal care for the Advancement of good Learning to make & E≈øtabli≈øh the following Orders to be ob≈øerved by all, whom it may concern as a Statute for the future, that is to ≈øay, That every Senior or midle Bachellor of Arts, appointed to Re≈øpond or Declame in the Bachellors Schools, by the Combination to be made for that purpo≈øe, and Signed by the Vice-Chancellor and the Senior Proctor for the time being, not performing his Duty in the cour≈øe allotted him then, ≈øhall be puni≈øhed 20 s. and moreover be obliged under the ≈øame penalty to perform the ≈øame on the next u≈øual day for ≈øuch Exerci≈øe, and ≈øo from time to time, till he ≈øhall have actually performed it, or el≈øe be excu≈øed upon ju≈øt and nece≈ø≈øary cau≈øe to be allowed and appointed by the Vice-Chancellor and Senior Proctor for the time being, and the Ma≈øter of the College, to which ≈øuch per≈øon doth belong: Which Method of proceeding we will have al≈øo to take place and be duely ob≈øerved as to the exerci≈øe of oppo≈øing in tho≈øe Schools, ≈øaving that the puni≈øhment for the neglect thereof ≈øhall be but 10 s. to be repeated as we have above directed.

div.head: ¬ß. 10. A Command to the Univer≈øity to grant a Di≈øpen≈øation.
div.p: In ≈øome Mandates I find the Univer≈øity is Commanded to Di≈øpen≈øe as in the following.

‚Äî We have thought fit hereby to recommend Richard Thomp≈øon Ma≈øter of Arts to you in the mo≈øt effectual manner, for the Degree of Doctor of Laws, Willing and Requiring you forthwith upon Receipt hereof (all Di≈øpen≈øations requi≈øite being fir≈øt granted) to Confer the ≈øame upon him by Accumulation, he performing the Exerci≈øes requi≈øite thereunto, or
Cautioning for the ≈øame, any Statute, Order or Con≈øtitution of that Our Univer≈øity, to the contrary notwith≈øtanding. Dated the 4th. of April 1684.
An Example of a Revocation of a Mandate I think fit to In≈øert.

Tru≈øty,The Revoking of a Mandate. &c. Whereas We were Graciou≈øly plea≈øed by Our Letters bearing date the 4th. of this In≈øtant April, to require you to Admit Our, &c. Charles King, of Wadham College in that Our Univer≈øity, into the Fellow≈øhip then void, if any ≈øuch then were, or otherwi≈øe into the fir≈øt that ≈øhould any way become void in that Our College, We have thought fit to Revoke, and do accordingly hereby Revoke Our ≈øaid Letters, and all Clau≈øes therein contained Dated the 28th. of April 1684.

div.head: ¬ß. 11. The Kings Order, that Mandates ≈øhould not be granted without the Te≈øtimony of the Arch-Bi≈øhop of Canterbury and the Bi≈øhop of London.
div.p: Some complaints having been made, that the too frequent obtaining of Mandates for Fellow≈øhips, &c. was prejudicial to the Graduates in the Univer≈øities, whereby they were put by their Rights, and the liberty of the Elections Infringed, ≈øince by the recommendation of ≈øome Friends at Court, the King was prevailed withal to grant ≈øome, that upon due con≈øideration and right Information probably the King would have rejected. That the King might have a fit Te≈øtimony of the Per≈øon, before he granted any ≈øuch Mandate, it plea≈øed his Maje≈øty to make this following Order.

Having taken into Our ≈øerious con≈øideration how much it will conduce to the Glory of God, Our own Honor, and the welfare both of Our Church and the Univer≈øities, that the mo≈øt worthy and de≈øerving Men be favored and preferred according to their Merit, and being ≈øatisfied that the Lord Arch-Bi≈øhop of Canterbury, and the Bi≈øhop of London are the
mo≈øt Competent Judges in ≈øuch Ca≈øes, We have thought fit, and do hereby declare Our plea≈øure to be, that neither of Our Principal Secretaries of State do at any time move Us on the behalf of any per≈øon what≈øoever, for any Preferment in the Church, or any Favor or Di≈øpen≈øation in either of Our Univer≈øities without having fir≈øt Communicated both the per≈øon and the thing by him de≈øired unto the Lord Arch-Bi≈øhop of Canterbury and Bi≈øhop of London, or one of them now and for the time being, and without having their or one of their Opinions and Atte≈øtations in the Ca≈øe, and if at any time We be moved in like manner by any other per≈øon what≈øoever, Our plea≈øure is, and We do hereby declare, that neither of Our ≈øaid Principal Secretaries ≈øhall pre≈øent any Warrant unto Us for Our Royal Signature in ≈øuch a Ca≈øe, until the ≈øaid Arch-Bi≈øhop of Canterbury and Bi≈øhop of London or one of them have been acquainted therewith, and have given therein his Opinion and Atte≈øtation as afore≈øaid.By this we find, that the King re≈øolved to have perpetuated this, yet it was Revoked, as al≈øo a later Mandate, as appears by the following Mandate. And that this Our Declarati√≥n may ≈øtand as a la≈øting and inviolable Rule for the future, Our further Will and Plea≈øure is, that the ≈øame be Entered not only in both the ≈øides of Our ≈øaid Principal Secretary of State, but al≈øo in the Signet Office there to remain upon Record. Given, &c. the 27th. of February 1680/1.

div.head: ¬ß. 12. The Re-calling of a Mandate after the former.
div.p: I In≈øert this out of the Series, becau≈øe I may joyn the Revocation of another Order as followeth.

Whereas We did by Our Warrant under Our Signet Manual bearing Date at Wind≈øor the 12th. of Augu≈øt 1681. Signifie and Declare Our plea≈øure to be, that neither of Our Principal Secretaries of State, ≈øhould at any time move Us on the behalf of any
Favor or Di≈øpen≈øation in either of Our Univer≈øities without having fir≈øt Communicated both the per≈øon and the thing by him de≈øired unto the Lord Arch-Bi≈øhop of Canterbury for the time being, John Earl of Radnor, George Earl of Hallifax, Lawrence Vi≈øcount Hyde, the Lord Bi≈øhop of London for the time being, and Edward Seymour E≈øq and without having the Opinion and Atte≈øtation of them, or any Four of them in the Ca≈øe, and that if at any time we ≈øhould be Moved in like manner by any other per≈øon what≈øoever, Our plea≈øure was, and We did thereby Declare, that neither of Our Principal Secretaries of State ≈øhould pre≈øent any Warrant unto Us for Our Royal Signature in ≈øuch a Ca≈øe, until the ≈øaid Lord Arch-Bi≈øhop of Canterbury, &c. had been acquainted therewith, and had given their Opinion and Atte≈øtation as afore≈øaid, and whereas We have thought fit, for ≈øpecial Cau≈øes Us thereto moving, to Revoke and determin Our ≈øaid Warrant, We do accordingly hereby Revoke and determin the ≈øame, and all the Authority thereby Granted, and Our plea≈øure al≈øo is, that Our Order be Entred, not only in both the Offices of Our ≈øaid Secretaries, but al≈øo in the Signet-Office. Dated the 20th. of September 1684.
By this mandate it appears, that it is in the Kings power to Revoke his own Con≈øtitutions at his plea≈øure.

div.head: ¬ß. 13.
div.p: I might add to the≈øe the King's di≈øpen≈øing with Statutes of Cathedral Churches about Lea≈øes, annexing the Revenues of Prebends to a Deanry, ordering the Arch-Bi≈øhop of Canterbury to Grant Di≈øpen≈øations for a Bi≈øhop to hold Rectories in Commendum of which I could produce many In≈øtances, but I keep my ≈øelf to the bu≈øine≈øs of the Univer≈øities.

In which I hope, by a ≈øufficient enumeration of particulars, I have made it clear beyond all po≈ø≈øibility of Di≈øpute, that the Kings of England have di≈øpen≈øed in all the Ca≈øes before recited, with Statutes of Colleges: yet it is as manife≈øt, that all the Members of the Univer≈øities and of particular Colleges, upon their taking of Degrees, or being Elected into Fellow≈øhips, &c. take an Oath to ob≈øerve the Statutes of the Univer≈øity, or particular College, and yet by the power of the Kings Di≈øpen≈øation are no ways Involved in the Sin of Perjury.

I ≈øhall now proceed to give ≈øuch An≈øwers as I Judge requi≈øite to tho≈øe arguments I find couched in any of the defences made by the Fellows of St. Mary Magdalen College, and begin with that of the obligation of their Oaths.

div.head: CHAP. VII.

argument.p: The An≈øwer to the Arguments u≈øed by the Vice-Pre≈øident and Fellows of St. Mary Magdalen College, in defence of their proceedings.

div.head: SECT. I.

argument.p: An≈øwer to what is urged in their Ju≈øtification from the Obligation of their Oaths to ob≈øerve their Statutes.

div.head: ¬ß. 1.
div.p: THe mo≈øt plau≈øible plea the Vice-Pre≈øident and Fellows u≈øed in Vindication of their Electing Dr. Hough and di≈ø-obeying the Kings Mandate, was that they were under the obligation of their Oath to ob≈øerve the Statutes of their Founder in the Literal and Grammatical ≈øen≈øe of them. And the per≈øons Nominated by the Fir≈øt and Second Mandate of the King were not Qualified according to tho≈øe Statutes, ≈øo that in obeying the Kings Mandates they ≈øhould either be Perjured or forfeit their Rights in their Fellow≈øhips, if they Elected or Admitted any per≈øon not Statutably Qualified, and that they were under the like obligation, neither to procure, accept or make u≈øe of any di≈øpen≈øation from that Oath, or any part of it, by whom≈øoever procured, or by what Authority ≈øoever granted.
