To which in Aggravation and Improvement was urged,See p. 6. here, & p. 75. where the King's Declaration is urged, which I ≈øhall con≈øider in its place. the di≈øagreeablene≈øs of being pre≈ø≈øed to for≈øwear them≈øelves, at a time when his Maje≈øty had been Graciou≈øly plea≈øed to Grant Liberty of Con≈øcience.

Finding this Argument looked upon by the favourers of the Ejected Fellows as unan≈øwerable, I think my ≈øelf obliged to clear the point, not only by producing the Opinions of Ca≈øui≈øts, but likewi≈øe by the Authority of Bi≈øhop Sander≈øon, who de≈øerves the greater re≈øpect and credit, for that he Adorned the Divinity chair in that Univer≈øity long before he did the Epi≈øcopal.

div.head: ¬ß. 2. Definition of an Oath.
div.p: In this matter we may con≈øider what an Oath is, which is generally defined to be the Invocation of God, to beMart. Bonacina Tom. 2. Di≈øp. 4. q. 1. puncto 2 fol. 214. witne≈øs of the plighting of our Faith, that we will do or ≈øuffer to be done, ≈øuch or ≈øuch a matter; by Bonacina thus expre≈ø≈øed, e≈øt Actus quo Divinum numen fidei faciendae cau≈øa adhibemus, vel Invocatio Divini numinis in Te≈øtimonium.
I need not trouble the Reader with the divi≈øions of Oaths, or with the Schoolmens Opinions, who can Ab≈øolve per≈øons from the obligation of them.

‚òû The forementioned Author a≈ø≈øerts, that Superiors,Po≈ø≈øunt enim Superiores (ut Papa Princeps & alii) irritare Juramenta facta de re ≈øibi ≈øubjecta ≈øicut po≈ø≈øunt, irritare vota: qualem facultatem habet pater re≈øpectu liberorum, Superior re≈øpectu≈øubditorum, Dominus re≈øpectu Servorum, maritus re≈øpectu Uxoris, in iis rebus in quibus tales per≈øonae ≈øunt ≈øubjectae & ratio e≈øt quia nullus Jurare pote≈øt in praejudicium alterius. Id. Ibid. puncto 17 propo≈øit. 4. as the Pope, Princes or others, may Vacate the Oaths made in a matter ≈øubject to them, as well as they can Vows, which kind of faculty he ≈øaith a Father hath in re≈øpect of his Children, a Superior in re≈øpect of his Subjects, a Lord in re≈øpect of his Servants, an Husband in re≈øpect of his Wife, in tho≈øe things in which ≈øuch per≈øons are ≈øubject, the rea≈øon of which is, becau≈øe none can Swear in prejudice of another.

As to the ≈øeveral ways how the obligation of an Oath is taken away, the School-menQuando Materia juramenti promi≈ø≈øorii ≈øube≈øt alterius pote≈øtate ≈øive ille ≈øit Eccle≈øia≈øticus ≈øive Laicus, ≈øive per≈øona publica vel privata: hoc modo interdum irrita redduntur a Conciliis & ≈øummis Pontificibus Juramenta qua fiunt in Capitulis a Canonicis de Servandis Statutis & con≈øuetudinibus de acceptando vel non acceptando Beneficio & ≈øimilia & quae≈øiunt in Univer≈øitatibus, &c. & alia Id genus ‚Äî cen≈øetur enim in huju≈ømodi ≈øemper excepta pote≈øtas Superioris quam Inferiores per ≈øuum Juramentum re≈øtringere non po≈ø≈øunt. Le≈ø≈øius lib. 2. c. 42. Dub. 12. num. 61. call it by Irritation when the matter of a Promi≈ø≈øary Oath is ≈øubject to anothers power, whether it be an Eccle≈øia≈øtic or Lay, a public or private per≈øon.

‚òû In this manner ≈øaith my Author, both by the Decrees of Councils and Popes, if the Superior forbid, tho≈øe Oaths are void which are made in Chapters by the Canons of the ≈øame, for ob≈øerving Statutes and Cu≈øtoms of receiving, or not receiving Statutes and the like, of the ob≈øerving of Statutes of Univer≈øities, and gives the Rea≈øon out of Cajetan, becau≈øe in all ≈øuch Promi≈ø≈øory Oaths, the power of the Superior is to be excepted, whom the Inferiors cannot bind by their Oaths.

So they who have Sworn to ob≈øerveIlli qui Statuta Civitatis Jurarunt ob≈øervare, Juramenti Vinculo non tenentur: po≈øtquam Statuta legitimi Superioris Authoritate fuerint abrogata. Bonacina Di≈øp. 4. q. 1. punct. 17. prop. 1. n. 15. the Statutes of a City, are not obliged by their Oaths after the Statutes have been Abrogated by the Authority of a Lawful Superior. The like may be ≈øaid of all College Statutes and Con≈øtitutions: And that the Kings Di≈øpen≈øation is a Temporary Abrogation, at lea≈øt of any ≈øuch Statutes, will be made appear below.

So Bi≈øhop Sander≈øon Cum quis Juravit Statuta alicujus Collegii ≈øibi praelecta ob≈øervare & po≈øtea contigerit ea Statuta revocari vel abrogari Jurans ab≈øolvitur a vinculo Juramenti. Sander≈øon de Juramento obligatorio praelect. 7. Sect. 7. p. 225. ≈øaith, when any hath Sworn to ob≈øerve the Statutes of any College Read to him; if it happen, that tho≈øe Statutes are Revoked or Abrogated, he that Swears is Ab≈øolved from the obligation of that Oath.

The rea≈øon of which is:That the Sovereign hath Power to alter and adnul. See Cap. 6. Sect. 2. here. For that if the Sovereign have power to take away a College Statute, and hath Abrogated and Su≈øpended it for a time. The Oath to ob≈øerve that Statute is Null, becau≈øe they Swear to ob≈øerve that which is not in Being; for de non ente nulla ≈øunt praedicata: And in the particular Ca≈øe of St. Mary Magdalen College, they Swore to ob≈øerve the Statute about Election, which the King had taken away by his Mandate.

div.head: ¬ß. 3.
div.p:
Thus Martinus
Tom. 2d. Di≈øp. 4. q. 1. punct. 17. prop. 1. fol. 228. Bonacina ≈øaith, the obligation of an Oath is hindred, fir≈øt by a Law which de≈øtroys the Human Contract or matter of the promi≈øe upon which it is built. For the Foundation being taken away, the Super≈øtructure is likewi≈øe de≈øtroyed, and Layman gives the rea≈øon, for thatQuia Juramentum e≈øt acce≈ø≈øorium contractui ≈øeu promi≈ø≈øioni: ≈øicut ergo promi≈ø≈øio hanc habet tacitam conditionem ni≈øi promi≈ø≈øio remittatur a promi≈ø≈øario, vel re≈øcindatur, ita etiam eandem conditionem habet Juramentum. Lay-man lib. 4. Tract 5. c. 8. n. 3. an Oath is an Acce≈ø≈øary to the Contract or Promi≈øe, ≈øo that as a promi≈øe hath that Tacit condition unle≈øs the promi≈øe be remitted by the per≈øon to whom it was promi≈øed, or be re≈øcinded by the Judge, ≈øo the like condition hath the Oath which is Appendant to the promi≈øe.
The forementioned Bonacina ≈øpeaking of the ob≈øervance of Statutes of a Society, &c. ≈øubjoyns this which is oppo≈øite to our Ca≈øe.

‚ÄîFrom which weEx quo licet inferre Jurantem revocato Statuto non amplius obligari ad illud ≈øervandum Ratio e≈øt quia Juramentum obligat ad ≈øervanda Decreta, ≈øicut continentur in Statutis & ita explicandum e≈øt Juramentum ≈øicut res ≈øupra quamcadit, tum quia Juramentum ≈øtricte Interpretandum e≈øt; non vero dilatandum propter periculum perjurii. Idem. Di≈øp. 4. q. 1. punct. 16. prop. 1. n. 2. fol. 226. a. may conclude ≈øaith he, that a Statute being revoked, the Swearer is no longer obliged to the keeping of it, and the rea≈øon he gives is, That the Oath obligeth to the keeping of Decrees as they are contained in the Statutes, and the Oath is ≈øo to be explained as the thing is which enforceth the obligation, and for that the Oath is to be Interpreted ≈øtrictly not to be enlarged, for that otherwi≈øe one may be endangered to be perjured. The meaning of which is, that ≈øuppo≈øing a Lawful Authority (which
I pre≈øume none will deny the King hath) ≈øhall Su≈øpend, or for the time revoke the Statute, the per≈øons that have taken an Oath to ob≈øerve them are ab≈øolved from all obligation to that Oath, becau≈øe an Oath that really obliges is to be taken in the ≈øtricte≈øt ≈øen≈øe, becau≈øe perjury is a great Sin, therefore all the Latitude is to be allowed, that rationably may be before an Oath be adjudged obligatory, le≈øt Men be Involved in it. To back this he Cites many School-men, which the Reader may have recour≈øe to if he plea≈øeth.

Secondly, By prohibitingIdem ibid. vide Sanchez in ≈øumma lib. 3. cap. 11. the Execution: ≈øo tho' a Prince cannotLege civili Impediri po≈ø≈øe obligationem Juramenti ne inducatur; quamvis enim ≈øupremus princeps non po≈ø≈øit immediate & directe Irritare vinculum Juramenti utpote Spirituale & ip≈øius facultatem ≈øuperans, pote≈øt tamen in directe & remote quatenus pote≈øt de≈øtruere contractum antequam celebretur, vel quatenus pote≈øt executionem contractus ≈øub culpa prohibere, Bonacina Di≈øp. 4. q. 1. punct. 17. prop. 1. a. immediatly and directly Irritate the obligation of an Oath becau≈øe it is Spiritual, and ≈øo is above his faculty, yet indirectly and remotely he can, becau≈øe he can de≈øtroy the Contract before it be Celebrated, or may forbid the Execution of the Contract under a penalty.

div.head: ¬ß. 4.
div.p: Thus the obligationDi≈øpen≈øatione tollitur obligatio Juramenti & haec ab≈øolutio fit Authoritate Superioris ≈øolius. J. Le≈ø≈øius lib. 2. cap. 42. Dub. 12. n. 62. fol. 631. of an Oath is taken away by Di≈øpen≈øation according to the Opinion of a Learned School-man, and con≈øequently the Ab≈øolution is by the Authority of the Superior alone.

Hence it is ea≈øie to under≈øtand how a Superior can relea≈øe an Oath, forSicut enim is in cujus favorem & commodum prae≈øtitum e≈øt pote≈øt illud Relaxare ita etiam illius Superior cui vel ille pleno jure ≈øube≈øt ‚Äî ≈øicut enim Superior pote≈øt co gere inferiorem ut obligationem Juramenti remittat quando ju≈øta cau≈øa po≈øtulat vel ≈øube≈øt, ita ip≈øe per ≈øe pote≈øt eam remittere illo nolente vel non comparente vel alias quando expedit, & tunc con≈øen≈øus Superioris ≈øupplet defectum con≈øen≈øus Inferioris. Idem n. 63. as he in who≈øe favor and for who≈øe profit the Oath is made, can relea≈øe the Oath, ≈øo the Superior to whom he is ≈øubject pleno jure can: For as the Superior, ≈øaith Le≈ø≈øius, can compel the Inferior to remit the obligation of his Oath when a ju≈øt cau≈øe requires, is expedient, or under≈øtood.
So the Superior can relea≈øe the Inferior, tho' the Per≈øon Swearing be not willing, or is not pre≈øent to con≈øent: therefore in ≈øuch ca≈øe the con≈øent of the Superior ≈øupplys the defect of the con≈øent of the Inferior. Thus far Le≈ø≈øius.

‚òû Which Bi≈øhop Sander≈øon Nec obligatur Jurans ad faciendum quod Juravit; imo obligatur ad non faciendum ni≈øi accedit Superioris, ubi rem re≈øcierit, Licentia. de juram. obl praelect. 4. Sect. 5. p. 104. Confirms when he ≈øaith, that in ≈øuch a ca≈øe without the Superiors Licen≈øe, the Swearer is not obliged to perform what he Sweareth to, yea he is obliged not to do it, unle≈øs there intervene the Superiors Licen≈øe when he knows the thing, and further adds,Omnine dicendum e≈øt Juramentum ejus qui ≈øub alterius pote≈øtate e≈øt ab≈øque ip≈øius con≈øen≈øu nec licitum e≈ø≈øe nec obligatorium Idem p. 105. that it is mo≈øt true, that the Oath of him that is under anothers power without his con≈øent, is neither lawful nor obligatory, and it was upon this very ground that all the Loyal Divines of England Judged the Solemn League and Covenant was unlawful, as wanting the Kings con≈øent, much more he having declared his di≈ø≈øent.

Be≈øides in all Promi≈ø≈øory Oaths there is a Tacit condition implyed: as Fir≈øt, If the promi≈øe be not remitted by him to whom it is promi≈øed: or Secondly, That no public Law be made to di≈ø≈øolve the Statute. Thirdly, If the SuperiorQui enim aliquid promittit alteri, tacite ≈øubintelligit hanc conditionem [ni≈øi Superior cui Materia ≈øube≈øt contradicet ni≈øi ip≈øe ≈øua Autoritate condonat] hinc dici ≈øolet in Juramento cen≈øeri exceptam Superioris Autoritatem. Le≈ø≈øius lib. 2. c. 42. Dubit. 12. n. 63. to whom the matter is ≈øubject contradict it not, or by his Authority pardoneth not the breach of it. Hence it is a Rule, that in any Oath the Authority of the Superior is to be excepted; Therefore where the Sovereign power re≈øides (as in the King of England) there the di≈øpen≈øing power re≈øides, and thePromi≈ø≈øio hanc habet junctam conditionem ni≈øi promi≈ø≈øio remittatur a Superiore vel re≈øcinditur a Judice. Bonacina. Di≈øp. 4. q. 1. punct. 17. prop. 1. fol. 228. ≈øecret or ≈øilent condition, viz. If the King di≈øpen≈øe not with the ob≈øerving of it, is to be Implyed in every ≈øuch Oath. Wchhi leads me to the Fourth condition of a Promi≈ø≈øory
Oath, viz. the IntentionTacita Conditio ≈øub e≈øt vel ex Juris Di≈øpo≈øitione vel ex Jurantis Intentione. Le≈ø≈øius Dub. 2. n. 12. fol. 617. of the Swearer, which mu≈øt con≈øtantly be under≈øtood, that he will keep his Oath if he be not prohibited by the Law or the Sovereign.

div.head: ¬ß. 5.
div.p: ‚òû Bi≈øhop Sander≈øon Illu≈øtrates this in this manner;De juram. obl. praelect. 2. lect. 10. pag. 48. If a Son Swear to do any thing Lawful in it ≈øelf, and the Father Command him to do another which hinders him from doing that which he had Sworn to do, the Son is not bound by his Oath, becau≈øe he is bound by the Natural Divine Law to obey the Command of his Father, and he Cites in the Margent, that Rule both of the Canon and Civil Law which he approves of, in Juramento ≈øemper jus Superioris Intelligitur exceptum.

Hence Le≈ø≈øius affirms, that when a promi≈øe or propo≈øition of a thing good in it ≈øelf is made, a Man is not obliged to perform it, but with Tacit Conditions of which he hath many In≈øtances which are forreign to our bu≈øine≈øs, but one is expre≈øly to our purpo≈øeJura≈øti ≈øervare Statuta capituli, tacita conditio e≈øt, ≈øcilicet quae nunc ≈øunt in vigore & majoris momenti, ≈øeu quae ex vi Juramenti ≈øunt in u≈øu, non enim ≈øe Juramento vult a≈øtringere ad minima neque ad ea quae non ≈øervantur vel ≈øi ≈øerventur non ex Religione Juramenti, neque etiam ad Statuta futura, ni≈øi aliud Intenderit. Le≈ø≈øius, lib. 2. c. 42. Dub. 4. n. 21. fol. 619. when one Swears to ob≈øerve the Statutes of a Chapter. It is to be under≈øtood of ≈øuch as are in force (which as before I have ≈øhewed tho≈øe are not which are Abrogated by the Superior) or are of greater moment, (and ≈øurely in our ca≈øe the obligation of our Allegiance, and owning the Kings Supremacy, is much a greater tye upon our Con≈øciences than tho≈øe of private Statutes) or are in u≈øe by virtue of our Oath.

div.head: ¬ß. 6.
div.p: To Conclude this Head, Bonacina Juramentum ≈øequitur naturam Actus ≈øuper quem cadit, acce≈ø≈øorium enim ≈øequitur naturam principalis ut habet Regula Juris 42 in ≈øexto itaque ≈øi actus habet tacitam Actionem, etiam Juramentum habere cen≈øetur: confirmatur, quia Juramentum non additur, ut promi≈ø≈øio, propo≈øitum, aut contractus aliter accipiatur quam per ≈øe accipi ≈øolet; ≈øed ut eo mode Intellecta quo ≈øolent Intelligi non po≈ø≈øint revocari itaque non tollit nec excludit ≈øolitas conditiones. gives the rea≈øon why in ≈øuch like Oaths, Tacit Conditions are to be under≈øtood. Becau≈øe an Oath follows the nature of the Act upon which it falls, for the Acce≈ø≈øory follows the nature of the principal, as it is a known Rule in Law; Therefore if the Act have a Tacit Condition, the Oath is likewi≈øe to be Judged to have the ≈øame, and this is Confirmed becau≈øe the Oath is not therefore added, that the promi≈øe, purpo≈øe or contract ≈øhall be otherways ob≈øerved, than as it is wont in it ≈øelf to be under≈øtood. But in that manner to be Interpreted as tho≈øe things are, which cannot be revoked, [if the obligation be to keep them, or e contra] Therefore ≈øuch an Oath neither takes away nor excludes the Cu≈øtomary conditions, that is, ≈øuch as are before mentioned, and are always ≈øuppo≈øed to be implyed. Thus far that Judicious Author.

div.head: ¬ß. 7.
div.p: If it be objected, that the General Oath, Objection. See p. 16. here & p. 25. which the Fellows take at their Admi≈ø≈øion to ob≈øerve the Statutes (which had the Kings Tacit con≈øent) did oblige the Fellows to take that Oath before the Election and ≈øo to go to Election.

‚òû For An≈øwer we may con≈øider,An≈øwer. that tho' an Oath in it ≈øelf be lawful, e≈øpecially ≈øo long as the Prince or Superior forbids not the performance of what was Sworn to, yet in the ca≈øe of the Magdalenians, the King had expre≈øly commanded them to choo≈øe one he appointed, and that Included a Prohibition, for he that Commands me to Elect this Man forbids me to Elect another, and this is agreeable to the Explication the Church of England gives of the Fifth
Commandment. He that Commands me to Honor Father and Mother forbids me to di≈ø-honor, them. And Bi≈øhop Sander≈øon Si Superior quamprimum rem re≈øcierit Statim di≈ø≈øen≈øum ≈øuum palam & peremptorie ≈øubdito ≈øignificaverit prohibueritque Id in quod Juratum e≈øt fieri ce≈ø≈øare continu√≤ obligationem Illam Juramenti Tran≈øitorii & ≈øubditum vi obligationis Officii quae permanens e≈øt & perpetua rencri contra quam Juraverat facere. Sander≈øon de Jurament. oblig. praelect. 7. ≈øect. 6. pag. 243. well ob≈øerves, that if a Superior as ≈øoon as he knows the matter, doth pre≈øently, openly, and peremptorily ≈øignifie to the ≈øubject his di≈ø≈øent, and forbids that to be done which is Sworn to; In≈øtantly that Tran≈øitory obligation of the Oath cea≈øeth, and the ≈øubject, by force of the obligation to his Office or Supremacy, which is permanent and perpetual, is obliged to do contrary to what he hath Sworn to. And the ≈øame mo≈øt Judicious Bi≈øhop is ≈øo far from allowing ≈øuch ≈øubjects, at lea≈øt Fellows of Colleges, to re≈øi≈øt the Mandate of their Sovereign, under pretence that they have Sworn to the contrary, that he ≈øaith expre≈øly, that the ≈øubject ought not in tho≈øe things in which he is ≈øubject to another, Swear to do any thing without at lea≈øt pre≈øuming his Superiors con≈øent, his words are, Non debet Subditus in iis rebus in quibus alteri ≈øube≈øt Jurare ≈øe facturum quicquam ab≈øque prae≈øumpto ≈øaltem Superioris ≈øui Con≈øen≈øu.

Hence in the In≈øtance Bi≈øhop Sander≈øon brings of the Sons obligation to obey his Fathers Command, tho' it hinder him from performing his own Oath, he ob≈øerves that the Son Swore to act with the Tacit con≈øent of his Father, which he had rea≈øon to ≈øuppo≈øe the thing being lawful in it ≈øelf, and yet the Oath is re≈øcinded, which directly An≈øwers the Objection.

‚òû It is further urged,Second Objection. that the Fellows bind them≈øelves by Oath, neither to ≈øeek to obtain any Di≈øpen≈øation with any of their Statutes, nor yet Admit of any directly or indirectly obtained, which is the highe≈øt of Tyes that an Oath can bind to, without a direful
Imprecation, which is annexed in ≈øome Statutes.

To this I An≈øwer, that ≈øuch Oaths are ill impo≈øed by Founders, not ≈øo much becau≈øe the obligation is in it ≈øelf not to be di≈ø≈øolved, but becau≈øe it may perplex ≈øome ≈øcrupulous Con≈øciences and may afford Umbrages to ≈øuch as are unwilling to yield to their Superiors di≈øpen≈øation to in≈øi≈øt more earne≈øtly and tenaciou≈øly upon the obligation.

I rather believe ≈øuch Clau≈øes have been In≈øerted by Founders to prevent as much as in them lay, the Members of the Societies to Innovate matters, than that they could fore≈øee, that it was more obligatory by the addition of that Clau≈øe. We may ea≈øily Judge that all Munificent Founders would contrive all the ways whereby their Gifts, and the u≈øes and applications of them might be perpetuated, as we ≈øee in ≈øeveral per≈øons ≈øettlements of their E≈øtates, whereby they endeavor to Entayl them to their Heirs pa≈øt all po≈ø≈øibility of Alienations; yet by the Laws of the Land, which are not favorable to ≈øuch perpetuities, we find dayly examples of docking the mo≈øt Artificially contrived Entayls.

‚òû Now that any Founder in the time when the Roman Catholic Religion was E≈øtabli≈øhed here, could think that ≈øuch Clau≈øes could be perpetually obliging, I can ≈øee no rea≈øon when they could not but know, that none of their Statutes or Con≈øtitutions had any force, but as they were confirmed by their Sovereigns whether Civil or Eccle≈øia≈øtical, and in all ≈øuch Ca≈øes, tho' the pre≈øent Sovereigns, whether the King of England or the Pope did ratifie them, yet this could bind neither of their Succe≈ø≈øors.

‚òû For as to the King it is a Rule in Common-Law, that general words of an Act of Parliament where the King is not named cannot bind him, as may be ≈øeen in the Authorities Cited in theCro. 3d. part. A≈øcoughs ca≈øe fol. 225 & Magna Charta c. 11. Margent.

‚òû If therefore the Common-Law, which ≈øeems in many particulars le≈øs to favor the Prerogative, be ≈øo ju≈øt to the King, that he is Exempted from the force of an Act of Parliament in which he is not named, ≈øurely he mu≈øt be exempted from a College Statute in which he is not named, Secondly, If the King had been excepted by Name the exception had been Null, for the Founder neither if Living would have Exempted the Society from the Kings Paramount Juri≈ødiction, neither could, being a ≈øubject, if he would have done it asCujus i. e. Regis Juri≈ødictioni ≈øodalitium Illud neque volui≈ø≈øe fundatorem, neque (≈øubditus cum fuerit) ≈øi vellet potui≈ø≈øe omnino con≈øtare. Wood Antiq. Oxon lib. 1. fol. 403. Dr. Bayly urged to Mr. Prynn upon the Parliaments Vi≈øitation, Anno 1647.

‚òû Thirdly, If it be further urged, that the Founders Founded the Colleges and Endowed them on condition the King would allow the Society to be Governed by their Statutes, which is but an unproved pre≈øumption, as not appearing in any Charter I have met with, yet if ≈øuch conditions were to be found, the Succeeding Kings at lea≈øt are not obliged in point of ≈øtrict Ju≈øtice to ob≈øerve ≈øuch Orders or Decrees of their Predece≈ø≈øors, becau≈øe Par in Parem non habet pote≈øtatem aut Imperium, and in ≈øuch matters the Graces and Favors of Preceeding Kings are alterable and ≈øu≈øpendible at the plea≈øure of the Succeeding Sovereign, who cannot be Impaired in any Act of his Sovereignty by his Predece≈ø≈øor; ≈øo that to think that a King of England can by any of his Subjects Con≈øtitutions be bound from Vi≈øiting or giving his own Interpretation of the Statutes is a great weakne≈øs; of which I ≈øhall Treat more fully in it's proper place,
and only Infer at pre≈øent, that the obligation of any Subjects Oath neither to take nor Admit of any Di≈øpen≈øation, is in it ≈øelf of no force to ob≈øtruct the Sovereign from di≈øpen≈øing, and when he doth di≈øpen≈øe no Oath is obligatory to any that hath Sworn to ob≈øerve ≈øuch Statutes as are not in being while he di≈øpen≈øeth with them.

‚òû Thus much I thought fit to offer as to what relates to the Secular power. As to the Popes Di≈øpen≈øing it was very Incongruous and weak for any Founder to expect that the Members of the Society could oppo≈øe the Popes di≈øpen≈øation with any Statute which his Holine≈øs for the time being ≈øhould think fit to alter or Abrogate; for asValidum e≈ø≈øe vo≈øum aut Juramentum non petendi di≈øpen≈øationem aut relaxationem voti quamdiu animae volentis utilius e≈øt non petere di≈øpen≈øationem ‚Äî Superior tamen pote≈øt non ob≈øtante tali voto di≈øoen≈øare, & di≈øpen≈øatio valida e≈øt, nam vetum ≈øubditi non aufert Superiori pote≈øtatem di≈øpen≈øandi. ‚Äî Jurantes vel volentes, &c. ≈øub paena, ut ≈øi fecerint non po≈ø≈øunt ab alio ab≈øolvi vel di≈øpen≈øari quam √† ≈øummo Pontifice, po≈ø≈øunt adhuc ab≈øolvi ab Epi≈øcopo ‚Äî nam huju≈ømodi votum vel Juramentum non aufert Epi≈øcopis Juri≈ødictionem ‚Äî Ita communiter D. D. Di≈øp. 4. q. 2. punct. 1. n. 28. 29.
Bonacina determins, that tho' the Vow or Oath of any not to ≈øeek for a di≈øpen≈øation or relaxation of them, be valid as long as the Swearers Con≈øcience is convinced it is profitable to his Soul to keep it, and not to ≈øeek a di≈øpen≈øation, as Rodrique and other School-men there Cited allow, and ≈øo in like manner not to u≈øe a di≈øpen≈øation, yet the Superior notwith≈øtanding ≈øuch a Vow or Oath may di≈øpen≈øe, and the di≈øpen≈øation is valid, and A≈ø≈øigns the Rea≈øon, for that the Vow of the Subject doth not take away from the Superior the power of di≈øpen≈øing, as Azorius Cap. 19. Quae≈øt. 13. Sanchez. lib. 4. Cap. 8. n. 35. yea he further ob≈øerves, that if one Vow (the like is to be under≈øtood of an Oath) not to do ≈øuch or ≈øuch a thing under the Penalty, that if they do it they cannot be ab≈øolved or di≈øpen≈øed with by any but the Pope; yet for all this they may be Ab≈øolved by the Bi≈øhop, for he ≈øaith, by this the Authority of the Bi≈øhop is not taken away.

Yea I find in Le≈ø≈øius Unde etiam po≈ø≈øunt di≈øpen≈øare in voto non petendi di≈øpen≈øationem; hoc enim non e≈øt re≈øervatum. Le≈ø≈øius lib. 2. cap. 40. Dub. 18. n. 134. fol. 568. that the Confe≈ø≈øors of the Mendicant Order can di≈øpen≈øe with the Vow or Oath to take no di≈øpen≈øation, and that by a Privilege Granted them by the Pope, if they be partakers of the Faculties Granted to the Benedictines by Pope Martin the Fifth, becau≈øe this is not re≈øerved.

div.head: SECT. III.

argument.p: Some other Objections con≈øidered, either relating to the Vi≈øitation in General, or urged in Defence of ≈øome particular Members of the Society.

div.head: ¬ß. 1.
div.p: A Second Objection I have met with is, that the Bi≈øhop of Winche≈øter being the Local Vi≈øitor appointed by the Statutes of Bi≈øhop Waynflet, it ≈øeemed more agreeable to a formal proceeding, that he ≈øhould have exerci≈øed his power of Vi≈øitation before the King had ordered Dr. Hough, &c. to have been proceeded again≈øt by the Lords Commi≈ø≈øioners for Eccle≈øia≈øtical Cau≈øes.

To which I an≈øwer, Fir≈øt in the Re≈øolution of a very Eminent Lawyer, that the Local Vi≈øitor is appointed and tru≈øted by the Founder, and thereby hath a private Tru≈øt. But the King as King hath a public Tru≈øt by operation and con≈øtruction of Law, and by his Sovereign Authority and Juri≈ødiction is Supreme Vi≈øitor, and may exerci≈øe that Royal Tru≈øt (as tho≈øe of the long Robe u≈øe to expre≈øs his Prerogative ≈øometimes) when and as often as he plea≈øeth, without any Commanding or expecting the Vi≈øitation of the Local Vi≈øitor; and having the general care of, and
In≈øpection into the Manners and Duties of his Subjects may not only Vi≈øit, Enquire into, and Reform the Members of the College as to their Actions, but al≈øo Vi≈øit the Local Vi≈øitor him≈øelf as to his doing and performances in or about his Tru≈øt.

Secondly, It is certain the Arch-Bi≈øhop of Canterbury, and the Bi≈øhop of Lincoln, as I have by many Pre≈øidents cleared before, have Vi≈øited, notwith≈øtanding the Local Vi≈øitors being appointed. Therefore much more may the King who is Supreme Vi≈øitor.

Thirdly, By the ≈øpeedy Application of Dr. Hough to the Bi≈øhop of Winche≈øter, before I pre≈øume his Lord≈øhip could have notice of the Kings Inhibition, he had Admitted him, ≈øo that he was ≈øo far become a party concerned, that it was no ways convenient for him to have proceeded in it.

Fourthly, The Local Vi≈øitor is appointed only for the ea≈øe of the Crown in ordinary Ca≈øes. But it cannot be ≈øuppo≈øed that if a Local Vi≈øitor ≈øhould neglect to do his Office, or ≈øhould be partial, there ≈øhould not be a power in the Sovereign to order the Vi≈øitor, ≈øeeing it would be a great deficiency in the Oeconomy of Government, that a power ≈øhould not be lodged ≈øome where to compel a Local Vi≈øitor to do his duty if he failed in it, which can ultimately remain in none but the King.

div.head: ¬ß. 2. The third Objection.
div.p:
In the third place in the particular concerns of Dr. Hough it is urged, See here p. 67. that the Sentence again≈øt him could not be good in Law, ≈øince he was not Cited before the Lords Commi≈ø≈øioners at Whitehall, nor appeared in per≈øon or by Proxy before them, nor had his cau≈øe brought before them when Sentence of Expul≈øion was given again≈øt him, which tho≈øe that are
his favorers Cen≈øure as very hard u≈øage that one ≈øhould be condemned unheard.

In An≈øwer to which it mu≈øt be con≈øidered, that the King by his Mandate having ≈øet a≈øide and ≈øu≈øpended the College Statutes for Electing a per≈øon Qualified within tho≈øe Statutes and impowering the College by his Royal Command without breach of their Founders Rule, and their Oath upon it to Elect a per≈øon not capable of being Elected by their College Statutes, as hath been abundantly cleared in the la≈øt Section, Dr. Hough was not to be con≈øidered as duely Elected, and ≈øo revera was no Pre≈øident, therefore could not be taken cognizance of as ≈øuch.

But as Fellow he was Cited, and did make appearance, and was heard as the re≈øt of the Fellows were, and under other Circum≈øtances he was not Legally to be taken notice of. His cau≈øe likewi≈øe was before the Court, in that the Vice-Pre≈øident and Fellows that were Electors were Cited, and their Plea for their Election was Examined and di≈øcu≈ø≈øed, and upon full hearing was by the Lords Commi≈ø≈øioners. Adjudged to be void and null, ≈øo that the Vice-Pre≈øident and Delegated Fellows were in this Ca≈øe his Proxies.

div.head: ¬ß. 3. The fourth Objection.
div.p: It is Fourthly objected, See here p. 67. That Dr. Hough was Ejected out of a Free hold for Life without any Writ of Ejectment or Tryal at Common-Law, contrary to the freedom of a Subject.

To this I An≈øwer, That there are two ≈øorts of Free-holds, viz. Ab≈øolute and Conditional; as to the fir≈øt it is true, that no per≈øon can be di≈øpo≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of it, but by due cour≈øe of Law, and in ca≈øe of re≈øi≈øtance no other way but by the Sheriff and his Po≈ø≈øe Comitatus. But in a Conditional or Attendant Free-hold as this
of a College is, a Man may be di≈øpo≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed without that Cour≈øe if he perform not the Condition of his Free-hold, ≈øo Thomas Coveney ≈øometime Pre≈øident of this College was deprived of his Free-hold Attendant on the Pre≈øident≈øhip, for that he was not entred into Holy Orders, and another ≈øub≈øtituted in his place without a Sheriff or Po≈ø≈øe Comitatus, for not performing ≈øome conditions required by his Office, tho' duly Elected. Therefore much more might Dr. Hough be Ejected by the Lords Commi≈ø≈øioners Sentence, who never was de Jure Pre≈øident.

In this Ca≈øe the Free-hold is only Attendant upon the Office, ≈øo that by whatever Legal proceeding, the Office is declared and adjudged void, by the ≈øame the Attendant Free hold cea≈øeth, any more to appertain to the per≈øon Ejected or Deprived. So a Par≈øon hath an Hou≈øe and Glebe-Land, and by his Ordinary is ≈øu≈øpended or deprived ab Officio & Beneficio, immediately his Right cea≈øeth, as to that Free-hold, during his ≈øu≈øpen≈øion or deprivation, yea it is more here, for he is as a per≈øon Dead.

So in any like Ca≈øe, an Officer that hath an Hou≈øe, Garden, &c. annexed to his Office, and holds that Office durante beneplacito Regis, this is his Freehold while he holds the Office, but when ever the King gives him a Super≈øedeas, the Free-hold Attendant upon that Office from that moment cea≈øeth to be his Free-hold; now the Decree of the Lords Commi≈ø≈øioners of Deprivation, Expul≈øion or Su≈øpen≈øion is as much a final Judgment again≈øt Dr. Hough, who≈øe Cau≈øe was of their Cognizance, as any Verdict in a Court of Common Law for Ejectment, &c.

Hence the Reader may Judge how groundle≈øs and bold an A≈ø≈øertion it was in Dr. Stafford to ≈øay,See here p. 75.
that as to the Decree of his Maje≈øties Commi≈ø≈øioners again≈øt Dr. Hough, they humbly conceived it was null and void in it ≈øelf, he being thereby deprived of a Free hold for life, the which he was duly and Legally po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of, without ever being called to defend his Right or any Mi≈ødemeanor objected again≈øt him. When the Doctor could not but know that Dr. Hough had neither Right to Pre≈øident≈øhip or Free-hold, if he were not duly Elected, and that he could not be, if the Kings Mandate and the re-inforcing of it up on the Petition of the Society, that he would be obeyed, was of any force, as I ≈øhall in the next Paragraph further clear.

div.head: ¬ß. 4. The fifth Objection.
div.p: It is Fifthly objected, that it doth not plainly appear, that a Mandate implyes a Prohibition, e≈øpecially when the per≈øon propo≈øed is by the Statutes of the College in no capacity to be Elected, it being, as Dr. Stafford urged,See here p. 78. a contradiction in Terminis, that to Command to Elect a per≈øon uncapable, ≈øhould oblige not to Elect a per≈øon capable.

To this fir≈øt I An≈øwer in General,An≈øwer. That the Mandate having tho≈øe expre≈øs words in it [Any Statute, Cu≈øtom of Con≈øtitution to the contrary in any wi≈øe notwith≈øtanding, wherewith we are Graciou≈øly plea≈øed to di≈øpen≈øe in that behalf] takes off all di≈øability from the per≈øon to be Elected. As the Kings Pardon Ab≈øolves the Criminal from undergoing the Penalty of the Laws, and re≈øtores him to the condition of a good Subject; ≈øo that the per≈øon being in all re≈øpects as capable as if he had been Statutably Qualified, as in the An≈øwer to the fir≈øt Objection I pre≈øume is cleared. The Que≈øtion is fir≈øt, whether any thing was to be done by the Fellows but to obey after they had received his Maje≈øties An≈øwer to their Petition.
And Secondly, whether that Mandate Implyed an Inhibition and Command to chu≈øe no other.

As to the fir≈øt part the whole Di≈øcour≈øe hath been a Set of Arguments to prove by a Deduction of In≈øtances, the obedience that hath, or ought to have been payed to the Kings of England in all Ca≈øes where they have In≈øi≈øted upon having their plea≈øure obeyed: And there is good rea≈øon for it, ≈øince there hath been either anSo I find that King Henry the 5th. e≈øpecially re≈øerved to him≈øelf and Succe≈ø≈øors, the power of di≈øpen≈øing with any of the Statutes made or to be made, as appears in a di≈øpen≈øation for Re≈øidence granted to Dr. Blanford, 21 Aug. 1663. Expre≈øs or Tacit re≈øerve, according to the Con≈øtruction of the Law, in all the Grants made to the Univer≈øities or particular Founders, Impowring them to make Statutes, that the Kings ≈øhould have a power to alter, change, amend, abrogate, or annul them at their plea≈øure.

However the Kings of England have by their Gracious Conce≈ø≈øions in other particulars limited their power to act conformable to Laws made: Yet in this particular of College Statutes, it may be truly ≈øaid of them, as of the Roman Emperors, whatQuicquid principi placet, legis habet vigorem in≈øtit. de lege naturali ¬ß. ≈øed. ever plea≈øeth the Prince hath the force of a Law, as may be ≈øeen Cod. de con≈øtit. principis l. 1. In principe & In≈øtit de lege naturali ¬ß. ≈øed.

So we find in the Civil Law, whateverQuodcunque igitur imperator per Epi≈øtolam, & ≈øub≈øcriptionem Statuit Legem e≈ø≈øe con≈øtat. quod principi Fide con≈øtit. Princ. Tit. 4. the Emperor appoints by his Epi≈øtle and Sub≈øcription is to be e≈øteemed a Law. This may look like a Character of an ab≈øolute Prince who is Solutus Legibus; but it is what is mo≈øt true in Relation to Univer≈øities for by the con≈øtant practice it is experienced, that tho' ≈øometimes Mandates of our Kings have been eluded or evaded, or by Petitions have been Recalled; yet when our Kings In≈øi≈øted upon them they
were obeyed, according to the words of the Dige≈øtsL. merito ‚Ä¢ . 2. ≈øed de F. quod Infra. Accur≈øius in comment. that a Mandate requires a ready obedience, ≈øo that in Civil Law it is a known Rule, that Rogatio Domini praeceptum e≈øt, & Mandatum Spontaneam ob≈øequii prae≈øtationem prae ≈øe fert. In≈øtit. ut de Attil. Tut. ¬ß. penult. And the ab≈øolutene≈øs of a Mandate is yet further cleared by the Rule in Civil Law, that the PrincePrinceps Re≈øcribens contra jus ≈øi ≈øit certificatus de ip≈øo facto videtur quoad hoc illud jus tollere Lancelottus de Attentatis par. 2. q. 4. Limit. 18. n. 6. Re-≈øcribing, that is, Re-inforcing his Mandate contrary to Law, that is, contrary to ≈øuch Statutes that he hath power to Abrogate, if he be certified of the ≈øpecial Fact, ≈øeems as to that particular, to Abrogate the Law or Statute.

It is clear al≈øo that a mandate may either be by Epi≈øtle or Me≈ø≈øage, which ≈øhews, that the Fellows of the College were to receive the Kings An≈øwer by my Lord Pre≈øident,See here p. 8. when they delivered their Petition again≈øt Mr. Farmer, that the King would be obeyed, as a Re-inforcement of the former Mandate; ≈øeeing the words of the Law are Ideo per nuncium quoque L. obligatio Mandat. ¬ß. 2. Ideo Mandati vel contra. per Epi≈øtolam Mandatum ≈øu≈øcipi pote≈øt, and what part they are to Act that receive ≈øuch Mandates is clear by what we find thus expre≈ø≈øed ‚Äî Qui Mandatum L. ≈øi quis alicui 27. ¬ß. 2. qui Mandatum F. Mandati vel contra. ≈øu≈øcepit, ≈øi pote≈øt id explere, de≈øerere promi≈ø≈øum Officium non debet, alioquin quanti Mandatoris Inter≈øit damnabitur. Si vero Intelligit explere ≈øe id Officium non po≈ø≈øe; Id ip≈øum quam primum poterit debet Mandatori nunciare. ∆≤t is ≈øi velit alterius oper√¢ Utatur; quod ≈øi, cum po≈ø≈øit, nunciare Ce≈ø≈øaverit, quanti Mandatori Inter≈øit, tenebitur. Si aliqua ex cau≈øa non poterit nunciare ≈øecurus e≈øt.

The Sen≈øe of which is, that he that receives a Mandate, if he can do it ought not to defer the performing of it, otherwi≈øe he ≈øhall be condemned or puni≈øhed ≈øo deeply, as the concern of him that ≈øends
the Mandate is; but if he under≈øtands, that he cannot fulfil the Command, he ought upon the fir≈øt opportunity by Me≈ø≈øage to relate this to him that ≈øends the Mandate, that he may employ another, and if when it is in his power, he ≈øurcea≈øe from doing of it, he ≈øhall make ≈øatisfaction to him that ≈øent the Mandate as much as he is Intere≈øted. But if for ≈øome cau≈øe he cannot return this Me≈ø≈øage, he is excu≈øed.

That the ≈øignification of the Kings plea≈øure in this ca≈øe is ≈øufficient appears in that Rule often inculcated by ourSi de voluntate apparet de pote≈øtate non e≈øt di≈øputandum. Id. a. cap. 4. 12. n. 5. Author, if the will and plea≈øure of the Prince appears, we are not to doubt of the power.
As to the Second Que≈øtion.

div.head: ¬ß. 5.
div.p: ‚òû That this Mandate included a prohibition to choo≈øe any other per≈øon be≈øides him that was named in the Mandate, ≈øeems clear to me by the known Rule Intus exi≈øtens prohibet alienum.

If therefore the Fellows were bound to choo≈øe him whom the King appointed by his Mandate,See this replyed to in the An≈øwer to the fir≈øt Objection cap. 7. ≈øect. 1. parag. 7. then ≈øurely they could choo≈øe no other, and that is enough to make a prohibition: For the per≈øon who is bound to choo≈øe one Commanded, ≈øurely cannot choo≈øe another, for he hath no liberty to choo≈øe any but him for whom the Mandate was directed; ≈øo that there ≈øeems no Medium, but either to obey, and then the liberty of all other choice is taken from him, which amounts directly to the prohibition of all other per≈øons,This was what Dr. Tho. Smith prudently advi≈øed the Morning of the Election, here pa. 7. or he ≈øhould Su≈øpend all Election, till he had prevailed with the King to have re-called his Mandate, and this had been, tho' not exqui≈øite Dutifulne≈øs, yet, a more civil re≈øpect to the King.

But in the Civil Law we find, that tho≈øe thingsMandato contineri ca videntur ≈øine quibus Mandatum explicari non pote≈øt. l. Invitus 19. Tit. de procurat. are Judged to be contained in a Mandate, without which the Mandate cannot be explained. Now I think it is impo≈ø≈øible to explain the po≈øitive Mandate to choo≈øe Mr. Farmer, without under≈øtanding, that by that the choice of all other per≈øons was forbid, which is ≈øtill made apparent by another Law,Mandato aliquo ea quoque Mandata Intelliguntur quae ex co con≈øequuntur. l. Indebit. 47. de condit Indebit. that in any Mandate, tho≈øe things al≈øo are under≈øtood to be Commanded, which follow naturally or con≈øequenter upon it, as it doth in this Ca≈øe, that if Mr. Farmer by vertue of the Kings Mandate was to be cho≈øen, none other could be cho≈øen, or what is aequivalent, all other per≈øons without a revoking of that Mandate were forbid to be cho≈øen.

Upon this ≈øuppo≈øition therefore, that an Inhibition was in the Ca≈øe, it is ea≈øie to conclude how great a Crime it was in the Fellows to di≈ø-obey, for it was no le≈øs than to di≈øpute the Kings Sovereignty, and Juri≈ødiction, than which there can be no Crime greater but open Rebellion, for there is but that difference betwixt one that draws the Sword to re≈øi≈øt the Kings Authority, and one that by Vote and ob≈øtinacy doth it, but that one is Armed and the other un-armed, for the denying the Authority is alike in both.

Therefore we Read in Lancelottus, that he that contravenesContra veniens Inhibitionem incurrit paenas Inhibitione contentats. Idem n. 17. dehinc videmus quod Inhibitione contra veniens videtur Judicem in ≈øua Juri≈ødictione contra venire De Attentatis par. 2. c. 20. n. 10. an Inhibition is ≈øaid to contemn the Judge in his Juri≈ødiction, and the like mu≈øt be ≈øaid of the di≈ø-obeyer of the prohibition of a King; now what a Crime the contempt of a King is, may be≈øt be learnt from the puni≈øhments the Laws of all Nations inflict upon the Tran≈øgre≈ø≈øors; a mea≈øure of which, becau≈øe tho≈øe unfortunate Gentlemen have felt by their per≈øi≈øting to the la≈øt in ≈øo great an ob≈øtinacy,
I ≈øhall not at pre≈øent touch upon.

div.head: ¬ß. 6.
div.p: As in an Inhibition, Is qui Inhibet co ip≈øo videtur velle quod ≈øi contra fiat Actus non valeat. Idem Ampl. 10. fol. 375. Non ≈øolum Regula procedit in Inhibitione expre≈ø≈øa verum in Inhibitione Tacita pro ut e≈øt illa quae re≈øultat ex a vocatione cau≈øae quam princeps ex certa ≈øcientia facit, quoniam per huju≈ømodi avocationem videtur Princeps Judici & partibus Inhibere. Idem Amp. 4. n. 2. the Prince or Superior that forbids, by that very Act ≈øeems to will, that no Act ≈øhall be valid which is again≈øt it, ≈øo a Command to do any thing mu≈øt be a forbidding of doing the contrary, as Lancellottus ob≈øerves.

The Civilians do further di≈øtingui≈øh betwixt an Expre≈øs and a Tacit Inhibition, as when a Prince doth avocate the Cau≈øe from any Court; for when a Prince doth this of his certain knowledge, he lays an Inhibition on the Judges and parties. So in this Ca≈øe of St. Mary Magdalen College, the King took away from the Fellows the liberty of choo≈øing ≈øuch a per≈øon as their Statutes obliged them to choo≈øe, by the di≈øpen≈øing with the Statutes; therefore in that he ≈øeems plainly to Inhibit their Electing of any according to the Letter of the Statutes as before I have cleared in the An≈øwer to the Objection, Chap. 7. Sect. 1. ¬ß. 7. pag. 295. here to which I refer the Reader.

Therefore the Dilemma of Dr. Stafford ≈øeems to have no ≈øuch contradiction in Terminis, See here p. 73. 74. that his Maje≈øty in Commanding the Fellows of the ≈øaid College to Elect Mr. Farmer Pre≈øident, ≈øhould thereby prohibit them to Elect any other per≈øon what≈øoever. Becau≈øe that power of Election is as much, but no more than the Conge de e≈ølier, for a Bi≈øhop where the Title of Election is only pro forma; but the Chapter can Elect none but who is Nominated by the King, and for his being unqualified that is no ≈øort of Objection, ≈øince the di≈øpen≈øation as effectually ca≈ø≈øeth and nulls the Statutes, enjoyning tho≈øe qualifications for the time, as if they had never been extant.

By ≈øuch Mandates the King lays his Hand upon the Statutes,Manus Appo≈øitionis Papae natura ea e≈øt ut omnium Inferiorum pote≈øtas per eam Ligata cen≈øeatur Idem cap. 12. limit. 52. n. 15. which in Civil Law is Styled Manus Appo≈øitio. Now I find two of tho≈øe, viz. the Popes laying on of Hands, which is de≈øcribed to be of that nature, that the power of all Inferiors is thought to be bound by it; and the laying on of the Hand of the King hath the power of a Nullitive Decree, and Derogation, and works more than a Re≈øervation, the words of my Author are,Idem cap. 4. declar. 4. n. 6.
Principis Manus Appo≈øitio habet vim decreti annullativi & derogationis, & operatur plus quam re≈øervatio.

Hence we may conclude by the Civil law, that after the Inhibition, tho' Tacit, the Fellows ought not to have proceeded to Election, no more than other Courts could go on in their proce≈øs after an Inhibition,Idem cap. 20. n. 14. according to that Rule proce≈ø≈øus po≈øt Inhibitionem factus, Regulariter e≈øt ip≈øo Jure nullus.

div.head: ¬ß. 7.
div.p: That I may more clearly An≈øwer this Objection, See here p. 4. and ≈øhew that however the Bi≈øhop of Winche≈øter in his Letter to my Lord Pre≈øident alleged, that the Rules of the College Statutes had been hither to con≈øtantly ob≈øerved, excepting in the times of Rebellion; A parallel ca≈øe in King Edw. the 6ths. time. I ≈øhall give an account of one of the Pre≈øidents of this College, who was no ways Statutably Qualified, and yet was Elected by King Edward the Sixths Mandate.

I have deferred the Narrative of this,The rea≈øon why the Author in≈øerted this no ≈øooner. which I might have brought in ≈øooner, in hopes to have got a more particular account of it out of the Regi≈øters; but tho' I have ≈øollicited the procuring of it ≈øeveral ways; yet by the taking away of one of the Keys where it was kept, acce≈øs could not be had to it. So I Writ to Mr. Wood who Compiled the Learned and Laborious Hi≈øtory of the Antiquities of that
Univer≈øity, in hopes that out of ≈øome of his Notes I might have been ≈øupplyed. But I received the following Letter from him, which giving me ≈øo little hopes of further Information, I mu≈øt content my ≈øelf with what he hath publi≈øhed. That part of his Letter relating to this matter is as followeth.

body.p: VVHen I peru≈øed Magdalen College Regi≈øters, A. B. C. &c. in order to the drawing up the Hi≈øtories of that Hou≈øe, I did not in the lea≈øt dream what would come to pa≈øs relating to the Office and Election of a Pre≈øident; otherwi≈øe I ≈øhould have Collected all, and con≈øequently have been more full in the matter.

What I have ≈øaid of Dr. Haddon was from ≈øeveral Commendatory and Mandatory Letters, and An≈øwers to them in the Regi≈øter E. all which being by me peru≈øed, and finding them very tedious to recount, I only made mention of them in General, and have not ≈øo much as a Docquet of them by me, &c.

closer.signed: A. WOOD.

div.p:
The Hi≈øtory in ≈øhort, Wood Antiq. Oxon lib. 2. fol. 191. a. Gualterus Haddon Juris Civilis Doctor po≈øt multas inter Regem & Societatem hinc Mandatorias illinc excu≈øatorias literas (quippe admi≈ø≈øioni ejus omnes ≈øe ≈øtrenue oppo≈øuere) tandem ultimo Sept. Anno 1552. Electus e≈øt. as to be found in the fore≈øaid Author, is thus, Walter Haddon Doctor of Laws, was bred in the Univer≈øity of Cambridge, and took his Degrees there, and ≈øo was neither of the Foundation of New College, nor of St. Mary Magdalen College, whereof he ought to have been a Member according to the Founders Statutes: Yet King Edward the Sixth, Anno 1552. 5 Regni by his Mandate Commanded him to be Elected Pre≈øident. The Society oppo≈øed this Strenuou≈øly, no doubt upon
the like grounds, that he was not Statutably Qualified, this occa≈øioned a re-inforcing the Mandates, and the Excu≈øatory Letters of the College. However at la≈øt they yielded to the Kings Mandate, and on the la≈øt of September the ≈øame Year, he was Elected Pre≈øident.

This exactly parallels the pre≈øent Ca≈øe of St. Mary Magdalen College: Yet we find the Kings Mandate then was at la≈øt obeyed; and Dr. Haddon was Elected: Whereas the late Ejected Fellows might have kept their Fellow≈øhip, if they had but yielded to Admit the Bi≈øhop of Oxford, or ≈øubmitted to him and owned the Kings Authority, which ≈øurely could not happen for want of knowledge of this precedent; whereof if I can obtain a fuller account before the publication hereof, I will in≈øert it in an Appendix.

There is an In≈øtance al≈øo of a Pre≈øident removed from his Office by the Bi≈øhop of Winche≈øter as Vi≈øitor;Idem ibid fol. 191. a. and what was alleged again≈øt the Pre≈øident Dr. Thomas Coveney, was that he was not in Holy Orders, and had treated ≈øome of the Fellows roughly, this was betwixt the Years 1560. and 1561. the 3d. or 4th. of Queen Elizabeth.

div.head: ¬ß. 8. The ≈øixth Objection.
div.p: It is is Sixthly Objected in behalf of Dr. Fairfax, See this in Dr. Fairfax's Ca≈øe, in the Oxford Relation, f. 27. col. 1. that his Su≈øpen≈øion could not be according to the Rules of Law, ≈øince it was for his not obeying the Kings Mandate, in Electing Mr. Anthony Farmer, and his Su≈øpen≈øion was not affixed on the College Gates till five days after Mr. Farmer was proved before the Lord Commi≈ø≈øioners to be uncapable, by rea≈øon of his Immorality. So that as the Sentence was ≈øevere, ≈øo the Execution of it was more rigid after Mr. Farmer was expo≈øed, as they allege.

In An≈øwer to this,An≈øwer. it is well known, that at the fir≈øt hearing of Dr. Fairfax before the Lords Commi≈ø≈øioners at Whitehall, he denyed the Authority of the Court, alledged that he ≈øhould have been proceeded again≈øt by Libel, and have had a Copy of his Charge, and u≈øed ≈øuch expre≈ø≈øions as gave ju≈øt offence to the Court; ≈øo that tho' the Sentence of Su≈øpen≈øion was pronounced,See p. 35. here. for his Contempt in not obeying His Maje≈øties Letters Mandatory, for Electing and Admitting Mr. Anthony Farmer Pre≈øident of that College; yet if it had not been becau≈øe of his di≈øagreeable deportment to the Court, it is probable he had at that time no more Incurred the Cen≈øure of the Court than the re≈øt of the Fellows, who concurred in the ≈øaid Election.

As to the affixing the Sentence on the College Gates,See chap. 1. ≈øect. 2. p. 43. that was not a material circum≈øtance, nor whether Mr. Anthony Farmer was then or after laid by, or whether he was unfitting, by rea≈øon of his Immorality or otherwi≈øe.

It is nece≈ø≈øary for every Court to A≈ø≈øert it's Juri≈ødiction, and much more ought the Lords Commi≈ø≈øioners to do it, being they have ≈øuch Ample powers from the King, ≈øo that whatever Contempt was offered to their Lord≈øhips, was to the King him≈øelf, and that Dr. Fairfax per≈øi≈øted to the la≈øt in denying the Authority of the Lords Commi≈ø≈øioners, and di≈øobeying the Kings Mandate for Admitting the Bi≈øhop of Oxford Pre≈øident, or ≈øubmitting to him as ≈øuch, appears by his la≈øt An≈øwer to the Que≈øtion propo≈øed October the 25th. whether he owned their Lord≈øhips Juri≈ødiction? To which he replyed,See here p. 84. 85. Under Correction he did not: And being asked whether he would ≈øubmit to the Bi≈øhop of Oxon as Pre≈øident? His An≈øwer
was, he would not, nor could not, becau≈øe he was not his Legal Pre≈øident.

Whoever con≈øiders this ob≈øtinacy, per≈øi≈øted in to the la≈øt, cannot think the Lords Commi≈ø≈øioners could do le≈øs than they did. Had this been done in another Kings Reign, perhaps it might have been Interpreted a Que≈øtioning the very Supremacy it ≈øelf, which how fatal it was to John Fi≈øher Bi≈øhop of Roche≈øter, and Sir Thomas Moor, is worthy to be con≈øidered, both as a demon≈øtration of our Kings Clemency, and that the Doctor hath not ≈øo much rea≈øon to complain of the hard u≈øage.

However the Doctor thought him≈øelf obliged to the ob≈øervation of the Statutes, and to ≈øubmit to the Pre≈øident only, he and the re≈øt of the Fellows had cho≈øen; yet he ought to have con≈øidered, what Baldus in his Comment upon the Code 3. Tit. 14 n. 7. ≈øaith,Qui ≈øunt in aliquo Collegio ratione profe≈ø≈øionis vel negotiationis, Juri≈ødictionem ejus qui praee≈øt Collegio recu≈øare non po≈ø≈øunt, non minus tamen ≈øunt ≈øub prae≈øide vel alio Superiore. That tho≈øe that are in any College by rea≈øon of their Profe≈ø≈øion or Negotiation there, ought not to refu≈øe the Juri≈ødiction of him that pre≈øides in it, yet they are no le≈øs ≈øubject to the Pre≈øident or another Superior, which Superior, or rather Supreme I take the King to be.

Be≈øides, if the Doctor and the re≈øt of the Fellows would have con≈øidered, that in relation to College Statutes (however it may be di≈øputed in other matters) the King hath the ≈øame power as the Emperors had; and that is to be found in the Dige≈øts thus.‚ÄîQuodcunque igitur Imperator per Epi≈øtolam & ≈øub≈øcriptionem Statuit, vel cogno≈øcens decrevit, vel de plano Interlocutus e≈øt, vel Edicto praecepit, Legem e≈ø≈øe Statuit. Dig. lib. 1. Tit. 4. n. 1.
Therefore whatever the Emperor appoints by Epi≈øtle and Sub≈øcription, or knowing doth Decree, or plainly doth expre≈øs, or Commands by Edict, ;is to be e≈øteemed a Law. Which is Literally true in all the Kings power of di≈øpen≈øing with, or Su≈øpending College Statutes, for ≈øince it is clear by many
In≈øtances before in≈øi≈øted upon, that the Kings of England have power to alter, abrogate, and annihilate Statutes of Colleges, much more mu≈øt they have the power to Di≈øpen≈øe with, or Su≈øpend them.

‚òû Therefore when any per≈øon refu≈øeth to ≈øubmit to the Kings Authority in this particular, he is de≈øervedly puni≈øhable by Su≈øpen≈øion or Deprivation. Neither ought Fellows of Colleges a≈ø≈øume to them≈øelves a power of Judging of the Rea≈øons why the King Grants Mandates in favor of any particular per≈øon, or to deny their obedience to the per≈øon ≈øo recommended by Mandatory Letters, becau≈øe they have heard or can prove ≈øome Immortalities again≈øt him; for if that liberty of oppo≈øing the Kings Mandate upon any ≈øuch grounds were once allowed, the Kings power mu≈øt be ≈øolely precarious, and every Mandate of the Kings would be lyable to di≈øputes and debates, and the Kings Sovereignty and Authority would dwindle to an Impotent wi≈øh, that he might obtain his de≈øire in≈øtead of being po≈øitively obeyed, which would be ≈øuch a condition of the Monarchy as would render it contemptible; and whoever endeavors to lower the Dignity of the Crown in ≈øuch a manner de≈øerves ju≈øt Cha≈øti≈øement for it; which was but the bare Su≈øpen≈øion of the Doctor from his Fellow≈øhip at fir≈øt, but by his perfi≈øting in his undutifulne≈øs to the highe≈øt Degree of denying the Kings Authority, he was ju≈øtly puni≈øhed by Expul≈øion, and after with Incapacitating.

div.head: ¬ß. 9. The ≈øeventh Objection.
div.p:
It is Seventhly Objected by ≈øome of Magdalen College, that no Commi≈ø≈øion can be granted under the Great Seal to Vi≈øitors, to place and di≈ø-place Members
of Colleges (who≈øe places are Free-holds) ad Libitum or di≈øcretion.The≈øe are the words of the Oxford Relation. pag. 21. But they mu≈øt proceed according to Legal di≈øcretion, that is, by the Laws and Statutes of the Land, and Local Statutes of the College. And places concerned [con≈øigned rather] for the Head≈øhip and Fellow≈øhips of Colleges are Temporal Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions, and cannot be Impeached by Summary Proceedings.

p.q: For this they Allege the Ca≈øe of Dr. Thomas Coveney Pre≈øident of the ≈øame College, who was deprived in Queen Elizabeths time by the Bi≈øhop of Winton, the Local Vi≈øitor thereof, E≈øtabli≈øhed by Royal Authority, and he Appealed to the Queen. But by the Advice of all the Judges it was held, that the Queen by her Authority, as Supreme Vi≈øitor could not medle in it, but he mu≈øt bring his Action in We≈øtmin≈øter Hall, becau≈øe Deprivation was a cau≈øe merely Temporal. The King, they own, has a great Authority Spiritual as well as Tmeporal, but no Commi≈ø≈øioners can be Authorized by the Crown to proceed in any Commi≈ø≈øion under the Great Seal or otherwi≈øe, but according to Law, in Spiritual Cau≈øes by the Canon Law, in Temporal by other Laws and Statutes of the Land. And wherein the Proceedings in ≈øome Commi≈ø≈øions, are directed to be Summarie & de plano ≈øine ≈øtrepitu forma & Figura Judicii, tho≈øe words are to be applyed to ≈øhorten the Forms of Proce≈øs, and not for matter of Judgment. For Magna Charta provides for our Spiritual as well as Temporal Liberties.

div.head: ¬ß. 10. An≈øwer to it by parts.
div.p: To An≈øwer this Objection di≈øtinctly, we mu≈øt con≈øider the ≈øeveral parts of it, for it is an huddle of ≈øeveral matters jumbled ≈øomething confu≈øedly to ≈øet off the matter more plau≈øibly.

In the fir≈øt place it is urged, that no Commi≈ø≈øion can be granted under the Broad Seal to Vi≈øitors, to place and di≈ø-place Members of Colleges, but, ≈øo as they mu≈øt proceed according to Legal di≈øcretion, viz. by the Laws and Statutes of the Land, and Local Statutes of the Colleges. By this Allegation they would In≈øinuate, that the Lords Vi≈øitors did not proceed according to ≈øuch Laws and Statutes, nor could proceed ≈øummarily, as in the latter part of the Objection they In≈øinuate.

To this I reply,The Kings Prerogative a part of the Law of the land. See chap. 4. ¬ß. 1. & 2. here. that the Kings Prerogative in ≈øuch Ca≈øes is to be taken and accepted as a Fundamental of the Laws of the Land; and I hope I have ≈øufficiently cleared the continued u≈øe of the Kings of Englands exerci≈øing this power in granting Commi≈ø≈øions to Vi≈øit the Univer≈øities, and particular Colleges, &c.

Among≈øt the Patents 26 E. 3. There is a Commi≈ø≈øion directed to ≈øeveral Commi≈ø≈øioners to Vi≈øit St. Mary Magdalen College in Rippon (which by the Foundation of that College was under the Vi≈øitation of the Arch-Bi≈øhop of York) and to enquire of the ≈øeveral mi≈ø-carriages of the re≈øpective Members, and whether they con≈øumed, or wa≈øted any of the Lands or Goods of that College, and to return the ≈øame to the King who would take care therein.

So in the Parliament RollsRot. Parl. 40 E. 3. n. 12. the Univer≈øities of Oxford and Cambridge, complained in Parliament of the Fryers Mendicants of both the ≈øaid Univer≈øities, how Injurious they were to the Ancient Immunities of the Univer≈øities, and how faulty and offen≈øive they were to them, and it was declared and re≈øolved in Parliament, that the King had ≈øole power to redre≈øs tho≈øe Controver≈øies at his Will and Plea≈øure.

In the PleaPlacit. 15 E. 2. n. 10. Rolls 15 Ed. 2. It is declared, that the King hath an ab≈øolute power to puni≈øh contempts and the offences again≈øt him as Supreme Ordinary, without proceeding in the Common and u≈øual Cour≈øe of Judicial proceedings.

‚òû Conformable to this King Henry the 8th. granted his Commi≈ø≈øion for the Vi≈øitation of Mona≈øteries, and di≈ø-placing ≈øeveral Monks and other Regulars for their mi≈ø-carriages, as the Inqui≈øitive Reader may find in Dr. Burnets Hi≈øtory of the Reformation, and that by his Sovereign and Supreme Authority without Act of Parliament.

So King Edward Rot. Pat. 3 E. 6. 1 part. the 6th. Commi≈ø≈øioned Cranmer, Ridley, and others to proceed de plano in a ≈øummary way again≈øt Bonner, by the Examination of Witne≈ø≈øes again≈øt him, and ≈øo to Impri≈øon, Su≈øpend or Deprive him, as they ≈øaw cau≈øe; in pur≈øuance of which Commi≈ø≈øion they Deprived him of his Bi≈øhopric.

So Queen Mary Rot. Pat. 1 Mariae part. 7. granted Commi≈ø≈øion to the then Bi≈øhop of Winche≈øter and others, to Impower them to proceed in a ≈øummary way, to the Deprivation of the then Arch-Bi≈øhop of York, and other Bi≈øhops.

So Queen Elizabeth Pat. 24 June, 1 Regni. granted Commi≈ø≈øion to the Earls of Derby and Northumberland, and others, to Vi≈øit all the Clergy in the North, to place and di≈øplace them as they ≈øaw cau≈øe.

div.head: ¬ß. 11. Inferences from the foregoing Records.
div.p:
By all which Authorities, See chap. 4.5, 6, and 7. here. the Opinion of Parliaments, the Antiquities of Pre≈øidents, and frequent In≈øtances in later days, which I have abundantly produced in the foregoing Chapters, I hope I have convincingly cleared, that the King in all Ages by his Prerogative hath Regulated and Reformed Univer≈øities
and Colleges, puni≈øhed their offences, placed and di≈ø-placed their Members, without anything of the Ceremony of We≈øtmin≈øter Hall, and have been advi≈øed by their Judges and Learned Council, that it was their Prerogative to proceed by their Commi≈ø≈øioners Delegated by them in a ≈øummary way, to the Su≈øpen≈øion and Deprivation of the Bi≈øhops and Clergy; nor can it be denyed, but the Bi≈øhops of England have great Free-holds, Temporalities, and Honorable Baronages to lo≈øe by ≈øuch Deprivations, and ≈øuch were more con≈øiderable in the Eye and e≈øteem of the Law, than the Exhibitions, Head≈øhips or Fellow≈øhips of any College.

‚òû Hence it may be noted,The Kings of England exerci≈øing the power of ≈øupen≈øion and deprivation by Commi≈ø≈øioners upon Bi≈øhops, Abbots, Priors, &c. may well do it on Members of Colleges. that ≈øince our Kings have exerci≈øed ≈øuch a power over Mona≈øteries, Colleges, purely Religious, Arch-Bi≈øhops and Bi≈øhops, they may much more exerci≈øe the like over Univer≈øities and Colleges, ≈øince whatever power they or their Founders had or have, it was never given them by any Statute, or any part of the Common Law, it being the Kings ≈øole Prerogative to Con≈øtitute Coporations or Bodies Politic, ≈øole or Aggregate, Eccle≈øia≈øtical or Civil, under ≈øeveral and di≈øtinct qualifications, conditions and tru≈øts; and the Univer≈øities and Colleges derive their Exi≈øtence from the Royal bounty of the Prince who made them Corporations, Con≈øtituted them by the direction of their re≈øpective Founders, Bodies with Heads, and Members to be Governed by ≈øuch Rules and Statutes, as the Founder by the Kings Licence ≈øhould appoint: But it was never certainly Intended, that the King by ≈øuch Grant or Licence ≈øhould Delegate ≈øuch Authority to Founders, Vi≈øitors, or the Members of Colleges,See chap. 4. ≈øect. 1. here. whereby to injure his Prerogative or determin the Supremacy,
which the Law of the Land had Annexed to his Imperial Crown, as at large I have cleared before.

That the King is Supreme Head and Vi≈øitor in all Eccle≈øia≈øtical and Civil cau≈øes,See cap. 4. here. hath been fully proved; and that from the King all Judges Eccle≈øia≈øtical and Temporal derive their Authority: And ≈øure a Delegation of power from the King can be no Bar or E≈øtople to the King to exert his Prerogative, that he thereby can be concluded from Delegating power to others to correct and reform mi≈ødemeanors and offences in Communities created by him, or his Ance≈øtors, or to ≈øupervi≈øe the Actions and Management of his Judges Eccle≈øia≈øtical, Local Vi≈øitors, or per≈øons Commi≈ø≈øioned by him.
As to Dr. Thomas Coveneys Ca≈øe, I ≈øhall con≈øider it when I come to Treat of Appeals.

div.head: ¬ß. 12. Whether Colleges be of Temporal or Spiritual nature.
div.p:
‚òû Concerning the Temporal E≈øtates of the Fellows, and the profits of the Fellow≈øhips being Free-holds, that alters not the Ca≈øe of the Kings power of Vi≈øiting; for altho' it is di≈øputed by Learned Authors, whether Colleges be of a Lay or Spiritual nature; yet it is mo≈øt clear, that they have undergone Vi≈øitations; the rea≈øon of which is, becau≈øe they are the Nur≈øeries of Learning and Piety, Qualifications of great Moment to the well-being of Government, and con≈øequently require the Princes ≈øpecial care, ≈øince upon the purity or impurity of the≈øe Fountains much good or bad mu≈øt be derived to the Sovereign and Subject: And altho' in the Univer≈øities ≈øome Studies relate not at all to Divinity, as Civil Law, Phy≈øic, &c. yet the Body of the Students generally are bred up to Divinity, and the hours of Devotion, Lectures in Divinity, Di≈øputations, &c. are mo≈øtly about Spiritual
matters, in Ordine ad Spiritualia, and Grammar Schools being for Education, Vertue and Learning are called Spiritual, much more Colleges which are Founded ad Studendum & Orandum, and if there were none of the≈øe con≈øiderations, yet it is well known, that Colleges are to an Eleemo≈øinary end, and it is clear in the ≈øen≈øe of the Law where per≈øons are lay there may be a Spiritual end, 11 H. 4.47. of which matter the curious may find more inKeebles Reports 2d. part page. 166. &c. Dr. Patricks Ca≈øe.

As to the Statute of Magna Charta, The Kings Prerogative is not again≈øt Magna Charta. altho' it grants and confirms many Liberties and Immunities to the people, yet it does not deprive the King of his Prerogative, who hath the power to Create Courts at Law, and give them Juri≈ødiction, as al≈øo to E≈øtabli≈øh Courts by Commi≈ø≈øion for Regulating deceits, oppre≈ø≈øions, frauds, and other matters, as ≈øeems be≈øt to his Royal Will, which is no encroachment on our Liberties, Temporal or Spiritual, as is objected.

div.head: ¬ß. 13. The eighth objection concerning liberty of Appeals.
div.p:
This leads me to the Eighth Objection made by the favorers of the Ejected Fellows, viz. That it is contrary to the Laws of the Land, that any per≈øon ≈øhould be deprived of his Fellow≈øhip by the Lords Vi≈øitors, without having liberty to Appeal to the King in his Courts of Ju≈øtice,See pa. 70. here. as Dr. Hough words it, in his Prote≈øtation again≈øt the Illegality, and Inu≈øtice of the Lords Vi≈øitors Sentence again≈øt him,See here pa. 116. and Dr. Fairfax in his Prote≈øtation in the ≈øame words with the Addition, as the Laws, Statutes, and Ordinances of this Realm will permit in that behalf, who≈øe Ca≈øe differed from Dr. Houghs in that particular, that Dr. Fairfax had long enjoyed his Fellow≈øhip, and was Ejected for his di≈ø-obedience to the Kings Mandate, whereas it was di≈øputable, whether Dr. Hough
was lawfully Elected Pre≈øident. But in one particular they alleged, that their Ca≈øes were alike, in that they might have remedy again≈øt all ≈øuch di≈ø-po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of Head≈øhip's or Fellow≈øhip's in the Kings Courts, where relief in all Ca≈øes of Property and Free-hold ought to be had.

‚òû In Crroboration of this,Dr. Coveneys Ca≈øe urged. they bring the In≈øtance of Dr. Coveney, as in the la≈øt Objection is urged, that he being deprived by the Local Vi≈øitor, and Appealing to the Queen by the advice of all the Judges, it was held, that the Queen by her Authority as Supreme Vi≈øitor could not medle in it, but he mu≈øt bring his Action at We≈øtmin≈øter Hall, becau≈øe deprivation was a cau≈øe merely Temporal.

div.head: ¬ß. 14. The An≈øwer.
div.p: In An≈øwer to this, Fir≈øt, It is apparent in matter of Fact (by what I have before from Records made clear,) that Heads of Colleges,Chap. 5. ≈øect. 1. ¬ß. 10. ≈øect. 2. per totum ≈øect. 3. ¬ß. 3. Fellows, &c. have been Expelled and deprived by Commi≈ø≈øioners for Vi≈øitation, as appears in the places quoted in the Margent.

Secondly,
Coke In≈øtit. 4. fol. 339.340, 341. Stephen Gardiners Ca≈øe. It is owned, that it is not only an u≈øual practice of the Crown to grant Commi≈ø≈øions ad revidendum the former proceedings before the proper Judges; but likewi≈øe the Kings have often granted Commi≈ø≈øions with a Clau≈øe of Appellatione remota, which is a definitive conclu≈øive Sentence, from which no Appeals lies.

‚òû For clearing the point more fully we may con≈øider, that the Statute 25 H. 8. C. 19. grants an Appeal from any of the Arch-Bi≈øhops Courts to the King in Chancery,Appeals according to the Statute 25 H. 8. c. 19. where the King may by Commi≈ø≈øion, Delegate others to determin that Appeal according to the direction of that Act, but where Sentence is given by Commi≈ø≈øioners Delegated by the
Prince, and not in any Bi≈øhops Court, as by Vi≈øitation pur≈øuant to the Statute 1 Eliz. c. 2. there Appeals from ≈øuch a Sentence is not within the Statute of 25 H. 8. c. 19. Yet the King may grant a new Commi≈ø≈øion to revi≈øe the former Sentence.

Likewi≈øe there may be an Appeal to the King in per≈øon from all Courts Erected by his Prerogative,Appeals to the King in per≈øon. as from the High Court of Chancery, Coke 4. In≈øtit. fol. 340. and it is upon Record by Commi≈ø≈øion 14 Jac. 1. as the words are,14 Jac. 1. par. 6. n. 25. that it appertaineth to our princely care and office only to be Judge over all our Judges, the meaning whereof can be no other, than that from the Judges Sentence and Decrees there may be an Appeal to the King in per≈øon, 2 Ander≈øons Reports fol. 163.

So by the Commi≈ø≈øion granted by the King to the Commi≈ø≈øioners to Vi≈øit St. Mary Magdalen College in Oxford, the Commi≈ø≈øioners were a Court, then only for that purpo≈øe created by the King, Goodmans Ca≈øe 4. In≈øtit. 340. and from any Sentence or Decree pronounced by them, the Fellows might Appeal to the King in per≈øon, but could not Appeal to any Court in We≈øtmin≈øter Hall; ≈øo that the Appeal to the King in Chancery is in ≈øuch ca≈øes as are particularly limited in the Statute, of matters in ≈øits, in the Courts of Bi≈øhops,Rolls Abridgment part 2. fol. 233. as Judge Rolls ob≈øerves, who likewi≈øe affirms, that if a ≈øuit be by a Commi≈ø≈øion General of the King, no Appeal can be to the King in Chancery, by the words of the Statute, for in ≈øuch Appeals to the King it mu≈øt be General as he is Supreme Head of all Eccle≈øia≈øtical Juri≈ødiction within the Realm, and this mu≈øt be by a Bill Signed by the King, after which the King may grant a Commi≈ø≈øion to Delegates to hear it.

So that the ca≈øe of Dr. Coveney is not rightly ≈øtated in the Allegation of tho≈øe of Magdalen College,The ca≈øe of Dr. Coveney not rightly ≈øtated. that becau≈øe Dr. Coveney being deprived by the Bi≈øhop of Winche≈øter Local Vi≈øitor, and Appealing to the Queen, it was adjudged, that the Appeal did not lye, becau≈øe deprivation was merely Temporal and Tryable at Common Law;Dyer's Reports fol. 209. for my Lord Dyer only ≈øhews, that according to the Statutes of 24 and 25 H. 8. the Appeal was to be from a Sentence in the Arch-Bi≈øhops Court to the King in Chancery, but Dr. Coveneys deprivation was not by any Sentence in the Arch-Bi≈øhops Court, and con≈øequently not within the Statutes to bring his Appeal to the Queen in Chancery.

Now the Artifice u≈øed by the favorers of the Fellows is,The Artifice u≈øed by tho≈øe of St. Mary Magdalen College, in citing this ca≈øe. that they make Dr. Coveney to Appeal to the Queen, without mentioning in Chancery, and ≈øo it was not brought before the Queen as Supreme Vi≈øitor, and ≈øo was not within the Statute either way, ≈øince the deprivation was by the Local Vi≈øitor only, and in that ca≈øe his remedy had been at Common Law only.

It were ea≈øie to quote the re≈øolutions of ≈øeveral Judges,Savil's Reports fol. 83.105. that no Appeals lye to any but the King in per≈øon from a Sentence of the Kings Commi≈ø≈øioners in Eccle≈øia≈øtical cau≈øes; ≈øo Baron Savile affirms, that no Appeal doth lye from a Sentence in the High Commi≈ø≈øion Court, and that the high Commi≈ø≈øion Court is not within the meaning of the Statute of the 25 of H. 8. but the Opinion of my Lord Dyer or others do not exclude an Appeal to the King in per≈øon,Dyer's Reports for. 42. who is the Fountain of Ju≈øtice, and all the Statutes of King Henry the 8th. and Queen Elizabeth as to the Erecting of Courts and granting Juri≈ødiction
do only remit and re≈øtore the King to his Ancient Juri≈ødiction of Vi≈øiting and Reforming abu≈øes, recieving Appeals and other Judicial Acts, as Supreme Head and Ordinary, as Serjant Dacres ob≈øerves.

div.head: ¬ß. 15. The Ca≈øe of Charles Cottington E≈øq about Appeals.
div.p: I ≈øhall now In≈øtance in a ca≈øe of later date, wherein there being an Appeal made to the Hou≈øe of Lords again≈øt a Decree of the Delegates, the Lords di≈ømi≈ø≈øed it as not coming properly before them.

‚òû The ca≈øe was this, Ex Autographo In the Cu≈øtody of the Clerk of the Parliament.
Charles Cottington E≈øq exhibited his Petition May the 10. 1678. to the Lords, ≈øhewing, that in the Year 1677. he Travailing into Foreign parts, unfortunately fell into acquaintance with one Angela Margareta Gallina, Daughter to a broken Gold-≈ømith in Turin in the Dukedom of Savoy, The Petition of Mr. Cottington. and was contracted to her in the pre≈øence of a Romi≈øh Prie≈øt in Turin, that afterwards he found her a vicious per≈øon, Married to one Frichinone Patrimoniale, upon which Information he left her and returned for England. Then he ≈øets forth that this Gallina came to England and claimed to be the Petitioners Wife, that he had cited her before the Dean of the Arches in a cau≈øe de jactitatione Matrimonii, and ≈øhe alleged that before the contract with the Petitioner ≈øhe was Divorced from Patrimoniale, and the Divorce was pronounced by the Arch-Bi≈øhop of Turin, and that tho' he made it appear that the Sentence was Collu≈øory, and in it ≈øelf void and not to be regarded in England, yet the Judge of the Arches had Sentenced the ≈øaid Gallina to be the Petitioners Wife. Then follows the premi≈øes, ≈øo highly concerning your Petitioner both to the peril of his Con≈øcience, Honor, Body, and E≈øtate, and concerning this his Maje≈øties Kingdom
in the E≈øtabli≈øhing a Foreign Juri≈ødiction again≈øt the Laws of the Kingdom.

p.q: Your Petitioner humbly Appealeth in the premi≈ø≈øes to this High and Honorable Court, and humbly prayeth that the ≈øaid Sentence of the ≈øaid Dean of the Arches, and Commi≈ø≈øioners Delegates may be rever≈øed.
This was referred to the Committee of privileges.
p.note: Referred to the Committee of privileges.

p.q: June the 6th. it was ordered that Pre≈øidents, and Records ≈øhould be brought, and Council to be heard.

June the 12th. The Earl of E≈ø≈øex's Report from that Committee. The Earl of E≈ø≈øex made report from the Committee, that upon full hearing what was alleged by Council on both ≈øides, and upon peru≈øal of ≈øeveral Pre≈øidents, they are of Opinion that the ≈øaid Appeal did not come properly before them, the Earl of Shaftsbury only di≈ø≈øenting, as by his Sub≈øcription appears.

div.p: The Order is entred in the≈øe words.

q.p: According to the Order of the 12th. of this In≈øtant June, The Hou≈øe of Lords Order upon it. the Hou≈øe took into con≈øideration the Report from the Committee of privileges, concerning the Appeal of Charles Cottington E≈øq from the Commi≈ø≈øioners Delegates; whether the ≈øaid Appeals be properly brought before this Hou≈øe. The Opinion of the Committee being, that the ≈øaid Appeal did not properly come before this Hou≈øe. The Opinion of the Committee being, that the ≈øaid Appeal did not properly come before this Hou≈øe. After debate and con≈øideration of Pre≈øidents, the Que≈øtion being put, Whither to agree with this Committee in the Report? It was re≈øolved in the Affirmative, and it is thereupon Ordered, that the Petition and Appeal of the ≈øaid Charles Cottington be di≈ømi≈ø≈øed the Hou≈øe of Peers.

div.p: It is to be con≈øidered in this matter,Con≈øiderations upon this Ca≈øe. that after the Sentence in favor of this Gallina by the Delegates, Mr. Cottington Petitioned the King in per≈øon for a review or di≈ø-annulling the Decree, which the King refu≈øed to grant, and upon that the Petitioner Addre≈ø≈øed him≈øelf to the Lords, who≈øe Order I have recited, and tho' it be not expre≈ø≈øed in the ≈øame Order, why the matter was not properly brought before their Lord≈øhips; yet it is well known, that the cau≈øe was by rea≈øon that Appeals in Eccle≈øia≈øtical cau≈øes do not lye before their Lord≈øhips. If I could have procured the Printed Ca≈øe I might have enlarged upon this matter, and if it be my good fortune to meet with it before the Publication hereof; I ≈øhall take notice of what may be material in the Appendix.

div.head: ¬ß. 16. The Ninth Objection, that matter of Fact proves not right.
div.p: It is Ninthly Objected, that tho' it be allowed that the Kings of England have ≈øometimes di≈øpen≈øed with College Statutes, and done tho≈øe things I have all along In≈øtanced in; yet that proves not the Right or Ju≈øtice of the thing; ≈øince √† facto ad jus, non valet con≈øequentia.

To this I An≈øwer,The An≈øwer. there is a va≈øt di≈ø-proportion betwixt the Acts of Kings, and of Subjects. Con≈øtant and un-interrupted u≈øage are the Foundations of the Cu≈øtoms of England, which are Incorporated into the Common Law of the Land, and ≈øo many Rights are determined for private per≈øons. But in the Orders of the Sovereign, one declaration of his plea≈øure by Mandate, in ≈øeveral Ca≈øes is ≈øufficient Precedent, tho' but rarely made u≈øe of, upon the pre≈øumption in Law, that ≈øuch Acts of Kings are not without deliberate con≈øultation. However the con≈øtant practice of the Kings of England, which I hope I have fully proved, takes away all colour for this Argument: And it is mo≈øt
certain, if the Kings di≈øpen≈øing power with Statutes, and putting in Heads of Colleges, Fellows, &c. by Mandates,If the Kings Prerogative in this Ca≈øe had been again≈øt Law, it would have been que≈øtioned at ≈øome time. had been again≈øt the Law, we ≈øhould at ≈øome time or other heard of Actions brought before the Judges, again≈øt the Kings Authority in that matter, and found determinations upon them in favor of the aggrieved, which I think is not to be found. But the Kings of England have been in Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of this Prerogative in all Ages,The King in Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of this Prerogative. tho' mo≈øt con≈øpicuou≈øly ≈øince the Reformation, and ≈øo this Prerogative mu≈øt be adjudged to appertain to the King, till by ≈øome Legal Tryal it ≈øhall be determined otherwi≈øe.

It may be upon this Topick rationally urged, that tho' the Kings di≈øpen≈øing power in other matters be in the Law Books only made out in ≈øome particular Ca≈øes; yet tho≈øe ≈øufficiently prove that the Original Prerogative of Di≈øpen≈øation being in the King;The Original Prerogative of di≈øpen≈øing in the King. it may branch it ≈øelf to all ≈øuch matters as the King plea≈øeth to apply it to, which by no particular Act he or his Predece≈ø≈øors, as far as they can oblige him, have debarred them≈øelves from the exerci≈øe of, and the continual Series of this di≈øpen≈øing ≈øometime in one & other times in a fre≈øh matter, is ≈øufficient evidence that our Kings have not given up this Prerogative wholly.

Thus I have gone through the mo≈øt material Objections I have met with in the Vindication of the di≈ø-obedience of the Fellows. As to the puni≈øhments inflicted upon them for it, I ≈øuppo≈øe none will que≈øtion but they are according to Rules of Law, upon ≈øuppo≈øal the Crimes were clearly proved.

I ≈øhould now have clo≈øed this Di≈øcour≈øe, but that I am obliged for the Rea≈øons given in the Preface to add ≈øome things that came not ≈øoon enough to my Hands,A Tran≈øition to what is to be Treated of in the Appendix. or went too ≈øoon out of them, which I ≈øhall dige≈øt into Order of time, and put them in this following Appendix.

div.head: AN APPENDIX.
¬ß. 1. A Mandate for Re-placing a Graduate Expelled.
div.p: HAving been nece≈ø≈øitated, for the Rea≈øons foregoing, to make the≈øe Additions; I mu≈øt de≈øire the Courteous Reader to refer them to their proper places noted in the Margent.

I ≈øhall begin with this following Mandate for Replacing a Graduate Expelled out of the Univer≈øity of Oxford in the≈øe words.Clau≈øe 40 E. 3. part 2. M. 8. rot. 10. √® Ms. D. Hales in Bibliotheca Societatis Lincolnien≈øis. lib. B. fol. 180.

Rex dilectis in Chri≈øto Cancellario & Magi≈øtris Regentibus Oxonii ≈øalutem. Supplicaverunt nobis venerabilis in Chri≈øto Pater R. Dei Gratia London Epi≈øcopus, & Tho. Ru≈ø≈øel Prior Provincialis Ordinis Fratrum Praedicatorum in Anglia, ut cum Johannes de Wul≈øington Baccalaureus in Theologia, confrater praedicti Prioris, ad ≈øugge≈øtionem, & procurationem quorundam inimicorum ≈øuorum, extra Univer≈øitatem
praedictam, malicio≈øe, & ≈øine cau≈øa rationabili Bannitus extitit, in ip≈øius Johannis grave dampnum, & ≈øu≈øceptionem Altioris gradus in eadem facultate; & quod volumus ip≈øum Johannem ad Statum ≈øuum pri≈øtinum re≈øtitui jubere.

Nos ≈øupplicationi praedictae favorabiliter Annuentes, vobis Mandamus quod ip≈øum Johannem ad praedictam Univer≈øitatem, & Statum, & gradum quibus ≈øteterit prius in eadem, ≈øine difficultate aliqua Admittatis & reconciliatis, & ip≈øum ≈øic Admi≈ø≈øum, & reconciliatum, omnino quae ad facultatem dictam, quou≈ø. que ad Statum Altiorem juxta Statuta Univer≈øitatis illius promotus fuerit, facere & exercere permittatis, ne ob ullum defectum ip≈øum √† pote≈øtate no≈øtra deduci, & reconciliari ‚Ä¢ aciamus. Te≈øte Rege apud We≈øtm. 18 die Nov.

The King to the Well-beloved in Chri≈øt the Chancellor and Regent Ma≈øters in Oxford Greeting.See chap. 4. ≈øect. 3. ¬ß. 1. pag. 176. and pag. 270.
