The venerable Father in Chri≈øt Ralph by Gods Grace Bi≈øhop of London, and Tho. Ru≈ø≈øel Prior Provincial of the Order of the Fryers Preachers in England, that whereas John de Wul≈øington Bachellor in Divinity confrere with the ≈øaid Prior, by the ≈øugge≈øtion and provocation of certain his Enemies, maliciou≈øly and
without rea≈øonable cau≈øe was Expelled the ≈øame Univer≈øity to the great damage of the ≈øaid John, and the hindring of his recieving an higher Degree in the ≈øaid faculty, and that we would Command the ≈øaid John to be re≈øtored to his former State.

We favorably allowing the fore≈øaid Petition, Command you without any difficulty to Admit and reconcile or re≈øtore the ≈øaid John to the ≈øame Univer≈øity, and to the State and Degree in which he ≈øtood before in the ≈øame, and that you permit him ≈øo Admitted and Reconciled or re≈øtored, in all things to do and exerci≈øe what appertains to the ≈øaid faculty, until he be promoted to an higher State, according to the Statutes of the Univer≈øity, le≈øt for any defect, you make us bring back and re≈øtore the ≈øaid John by our power or Authority. Witne≈øs the
King at We≈øtmin≈øter the 18th. day of November.
This being the olde≈øt Mandate I have met with, I thought it needful to in≈øert it at length, that all might know what Authority the King exerci≈øed in that Age.

div.head: ¬ß. 2. Inferences from this Record.
div.p: By this Record it is manife≈øt, that the King by Mandate could re≈øtore a Graduate who had been Expelled the Univer≈øity, and by parity of rea≈øon he mu≈øt have the ≈øame Right to place any in the Univer≈øity according to his Royal plea≈øure; and whereas by this Expul≈øion there was a Su≈øpen≈øion of his Degree, the King Capacitates him to receive it, when the time required by the Statutes of the Univer≈øity was expired, altho' he was thus di≈ø-enabled.

So that in this one precept four particulars of the Kings Prerogative over the Univer≈øity are A≈ø≈øerted expre≈øly,The prerogative of the King over the Univer≈øity, cleared in four particulars by this Mandate. which in the foregoing parts of this Treati≈øe I have by other In≈øtances cleared, viz. Fir≈øt that the King is Supreme Vi≈øitor, to alter at his plea≈øure the Sentences, Decrees, or determinations of the Univer≈øity. Secondly, that tho' the Univer≈øity by their Statutes might ≈øtop a Graduate from taking an higher Degree, yet the King at his plea≈øure might re≈øtore him to his Pri≈øtin State, and make him capable of receiving his Degrees at the time limited by the Statutes. Thirdly, that the King did this without any formal proceedings at Law, but by his own Sovereign Authority and plea≈øure only declared in a Mandate. Fourthly, that if the Chancellor did refu≈øe to obey the Mandate, the King threatens to have his plea≈øure fulfilled by his Royal power.

div.head: ¬ß. 3. The King Founder of Colleges
div.p: That the King by his Royal Authority Con≈øtituted made and Erected Colleges, pat. 14 E. 3. part 3. M. 9. appears by the following Clau≈øe of King Edward the Thirds Charter to Queens College in Oxford in the≈øe words. Memoratam Aulam, cum Praepo≈øito, & caeteris Sociis, per Electionem in futurum habitantibus & morantibus in eadem, quos ad verum Collegium erigimus & exi≈øtere ex nunc proponimus; & ut Collegium Licitum & approbatum agno≈øcimus Authoritate no≈øtra plena qua po≈ø≈øimus ratificamus & confirmamus, &c. This is Dated 18 January Anno 1340. Granted to Robert Eglesfield of Cumberland Bachellor of Divinity Chaplain to Philippa, Queen Con≈øort to King Edward the Third, and Rector of Burgh under Stanemore, being de≈øcended of an Ancient Family in that County, and in this Charter, the King Grants him liberty to Found it and Endow it with Lands, and to appoint the Orders of the Government of it, as at large may be ≈øeen in the Tower of London, and a con≈øiderable part of it inLib. 2. fol. 113. Mr. Woods Antiquities of Oxford, to which I refer the Reader.

That the Kings of England had re≈øerved to them≈øelves power of Vi≈øiting and Reforming Abbies, Priories, Ho≈øpitals, and Religious Colleges and Hou≈øes is not to be doubted. I ≈øhall only give an account of a Mandate of King Edward the Third, concerning an Amercement relaxed; the Ca≈øe was this.

The Prior of St. Swithins being ab≈øent from his Convent a longer time than the Statutes allowed,The Kings Mandate for taking off an Amercement from the Prior of St. Swithins Rot. Clau≈ø. 20 E. 3. part 3. M. 7. √® D. Hales, ut ≈øupra. was Amerced by the Chapter of the Priory. But the King ≈øends his Mandate to the Chapter Commanding them to di≈øcharge the Amercement Impo≈øed by them upon the Prior; who had been in his Service and was under his Protection, which was ordered
accordingly. From which we may learn, that the King hath a Supreme power over ≈øuch Societies, and ≈øo likewi≈øe over Colleges to remit Penalties, and con≈øquently mu≈øt have power to inflict them upon Offenders.

I ≈øhall give one Precedent more concerning the Kings power to enjoyn obedience of the Head and Fellows of a College to ≈øubmit to a Local Vi≈øitor,The Kings Mandate to enjoyn the Provo≈øt and Members of Queens College in Oxford, to ≈øubmit to the Vi≈øitation of the Arch-Bi≈øhop of York their Local Vi≈øitor. where the Plea again≈øt him probably was an Exemption granted them by the Pope; the Ca≈øe was this.

The Provo≈øt and Scholars of Queens College in Oxford by their Statutes were to be under the Vi≈øitation of the Arch-Bi≈øhop of York, or his Commi≈ø≈øary,See here chap. 4. ¬ß. 2. ¬ß. 12. pag. 175. and it ≈øeems they refu≈øed to ≈øubmit to the Vi≈øitation of Alexander Nevil Arch Bi≈øhop of York; whereupon the King Commands them to obey him as may be ≈øeen in the Mandate at large. Rot. Clau≈ø. 50 E. 3. par. 2. M. 9. e M≈ø. D. Hales, ut ≈øupra. I ≈øhall only note the la≈øt Clau≈øe, viz. Quod ≈øi in vobis Rebellio vel defectus in hac parte reperitur, vos, qui Regii Mandati contemptores, & Rebelles eritis, taliter puniri faciamus, quod punitio ve≈øtra aliis omnibus cedet perennem in Terrorem con≈øimilia po≈øt modum prae≈øumentibus T. Rege apud We≈øtmona≈øt. 18. Nov.

The Engli≈øh of which is, Nota, that di≈øobedience to the Kings Mandate is Styled Rebellion. that for certain they ≈øhall know if in them be found Rebellion, (≈øo it ≈øeems di≈ø-obedience to the Kings Mandate is Styled, which ought to be noted well by ≈øuch as ob≈øtinately refu≈øe obedience to it) or defective in that particular,See chap. 4. ≈øect. 3. ‚Ä¢ . 6. pag. 187. the King will cau≈øe them to be ≈øo puni≈øhed, that their puni≈øhment ≈øhall be to the la≈øting Terror of tho≈øe who ≈øhall pre≈øume hereafter to do the like.
I ≈øhall now In≈øert a determination of the Bi≈øhop of Ely as Local Vi≈øitor, about the Interpretation of ≈øome Statutes of St. Johns College in Cambridge, as followeth.

div.head: ¬ß. 4. The Interpretation of a Statute of St. Johns College in Cambridge by the Bi≈øhop of Ely their Vi≈øitor.
div.p: Cum in Injunctionibus per Vi≈øitatores Regios ve≈øtro Collegio jam diu editis,Paper-Office at Whitehall. & prae≈øcriptis, po≈øitum ≈øit, ut in Electionibus quibu≈øcunque ille Electus habeatur quem ≈øex ≈øeniores, etiam di≈ø≈øentiente, & repugnante Magi≈øtro eligendum duxerint: Jam vero po≈øtea aliae Ordinationes, & Statuta vobis ab ip≈øa Reginea Maje≈øtate nuper Impo≈øita ≈øunt his verbis. Ut in omnibus & ≈øingulis Electionibus, Locationibus, & Conce≈ø≈øionibus quibu≈øcunque, Magi≈øtri ≈øeu Praepo≈øiti illius Collegii A≈ø≈øen≈øus & con≈øen≈øus, nece≈ø≈øario requirendus e≈øt, quoniam po≈øteriora tollunt Priora, meo Judicio & Interpretatione po≈øterius hoc Statutum Regium valere magis debet; ita tamen ut pro modo & ratione omnium & ≈øingulorum Officiariorum referendi omnino e≈øtis ad formam illam di≈øcriptam in Statuto de Electione prae≈øidis, & ad Injunctionem in Margine eju≈ødem Statuti per Regios Vi≈øitatores editam. Haec demum mea Interpretatio & Sententia e≈øt.

This was Richard Cox, Con≈øecrated Bi≈øhop of Ely 21 December Anno 1559. who continued Bi≈øhop Twenty one Years; After who≈øe Death the See was Vacant about Twenty Years, as appears by Godwins Catalogue of Bi≈øhops. Whereby we may Obiter note that it is no new thing for Bi≈øhoprics to be kept long in the Kings Hands un-di≈øpo≈øed of.

From this Interpretation of the Local Vi≈øitor,Ob≈øervations upon this Interpretation of the Local Vi≈øitor. it may fir≈øt be ob≈øerved, that the Vi≈øitors appointed by the Queen did publi≈øh Injunctions about Elections by the powers given them from the Queen; yet after the Queen did her ≈øelf impo≈øe upon the College new Ordinances and Statutes. Secondly, that the Bi≈øhop judgeth that the later Statutes made void the former, and ≈øo adheres to the ob≈øervation of the la≈øt. From hence Thirdly, it is mo≈øt rational to ob≈øerve, that the Kings of England having power to change Statutes, either by them≈øelves in their Clo≈øets, or by their Commi≈ø≈øioners, as it is manife≈øt the Queen in this Ca≈øe did, then it much more follows, that the Kings of England may by di≈øpen≈øation ≈øuper≈øede the execution of any Statute. Fourthly, it is clear that the Local Vi≈øitor by his Interpretation may decide a Controver≈øie in a College, whether the Society ≈øtand obliged to ob≈øerve the old or new Statutes, and if the Local Vi≈øitor hath ≈øuch a power, much more may a King of England exerci≈øe the like.
I now pa≈øs to ≈øome things more immediately relating to St. Mary Magdalen College.

div.head: ¬ß. 5. Extracts of ≈øome Statutes.
div.p:
Having after long Sollicitation obtained by the help of Mr. Thomas Fairfax, See pag. 17. here and pa. 18.23, 24, 33. a Tran≈øcript of ≈øome Branches of the Statutes made by Bi≈øhop Waynfleet out of the Regi≈øter E. I ≈øhall here In≈øert them, that the Judicious Reader may ≈øee, that notwith≈øtanding the Plea ≈øo much In≈øi≈øted upon,How the Fellows of St. Mary Magdalen College cannot ju≈øtifie their adhering to the Literal and Grammatical ≈øence of their Statutes, nor that they cannot be di≈øpen≈øed with. that the Fellows were obliged by Oath to ob≈øerve their Statutes in the Literal Grammatical Sen≈øe, and neither ≈øeek nor admit of any di≈øpen≈øation by any Authority whatever, yet ≈øuch Statutes have not been ob≈øerved by them≈øelves, but either by too great ≈øtrictne≈øs of them or ≈øome Immemorial di≈øpen≈øation, or the pravity of the
Ages by-pa≈øt and current, that can endure no re≈øtraints, the≈øe Statutes have been di≈ø-u≈øed and grown ob≈øolete, yet the Oaths are taken in General to all the Statutes, ≈øo that the Scholars and Fellows can no ways be free from the guilt of perjury, without a Tacit re≈øerved Sence, that ≈øuch are to be under≈øtood they Swear to keep, as are then of force and u≈øe: And Admitting ≈øuch a re≈øerve; it may be allowed in the obligation to any other Statute which they bind them≈øelves to ob≈øerve, ≈øo long as the Sovereign di≈øpen≈øeth not with them, which di≈øtinction being allowed a readier, obedience would be payed to the King, and the pretences of a Con≈øcienciou≈øne≈øs not to be perjured would vani≈øh.

div.head: ¬ß. 6. Tran≈øcripts of the Statutes to be ≈øerved by Males only.
div.p: But I pa≈øs now to the Statutes them≈øelves.
The words of that again≈øt being ≈øerved with Women runs thus.
The Title is Quod omnia Mini≈øteria fiant per Ma≈øculos.
The Body is thus.

Ordinamus autem pro perpetuis futuris Temporibus ac firmiter ob≈øervari praecepimus, quod ≈øingula Mini≈øteria, dicto Collegio & per≈øonis eju≈ødem competentia, prae≈øertim infra Manerium Collegii eju≈ødem fiant per Ma≈øculos, ut quaelibet ≈øini≈øtra ≈øu≈øpicio, quantum fieri pote≈øt cautius evitetur, ni≈øi forte ≈øit Mapparum,
ac aliorum u≈øualium ve≈øtimentorum lotrix, quae per Manus Janitoris ≈øingula recipiat ≈øic lavenda in defectu lotoris Ma≈øculi, quam talis aetatis, tali≈øque conditionis e≈ø≈øe volumus in quam ≈øini≈øtra ≈øu≈øpicio cadere veri≈øimiliter non debeat.

We Ordain and Command firmly to be ob≈øerved in all future times, that all the Services to be done in the ≈øaid College, and the per≈øons therein, e≈øpecially within the compa≈øs or Manor of the College, be performed by Males, that all evil ≈øu≈øpicion as much as may be, may more cautiou≈øly be avoided unle≈øs it be on
Wa≈øher-woman of Table Cloaths, Towels and other u≈øual wearing Cloaths, which ≈øeveral things ≈øo to be wa≈øhed ≈øhe ≈øhall recieve by the hand of the Porter in default of a Male wa≈øher, & the Wa≈øher-woman we will ≈øhall be of ≈øuch Age and condition as on whom probably no evil ≈øu≈øpicion ought to fall.

However ≈øtrict this Statute is, yet it is manife≈øt, that Laundre≈ø≈øes recieve not now their Linnens at the Porters Lodge, but tho≈øe and Bed makers are con≈øtantly Admitted to the Chambers of Students and Fellows.

div.head: ¬ß. 7. Statutes again≈øt Dice and Cards.
div.p: There is another Statute as little ob≈øerved concerning playing at Dice and Cards and haunting of Taverns, the words are, Regi≈øt. E. pag. 6.

Statuimus Odinamus & Volumus quod nullus Scholarium vel Sociorum dicti Collegii leporarium teneat ‚Äî Taxillorum in≈øuper & alearum tam Cardarum quam Carparum Ludum infra Collegium praedictum vel alibi infra Univer≈øitatem ip≈øis penitus Interdicimus &
etiam prohibemus, ≈øi quis vero praedictus prohibitioni no≈øtrae Contravenerit, ≈øi ≈øuper hoc Convictus fuerit, poenam Scholaribus & Sociis dicti Collegii extra Univer≈øitatem ≈øine Licentia divillantibus in proximo praecedente Capitulo Limitatum Incurrere Statuimus & Volumus ip≈øo facto.

We Con≈øtitute Ordain and Will, that none of the Scholars or Fellows keep a Grey-hound ‚Äî and we moreover wholly Interdict and forbid the ≈øame all Play,What is meant by Carparum I have not found. at Dice or Cards within the College or other where within the Univer≈øity, and if any of tho≈øe contravene
our prohibition, if he be Convicted of it, We Con≈øtitute and Will, that Ip≈øo facto they incur ≈øuch penalties as in the next foregoing Chapter are appointed for tho≈øe Scholars and Fellows who go out of the Univer≈øity into the Country without leave.
The Statute which this refers to,Id. pa. 59.60. runs thus.

Dum ab≈øentes fuerint in Patria, ≈øicut decet Clericos Induantur & hone≈øte Moribus Conver≈øentur, nec pro tunc vel dum in Univer≈øitate fuerint iidem Socii ac Scholares, Tabernas Spectacula vel alia loca Inhone≈øta exererunt aut frequentent, & √† Comitivis ≈øu≈øpectis penitus ≈øe ab≈øtineant.

While they are ab≈øent in the Country, let them be Habited as Clerks and conver≈øe hone≈øtly in manners, neither let the ≈øame Fellows or Scholars while they are there or in the Univer≈øity, go forth to ≈øpend their time or frequent Taverns, public Shews (≈øuch we may reckon Bear and Bull-batings, Stage-plays) and let them wholly ab≈øtain from ≈øu≈øpected Company.
The Penalties for all the≈øe follow.

Alioquin ≈øi for≈øan qui≈øquam Scholarium aut Sociorum praedictorum po≈øt publicationem prae≈øentis no≈øtri Statuti, (quam loco monitionis Legitimae haberi volumus) in praemi≈ø≈øis vel eorum aliquo culpabilis invenietur, cuju≈øcunque gradus Status aut conditionis fuerit, pro 1a. vice, per ≈øeptimanam, pro 2da. vice per quindenam, pro tertia vice per men≈øem tunc proxime ≈øequentem Communis ≈øuis careat ip≈øo facto; ≈øi ver√≤ 4o. deliquerit in hoc ca≈øu ab ip≈øo Collegio no≈øtro praefato vigore Statuti ip≈øum exclu≈øum & privatum fore decernimus.

If it happen that any of the Scholars or Fellows afore≈øaid after publication of this our pre≈øent Statute, (which we will to be reputed in≈øtead of a lawful Admonition) be found culpable in the premi≈øes or any of them of what Degree State or condition he be, we appoint that he want his Commons for the fir≈øt fault one week, for the ≈øecond 15 days, and for the third a whole Month; and if he offend the fourth time, in this Ca≈øe by the force of this Statute we Decree him to be Expelled from our ≈øaid College.

How the≈øe Statutes have been ob≈øerved is ≈øufficiently known, while Tables. Dice and Cards have been continually for many Years la≈øt pa≈øt expo≈øed for the u≈øe of all in the Common-Room, which how innocent ≈øoever a Recretation it may be in private Rooms, yet in ≈øo public a manner in a College where by the Statutes they are forbid under ≈øuch penalties, cannot but ≈øugge≈øt to all that the≈øe Statutes are neither Literally and Grammatically, nor at all ob≈øerved.

div.head: ¬ß. 8. Statute concerning repair.
div.p: There is another Statute, that hath not been very Religiou≈øly ob≈øerved by ≈øome of the late Ejected Fellows, as I am Informed, and that is about the keeping in repair the buildings appertaining to the College, the Statute runs thus.

Sub obte≈øtatione Divini Judicii ≈øpecialiter Injungimus munimus & in≈øuper Statuimus ut Capella no≈øtri Collegii & Aula, ≈øingulaque alia Aedificia Dei adjutorio laborio≈øe no≈øtris ≈øumptibus aedificata in muris Cooperturis, & qualibet ≈øui parte perpetuis futuris Temporibus per Dei gratiam debite ≈øufficienter & congrue in omnibus ≈øu≈øtententur.

Under the humble be≈øeeching of Divine Judgment we ≈øpecially enjoyn Strengthen and likewi≈øe Con≈øtitute that the Chappel of our College, and the Hall and all other the Buildings which by the help of God at our co≈øts with great labor have been Erected, may by Gods Grace in all ≈øucceeding times be duely ≈øufficiently and conveniently kept in repair in the Walls, Rooffs and every part in all things.

How this Statute hath been ob≈øerved, appears by the late pulling down and Selling the Materials of the College of Brakley in Northampton-≈øhire, which by the Founder was built as a place for the Members of the College to Inhabit in and pur≈øue their Studies, in ca≈øe Fire or Plague, or any other public Calamity might enforce the Scholars and Fellows to remove from the College at Oxford.

div.head: ¬ß. 9. About ≈øaying of Ma≈øs.
div.p:
Upon the Ejected Fellows grand plea of ob≈øerving the Literal and Grammatical Sen≈øe of the Statute
and admitting no di≈øpen≈øation by any Authority ≈øoever, I ≈øee not how the Fellows can avoid being obliged to ≈øay the Ma≈øs of the Holy Gho≈øt before they go to Election, as the Statute expre≈øly enjoyns, as likewi≈øe to ≈øay dayly Ma≈ø≈øes, Solemn Obits, and particular Prayers for the Souls of the Founders and Benefactors, &c. For if they allege that they are prohibited to u≈øe ≈øuch by Act of Parliament, they confe≈øs that their Statutes are di≈øpen≈øed with by ≈øome Authority, and that they yield to and allow ≈øuch di≈øpen≈øation which is again≈øt the Literal ≈øence of the Oath, which I have recited before:Vide pag. 33. here. And I hope I have made it clear, that the King hath as much Authority to Su≈øpend, and ≈øo Temporarily aboli≈øh any of their Statutes, as an Act of Parliament hath to perpetuate it.

‚òû I need not touch upon the Qualifications required in the per≈øons to be Elected,Concerning purcha≈øing of Fellow≈øhips. as that they ≈øhould be poor, when it is notoriou≈øly known, that not only in the times long ≈øince Fellow≈øhips have been bought, but Mony payed for Re≈øignations, and if I be not mi≈øinformed, even ≈øome of the late Ejected Fellows had not re-inbur≈øed them≈øelves of the Mony they had payed to purcha≈øe their Fellow≈øhips, ≈øo that it was grown to a by-word, that an Election at St. Mary Magdalen, was a Magdalen Fair.

Having thus touched upon ≈øome of the Statutes, which we find the Society have taken upon them to di≈øpen≈øe with or aboli≈øh, Pag. 311. here. I proceed to give a true Narrative of Dr. Haddons Ca≈øe, of which I gave an Account before, ≈øuch as I was then able to do; but now by the direction of Bi≈øhop Giffard and the great care of my Honored friend the Learned Mr. Thomas Fairfax, who hath extracted the Materials out of
their public Regi≈øter, I am enabled to clear the Ca≈øe mo≈øt fully.

I ≈øhall not repeat what I have ob≈øerved before out of Mr. Woods Antiquities of Oxford, but only note how faithful he hath been in his Collections, and that this Dr. Haddon was every way as uncapable of being Elected Pre≈øident by the Literal and Grammatical ≈øence of the Statute, as Mr. Farmer was.
But I ≈øhall pa≈øs to the account I have received from the Regi≈øter.

div.head: ¬ß. 10. Concerning Dr. Haddon.
Out of the Petition of the College to Edward the 6th. Dated the 3d. of July 1552.
div.p:
WHere it has plea≈øed your Highne≈øs upon con≈øideration, that Dr. Oglethorp Pre≈øident of your College, was fully re≈øolved and determin'd to leave and re≈øign at Michaelma≈øs next en≈øuing, his Office afore≈øaid, to direct unto us your mo≈øt Honorable Letters in favor of Dr. Haddon, therein requiring us to Nominate and Elect him to the ≈øaid Room, when it ≈øhall be void: Like as we have hitherto and ≈øhall gladly forbear to conde≈øcend upon any other Man, in con≈øideration of your mo≈øt Gracious Letter, and much more to proceed to the Election of any other; ≈øo do we upon our Knees mo≈øt humbly be≈øeech your Maje≈øty to con≈øider, that we your Orators have not only an Ordinance and Statute in your ≈øaid College, whereby we ≈øtand ≈øpecially bounden to Nominate unto the ≈øaid Office ≈øuch as have been of our Foundation being Mini≈øters but al≈øo are thereunto by our Oaths every one of us ≈øtrictly enforced; and albeit Dr. Haddon is a Man of approved Learning, hone≈øty and worthy of much better preferment, and ≈øuch a
one as mo≈øt willingly, at your Graces Hands, before all other, we would thankfully accept, Here we mu≈øt note the different way of this Societies proceeding in King Edw. the 6ths. time, from the late Fellows proceeding to Election contrary to the Kings expre≈øs Mandate. Nominate and Elect, if he were eligible, being ≈øorry even with all our hearts, that there is an impediment in our Statutes, that may re≈øtrain our willing minds and good hearts: Yet con≈øidering he is not of our Foundation; that it toucheth us all in Con≈øcience to violate our Statute, whereunto we have Sworn, and that he is not a Mini≈øter, which is required by our Foundation, and on the other ≈øide, that we have of our own Foundation ≈øundry per≈øons of much hone≈øty and Learning ‚Äî which are Mini≈øters, whereby they may in their own per≈øons further the word of God. Finally, that it were not only a great di≈øgracing and di≈øcomfort to our College, that no one Man of our Foundation could be thought meet to ≈øucceed our former Pre≈øident; but al≈øo it might appear a blemi≈øh to the whole ∆≤niver≈øity of Oxford to ≈øu≈øtain of all their Students an utter repeal; we have thought good to become humble Petitioners to your Maje≈øty, mo≈øt humbly on our Knees be≈øeeching your Highne≈øs to be ≈øo Gracious Lord and Sovereign to us, not to co-act us by your Power Royal, and Supreme Authority, which we mo≈øt humbly pro≈øtrate do acknowledge, and on our Knees Reverence, but rather ‚Äî to grant us your Gracious favor, that we may have a free Election, and follow our Oaths and Con≈øciences, &c.

closer.signed: Sub≈øcribed The Vice-Pre≈øident and more part of the Fellows.

div.p: The King per≈øi≈øting, Dr. Haddon was Elected and Pre≈øented to the Bi≈øhop of Winche≈øter thus by the College.

p.q: Reverendo in Chri≈øto Patri ac Domino Dro. Joanni permi≈ø≈øione Divina Winton. Epi≈øcopo Collegii B. Ma. Magdl. in Univer≈øitate Oxon. patrono intigerrimo, aut cuivis alii admittendi pote≈øtatem habenti, Gulielmus Reding V. Prae≈øidens Collegii praedicti, nec non eju≈ødem Collegii Scholares ≈øalutem in Domino. Ad Officium Prae≈øidentis in Collegio tuo praefato per liberam re≈øignationem ornati≈ø≈øimi viri Owini Oglethorpe nuper Prae≈øidentis 27 Septemb. Anno Regni Sereni≈ø≈øimi Principis Edw. 6. ‚Äî factam jam vacuam, non ≈øolum ad contemplationem binarum litterarum praedicti Domini no≈øtri Regis in favorem egregii viri Gaulteri Haddon Scriptarum, quam ad Speciale Mandatum eju≈ødem Principis ex Autoritate Regia Suprema,Note here the grounds of the Societies obedience was the Kings ≈øpecial Mandate by his Supreme Authority and his di≈øpenceing with the Impediments of their Statutes and their Oath. Autoritate ≈øu√¢ non ≈øolum cum Statutorum impedimentis no≈øtroque juramento di≈øpen≈øantis, ≈øed etiam interdicentis, ne ad alterius cuju≈øque Electionem procederemus quam praefati Gualteri Haddon ≈øufficiendi in praefatum Officium: Nos itaque praefati Vice-Prae≈øidens & Scholares omi≈ø≈øis quibu≈øcunque prae≈øcriptiunculis, alioquin in hac Electione requi≈øitis, ≈øed quas in prae≈øenti ob≈øervare non potuimus, eximium virum Gualterum Haddonum ‚Äî in tui praefati Collegii Prae≈øidentem unanimiter elegimus, &c.

div.p:
I need not enlarge upon this matter,Inference from this. but refer to the Reader to what I have Writ before concerning it; only ob≈øerving, Pag. 311. here. that notwith≈øtanding Dr. Haddon was no ways Statutably qualified, and that the Vice-Pre≈øident
and Fellows did urge the obligation of their Oaths; yet they did not proceed to Election of another Pre≈øident, in contempt of the Kings Mandate, as the Modern Fellows have done; but after ≈øuch a Dutiful repre≈øentation of their Ca≈øe as is ≈øeen in their Petition, they finding the King In≈øi≈øting upon being obeyed, they yielded entirely, not only to Admit, but Elect him, and in the In≈øtrument of pre≈øenting him to the Bi≈øhop of Winche≈øter, they own the Kings di≈øpen≈øing power, and ≈øignifie likewi≈øe that they yielded in this to the Kings Supreme Authority.

div.head: ¬ß. 11. The Queen Commands Dr. Bond to be Admitted Pre≈øident, and declares Null the Election of Mr. Smith.
div.p: I ≈øhall add but one In≈øtance more of a Pre≈øident of St. Mary Magdalen College placed by the Queen, contrary to the de≈øire of the Electors, who were more favorable to Mr. Richard Smith. For I find that the Queen placed Dr. Bond her Chaplain by her Authority, rejecting and declaring Null and Invalid the Election of Mr. Smith.
The words of the Regi≈øter are as followeth.

Quinto die men≈øis Aprilis-Anno Domini 1589 Eximius vir Dr. Nicolaus Bond, Regi≈øt. G. fol. 280. Sacrae Theologiae Profe≈ø≈øor in Magna Aula Collegii B. Mariae Magdalenae in Univer≈øitate Oxon protulit litteras patentes Regiae Maje≈øtatis de ejus admi≈ø≈øione in Officium Prae≈øidentis dicti Collegii,This is a very pertinent Precedent of a Mandate like that of our King for the Bi≈øhop of Oxford obeyed by the Society, which ≈øome of the late Fellows could not be Ignorant of. quae in prae≈øentia omnium Sociorum dicti Collegii in Univer≈øitate exi≈øtentium public√® legebantur; quarum quidem litterarum tenor ≈øequitur in his verbis.

Elizabetha &c. Praeten≈øam nominationem & Electionem de Ricardo Smith ad omnem juris effectum nullam & invalidam declaramus: ‚Äî Nicholaum Bonde Capellanum no≈øtrum in eju≈ødem Collegii Pre≈øidentem, durante vita ≈øu√¢ naturali nominamus & con≈øtituimus, ac ad omnes effectus praeficimus, curamque, regimen, & admini≈øtrationem dicti Collegii eidem tanquam legitimo Prae≈øidenti in omnibus committimus,
in tam amplis modo & forma, quam quivis alius munus & Officium Prae≈øidentis in dicto Collegio unquam habuit, exercuit, po≈ø≈øedit, aut gavi≈øus e≈øt, vel habere, exercere & po≈øidere aut gaudere potuit aut debuit: Mandantes in≈øuper Vice-Prae≈øidenti, Sociis, Scholaribus, caeteri≈øque dicti Collegii Mini≈øtris ac per≈øonis omnibus & ≈øingulis, quorum aliqua ratione intere≈ø≈øe potuit, quatenus Dictum Nicolaum Bonde in Prae≈øidentem Collegii praedicti benigne admittant & recipiant, Here the Queen di≈øpen≈øeth with the Statutes Sworn to by the Society, and all other thing cau≈øe or matter to the contrary what≈øoever. ac ei ut Prae≈øidenti ≈øuo in omnibus ac Per omnia pareant, ac obtemperent, aliquibus Statutis & Ordinationibus dicti Collegii etiam juratis aut quacunque nominatione vel Electione dicti Nicolai Bonde, aut Ricardi Smith per aliquos dicti Collegii Socios in di≈øcordia for≈øitan nuper factis vel aliqua alia re, cau≈ø√¢, vel materia in aliquo quovi≈ømodo nonob≈øtantibus ‚Äî In cujus rei Te≈øtimonium has litteras no≈øtras fieri fecimus patentes, Te≈øte mi≈øp≈ø√¢ apud We≈øtm. 4o. Die Aprili Anno Regni no≈øtri 31.

Eodem anno,Here the Fellows were all pre≈øent at Dr. Bonds taking his Oath, and he was recieved and Admitted Pre≈øident according to the Queens Mandate. men≈øe, & Die po≈øt dictarum litterarum lectionem, tactis ac in≈øpectis per dictum Nicolaum Bonde Sacro Sancti Evangelii, Juramentum Sub≈øcriptum prae≈øtitit in prae≈øentia omnium Sociorum in Univer≈øitate praedicta tune exi≈øtentium, & in dicta magna aula Collegii praedicti quo quidem juramento prae≈øtito receptus & admi≈ø≈øus e≈øt ut Prae≈øes dicti Collegii. Sequitur juramentum Prae≈øidis in Statutis.

By this Mandate of the Queens,Inferences from this Mandate. it appears, that without any Election according to the Statute of the College, ≈øhe Nominates and Con≈øtitutes, and to all effects Prefers Dr. Bond tot he Pre≈øident≈øhip during his Natural Life, Commits to him the Care, Government, and Admini≈øtration of the ≈øaid College in all things, as Lawful Pre≈øident, in as ample manner and form as any other ever had, exerci≈øed, po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed, or enjoyed
the Office of Pre≈øident in the ≈øame College. Commanding the Vice-Pre≈øident, Fellows, and Scholars, and the re≈øt of the Servants of the ≈øaid College, and all and every per≈øon, who by any means could have intere≈øt therein, that they kindly Admit, and Receive him as Pre≈øident, of the College, and in all things obey him as their Pre≈øident, notwith≈øtanding any Statutes and Ordinances of the ≈øaid College, tho' Sworn to or any Nomination or Election of the ≈øaid Nicholas Bond or Richard Smith by any of the Fellows of the ≈øaid College, happly done in their late differences or any other cau≈øe or matters in any thing what≈øoever.

div.head: ¬ß. 12. An Hi≈øtorical Account of King Charles the fir≈øt, di≈øpen≈øing with a Statute of Emanuel College in Cambridge.
div.p: I ≈øhall now give an account of a Petition I have found in the Paper-Office, which will clear the matter of the Kings di≈øpen≈øing power with College Statutes mo≈øt fully.

For the better unde≈øtanding this Petition, it mu≈øt be ob≈øerved, that Sir Walter Mildmay Founded Emanuel College in Cambridge for Students in Divinity, that it might be a Nur≈øery for Divines; and gave ≈øeveral Benefices with Cure of Souls, to be be≈øtowed upon the Fellows, as they fell void, that they might be Preachers in the Country. That therefore they might not be ≈øuperannuated in the College, he made one of the Statutes de Mora Sociorum, that the Fellows ≈øhould leave the College ≈øome ≈øhort ≈øpace of time after they were Doctors of Divinity, and they were to take the preceding Degrees, according to the ≈øtrictne≈øs of the Statutes of the Univer≈øity, for the taking Degrees when of due ≈øtanding. By another Statute de Re≈øidentia Sociorum, they were tyed to ≈øtrict Re≈øidence, ≈øo that they could not go abroad to have conver≈øation and obtain the advantages that a relaxation of that ≈øtrict Re≈øidence might have
afforded them, whereby they might have made provi≈øion for them≈øelves in obtaining Benefices, in ca≈øe there ≈øhould none fall in the Interim.
Now it ≈øo hapned, that the Founder had not annexed a ≈øufficient number of Spiritual Benefices, ≈øo that ≈øome of them when Doctors of Divinity mu≈øt have left the College un-provided for.
The≈øe con≈øiderations induced ≈øome of the Fellows to Petition for a di≈øpen≈øation with this Statute; and upon the ≈øugge≈øtions in that Petition, King Charles the Fir≈øt granted it.
But it ≈øeems this di≈øpen≈øation was not ≈øo well liked by others, and even ≈øome of the fir≈øt Petitioners joyned with them, and exhibited this following Petition.

div.head: ¬ß. 13. The Petition of the Ma≈øter and Fellows of Emanuel College in Cambridge, to the Honorable Chancellor of the ∆≤niver≈øity, humbly Sheweth.
div.p:
Paper-Office Eccle≈øia≈øtica Academica ab An. 1620. ad 38. THat whereas a Petition by four of the Follows was exhibited to the late Noble Chancellor,The Relation of the grounds of the Petition. touching the validity of one of our Statutes, viz. de Mor√¢ Sociorum in Collegio, upon which a Letter for the Su≈øpending of it, was granted by his Maje≈øty, we now the pre≈øent Ma≈øter and a greater part of the Fellows of the ≈øaid College, finding many inconveniences which do, and may en≈øue upon it (contrary to his Maje≈øties Royal intendment, and de≈øire of our relief and advancement by it, in that Su≈øpen≈øion graciou≈øly declared and ≈øignified) become humble Petitioners to your Lord≈øhip, as being the Noble Ornament of our College, and mo≈øt honorable Chancellor of the Univer≈øity, that you would vouch≈øafe to take it into your ≈øerious con≈øideration, and move his Maje≈øty for the Revocation of the ≈øaid Su≈øpen≈øion, in regard of
the≈øe Rea≈øons, which we pre≈øume to tender to your Honor.

1. The main ground the former Petitioners went upon,Nine Rea≈øons for this Petition. was a per≈øua≈øion that either this was no Statute, or not of like validity with the re≈øt, which upon full proof, (after long debating) being by the Heads of Colleges Confe≈ø≈øed to be otherwi≈øe, they did ≈øurcea≈øe their ≈øuit, and ≈øome of them became Petitioners that the ≈øaid Statute might be re-e≈øtabli≈øhed.

2. The Ma≈øter by his Oath which he took at his Admi≈ø≈øion, is bound both to keep all the Statutes inviolably him≈øelf, as al≈øo to ≈øee the ≈øame done by others, which the Su≈øpen≈øion forbiddeth him in this Statute de Mor√¢ Sociorum, &c.

3. The Fellows by their Oath at their Admi≈ø≈øion are debarred from accepting any di≈øpen≈øation, either again≈øt any of the Founders Statutes, or again≈øt that their Oath: and thereby ≈øeem to be di≈øabled from taking any benefit of this Su≈øpen≈øion expre≈øly containing a di≈øpen≈øation with the ≈øaid Oath.

4. None of the Fellows to our knowledge, was ever yet by vertue of the ≈øaid Statute turned out of his Fellow≈øhip unprovided, excepting one only of the pre≈øent Petitioners, who notwith≈øtanding before he left the College was provided of a good Par≈øonage, from whence he was ≈øince cho≈øen Ma≈øter of the ≈øaid College.

5. Since the Su≈øpen≈øion, ≈øix of the Fellows, before their time granted by Statute was expired, have been called to good Benefices with Pa≈øtoral charge, four of which were the Petitioners for the qualification of the ≈øaid Statute.

6. We conceive ju≈øt grounds of fear, partly by what we have heard, partly for other ≈øufficient rea≈øons, that the ≈øaid Su≈øpen≈øion hath already been and may prove hereafter, a di≈øcouragement to tho≈øe
who otherwi≈øe would be Benefactors to our College.

7. The Fellow≈øhips being but few in this College, if they be enlarged to perpetuity, younger Scholars will be di≈ø-couraged in their Studies, ≈øeeing ≈ømall hope of preferment for them, & be forced to leave the Univer≈øity before they be well fitted for a Pa≈øtoral charge.

8. Whereas our Honorable Founder Erected this College for a Nur≈øery to the Church of England, and expre≈ø≈øeth this to have been his meaning, that tho≈øe who were brought up in it, ≈øhould upon a fair Call, be tran≈øplanted hence, after they were fitted for the Mini≈øtry, the afore≈øaid liberty of longer continuance, will in likelihood, make ≈øome unwilling, to take on them a Pa≈øtoral charge being offered, whereby the Founders Pious intent ≈øhall be cro≈ø≈øed, the Church deprived of the labors of ≈øuch, and they ≈øhall not only remain unprofitable in the College, but al≈øo may in ≈øhort time draw to them≈øelves the Chief Government of the ≈øame, the Ma≈øter having no Negative voice to hinder it, as all other Ma≈øters of Colleges have.
9. The Statute ≈øtanding in it's former force, would have prevented no ≈ømall di≈øturbances of the peace of the College which have lately hapened.

signed.hi: For all which Rea≈øons we continue our former ≈øuit, and re≈øt your Lor≈øhips humble Petitioners.

div.head: ¬ß. 14. Ob≈øervations upon this Petion.
div.p:
Upon this Petition King Charles the Fir≈øt, in the beginning of his Reign, referred the matter to the Vice-Chancellor and ≈øome Heads of Colleges, as I am informed, upon who≈øe report the King ≈øaw no rea≈øon to take off his di≈øpen≈øation; altho' the Grand≈øon of the Founder promi≈øed to add more Spiritual Benefices
to the Revenue of the College, whereby the Fellows might be better provided for.

Here fir≈øt we may note, that one part of the Oath which the Fellows take being in the≈øe words, ‚Äî Nullam di≈øpen≈øationem contra Statuta fundatoris impetrabo, nec impetrari curabo, nec Impetratam acceptabo, viz. that they will neither obtain any di≈øpen≈øation contrary to the Statutes of the Founder, nor will endeavor that any other ≈øhould obtain them, or will accept of any ≈øuch being obtained, ≈øo that the Fellows of this College were under the like obligation as the≈øe of St. Mary Magdalen College were.

Yet Secondly they all own the Kings power in di≈øpen≈øing with this Statute, and only by way of Petition ≈øhew their Rea≈øons why the King ≈øhould be de≈øired to revoke it, but we hear of no per≈øi≈øting in the matter ≈øo as to cau≈øe the King to exerci≈øe his Supreme Authority to enforce their obedience; but pay a ready obedience, and that di≈øpen≈øation is in force to this day.

Thirdly, It is to be noted, that this di≈øpen≈øation was granted and yielded to, in a time when there were no public animo≈øities, or that any Factious Combinations in the State Caballed again≈øt the Crown; but all was Calm, it being in the Halcyon Days of King Charles the Fir≈øt, and the Prerogative of the Crown was not di≈øputed. Therefore we ought to allow this as a mo≈øt Authentic Precedent of the Kings di≈øpen≈øing power, not for one or more ≈øingle per≈øons, but with an entire Statute which concerned the Succe≈ø≈øion of ≈øeveral per≈øons in that, and in ≈øucceeding Ages.

Fourthly, As to the per≈øons that Petition, Dr. Sandcroft was then Ma≈øter, and Unkle to the pre≈øent Arch-Bi≈øhop of Canterbury, Dr. Tuckney was in the time of the long Parliaments U≈øurpation Ma≈øter of St. Johns College in Cambridge, and Dr. Hill Ma≈øter of
Trinity College, Dr. Bridge and Dr. Burges were great Preachers, and Daemagogs of that Parliament.

div.head: ¬ß. 15. Dr. Brady's Account of the Kings Nominating the Provo≈øt of Kings College in Cambridge.
div.p: I ≈øhall now clo≈øe this with an Account which the Learned Dr. Brady, Regius Phy≈øic Profe≈ø≈øor in Cambridge, hath given me at my de≈øire when he was at the la≈øt Commencement ‚Äî That in Kings College in Cambridge they have a Statute that directs them to choo≈øe a Provo≈øt in ≈øuch Form, and with ≈øuch Qualifications as are appointed in the Statute, and by Oath are bound not to accept of any Di≈øpen≈øation to the contrary, yet from the very Foundation by King H. 6. the Provo≈øt was ever named by the King to be cho≈øen by the Fellows, and it hath been ≈øo con≈øtantly ob≈øerved. The Fellows, as the pre≈øent Provo≈øt informs, put up a Petition to King James the Fir≈øt, that he would be Graciou≈øly plea≈øed to leave them to their free choice: But his An≈øwer was, that the Statute was Abrogated by the very practice of the Founder, who Named two Provo≈øts Succe≈ø≈øively in his Life time, and by the con≈øtant practice of Succeeding Kings, and that he was their Founder, for that the King never Dyes, and he would not part with his Right of Nomination, but in other things would leave them to the free u≈øe of their Statutes. Thus far the Doctors Letter.

I might add many other Modern In≈øtances of the entire obedience payed to the Kings Mandates by Ma≈øters and Fellows of Colleges, and the unque≈øtionablene≈øs of the Kings di≈øpen≈øing with Statutes in both Univer≈øities, and particularly in St. Mary Magdalen College, in the Reign of King Charles the Second, but under≈øtanding that a Member of that College hath Writ a Tract on that Subject, I ≈øhall here Conclude.
